column2: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES Cincinnati 5, New York 0. Houston 7, Philadelphia 0. San Francisco 7, Pittsburgh 2. Other teams not scheduled.

High school teachers call it "senioritis." The seniors themselves call it a drag. Some parents-and educators--are beginning to call it scandal. The problem they are all referring to is the growing realization that for many high school seniors the spring term is a yawning stretch of anticlimax and boredom.
Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz indicated today that he saw no good reason for the dollar and the stock market to be as weak as they are.

A South Vietnamese Government spokesman said today that Columbia University should forward its invitation for a teaching chair for Mrs. Ngo Ba Thanh either to North Vietnam or the Vietcong because she would soon be released to the Communists.
A 45 year-old circus laborer was picked up and thrown to the ground twice yesterday before being crushed to death by an elephant he was handling after a performance on Roosevelt Common.
Sweaters and sequins. That's the swing of the fashion pendulum for fall. If you have to make a choice, pick sweaters. They'll take you anywhere that sequins will-and they look a lot more up to date.

The trustee of the Equity Funding Corporation of America said today that he was confident that the bankrupt company could be rehabilitated. Robert M. Loeffler stated at a hearing conducted by Federal District Judge Harry Pregerson that he did not contemplate any recommendation of liquidation.
Major construction halted in an eight-county area around Chicago today as contractors countered laborers' strike with the threat of a lockout.
Tennis, the great equalizer between old men and young women, became the great tantalizer today when 12 superstars of other sports met in the Dewar's celebrity tournament at Kutsher's Country Club.

METROPOLITAN OPERA, Verdi's "Aida," 8. Concerts JOSEPHINE BAKER, Carnegie Hall, 8. NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC PROMENADE CONCERT, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30. DIANE ADDISON, soprano, Trinity church, 12:45. 12:45.
Manhattan's "Mr. District Attorney," Frank S. Hogan, yesterday overcame the first challenge in his 32-year reign and easily defeated William J. vanden Heuvel in the Democratic primary.
Skepticism and envy, once the elements of training room warfare, have begun to surface for the first time among athletes competing on the rival professional and amateur track and field circuits.

Gerald Martin Zelmanowitz, a confessed bond thief who has furnished pivotal testimony for the Government in two New Jersey Mafia trials, last week eluded United States marshals who had been protecting him from possible underworld reprisals, a Justice Department source said yesterday.

The upward surge of short-term money costs in the open market is likely to force an increase in the prime lending rate of the nation's largest banks to 7 1/2 per cent from 7 1/4 per cent within the next two or three days, informed bankers said yesterday. .

The New York Philharmonic will split into two 50-member orchestras and present nine Neighborhood Concerts in six days throughout the city. this month. The concerts will be conducted by James De Preist and David Zinman.
Aviation experts generally agreed yesterday that plans for introducing the era of supersonic air travel had been set back by the crash of the Soviet Tupolev-144 at the Paris air show on Sunday.

The Soviet leadership, after long hesitation, came down squarely today on the side of modern, Western-oriented economists who are seeking to break with Stalinist planning practices to insure a slower, but more balanced and orderly, growth of the Soviet economy.
The South African rand has been revalued by about 5 per cent against the dollar, effective tomorrow, Finance Minister Nicolaas Diederichs said today.

Carrying judicial complaints about low pay and bad working conditions a step further, Judge Fred G. Moritt in Brooklyn cut his robes to knee length because he "got tired of dragging all the filth and garbage" around with him.
Israel has opened a major campaign to persuade the Nixon Administration to drop its tentative plans to sell Saudi Arabia 24 to 30 F-4 Phantom jet-bombers.

Jack L. Clark, former chairman and president of Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy to defraud investors, purchasers of debentures and a lender of the nursing home chain.
Maryland, unsurprisingly, was named the No. 1 lacrosse team in the nation yesterday in the season's coaches' poll. The vote was unanimous.

A reduction in the "excessive number of surgeons and surgical specialists" and education of the Medical profession and the public to accept well-trained paramedical personnel were among proposals advanced yesterday by Dr. S.

City Controller Abraham D. Beame took first place in the Democratic mayoral primary, but fell short of 40 per cent and thus faces a runoff June 26 against Representative Herman Badillo. Mr. Badillo, who had taken the most liberal stance in the four-way contest, led Representative Mario Biaggi, the most conservative of the Democratic
A United States military team has found the remains of an American pilot whose plane crashed eight years ago in South Vietnam, a United States Embassy source reported today.
Yields on United States Treasury bills soared in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.

IN THE DAYS OF SIMON STERN. By Arthur A. Cohen. 464 pages. Random House. $8.95. What is the novelist's imagination to seize upon-especially if it belongs to an American Jew, torn, as it must apparently be, between the ancient demands of tradition and the modern pressures of assimilation?

The Lloyds Bank Group of London, which last week announced plans to dissolve its ties to the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said yesterday that it was "having discussions" with World Airways, Inc., about the possible acquisition of the First Western Bank Trust Company of Los Angeles.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market fell again yesterday as jittery investors watched the dollar decline abroad and the price of gold soar to $123.50 an ounce in London.

Dr. Gordon D. Hoople, a specialist in diseases of the ear, professor emeritus of otolaryngology at Syracuse University College of Medicine and former chairman of the university's board of trustees, died today in Crouse Memorial Hospital His age was 78.

Kuwait, the wealthiest of the Persian Gulf oil sheikdoms, said today that the $500-million in arms that she is arranging to purchase from the West was "not for use against anybody" but for her own defense.
Black residents of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn said yesterday that they were determined to remove police barriers that have been erected in the area at the request of Hasidic Jews.

Ed Tutwiler, a former United States Walker Cup star, and Ireland's Joe Carr led the advance today as the British Amateur golf championships opened with Frank (One Round) Strafaci of Miami living up to his nickname by losing in the first round for the 23d year.

In nominating Gary Leonard Seevers for one of the three seats on the Council of Economic Advisers today, President Nixon chose a doctor of agricultural economics with a knowledge of both theory and the long end of a pitchfork.
More than 100 sheriff's deputies and policemen returned to the Antioch College campus today to reopen buildings and tear down barricades reconstructed by striking students since Friday.

The task is being made easier for Secretariat to win the Triple Crown. Unless there are some surprise entrants from previously unproclaimed horses, the Meadow Stable colt will have only three rivals in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

The automobile and the housewrecker, those partners in urban debilitation, are about to claim another New York landmark. It's a modest place, and its modesty is part of its charm: a genuine trattoria in the heart of the garment district. There cannot be many of these honest, unpretentious, family-style bistrots left, and their clientele cherish them with jealous secrecy. .
The Sky lab spacecraft, carrying its three astronaut passengers, is scheduled to fly directly over New York City at dawn tomorrow and, weather permitting,
Gov. Patrick J. Lucey of Wisconsin, contending that the nation's economy was faltering and the Federal Government's programs were at a standstill, today called upon President Nixon to resign.

Su Mac Lad, the grand old gelding of Harness racing, returns to Yonkers Raceway Wednesday for an old-timers' night appearance. Sumie, perhaps the most popular trotter ever to compete in New York, is now 18 years old and enjoys retirement at Stanley Dancer's Egyptian Acres farm in New Egypt, N. J.

Because of the diurnal work habits of professional zoo keepers and the effects of a tight budget, the right hour when the last straggling visitor must be ushered out of the Bronx Zoo at 5:30 is the very time when much of the zoo start to come alive.

With a quarter century of active governmental service behind him, City Controller Abraham Beame campaigned hard on the issue of experience and confidence. Mr. Beame was the acknowledged frontrunner going into yesterday's four-way Democratic mayoral primary balloting. However, his failure to collect at least 40 per cent of the votes suggests that voter familiarity with his long service may actually have been a handicap. .
With three of four eligible voters expected to stay home, New Jersey Democrats and Republicans will choose party nominees tomorrow for Governor and all 120 legislative seats.

Dr. John Munn Hanford, a retired attending surgeon of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and former associate professor of clinical surgery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died Saturday at his summer home in Scottsville.
Elaborate clinical experiments are being conducted aboard the Skylab in earth orbit with three subjects, including a physician, d with experimental equipment ranging from

The average cost of feeding a family of two adults and two children in New York City rose in the week of May 24 to May 30 by 73 cents, from $51.62 for the week of May 17 to May 23, to $52.35, the Consumer Affairs Department reported yesterday.
How strong is Anatoly Karpov? No one I have spoken to doubts that he will one day become a leading candidate for world championship honors; the only question is when.
Mrs. Margaret Rangeley de Westfelt, who was an assistant program director of the national headquarters of the Girl Scouts at her retirement in 1960, died Saturday in New Haven Hospital.
Abbott Paige Mills, for 53 years a lawyer here, died yesterday in the Washington Hospital Center of burns suffered the previous Sunday. He was 83 years old.
The Supreme Court ruled today that the Standard Oil Company of California illegally conspired to monopolize the sale of petroleum products in American Samoa.

The Federal Aviation Administration, following five months without a hijacking in this county, is studying the possibility of ending the mandatory electronic-screening of all airline passengers and searches of all carry-on luggage.

State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that he was eager for the start of the post-primary part of the mayoral campaign and that, as the Republican candidate, he would have at least $1.5-million to spend in his election effort,

Within less than 24 hours last weekend, at least three Central Park bicyclists were attacked by youths who knocked them to the ground, made off with their bicycles or tried to, and in one case left a victim with serious knift wounds.

In a calendar punctuated by artificial "days" proclaimed by every level of government, World Environment Day is exceptional. So designated by the last Assembly of the United Nations, June 5 is worth observing both as an antidote to the pessimism of those who think ecological disaster is inevitable and as a spur to those who are actively working to head it off.
Laffit Pincay Jr. won his eighth race in three days yesterday when he rode Crimson saint to a length victory and a track record in the $33,500 Meteor Handicap at Hollywood Park.

Monmouth Park opened the 28th and longest season in its modern era of thoroughbred racing today. Track officials were counting on increasing support from the area's permanent residents to sustain their optimistic outlook for the seaside track.
The candidates for nomination for Governor in tomorrow's primary election report that they expect their campaign bills to total about $1.5-million. out $1.5-million.
Dozens of people in the South Bronx who had no party affiliation were permitted to vote yesterday by order of judges there according to the Board of Elections.
A full Madison Square Garden bayed, howled and stamped feet-all to persuade Alice Cooper to do an encore on Sunday. The commotion was ignored.

An ambitious song cycle by Jeffrey Kaufman was introduced by the Long Island Chamber Ensemble in a Carnegie Recital Hall concert Saturday night, Entitled "In Time Past and Time Remembered," the cycle incorporated eight poems by Mark Van Doren.

Stock prices continue to move down yesterday in slow trading, with the Dow-Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level in almost 18 months. The index tumbled 8.05 points to finish the session at 885.91. Its previous lowest closing level was at 881.47 on
With more than two-thirds of the vote in, Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein and Jacob D. Fuchsberg were battling this morning for the lead in the Democratic primary for chief judge of the state.

W. A. Boyle, deposed president of the United Mine Workers, his successor and a convicted union official were named today as prosecution witnesses in the trial of Albert E. Pass, a former union officer charged in the 1969 slaying of Joseph A.

Loews Corporation announced yesterday that it was making an offer to buy 2.65 million shares of the common stock of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., a department store chain, at $16 a share. If these shares are tendered, Loews will have accumulated, with shares already owned, a total of 4,307,000 shares,
The Maine Supreme Court today declared constitutional Maine's 1970 coastal conveyance law, which levies a tax of one-half cent a barrel on oil shipped over Maine waters.
The Senate Democratic Caucus unanimously adopted today a policy resolution calling for a 90-day freeze on wages and salaries, prices, profits, rents and consumer interest rates.

Premier Chou En-lai of China demanded tonight that the United States stop bombing Cambodia and otherwise end its military activity there. Mr. Chou said that no interference in Indochina, under whatever pretext and in whatever form, would be tolerated.

The Securities and Exchange Commission brought fraud charges today against Bausch Lomb, Inc., and three New York investment firms for alleged misuse of inside information involving shares of the Rochester optical company.
A 45-year-old circus laborer was picked up and thrown to the ground twice yesterday before being crushed to death by an elephant he was handling after a performance on Roosevelt Common.
Because of Congressional absenteeism, the appointment of a Senate-House conference committee to reconcile bills curbing funds for bombing in Cambodia was delayed today by at least a day.

Senator Philip A. Hart called yesterday for reorganization of the data processing and communications industry to increase competition. He spoke at the first National Computer Conference, held in the New York Hilton.

Former Mayor Samuel T. Wheeler defeated the incumbent, Mayor Elmer R. Sheffer, in today's primary election for the Republican nomination to the city hall post. Mr. Sheffer announced that he would run as an independent in November.
Archibald Cox, the special Prosecutor in the Watergate investigation, asked the select Senate committee today for a delay of one to three months in its hearings in the matter.
The Watergate special prosecution team has decided to investigate the conduct of Henry E. Petersen, the Assistant Attorney General who supervised the

Elliot L. Richardson, the new Attorney General, said today that he did not believe the publication of the Pentagon papers was a sufficient justification for the establishment of a special White House unit to investigate security leaks, or for some of the tactics it employed.

The White House acknowledged today that President Nixon conferred frequently this year with John W. Dean 3d about the Watergate scandal but said that logs detailing the time and place of - such conferences would not be turned over to investigators.

John N. Inglima, a senior engineer in the nuclear bureau of Consolidated Edison, died of a brain tumor on Sunday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 49 years old and lived at 1 Sherman Square.
Frank J. Pizzitola, in a surprise move, has resigned as president and director of the Jim Walter Corporation to come to New York City as a general partner of Lazard Freres Co.
The Illinois Supreme Court ruled today that 1973 racing dates awarded to William S. Miller, former state racing board chairman, were void.
A week of relative calm was broken today by fighting around two provincial capitals and the loss of two Government positions elsewhere.

The Canadian Consul General in New York, Bruce Rankin, will present the Outer Critics Circle acting award for 1973 to Christopher Plummer for his performance in "Cyrano." The awards dinner will be held Friday at Sardi's restaurant.

John N. Mitchell, former Attorney General, reportedly has told Senate investigators that he approved payments to the Watergate conspirators after their arrest to avoid embarrassment to President Nixon's reelection campaign.
The difficulty with many all-star productions of classics is simply that on occasion the stars get in your eyes and you can scarcely see the classic.
The Liberty ship John. W. Brown, a Greenwich Village waterfront fixture for several years, is the best-preserved American specimen of a species of ships rapidly approaching extinction.

Following are the texts of a letter from Archibald Cox, special prosecutor in the Watergate case, to Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate committee investigating Watergate, and of a statement by Senator Ervin replying to the letter:
An unprecedented demand for its services has depleted American Red Cross disaster reserve funds to absolute zero, the organization's national chairman said today.

The people who make TV commercials, always eager for recognition by their peers, flocked last night in their versions of formal wear to Philharmonic Hall in Lincoln Center for the 14th annual Clio Awards, the most ostentatious display in New York advertising circles.

Prof. Erwin Stengel, acknowledged as the world's leading authority on suicide, died here during the weekend. Professor Stengel was born in Vienna. He studied there with Sigmund Freud and was senior lecturer in neurology and psychiatry at the University of Vienna when he fled from Austria in 1938 during the Nazi purges.
The city is concerned about the future of services for the aged, blind and disabled after Jan. 1, when the Federal Government will assume a large share of the responsibility fox their care.

Interpool, Ltd., said yesterday that it had agreed to supply Sovinflot, the Soviet Union maritime agency, with about 5,000 20-foot equivalent containers over a three-year period in what is believed to be the largest container contract signed with the agency.
The Jordanian Government has started work on a $100 million plan to resettle farmers, some of them Palestinian refuges, in the war-ravaged Jordan River Valley.

The largest weekday crowd ever to attend an opening day was on hand at Liberty Bell today for the opening of the 78-day spring-summer session. A crowd of 10,431 saw Oak Crest Farm's Flight to Glory win the first division of the featured Sentinel Stakes and Patricia Blass's Annihilate 'Em take the second half.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., There they were, 13 boys and girls, all but two of them 4 or 5 years old (one was 3, one was 7), sawing away on undersized violins at the Anne Frank Montessori School here.
City Controller Abraham D. Beame ran first in the Democratic mayoral primary yesterday, but fell short of 40 per cent of the vote and faces a runoff against Representative Herman Badillo on June 26.
Eleven persons were charged today with gambling in indictments handed up by a special grand jury investigating organized crime and corruption among some officials in Rockland County.
Yale University won a gamble with the weather today and then went on to award 2,806 bachelor and graduate degrees, a record in its 272d commencement exercises.
Henry A. Kissinger will be accompanies by Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, when he flies to Paris tomorrow to resume talks with Mr. Tho's deputy, Tho, Hanoi's chief negotiator,

Five nominees of the regular Democratic organization won a primary contest for City Council today, defeating a single insurgent, Harvey Weisenberg, The five Democras will seek to regain control of the Council
A Coast Guard inquiry into he ramming early Saturday of n oil tanker by a cargo ship here was postponed for. one day yesterday to allow officials ?? to visit the two ships.
Senator Henry M. Jackson accused the Nixon Administration yesterday of not being tough enough in its negotiations with the Soviet Union.
The bleak world of the New York Mets grew even bleaker tonight when Bud Harrelson was injured while they were suffering their third shutout in four games.

HOAI TAN, South Vietnam-After a year as refugees, the people of this devastated central Vietnam village returned home recently under Government prodding. But now they wish they had stayed in their safe if squalid refugee camp.

An escapee from the Annandale Reformatory, failing to heed warnings to halt, was fatally shot by a Jersey City patrolman today after he was seen running form a house while branding a knife, authorities said.

City Controller Abraham D. Beame took first place in the Democratic mayoral primary yesterday but fell short of 40. per cent of the total vote and thus faced a runoff June 26 against Representative Herman Badillo, who finished second.
SEOUL, South Korea-"We have wonderful traditional music," Kang Kyung Hee said solemnly. "It is not inferior to Western music, and in some ways it is better."
The Brain was acting up again. It had been happening more often lately. Hey," said the Brain, "wake ?? Did you see that guy from Hermie's Bonanza New Car Sales?"
Six games were fought to conclusions yesterday in the opening round of the Interzonal Tournament here. The first three finishers in the 18-man round-robin will join the top three players from
Thirty-two persons were injured this morning, four seriously, when a bus collided with a car and plunged down a 30 foot embankment, city policemen said.
A law professor at an Eastern university, after an extended explanation of the legal and constitutional uncertainties in any move to subpoena the President, ended with a dissatisfied sigh.
Thirty-two persons were injured this morning, four seriously, when a bus collided with a car and plunged down a 30 foot embankment, city policemen said.

Marlon Brando and Maria Schneider, stars of "Last Tango in Paris," were convicted on obscenity charges Bologna, Italy, and given suspended sentences of two months in jail and $50 fines. The court also ordered that the film be banned in Italy starting today.
BASEBALL Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati. (Television--Channel 9, 8 P.M.] (Radio--WHN, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Rangers, at Arlington, Tex. (Radio-WMCA, 8:30 P.M.]
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson announced today the formation of "The Friends of the LBJ Library" to raise funds for the library and the LBJ School of Public Affairs.
BASEBALL Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati. (Television-Channel 9, 8 P.M.] (Radio-WHN; 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Rangers, at Arlington. Tex. (Radio-WMCA, 8:30 P.M.]

The question of what theatrical unions can do to encourage Broadway production activity was the subject of discussion at the latest luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk, the association of New York critics, editors and reporters, held at Sardi's Belasco Room.

The city took its primary elections in stride last night. The Hare Krishnas chanted and sold incense on 45th Street. At McGlade and Ward, a tavern near 86th on Columbus Avenue, a dozen patrons watched Satchel Paige

To the Editor: What if the ultimate judgment is that the President must be removed from his office? Does it follow that Mr. Agnew must succeed him? Perhaps it is worth noting that there is, in fact, no clear precedent for this situation.

The Gulf Oil Corporation and companies of the Royal Dutch-Shell Group announced today a joint venture in the international nuclear power Industry. The 50-50 partnership is intended to own and operate the business now conducted by Gulf Energy and Environmental Systems, Gulf's California-based nuclear power division.

Marya Mannes, the writer, urged the graduating class of Baruch College yesterday to help cleanse the English language so it would enlighten rather than spread the kind of "deception, evasion and downright dishonesty that has led to Watergate and other forms of rottenness eroding our society."

Otis Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, announced yesterday that he had resigned as a director of the GTR Management Company and its subsidiary, GeoTek Resources Fund, Inc., two concerns that operated a large oil drilling investment program.

Corporations continue to acquire their own shares. Yesterday, the Pillsbury Company announced plans to purchase 40,000 shares (of 5,408,909 outstanding) on the open market. Tiffany Industries, a farm-equipment and furniture concern that should not be confused with Tiffany Co., authorized the purchase of 50,000 shares. Ambassador Group, an insurance holding company, plans to buy 50,000 of its shares. .

Robert F. Wagner Jr., the 29 year-old son of the former Mayor, won the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Councilman at Large last night, and Robert S. Steingut, the 27 year-old son of the Assembly minority leader, was a victor in the Brooklyn Councilman at Large contest.
The Supreme Court ruled today, by 6-2, that a railroad was not entitled to a tax deduction for dpereciation of Government-financed facilities.
A staff member of the National Commission on Fire Prevention and Control charged to day that there is "outrageous racial discrimination in the nation's fire departments.

Nomination by the Democrats of Frank S. Hogan for District Attorney of Manhattan guarantees that this respected prosecutor will have four-party support in November for re-election to a ninth four-year term. This assurance represents deserved recognition of the splendid standards of fairness, integrity and freedom from politics that Mr. Hogan has made a hallmark of his office.
The Defense Department reports that 10,303 American servicemen died of noncombat causes in Vietnam, in addition to the 45,958 men who were combat casualties.

Committees in both houses of Congress have moved in recent weeks to revise drastically President Nixon's foreign assistance program, which Chairman J. W. Fulbright of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has already dismissed as "a relic of the past."
The spectacular problems of the $2.5-billion Skylab mission and the failure of the first three Soviet-Salyut space stations may have dealt a death blow to manned space flight.
The Watergate special prosecution team has decided to investigate the conduct of Henry E. Petersen, the Assistant Attorney General who supervised the

Ed Tutwiler, a former United States Walker Cup star, and Ireland's Joe Carr led the advance today as the British Amateur golf championship opened with Frank (One Round)Strafaci of Miami living up to his nickname by losing in the first round for the 23d year.
A team of top American swimmers opened a three-week exhibition tour today before 12,000 people who sat in open stands through a downpour in Canton, China.

Federal Judge Murray I. Gurfein signed yesterday an order permanently prohibiting four executives and one former officer of Weis Securities, the brokerage house put into liquidation last week, from violating Federal securities laws.

One section of Parkchester, the largest rental apartment complex in the country, has officially become a condominium. The conversion, which may foreshadow a far - reaching change in the nature of tenancy in large urban developments, came with the transfer of title to two apartments last month.
Three Army helicopter crewmen were killed when their helicopter crashed near their helicopter crashed near Oak Grove airport south of here yesterday.
Speculative price jumps in July delivery soybeans con tinued yesterday to a record of $12.90 a bushel. After reaching this level, the futures contract closed at $11.80, down from$12.11 on Monday.
A West Point senior who was ordered dismissed from the Corps of Cadets last month lost a court fight yesterday to graduate with his classmates.

During a sample week, the State Supreme Court justices handling criminal cases in Man hattan were on the bench an average of 3 hours and 21 minutes a day, or 52 per cent of their nominal working time, a study by the Economic Development Council has found.

A State Supreme Court jus tice ruled yesterday that finan cial statements of property owners, which are part of city records and which the city has kept confidential for decades, were subject to the city's "freedom of information" stat ute and open to public andpress inspection.

The Senate, expressing intense Con gressional concern over gasoline shortages, voted overwhelming ly today to authorize the Gov ernment to make mandatory allocations of crude oil and oil products to refiners and dis.tributors.

Hours after they had run one-two in the Democratic mayoral primary and thus Qualified for the June 26 run off, Controller Abraham D. Beame and Representative Her nan Badillo exchanged politicalcharges .

George Bennett Cassidy, ruddy, smiling and faultlessly tailored, climbs a short flight of stairs beside the inner rail at Belmont Park and stands watching while assistants lead the horses into the starting gate. The moment the doors are closed, four or five urgent voices rise: "No, boss, not yet!" "No chance, boss!" "Not ready!" Almost immediately, Cassidy's thumb presses the button at theend of an insulated cord.
Pakistan accused India in the World Court today of having illegally detained more than 92,000 Pakistani prisoners of war and civilian interneesfor over 17 months.

Dr. H. Herbert Fox, whose research in organic chemistry led to the development of isoniazid, an effective remedy in combating tuberculosis, died Friday when a raft overturned in northeastern Utah. His age was 60.

The Times of London charged in a long editorial today that The Wash ington Post and The New York Times were interfering with the course of justice by "publishing vast quantities of prejudicial matter" on the Watergate affair.

BORINQUEN The most liv ing Puerto Rican art in town marched up Fifth Avenue in the form of a parade last Sunday, but recognition has not ended with that. Today, the American Museum of Na tural History, 77th Street and Central Park West (873 1300), opens a relatively tiny but tidy display called "roots of Puerto Rico" in its firstfloor Education Gallery.

Hours after they had run one-two in the Democratic mayoral primary and thus qualified for the June 26 run off, Controller Abraham D. Beame and Representative Her man Badillo exchanged politicalpunches.

Raimo Pihl of Brigham Young University turned in a blazing 48.8-second time in the 400-meter dash, the final event of the night, to take a 79-point lead at the midway point of the National Collegiate decathlon championship.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers announced today that President Nixon - in a break with previous policy-had au thorized the sale of F-5E super sonic jet fighter planes to Chile and four other South Americancountries.

A technical rebound but tressed by some favorable eco nomic announcements propelled stock prices higher yesterday in stepped-up trading. The advance ended five con secutive sessions of losses onthe New York Stock Exchange.

Following are excerpts from the deposition given under oath by John D. Ehrlichman, former. assistant to President Nixon for domestic affairs, in a civil suit by the Democratic National Committee on theWatergate case.

Voters in the Republican pr mary yesterday spilt their ba lots in wholesale lots, election legislative candidates running on the same line as Governo Cahill and then switching ove to cast ballots for Mr. Ca hill's opponent, RepresentativCharles W.' Sandman Jr.
An International Civil Aviation Organization report released to day condemns Israel for shoot ing down a Libyan airliner over the Sinai desert, killing 108persons.

A 37-year-old Transit Au thority patrolman was slain in a shootout with two men yes terday in the waiting room of an IRT elevated subway station in the Bronx, the police said. One of the men was a member of the Black Liberation Army,the police said.
The New Jersey Army National Guard, despite recent pay increases, improved benefits and better working conditions for its re cruits, is suffering a seriousmanpower shortage.

Sanford D. Garelik accepted his defeat as City Council Presi dent with philosophic nonre signation yesterday, and Paul O'Dwyer, who defeated him in Monday's primary mused about what he would like to do withthe office.

Cardiss Collins easily won to day the Congressional House seat left vacant by the death of her husband, and former Representative Roman C. Pucin ski returned to elective office with a victory in one of fourAlderman races in Chicago.

Five American conductors will be given special posts with American symphony orchestras next season under a new pro gram administered by Affiliate Artists and supported by a grant of $50,000 from theExxon Corporation.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. seemed to be delighted. His thick, dark eyebrows swooped characteristically up and down like the wings of an eagle in flight. The corners of his lips curled with thehint of a satisfied smile.
Columbia Pictures Indus tries, Inc., will sell its build ing at 711 Fifth Avenue and move a major part of its in tegrated entertainment complex to California soon.
8:05-10 A.M., WNCN. A Musical Snuff Box, Liadov; Polonaise in A flat, Chopin; Tambourin, Ra meau; Queen Elizabeth, Her Gal liard Dowland; Waltzes, Tchai kovsky; Horn Concerto in D,Haydn.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday for the first time in four sessions, despite the fact that the price of gold closed at a record of$126 an ounce in London.
Edible spoons and aerating straws are in the wind. The Dairy Research Digest says the spoons were developed in an unnamed Scandinavian country. Only the bowls are ediblethe handles are plastic.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi-The tiny, mountainous, landlocked East African nations of Burundi and Rwanda are making large, although informal, population exchanges as people flee in thewake of "tribal" massacres.

The South Vietnamese Gov ernment said today that it asked Japan to replace Can ada as a member of the in ternational truce commission but that Japan declined. Japan refused because its laws prohibit sending troops aboard, said Pham Dang Sum of the South Veitnamese Foreign. Ministry.

Professional track and field moves into Madison Square Garden for the first time to night at 7:30 with a streamlined format, different objectives but the same challenging statistic a sub-four-minute mile.
AUBURN, Ala. - Queen Esther Parker, who worked as a housemaid here isn't quite sure-like many other Americans-what the minimum wage is these days.
The city will have to pay over 29 per cent more than last year for the fuel to heat municipal buildings and to power municipal vehicles as a result of tight oil supplies.
Jacob D. Fuchsberg held a chief judge of the state, with Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein a close second.

Two men from Huntington, L.I., were injured yesterday when their small irplanc crashed on take-off from a private airfield in this Windsor County community. Police Chief John Springer said Richard Freda, 41 years old, of 6 Crest Road, was in critical condition at Mary Hitchcock Hospital in Hanover,N. H.,
Ray Malavasi, Oakland Raider linebacker coach for the last two seasons, was named as defensive coordinator yesterday by the Los Angeles Rams.

World trade continued to boom last year despite international monetary uncertainty during part of the year, the International Monetary Fund reported today. Measured by the dollar value of world exports, trade last year increased by 18 per cent to $371-billion. This followed a rise of 12 per cent. in 1972 over 1971. Part of last year's rise simply represented the effect of inflationon the dollar value of exports, but much of it was "real."

The United States Auto Club, which sanctions the Indianapolis 500 and writes the specifications of the cars that race there, has done some hasty soul-searching about the accidents thatplagued last week's race.

Gold keeps climbing: It closed at $126 an ounce in London yesterday, almost double the price at which it started the year. The dollar keeps sinking: It has now lost about one-fifth of its value in relation to the West German mark since December, 1971.

Canada's Stratford is a comparatively small town, but it happens to be one of North America's major tourist at tractions. The reason for this is ridiculously simple, for not only is Stratford a quite ab surdly pretty little Ontario town, but also, for 24 weeks of the year, it is host, with its three theaters, to the most important drama festival on the North American continent.

When a Princeton team wins an Ivy League championship, the captain is awarded a white sweater with an orange "P". Those who have won white sweaters include Cosmo Iacavazzi, Bill Bradley and Marjory Gengler. Miss Gengler weighs 120 pounds, is 5 feet 6
The Court of Appeals in Albany ruled unanimously yesterday that a Manhattan apartment's owners "resorted to flagrant misrepresentation" in getting tenants to agree to make it a cooperative.

Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania has been elected chairman of the Mid-Atlantic Governor's Conference. Mr. Shapp, who is attending the national Governors Conference here, succeeds Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey as chairnan.

Fifteen hundred fishermen have perished on islands east of Bali since April because of storms and floods, the Communications Department said today. Damage to houses, Government buildings, mosques and dams has been estimated at more than $7-million.
James J. Pelosi was graduated from the United States Military Academy here today, more than a year and a half after he was officially "silenced" by his fellow cadets.

A state Republican official said today that he received $10,000 from Hugh W. Sloan Jr., then-treasurer of President Nixon's re-election drive, for a "legitimate" program involving the American Independent party.
Tenafly has become the first New Jersey school district in more than 20 years to adopt a year-round curriculum.

The Watergate fallout has been a large part of the crisis of confidence that has troubled the stock market recently, according to George L. Shinn, president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.

It was a disastrous day for the English at the British amateur golf championship today as Trevor Homer, the defending champion, bowed out in the second round and Mike Bonallack, a five-time winner, withdrew with an injury.
Dr. Fletcher Low, professor emeritus of chemistry at Dartmouth College, died at his home here today. He was 80 years old.
With summer television so far dominated by Watergate and dreary reruns, the National Broadcasting Company had the right idea last night at 7:30 with a new marinelife series called "Inner Space."
West Germany completed ratification today of a treaty to normalize its relations with EastsGermany. The Bonn Government also named it future representative in East Berlin.

Britain, West Germany and Belgium agreed today to buy Lance surface to-surface missiles from the United States. This decision, a cooperative venture by the three countries, was announced at the close of a meeting of Eurogroup, which consists of defense ministers from 10 European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia said here today that he had requested modification of the 1963 agreement with the United States under which American military installations are maintained on his country's Northwest Cape.
President Nixon named former Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird as his chief domestic adviser today in an effort to. shore up the Administration during the Watergate crisis.
A city detective was shot early yesterday in Central Park while trying to protect a Park Avenue woman whose life had previously been threatened several times, the police said.

Mayor Lindsay will make another attempt to bring off the Madison Mall. A slightly revised version of the plan has been presented to the Board of Estimate, and it is scheduled for a vote on June 21. Details will be disclosed by the Mayor at a news conference Monday.

Josephine Baker knows how to make an entrance. The American-born singer and dancer, who celebrated her 67th birthday on Sunday, brought a full house at Carnegie Hall to its feet cheering and applauding Tuesday evening merely by stepping into a spotlight wearing a spangled body-stocking that left no doubt about the slim,

Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who allegedly contributed $200,000 illegally to President Nixon's re-election campaign, said today that he did not consider himself a fugitive from the United States or subject to United States courts.
Many investors like to take possession of those crisp, colorful pieces of paper called stock certificates.
George F. Getty 2d, son of the oil billionaire John Paul Getty, died of a cerebral hemorrhage at Queen of Angels Hospital here this afternoon at the age of 48.
Two college-age couples, moving carefully near the teeming central market here, entered a small house one recent evening, locked the doors and shuttered the windows.
One of the largest underground nuclear tests ever conducted at the Nevada Test Site went off on schedule today, causing shock waves felt as far away as Las Vegas.
Egypt today renewed her demand that Israel withdraw immediately from all Arab land occupied during the 1967 war.

Princess is not a woman, or a horse, or an Angora cat. No, she's a boat-a 26-footlong sloop, with over 9 feet of beam, gaffrigged sails, and power, originally built for lobster-fishing by the incomparable Wilbur A. Morse of Friendship, Me., considerably before the turn of the century.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has asked the Federal Communications Commission to determine whether New York City's television stations should be allowed to shift their antennas from the Empire State Building to the top of the authority's World Trade Center.

Two former heroin addicts who say they have shaken the drug habit sued the Postal Service yesterday, charging that their Constitutional rights had been violated when they were denied jobs as clerk/carriers.
Dr. George B. Burch, professor emeritus of philosophy at Tufts University and an authority on India and Hindu thought, died Monday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

Police Officer Robert B. Laurenson, fatally wounded when he tried to thwart a holdup in a bar near Lincoln Center in Manhattan last Saturday, was buried yesterday in the graveyard of his family's church in Elmont, L. I.

The Federal Government has directed New York State to consider expanding and modernizing Grand Central Terminal before building a $341-million railroad and subway terminal underneath Third Avenue between 48th and 53d Streets.
The Federal Government officially dropped today its effort to prosecute Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. for stealing and copying the Pentagon papers.
In choosing poems for The New Oxford Book of English Verse, Dame Helen Gardner had no trouble with the monuments: sonnets by Shakespeare, satire by Pope, odes by Keats and narrative by Tennyson.

A drop in earnings and revenues for the first quarter was reported yesterday by DCL, r Inc., which through its wholly owned subsidiary, the Diebold Company, buys electronic data processing equipment for lease to others.
Governor Rockefeller's office has begun an inquiry into the recent assumption by Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo of a director's post on the board of Metromedia, Inc.

The Securities and Exchange Commission indicated today that it had serious questions about some aspects of the increase in commission charges on stock transactions that has been proposed by the New York Stock Exchange.

The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit upheld today that a lower court opinion that a strict law curbing abortions enacted in Rhode Island in March was unconstitutional. It declined to extend a stay to permit further appeal.

Coast Guard officials said yesterday that the American Export Lines freighter that rammed a Belgian oil tanker early Saturday morning in the Narrows after losing control of its steering mechanism had been plagued by mishaps since she was built in 1968.
The body of a 12-year-old boy was found yesterday afternoon on the tracks of the JRT Seventh Avenue subway line, 2,000 feet south of the East 149th Street station at Third Avenue, inthe South Bronx.
Experts in urban economic development from throughout the country toured Brooklyn in a bus yesterday to see some of the things the city has been doing to counter urban decay and unemployment.
James J. Pelosi was graduated from the United States Military Academy here today, more than a year and a half after he was officially "silenced" by his fellow cadets.
The stock market failed to sustain an early advance yesterday and finished slightly lower in slower trading.
The soft days of the sixth month are calling young and old to the outdoors, to beaches, to mountains, to hiking trails, to wilderness canoe trips.

Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told 939 graduating cadets at the United States Military Academy here today that peace could not be achieved "by good will and wishful thinking alone,"
The nation's Governors called today for mandatory allocation of petroleum supplies by the Federal Government.
Both total consumer credit and consumer-installment credit slowed their rapid growth in April, the Federal Reserve Board Board reported today.
Commodity futures prices general declined yesterday, reacting to more reports that the Government planned firm steps such as price controls and export embargoes to deal with inflation.
The New York Philharmonic beat the Metropolitan Opera in softball yesterday, 17 to 7, in Central Park. The Philharmonic's hero was Michael Gilbert, who hit two homers and ordinarily plays a violin.

A bill passed by the Legislature that would exempt the New York Telephone Company from taxation on certain equipment it owns that is installed after Dec. 31, 1974, was severely criticized today by Abe Seldin, a former Republican Assemblyman from Nassau County and candidate for chairman of the County Board of Assessors.

KABUL, Afghanistan-The other morning a handful of donkeys followed by a camel and half a dozen cars began moving, suddenly and inexplicably, through a red light on Djadi Maiwand, a busy main street in downtown Kabul.

Willie Mays hit his first home run since spring training tonight and it, too, came in an exhibition game. The 42-yearold outfielder led off the New York Mets' annual visit to their Tidewater farm club with his first hit since being reinstate to the active list June 3.
A small group of appointed and highly expendable aides to Governor Cahill sat in the sunshine outside the State House today, relaxing for the first time since the gubernatorial primary began.
The Soviet Union will pay France for damage caused by Sunday's crash of a supersonic TU-144 airliner near Le Bourget airport, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

Bond prices rallied for the second straight session yesterday, with the market embaracing any news report that could be interpreted as leading to less inflation, such as tighter economic controls and mostly ignoring those that clouded such hopes.

The chairman of Maryland's Republican party said today that organizers of a 1972 fund-raising event honoring Vice President Agnew hid for nearly a year a $49,900 contribution from the national Committee for the Re-election of the President.

President Nixon approved plan for expanded domestic in telligence' gathering in July, 1970, after being cautioned that parts of it were "clearly illegal" and involved "serious. risks" to his Administration if the operations were ever diScovered, according to White House documents.

In his choice of Melvin Laird, former Secretary of Defense and veteran Congressman from Wisconsin, as the new head of his domestic policy staff, President Nixon has selected a man with the political skills and experience which the former occupant of that post-John Ehrlichman-conspicuously lacked. The appointment has evoked a predictably favorable reaction on Capitol Hill and from Republican party activists.

MONTE CARLO-Although Mrs. Susan Blalack started her pug kennel only three years ago, it now is the second largest on the continent. In that comparatively short time, she has had eight international champions.

Lewis A. Engman chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said that the year-long investigation of the petroleum industry by his agency will be completed "no later than July 1."

Jerome Robbin's "An Evening's Waltzes," which was given its premiere only a week and a half ago by the New York City Ballet, had its first major cast change Tuesday evening at the State Theater. Heigi Tomasson, recovering from a back injury, essayed the male role in the third section.

The opening of the Marc Chagall show and here, after decades of denuncitation of the Russian-born artist as a "formalist," may have been big news in the West, but it has been a nonevent here for the ordinary Russian.
A city detective was shot early yesterday in Central Park while trying to protect a Park Avenue woman whose life had previously been threatened several times, the police said.
Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., moved through the third round of the Northern lawn tennins championships today with a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Barbara Downs of Alamo, Calif.
A 36-year-old man serving a nine-month 'sentence for criminal trespass hanged himself yesterday in his cell at the Correctional Institution for Men on Rikers Island.

The Zapata Corporation, whihc through subsidiaries is engaged in offshore drilling of oil and gs wells, announced yesterday that it had been offered about $200-million in cash and secured short-term notes for its international bulk shipping operation,

Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, conceded today that there was no legal way to prevent John W. Dean 3d and Jeb Stuart Magruder from testifying with immunity before the Senate Watergate committee next week.
Amid reports that the Yankees were close to a deal that could strengthen their staggering pitching staff, Steve Kline came through tonight with a successful test of his pazzling arm.
Mrs. Ethel Kennedy, nei children and Senator and Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy prayed at the grave of Senator Robert F. Kennedy yesterday in Arlington National Cemetery.

Mrs. Sada Smith, a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution and founder of the Shelter Island chapter, died today in Eastern Long Island Hospital. Her age was 89. She was the widow of Arthur Smith.
Tom Charles Huston, then a junior man on the White House staff, set out three years ago to conquer the late J. Edgar Hoover as only a 29-year-old newcomer to Washington would have tried.

There were any number of women gotten up as Zelda Fitzgerald the other night in front of the Plaza. But they weren't about to risk their rented 1920's finery by cavorting in the Pulitzer fountain even though it had been cleared of its normal flotilla of paper cups and Good Humor wrappers.
The 88-acre Manlius campus of the Manlius-Pebble Hill School has been sold to a real-state development concern for conversion into a retirement community.

Joint news conferences would be held by the two mayoral candidates in the Democratic runoff-limited to one subject and sure to get free time on television-under a proposal yesterday by aides to Representative Herman Badillo that Controller Abraham D. Beame's team agreed to "take under advisement."

Just down the corridor from the nationally televised Watergate hearings, another Senate committee listened today to appeals from several Senators for reforms in the Federal election laws to prevent future Watergates.

Uncertainty over the antiinflation plans of the Nixon Administrtion slowed down the buying pace on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and the market closed lower after being higher the day before.

France's over-all gold and convertible currency reserves rose 319 million francs in May to reach 47.41 billion francs, the Finance Ministry said today. The French franc is currently quoted at about 2370 cents.

President Nixon will deliver the commencement address Friday at 10:30 A.M. at Florida Technological University in Orlando, the White House announced today.
An audience that included a veritable who's who in New Jersey mental health circles was told today that sex was still the number one taboo in this country.
The Senate Finance Committee unanimously approved legislation today to block Administration efforts to reduce drastically Federal aid to such programs as day care and aid to the elderly.

A Pennsylvania engineering concern that has a design contract for the proposed $268-million Meadowlands sports development pleaded guilty today to charges of illegally deducting political contributions to Governor Cahill's first-term campaign on its 1968 and 1969 corporate income-tax returns.
Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam resumed their private talks today on how to enforce the Vietnam peace agreement signed Jan. 27.

Secretariat is by all odds the horse to beat in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, and Frank (Pancho) Martin is almost obsessive in his determination to conquer the Meadow Stable colt. Martin trains Sham, the colt who finished second to Secretariat in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, and up until yesterday Martin was satisfied to go it alone against Secretariat.

" Avenue" is the name of a dance work by Louis Falco given its premiere Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall. It preserves Mr. Falco's reputation, acquired within the last three years, as a young with-it choreographer, and there was a young with-it audience at the opening of the run-through Sunday by the Louis Falco Dance Company.

An 18-year-old Bronx youth who pleaded builty to attempted murder, robbery and assault of a 53-year-old storekeeper in Brooklyn last August was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in prison by State Supreme Court Justice Harry J. Donnelly.
ALEXANDER-Edna E. of Ardsley, N.Y. on June S, 1973. Beloved wife of the late Bernhard, devoted mother of Doris Zuckerman and grandmother of Anne. Services private.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that those selling the dollar to buy gold "may well wake up tomorrow with a speculative hangover." In a prepared Senate speech, he said there is no valid reason for the dollar's weakness.

With little campaigning and the help of the Cook County Democratic organization, Mrs. Cardiss Collins was elected yesterday as Illinois' first black Congresswoman, gathering about 92 per cent of the vote.

A special court-martial at Subic Naval Base, 80 miles northwest of here, today sentenced an American Navy man to three months at hard labor for having refused to obey orders during a minesweeping operation off North Vietnam in March.

To the Editor: A few years ago, the International Court of Justice suffered from a lack of cases. Now it has four cases before it but is beset by a new, graver crisis: The defendants refuse to appear. Iceland and France have declined even seriously to argue the jurisdiction of the Court.

Federal investigators in Newark believe that their inquiry on payola at Columbia Records has uncovered a "clear involvement" of organized crime in some segments of the record industry, according to sources close to the case.

Thirty-eight restaurants and other food establishments are on the Health Department's latest list of places found to have violated the city's Health Code.

The Wisconsin Public Service Corporation yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commsson in connection with an offering of 900,000 shares of common stock through Merrill Lynch and Robert W. Baird Co. The utility's stock closed at 16 7/8, up 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Doug Stein of the Glen Oaks Club won the 40th annual William R. Hochster amateur golf tournament today with a 36hole total of 145. Stein, the 22-year-old departing captain of Columbia University's golf team, put together rounds of 71 and 74 over the par 35, 35-70, 6,405-yard course of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

Foreign Minister Chi Peng-fei of China began a five-day official visit to Britain today. Mr. Chi, the first Chinese Foreign Minister to come here, will meet tomorrow with Foreign Secretary Sir Alec Douglas-Home.

BANGKOK, Thailand-While Europe basks in the sun of detente and, in the United States, people breathe more easily after the rapprochement with the People's Republic of China and improved Soviet relations-developments which led to the halt of hostilities in Vietnam - Thailand still remains bogged down, neck-deep, in the cold war quagmire because of a massive American military presence and unwarranted use of Thai territory for war operations in Indochina.

A small plastic vial that pharmacists use to dispense pills in plain view on a shelf in the office of Bobby Winkles, the manager of the California Angels. When asked about it, he said: "Oh that; it's not for any pills, it's only for some mouthwash I like to use after I finish chewing tobacco. No, I don't have an ulcer. If I had to take Maalox or any other stuff, I'd quit."
The Penn Central announced yesterday that it would close Grand Central Terminal from 1:30 A.M. to 5:30 A.M. starting July 2 and would discontinue nine trains that use the terminal during those hours.

Immunity was granted today to the prosecution's balky chief witness in the trial of a sailor accused of sabotaging the carrier U.S.S. Ranger, clearing the way for the witness's testimony about the defendant's alleged admission of guilt.

Another clash between British trawlers and an Icelandic patrol vessel last week underscores the dangers in a deepening dispute between two NATO allies. London appears to be eager for a negotiated settlement. The British already have agreed to recognize the preferential rights of Icelanders to fish in their recently extended fifty-mile zone and to join in efforts to prevent overfishing.

The head of the Transit Authority Patrolmen's Benevolent Association called upon the city yesterday to establish two-man patrols on the subway in the aftermath of the fatal shooting Tuesday of a transit plainclothes patrolman.

" BAA BAA, BAA BAA..." protested the shaggy, whitefaced ewe yesterday as Robert Taylor, a Biblical looking sheep shearer, yanked her from a red Volkswagen truck and then coaxed her down the stairs to the sunken plaza of the new McGraw-Hill building.

President Nixon approved a plan for expanded domestic intelligence gathering in July, 1970, after being cautioned that parts of it were "clearly illegal" and involved "serious risks" to his Administration if the operations were ever discovered, according to White House documents.

A White House lawyer sought to persuade an official of President Nixon's political organization to resist testifying at a Miami trial related to the Watergate affair, it was reported in Senate hearings today.

Leaders of the regular and Reform factions of the badly divided Manhattan Democratic organization agreed yesterday to give the winner of the June 26 mayoral primary runoff a voice in the selection of a new county leader.
A series of shelling and infantry attacks was reported along the central coast yesterday, and the Saigon command and the Vietcong blamed each other for the continued fighting in the Mekong Delta.
The Christian Democratic party, Italy's dominant but disunited political force, today opened a national convention in a search for stability that is expected to bring about a shift to the left.

In Lee Kalchim's "The by who Came to Leave," which opened last night at the astor Place Theater, two young men inhabit a loft apartment. Paul lives there; Jonathan is becoming a permanent guest.

Four years ago affluent Bergen County, where the average house sells for $40,000 and three of every five families make more than $15,000 a year, provided the margin of victory that made William T. Cahill the Republican candidate for Governor.

Propelled by the strongest gubernatorial primary victories in New Jersey's recent political history, the new Democratic and Republican candidates for Governor prepared today for an election campaign dominated by the state income tax issue and the Republican corruption scandal that led to Governor Cahill's humiliating defeat in yesterday's voting.
Two American shrimp boats detained last week for fishing Brazilian shrimp banks without proper documentation have been released, officials here said today.

Syracuse Department of Public Works Commissioner Ernest W. Speach resigned this afternoon in the midst of an investigation into missing department equipment and charges that the city paid for work done en a red truck he owns.
The 30th annual CareyThomas Awards for distinction in publishing were presented yesterday to Atlantic-Little, Brown, George Braziller, Inc., and the Yale University Press.
Agreement in principle to merge the two largest Cleveland-based investment banking and brokerage firms, Prescott, Merrill, Turben Co., and Ball, Burge Kraus was announced here today.

For decades, they said it couldn't be done, that pro track would never make it. But it has. With last night's meet at Madison Square Garden, the International Track Association completed a tour of 16 indoor meets.
Joseph Mann, manager since 1914 of the Peoples' Symphony Concerts, died yesterday of cancer at the Dewitt Nursing Home. He was 79 years old and lived at the Mayflower Hotel, 15 Central Park West.

When a magazine publisher announces the favorable results of an audience research project he has sponsored, the results are not scoffed at as patently self-serving by Madison Avenue. Such information is indeed welcomed.

The royal family of Cambodia, disgraced and under close confinement by a hostile revolutionary Government for three years, has cautiously begun its re-entry into the problems of daily life in a city at war.
The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed new rules today to make corporations disclose more about leases.
Clarence E. Johnson, 48 years old, of Camden, an investigator for the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Division, was indicted today in an alleged shakedown of four liquor licensees.

The Nixon Administration, in a further effort to control inflation and stabilize prices, announced today that it would resume sales tomorrow of surplus stockpile tin after five years. Initially it plans to sell about $30.5-million worth by the end of this year. A half-dozen or so of the nation's larger banks, led by the Girard Trust Bank in Philadelphia, announced yesterday, as expected, an increases in their prime lending rates to 7 1/2 per cent from 7 1/4 per cent, effective today.

Henry Loomis, president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, said today he had "talked long and hard to the White House" in an attempt to forestall a second veto of legislation granting two-year funding for public television.
Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho continued their discussions today in a meeting that had been postponed for several hours at the American's request.

A former official of President Nixon's campaign committee admitted today that he had lied last year in an effort to disguise the "dirty tricks" nature of cash payments to one of the Watergate conspirators.

The United States Court of Appeals upheld yesterday court proceedings that stripped a former Nazi concentration camp guard of her United States citizenship and made possible her extradition to West Germany to face charges of murdering prisoners.

Harold K. LaRowe, who retired as purchasing director of the American Cyanamid Company in Wayne, N.J., in 1962 after 15 years in the post, died today in Lawrence Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived here.

Charles O. Finley said today he could not afford to lose $550,000 a year and was selling the Memphis Tams of the American Basketball Association to a Providence, R. I., group. Finley also owns the Oakland Athletics in baseball and the California Golden Seals in hockey.

The former Columbia Records executive who has been cooperating with Federal authorities in their investigation of payola and narcotics traffic in the recording industry detailed yesterday the events that led to his appearance before a Federal grand jury,
The Association of Tennis Players said today that it would boycott tournaments that banned Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia, in cluding Wimbledon. The A.T.P. represents all of the leading tennis players.

Foreign Minister Chi Pengfei of China and Sir Alec Douglas-Home, the British Foreign Secretary, met in London for what were described there as the first major diplomatic talks between ranking representatives of the two countries in almost 25 years.

One-Mile Run (Qualifiers for Final)--Paul Cummings, Brigham Young, 4 minutes 0.9 seconds; Dave Wottle, Bowling Green, 4:02; Mark Feig, Oregon, 4:02.4; Ken Popejoy, Michigan State, 4:04; Knut Kvalheim, Oregon, 4:01.6; Reggie McAfee, North Carolina 4:02; Charles McMullen, Missouri, 4:02.5; Mark Schilling, San Jose Slate, 4:03.1; Hallu, Oregon State, 4:04;
After a six-week search, President Nixon named Clarence M. Kelley, police chief of Kansas City, Mo., today to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

TUB (premiere), choreography, Jennifer Muller; music, Burt Alcantara; costumes,Christina Ham; tub, John Duff; lighting, Richard Nerson. With Louis Falco, Jennifer Muller, Juan Antonio, Georgiana Holmes, Matthew Diamond and Mary Jane Elsenberg. Presented by the Louis Falco Dance Company at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center.

Two former officials of the Veterans Administration and a real-estate appraiser were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of conspiracy and bribery in the processing of mortgage loans to former servicemen.
With the Israeli Army band playing "Deutschland uber Alles," Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany arrived here today on a four-day state visit heavy with emotional memories.
William Attwood, president and publisher of Newsday, and Mrs. Attwood have announced the marriage on May 26 of their daughter, Miss Jan Attwood, to David McGreevy,
The police and students of the area around Yankee Stadium searched yesterday for Maria Acierno, a 3 1/2-year-old girl Who disappeared from a small park opposite her home at 901 Walton Avenue.
After a six-week search, President Nixon named Clarence M. Kelley, police chief of Kansas City, Mo., today to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The National Weather Service issued this forecast at 6:45 P.M. yesterday for New York Harbor, Long Island Sound, Long Island south shore and nearby coastal area:

The International Controls Corporation, the New Jersey company once controlled by Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier, sued him in Federal court here yesterday for damages for "corporate waste."

Secret funds from President Nixon's re-election campaign financed an unsuccessful effort to remove Gov. George C. Wallace's American Independent party from the California ballot last year, according to a former Nixon campaign official.
The New York Stock Exchange took steps today to curb the impact of rule changes that threaten to drain sorely-needed revenues from its member firms.

The Los Angeles County coroner's office ruled today that George F. Getty 2d, the 48-year-old eldest son of John Paul Getty, the oil billionaire died here yesterday from an overdose of barbiturates and alcohol.

A three-judge Federal Court of Appeals yesterday threw out the conviction of Nicholas Rattenni, the alleged Mafia leader of Westchester County, for conspiring to influence a juror in an earlier trial.

A court ruling that barred the New Jersey State Commission of Investigation from publicly identifying targets of its inquiry into alleged abuses, misconduct or fraud in workmen's compensation settlements was temporarily set aside today.
The great disadvantage of David William's production of "Othello," which opened rather shakily at the Festival Theater in Canada last night, is the Othello.
The fix-it crew of Skylab 1 pulled off the first major repair job in space yesterday when, in a daring space "walk," they managed to deploy a stuck solar-power wing on their orbiting space station.

Controller Abraham D. Beame shook hands serenely through crowds of shoppers in Manhattan and elderly benchsitters in the Bronx yesterday while his staff - apparently caught unaware by his failure to win 40 per cent of the vote on Monday - worked to improvise a runoff mayoral campaign.

John L. Loeb, a prominent Wall Street investment banker was fined $3,000 in Federal Court here yesterday for illegal ly disguising a $48,000 contribution to Senator Hubert H Humphrey's unsuccessful campaign for the Democratic nomination for President last year.

The Senate Watergate committee contended today that neither the Federal courts nor the special prosecutor in the case had the authority to prevent the committee from taking testimony from Watergate figures in public and on television.
The board of trustees of Fairleigh Dickinson University declared today that "a financial exigency," exists at the university.

Big game anglers will be pleased to learn that the first ironed swordfish of the season, a 114-pounder, was brought into Poole's Fish Market at Menemsha on Martha's Vineyard early this week by the Mayhew brothers. The Mayhews,

Investigations were begun today to determine whether Maryland law was violated by false entries on financial statements filed by organizers of a 1972 fund-raising affair honoring Vice President Agnew.
The first public appearance of Marlon Mrando since he refused to ateend the Oscar ceremonies, it seems, will b on the Dick Cavett television show next week.
A former leader in the electric utilities industry, Walter T. Lucking, whose special interest had been solar energy, has now moved into the business of selling pure water.

Attorney General Louis J. Lcfkowitz yesterday disclosed a six-month-old investigation of in alleged multimillion-dollar black market in the mostsought-after "hot" sports tickets in town, including those for Knickerbocker, Ranger, Giant and Jet games.
The Soviet Union has requested a postponement of Premier Kakuei Tanaka's projected visit to Moscow, saying it would be inconvenient to receive him at the end of August.
Nine Nobel Prize winners speaking for themselves and 8,000 other scientists, sent a letter to President Nixon today protesting the Administration's policies in funding medical research.

Mrs. Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights and the Mayor's executive assistant for neighborhood government, told the City University Graduate School's ninth annual doctoral commencement that there were "signs of economic recuperation" here. She said, for example, that the loss of manufacturing jobs had slowed and that "employment gains in nonmanufacturing industries have more than offset manufacturing job losses-500,000 service jobs in 1950 becoming 790,000 by 1970."
Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television-Channel 9, 8 P.M.) (Radio-WHN, 8 P.M.)
Both curious patrons of New York City Ballet and happy parents of students in its School of American Ballet mingled Wednesday afternoon at graduation performances in the Juilliard Theater.
People are watching it more but appreciating it less. That is the broad conclusion of "Television and the Public," a report by Robert T. Bower, director of the Bureau of Social Science Research.
Wholesale prices continued to increase in May at the highest peacetime rate since World War II, the Labor Department reported today.

If Clarence Marion Kelley were ever to appear in civilian clothes in a line-up with a handful of other unidentified men, the authorities would have little difficulty in spotting him for what he isa police chief-and always has been-a lawman. At least.
The talk of the day among the Yankees concerned the deals that made Sam McDowell and Pat Dobson part of them; the question of the night was where they were when the Yankees needed them.

Leroy, an amiable 36-yearold family man with a Brooklyn apartment filled with Spanish-modern furniture, proudly described himself as the United States's "biggest street scalper." No one has disputed his claim.
Francisco Aleman, a retired rear admiral, was freed today after having been held 68 days by kidnappers belonging to the leftist People's Revolutionary Army.

Many investors are disenchanted with the stock market because they feel unable to compete with the huge institutional traders that now account for the bulk of the volume on the New York Stock Exchange.
President Nixon urged his aides, both before and after the election last Nov. 7, to clear up the Watergate case and ease public doubts, according to H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff.
Governor Rockefeller signed into law today a bill that curbs some of the power of the State Urban Development Corporation, one of the Governor's pet agencies.
Department of Agriculture officials were criticized today by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for not spending authorized funds in a special food program for pregnant women and babies.

James R. Gilmore, who had been a pilot for Pan American World Airways for 33 years when he retired last year, died today at Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 60 years old and had lived here for the last several years.
A plan that would join the private security patrols of midtown skyscrapers into a nocturnal anticrime regiment and complement the police was announced yesterday.

The latest report on wholesale prices-showing a 2.1 per cent jump in May, which is 25.2 per cent at an annual rate-is a devastating blow to the Administration's contention that inflation would slow down after April and that Phase 3 was working just fine.
The New York City Health Research Council yesterday called attention to the leading contributing factor to death and disease in this city as well as the country - high blood pressure.

Parks Administrator Richard M. Clurman said that Central Park was "the greatest single asset for leisure the city has," but was in such poor shape it might need $20-million to $60-million in repairs over a fiveyear period to save it.

New agreements between the General Electric Company and two-major electrical workers unions will provide raises and cost-of-living increases that could total 88 cents an hour, or 22 per cent over 37 months, for 100,000 workers.
Alex Bail, executive vice president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, A.F.L.C.I.O., died today in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn. He was 73 yars old and lived here.

A senior spokesman for the Saigon Government denied today that South Vietnam had refused to sign any new appeal to carry out the Vietnam peace agreement that may be put forward in Paris by the United States and North Vietnam.
Government forces killed 16 Vietcong on the fifth consecutive day of fighting in the Mekong Delta, the Saigon command said today.
The United States Shoe Corporation, the Cincinnati-based shoe manufacturer, reported yesterday a decline in net and operating earnings for the quarter ended April 30.

The Metropolitan Museum's Blumenthal Patio, which is often a rather chilly-looking room with an antiseptically preserved look and which has also served as reluctant host to some altogether incompatible exhibitions,
The Voice of America may no longer carry news about the Watergate scandal based on information from unnamed sources.
