A Government official said today that a request from a representative of Prince Norodom Sihanouk for Australian help in arranging talks with President Lon Nol of Cambodia might have to await consideration by the Australian Cabinet.
American officials reassured the Philippines today of continued military and economic assistance.

Thomas F. Driscoll, a retired executive of Armour Co., the meat packers, died last night. He was 92 years old. Mr. Driscoll, who was with Armour for .47 years, was advertising manager from 1925 to 1955.

Striking gravediggers plan to expand their walkout Sunday morning - unless agreement is reached by then-to include 47 metropolitan area cemeteries, Sam Cimaglia, the union president, announced last night.

The United States cautioned its Atlantic allies today that the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact continued to pose a nuclear and non-nuclear threat to Western Europe and that the present climate of improved relations could change overnight.

Mike Ford, a Rollins College senior who was beaten in the final last year while playing with Bob Christie, demonstrated today that he may again be a top factor in the Anderson Memorial four-ball golf tournament.

NOTRE DAME, Ind.-On Jan. 18, 1961, promptly at 10:29 A.M., Sterling Green of The Associated Press said: "Thank you, Mr. President," and instantly, amidst a standing ovation from 309 journalists, Dwight David Eisenhower, thirty-fourth President of the United States, waved good-by as he concluded his 193d news conference-his last.

THERE IS A TREE MORE ANCIENT THAN EDEN: By Leon Forrest. Foreword by Ralph Ellison. 163 pages. Random House. $5.95. Leon Forrest is one of the few authors I've read who have made an art form out of being black.

Dick Siderowf, a 36year-old stockbroker from Easton, Conn., fought his way into the quarterfinals of the British Amateur golf championship today, the last of 50 United States competitors who started the title chase four days ago.

A new supper club called Alexander the Great has opened on the second floor of the restaurant on 46th Street just west of Broadway that once was Dinty Moore's, and Joseph Neal, one of the army of performers who served in the long run of "Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris," is its first attraction.
A broker and a Swiss banker were indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges that they conspired between 1965 and 1971 to buy $67-million of stock entirely on credit.
When Buddy Greco was both pianist and singer with Benny Goodman's orchestra a little more than 20 years ago, it was his work as a pianist that was more apt to catch one's attention than his singing.

A proposal to establish an interim rail-commuter service that would start in Stamford, Conn., serve parts of Westchester County and introduce rail commuting to the Co-Op City area of the Bronx is being sought by two Congressmen and the Mayor of Yonkers.
A white Rhodesian was shot dead by guerrillas on his farm last night about 70 miles north of Salisbury, his neighbors said today.
Prof. Sin-I Cheng of the aerospace and mechanical sciences department at Princeton University was granted a patent this week
The results of the games adjourned from the first three rounds of the interzonal tournament for world title aspirants closely followed predictions.

The Rutgers University board of governors today discharged an architectural firm it had hired to design a sports center because the firm had pleaded guilty to writing off political contributions as income-tax deductions.
Top law-enforcement officials of several states, including New York and Connecticut, expressed today the suspicion that the current gasoline shortage was artificial.
The Alabama Bar Association cleared Gov. George C. Wallace's brother today of charges of unethical legal conduct in connection with fees paid for processing bond issues for the State of Alabama.

Almost unnoticed in the spate of words and the flare of revelations, there was another confrontation between the legislative branch and the White House this week-the dust flew, there were jeers and cheers-and the beer ran out in the third inning.
A 15-year-old boy was fatally stabbed yesterday in the school yard of a junior high school in the northeastern Bronx aftercv what was believed to have been a dispute over his bicycle.

Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy, reasserted today his belief that broadcasters alone must determine what goes on the air, without any interference by the Government.
The space agency postponed tonight for at least 24 hours the launching of a small unmanned satellite toward an orbit around the moon.

At dusk Greeks here turn out each night for a mass promenade along the main street, past the statue of a dead hero and the ,town clock, saying hello to friends they have not seen since the walk of the night before.

Cathy Corcione of West Long Branch and Princeton University, who has been New Jersey's fastest woman swimmer for years, is back in the water at Dillion Pool at Princeton working out daily, and some days twice a day, preparing for the World University D Games in Moscow in August.

Dave Winfield scattered six lilts and pitched out of a bases-loaded ninth inning jam tonight as the University of Minnesota defeated Oklahoma, 1.0, in the opening game of the 27th Col. lege world series.

This was the big week for Seventh Avenue-the women's apparel capital of the nation-when most of the fall lines of ready-to-wear were presented to retail buyers. It was one of New York's busiest weeks too, since the garment industry is the city's largest and encompasses one out of every three manufacturing establishments here.

Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced today another large-scale, long-term business transaction with the Soviet Union-an agreement of intent to move Siberian natural gas to consumers on the West Coast of the United States.
South Vietnam has invited the International League of Red Cross Societies to visit its civilian prison camps, the Government news agency, Vietnam Press, reported today. .
A battle is shaping up in the affluent "back country" of this rich commuter town that may have an important effect on the town's development and on affluent suburbs across the country.

HIDE AWAY HILLS, Ohio-On a quiet evening, the high sheriff of my remote Ohio county knocked on my back door. With him was a deputy of the private guard service hired to patrol the secured 2,000-acre complex in which I reside with a hundred other. families.
In a rare public appearance, President Nixon visited Florida Technological University today and delivered a campaign-style speech that emphasized "what is right about this country."
The Senate approved today a farm d bill that would impose a $20,000 ceiling on subsidy payments that could go to any one farm.. TBe. present ceiling is $165,000.

The Watergate special prosecutor's office sought today to persuade the United States District Court that it should ban all radio and television coverage when two major witnesses. go before the Senate Watergate committee for questioning.
For the second time in two weeks, thousands of commuters who depend on the New Haven Division of the Penn Central were faced last night with the problem of finding other means of travel.

Rival guerrilla Unit groups held a clandestine Ford news conference today to explain their positions. The sessions represented the first attempt by guerrilla chiefs to explain their rival positions so openly after two years of kidnappings, murders and bombings.

The city high school system's best writers, artists, film makers and industrial designers were honored at a dinner at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel yesterday and awarded prizes for their winning entries in the city's first High School Arts' Festival.
Mrs. David Sanders of Plainfield, N. J., won the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 23d Uebelacker Memorial Tournament today at the Atlantic City County Club.
Major B. Coxson, a flamboyant entrepreneur and exconvict who ran second in a field of nine for Mayor of .Camden last month, was murdered in his sumptuous Cherry Hill home before dawn today.
To the Editor: I have read with interest your May 29 editorial about the Mideast oilproducing countries using their re. sources for political purposes.

The Penn Central Company asked a Federal judge today to extend a July 2 deadline calling for the Penn Central Transportation Company to come up with a plan to either reorganize or liquidate its bankrupt railroad operations.
A three-way playoff to determine the grand national champions for the NorthEastern zone will be held today and tomorrow at the New York Hilton Hotel.

Miss Harriet Walworth Pierpoint, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Powell Pierpoint of [New York and Madison, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Gerard Alford Bos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Karel Bos of Rock Hall, Md., and Manalanan. Fla.

ATHENS - Fate has reserved for Greece today the sad privilege of experiencing the essence of truth as expressed by Aeschylus-that in order to penetrate into the deeper meaning of a situation, one has to live with it and suffer. By being de. prived of our political freedoms, we came to appreciate the value of democ. racy and the meaning of human dignity. However, we pay too big a price for this knowledge.

Ron Turcotte rode six horses at Belmont Park yesterday, and he's scheduled to ride six more there today. One of his mounts today, of course, is a colt named Secretariat. But he'll be thinking of the others, too. At least he says he will.
Expectations that President Nixon will soon announce a new anti-inflation program helped the stock market make a sizable advance yesterday in moderate trading.
A barkless dog made himself heard today at the Tuxedo Park Kennel Club show in Sterling Forest when Mrs. George B. St. George found Ch. Reveille Be Sirius, a Basenji, best in a field of 1,328 dogs.
Egypt asked the Security Council today for a resolution "in basic English" plainly saying that despite her 1967 military victory Israel cannot acquire Arab territory.

Gene Shue, coach of the Baltimore Bullets of the National Basketball Association, said yesterday he was quitting his job and was negotiating with the Philadelphia 76ers, whose coach, Kevin Loughery, moved to the New Yort Nets of the American Basketball Association.
Generalissimo Francisco Franco, the leader of Spain for more than 30 years, relinquished some of his power today by naming a Premier to run the Government.

The successful emergency repair so brilliantly performed by the Skylab astronauts proves that a manned vehicle outside the earth's atmosphere is not completely helpless when unforeseen contingencies arise.
A cloudy day: do you know what that is in a town of iron-works? The sky sank down before dawn, muddy, flat, immovable. The air is thick, clammy with the breath of crowded human beings.
Spoltore, the former Mayor of Bridgeton, is Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s choice to be state Republican chairman.
Only one JocKey will ne chirping to Secretariat in today's 105th Belmont Stakes, but thousands of armchair strategists have already decided exactly how the $6.08million colt should be ridden.

An American official said tonight that Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam are expected to issue a joint communiqu6 this weekend, possibly tomorrow, on how the Vietnam cease-fire accords can be enforced.

Chako Higuchi, a five-time Japanese golf champion seeking her first victory in the United States, charged into a fourstroke lead today despite a controversial call against her in the second round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship.

A northbound Penn Central commuter express train smashed 1 into the rear of a standing i local train discharging passengers in the new Mount Vernon i station last night, killing at least one rider and injuring 75 others.

Six alleged underworld figures and the lawyer for the Trenton Patrolmen's Benevolent Association were indicted on charges involving the robbery and kidnapping of the wife of a local dentist. The lawyer, Lawrence N. Stein, was charged with aiding and abetting armed robbery, conspiracy and obstruction of justice. He was arrested and freed on a $50,000 bond backed by securities.
The coolie who hauls rice sacks for the local mill voted in the village council election here, but he does not know whom he voted for.
Top law-enforcement officials of several states, including New York and Connecticut, expressed today the suspicion that the current gasoline shortage was artificial.

Tromso University, a political creation of the Norwegian Government, is choosing 40 teenagers to become the first group of future doctors at the world's only medical school in the Arctic.
The Senate approved today a farm bill that would impose a $20,000 ceiling on subsidy payments that could go to any one farm. The present ceiling is $165,000.

A Federal district judge cleared the way here yesterday for Maurice H. Stans, President Nixon's former campaign finance chairman, to testify in Washington next Tuesday before the Senate Watergate committee.

Mrs. Anne Berry Plastrik, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmons Berry of Ridgewood, N. J., was married here yesterday evening to Joseph Bakst Zahm, son of Dr. and Mrs. William N. Zahm of New York and Moore's Mills, N. Y.
Three hundred Newspaper Guild members employed by Consumers Union ratified a new three-year contract yesterday ending a I16-day strike.

Herbert Elish, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, said yesterday that a ban on daytime taxi cruising should be instituted in midtown Manhattan this summer as part of the "drastic changes" in motor vehicles use that must be instituted here to achieve clean air standards.

The best insurance for keeping government agencies free of strikes is to provide comprehensive machinery for resolving civil service labor disputes through impartial methods, as called for by New York State's admirable Taylor Law.

Attorney General Elliott L. Richardson announced today that he was shifting to Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, authority to investigate all the ramifications of the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation with the Hartford Fire Insurance Companvy.

Dr. Alfred J. Marrow, a member of the board of trustees of Antioch College for the last three years, has submitted his resignation and in a brief letter said "the outlook [for Antioch] has grown even more pessimistic."
A fire on board a United States Air Force C-130 aircraft flying a regular liaison flight between Hanoi and Saigon injured seven people yesterday, an American Embassy spokesman said.
Dick Siderowf of Easton, Conn., putting erratically today' but driven by a dogged desire to win, moved into the final round of the British Amateur golf championship.
Castle Cooke, Inc., the big Hawaiian food-production, land-development, merchandising and manufacturIng company, named a new top banana yesterday in line with its new emphasis on that field.
The political violence of the Dominican Republic has made a sudden appearance in Washington Heights in the last two weeks, claiming at least four lives in gun battles in the streets and bars.

Chancellor Willy Brandt announced today that Premier Golda Meir had accepted his invitation to make a formal state visit to West Germany.
Despite its spacious, suburban acres and large, comfortable homes, Cherry Hill Township has been unable to escape sporadic outbursts of a big-city style of violence.

The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, in a comprehensive court challenge of the impoundment of Federal education funds by the Nixon Administration, filed today in United States District Court a suit seeking the releasee of $18-million in impounded Federal aid for the fiscal year 1973.

The Connrex Corporation, whose primary business is battery making, said yesterday it had agreed to invite a tender offer for 70 per cent of its 1.9 million shares of common stock from the Chloride Group, Ltd.,

President Hector J. Campora announced tonight a broad pact between business and labor un- 1 der which major unions would agree to abandon strikes and' collective bargaining for two years in return for moderate wage increases and price controls for kev consumer items.
The Greek Government announced plans tonight to insure the continued rule of Provisional President George Papadopoulos for at least seven more -years.

After a week of some wildly swinging prices commodity futures markets resumed a more leisurely pace yesterday, perhaps reflecting the traditional pre-weekend lethargy of summer months. Most prices showed only moderate changes.

Gov. Edwin Edwards of Louisiana, faced with a Fed. eral court order to desegregate predominantly black Grambling College and Southern University, said today that he would accept a cutoff of Federal education funds rather than "make a chocolate milk facility" out ,of the state's universities.

Whether new talent exhibitions should be confined strictly to young artists fresh from the academics, or whether the results are more satisfactory when the artists have gone through several years on the gallery circuit in New York or elsewhere -- is a debatable point. Seasoning in the field seems to account for the impressive new talents in the four exhibitions under review.
Ernest Warther, who carved intricately detailed figures from ivory, bone and wood for 60 years and became known as the "world's master carver," died today. He was 87 years old.
Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., and Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., advanced today in the $135,000 Italian open tennis championships.
The Alabama Bar Association cleared Gov. George C. Wallace's brother today of charges of unethical legal conduct in connection with fees paid for processing bond issues for the State of Alabama.
A northbound Penn Central commuter express smashed into ,the rear of a local discharging passengers at Mount Vernon last night, killing one rider and injuring 119, at least one of them critically.

Pope Paul VI, who will complete The 10th year of his pontificate on June 21, plans to open a new Vatican museum of modern art, including works by American abstractionists, a few days after that date.

Dozens of confused clashes between Government and Communist troops occurred today near Rout 4 west-southwest of Phnom Penh, with opposing soldiers so intermingled they often were unsure of where their own positions were.
Federal agents and city policemen stormed a West Side apartment just after dawn yesterday and captured a man they described as one of the leading members of the Black Liberation Army.

Top-seeded Marilyn Aschner of Holliswood, Queens, won the New York State women's ten-. nis championship today by de-' feating third-seeded Barbara Goldman of Fort Lee, N. J., 6-2, 7-5, at the Beach Point Club.

Fifth Avenue deserves to be called Filthy Avenue after a typical parade. Throughout spring and summer hardly a Sunday passes without the massive littering, not to mention congestion, that is the inevitable consequence of the city's compulsive marching.

Bert Blyleven, Minnesota's 22-year-old right-hander, won his fourth straight game and pitched his third shutout of the season last night, allowing two hits as the Twins beat the Baltimore Orioles, 2-0. Blyleven's hot streak may be due to a handkerchief and a tape recorder.

It was lunch time the other day aboard the visiting French aircraft carrier Foch, and several hundred crew members, most of them youths of 19 or 20, were lined up in the ship's cafeteria waiting for their meal of soup, pork chops, salad and French fries.

Mollie Parnis, as usual, had the last word. "When the chips are down, all a woman asks of a dress, whether she is 16 or 60, is whether she looks pretty in it," she told the audience at the opening of her fall collection.
Prime Minister Heath's governing Conservatives and the opposition Labor party emerged roughly even today in voting for 296 local-government councils in England and Wales.
The Nixon Administration has awarded four grants to finance voluntary metropolitan school desegregation and is about to approve a dozen other grants.

Bureaucratic infighting between departments of the Federal Government was so intense during the 71-day occupation of Wounded Knee, S. D., by militant Indians that a White House courier hid "security" copies of a proposed settlement for fear his mission would be blocked.

Spurred by the American Motors Corporation's highest production in 10 years, major domestic auto makers expect to reach record production levels this week, according to Automotive News.
The New York Cosmos suffered their first defeat in North American Soccer League play here tonight, a 2-1 setback by the Rochester Lancers. The game was held at Aquinas Stadium before 4,55: fans.
Funeral services for Sidney Thompson, a 37-year-old Transit Authority patrolman slain in a subway shoot-out were held yesterday in a small church in a South Bronx slum.

The United States Navy sentenced four more men today for disobeying superiors and refusing to do their duties aboard the amphibious transport ship Ogden on March 30 during a minesweeping operation off North Vietnam.

The Yankees made their debut on an all-artificial turf field tonight and discovered how beneficial it could be for their hit, ting: They socked four home runs as they whipped the Kansas City Royals, 8-1.

Speakers from northern Queens representing community groups, the School Board of District 26, Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts joined yesterday in calling for more funds for after-school centers to "keep the kids off the streets and out of trouble."

Jeff Dumansky of Leonia, N.J., seeded No. 8, led the early advancers by winning a firstround match yesterday from Pat DiBlasio of Howard Beach, Queens, 6-0, 6-0, as a field of 200 began the New York State Men's tennis championships at the North Shore Tennis .and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

The Belmont Stakes will have its 105th running today; and the race promises to be one of its most memorable renewals. Secretariat, the dynamic colt owned by the Meadow Stable, is poised to round out attainment of the Triple Crown of 3-year-old thoroughbred racing. He woni the Kentucky Derby at 11/4/4 miles, the Preakness Stakes at 1 3/16 miles and is the overwhelming favorite to sweep the triple by taking the 11/2-mile Belmont.

The television code board 'has barred commercials that frighten or exploit children or depict violence. In laying down 10 principles yesterday, the National Association of Broadcast Television Review Board also said advertisers must document all product claims.
Soviet sources said today that a hijacked plane crashed in southern Siberia two weeks ago killing all 40 persons aboard.

Maria Acierno, ~the 3/2-yearold Bronx girl who disappeared last Wednesday, was found yesterday in good condition in a vacant lot in the Bronx, five blocks from where she disappeared according to the police.
In a rare public appearance, President Nixon visited Florida Technological University today and delivered a campaign-style speech that emphasized "what is right about this country."

The Foreign Minister of South Korea, Kim Yong Shik, said today that his Government was prepared to take on North Korea at the United Nations next fall in a full debate over the destiny of this divided peninsula.
Jim Barber, who until this week had been an obscure campaigner on the pro golf tour, remained the leader today in the $150,000 Philadelphia. Classic with a 36-hole total of 132, or 12 under par.

The 1973 winter-wheat harvest, now under way in the southern Great Plains, is expected to produce a record crop of 1,315,672,000 bushels, the Agriculture Department said today.

The Senate approved today a farm bill that would impose a $20,000 ceiling on subsidy payments that could go to any one farm. The present ceiling is $165,000.

Charles Michael Sparacio, senior professor on the faculty of St. John's University School of Law and until 1970 conductor of a nationally known cram course for New York State bar examination candidates, died Tuesday at Maimonides Hospital.

Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France sought today to play down monetary differences with the United States in an effort to speed agreement on new rules for managing the world's currencies.

At the /same time, the British withdrew from the Persian Gulf and there was a dramatic build-up in Iranian military power.

John Conforti, who sued the Federal Government for $18,365,000 in damages after Federal agents tore up his house and yard in Massapequa, L. I., a year ago in a vain search for $4-million in narcotics proceeds, has agreed to accept $160,000 to drop the suit.

The Federal Reserve Board raised the discount rate today to 61/2 per cent, its highest level since 1921. The increase, from the present 6 per cent, will be effective Monday at 10 of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks, with the two others expected to follow shortly. The discount rate is the interest rate charged when commercial banks borrow from the Federal Reserve.

To the Editor: Within the last week I have seen your reports on the Indianapolis 500 motor race in the sports section. This race has been the last for 34 dead drivers. Many spectators have been injured from the countless accidents that have taken place at the Speedway.

JACQUES LIPCHITZ was born in the town of Druskieniki, in Lithuania, on Aug. 22, 1891. He died while vacationing on the island of Capri on May 26, and was buried in Jerusalem a few days later. For 60 years he had been an artist of great power and originality - one of the major sculptors of the modern era.

To the Editor: Your editorial of May 30 entitled "The President as Witness" argues that the President cannot be subpoenaed to testify before a grand jury or in a trial "because of obvious potentialities for politically motivated abuse" by prosecutors or others who may be acting irresponsibly. HOUSTON--When an astronaut steps out of his ship into the vacuum of space, he becomes a human satellite. His body, wrapped in helmet, gloves, and pressure suit, is orbiting the earth at the incredible speed of 17,000 miles an hour. And yet he appears only to be floating on an invisible sea, buoyed by Kepler's orbital laws and bobbing in obedience to Newton's action-reaction laws.

The European automobile market is one of the world's big business battlegrounds. Not only the strong national companies-West Ger-many's Volkswagen, Italy's Fiat, France's Renault and Britain's British Leyland-but also the European subsidiaries of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler are locked in competition for the European consumer. The Japanese are also making inroads.

NEWARK-After thinking about it for years, Mrs. Mary Ellen Lewis finally reached what she calls a "Christian decision" on how to dispose of her body after death: She is bequeathing her body to medical science.

MANORVILLE, L. I.-One should never burn one's back on a llama. Such a mistake can be followed by a persuasive shove from the rear, especially if one is standing in the middle of the Long Island Game Farm's new Llamaland while holding anything that looks like food in one's hand.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York has asked the State Public Service Commission to let new rates that include summer surcharges take effect pending their permanent approval. Delay of the surcharge income until late summer, the company said in a petition, would jeopardize its $3-billion construction program by limiting the stocks and bonds it could issue.

Lois Gould is owned by a summer house in the Hamptons; she has just finished her third novel. She broils not; neither does she swim. In the Hamptons, this alone may constitute a violation of local ordinances.
WHILE a carefully tended, lush green lawn, devoid of weeds and thick bluegrass, is certainly a beautiful sight, it is the natural colors and textures that stirs me to delight.
Willie Mays, the old man of the major leagues, staged a one-man Old-timers' Day before 47,800 persons at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon as the New York Mets defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4.2.

NEW BRUNSWICK - "I would like to establish New Brunswick as the cultural capital of the state, and also bring the arts back to the people of New Jersey," Clinton C. Crocker said in an interview last week.

Dereck Williamson, a newspaper editor in rural New Jersey, wrote "The Complete Book of Pitfalls." One summer day 35 years ago, a canoe rigged for sailing floated idly a few yards from the north shore of Long Island's Peconic Bay.

Beginning in a few weeks, neighborhood residents will be able to take part in policymaking workshops run by the City Planning Commission, And this week, the agency is releasing detailed and updated profiles on each of the city's 62 planning districts.

WASHINGTON -- The Senate voted 85 to 10 last week to keep Lester C. Ripley of Luverne, Minn., in business. Mr. Ripley has operated a filling station for more than 20 years, but now is afraid he will be forced to close. Like other independents-they account for one-fifth of the 220,000 filling stations in the United States-he is having difficulty lining up supplies of gasoline.

A new circuit-the Mediterranean-has been discovered by American dog fanciers. A group of 40, including a halfdozen who brought dogs, descended on San Remo, Italy; Nice, France, and Monte Carlo, Monaco, and left with wonderful memories and the major laurels.

SUMMIT--One of the most attractive new buildings to go up in northern New Jersey this year is the Summit Art Center at 68 Elm Street. Not the least of its attractions is a handsome gallery, currently graced by an extensive exhibition of abstractions by the Polish-born artist, Voy Fangor.

LINDOS, Rhodes--The village of Lindos was still a quiet, primitive place when we first encountered it 13 years ago. We were immediately won, even though our initial impression of it was all wrong. Seen from the heights of the approach, Lindos was undoubtedly beautiful, but on the "picturesque" side.

FROM beginning to end the meal was a long one. It really began last spring in New York City on the sidewalk outside an East Side Junk shop where I spotted and subsequently bought a heavy-gauge aluminum pot. It cost me $35, plus seven per cent sales tax.

As a result of complaints from a number of residents in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn that a governmentfinanced methadone clinic on Fulton Street treated more narcotics addicts than it could handle, the organization that runs the clinic is decentralizing its operations and will open a satellite center in Bushwick.

The Carnegie Corporation and the Danforth Foundation have announced $425,000 in grants to the Association of American Colleges to support a project on the status and rights of women in higher education.

The Times of London has suggested that the American press, which has played such a large role in the Watergate and related disclosures, now is publishing much prejudicial material which will make it difficult for justice to be done to President Nixon and other officials. Maybe so; but the unwarranted implication is that the newspapers ought to leave the matter to the official investigators.

WARWICK, R. I.-The day was bright, but a stiff northwesterly swept across Narragansett Bay, and Art Lavalley, my fishing host for the day, was not optimistic. "A north wind is only good in the fall," he said.

BRANCHVILLE-It's camping time again for the sixth grade. During May and June, all 500 sixth-graders in the Montclair public schools spend three days at Camp Munsey in Sussex County, seeing at first hand the things they have been studying about nature and ecology.

Raybestos-Manhattan, a rubber-products manufacturer here for the last 80 years, will cease all operations next Thursday amid widespread bitterness over what the workers call a bad deal on pensions and severance pay.

BREST, U.S.S.R.--Here on the Soviet-Polish frontier an unusual feat of engineering occurs every day: Entire trains are lifted off their carriages, car by car, and fitted with new sets of wheels to pass out of the Soviet Union into Europe.

IN 1891 a bridge was built over the Mississippi River between Muscatine, Iowa, and a point just south of Rock Island, Ill. Last April, with a new bridge already in service, the rickety old Muscatine bridge was blown up.

Federal investigators have joined the inquiry into the murder yesterday of Major B. Coxson, the flamboyant ex-convict and mayoral candidate who was found shot to death in his rented $200,000 home here yesterday.

BRUSSELS-It is an odd coincidence that the West's three leading democracies should face institutional problems at the same historic moment. While existing Governments in Britain and in France have not come under anything like the pressure facing President Nixon, certain administrative weaknesses have been exposed.

THERE are 6 million tennis players 7 million bowlers, and 12 million golfers in the United States. And each of the sports to which these millions devote themselves is occasional ly declared a "national pastime." Thai being the case, it will come as a surprise to many to learn that there are close to 20 million motorcyclists, enough to make motorcycling, far and away, our real national pastime.

PARAMUS - The $1.2million enclosure of Bergen Mall, a 57-store shopping center on Route 4 here, is proceeding on schedule for completion Aug. 15, just prior to the back-to-school shopping rush.

To the Financial Editor: The article on May 6 by David Sirota entitled "Job Enrichment: Nice but No Cure-All" does indeed just represent his point of view. I find that some statements he makes regarding the diagnosis and application of jobenrichment strategies do not check with my experience in implementing such efforts.

The irresistibly charming Delibes score for "Coppelia" is often saddled with very resistible choreographic realizations of its story. Karoly Zsedenyi, director of the Romantic Ballet Repertory Company, created one at the Fashion Institute of Technology on Friday evening.

Next Sunday ground is to be broken formally for the $780,000 restoration of Fort Greene Park and its monument to the Prison Ship Martyrs of the American Revolution. Rehabilitation of the monument and grand staircase will cost $250,000 and the restoration of the park to the original Olmsted and Vaux plan is to take another $530,000.
Charles Caldwell Watson has been appointed to succeed Archibald R. Montgomery 3d as headmaster of the Hill School, the boy's preparatory school in Pottstown Pa.

Delegates from most of the major cities bordering the Mediterranean fired the opening shots here this week in what they hope will be a war on the pollution of their sea. At the first international conference on pollution of the Mediterranean, they agreed to the "Beirut charter," which calls for urgent action to save the sea from certain death by pollution.
A department store here is selling "quake kits" in response to the increasing concern among some Japanese about predictions of another disastTous earthquake.
A Boeing 707 airliner carrying no passengers crashed into the bay while attempting to land Saturday at Rio's Galeao Airport. Authorities reported two crewmen were killed and two survived.
TRENTON - Almost a quarter of a million disadvantaged youths from New Jersey will again have an opportunity to participate in summer recreational and cultural day outings as a result of state grants.

Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho of Hanoi broke off their latest round of talks in Paris on how to strengthen the Vietnam peace accords and did not sign a draft document that was expected to be released this weekend.

TURIN, Italy -- This dusty city along the Po River is Italy's Detroit. Emotionally it throbs to the victories of its soccer team and financially and commercially it rolls along at the pace of its biggest employer, the giant Fiat auto works.

ROSLYN, L.I. - The first in a series of free art shows and concerts was held last week in the former Frick estate here as the beginning of what eventually will become the Nassau County Center for the Arts. Similar events are scheduled today and each Sunday for the remainder of the month.
The Federal Government's newest regulatory agency, the Consummer Product Safety Commission, has taken a firm pro-con latory action.
Undeterred by failures in its manned space program, the Soviet Union has been pursuing an active effort in launching a variety of instrumented spacecraft, mostly for defense intelligence purposes.
Dick Siderowf achieved something today that only 15 Americans had managed before. He won the British Amateur golf championship.

Miss Nancy Colwell Desrosier, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Wilfred Desrosier of Ho-Ho-Kus, and Jeffrey Hagstrom Stevenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Stevenson of Wyckoff, were married here this afternoon in St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church.

A survey of graduate schools at American universities has found that despite more limited opportunities for financial aid and scholarships, there was an increase of 2 per cent in graduate enrollments during the academic year just ending.

PHASE 3 of the Administration's inept economic stabilization program will reach the ripe old age of five months tomorrow-battered, floundering and ready for prompt retirement. The final examination for one course at Queensborough Community College was three days long and took place in the woods. The course, an introduction to camping out, was begun this year by the physical education department of the college in an attempt to bring its primarily urban students in touch with the natural environment.

Mark Donohue wasted no time this week in establishing the one-horse character of the 1973 Canadian-American Challenge Cup. The soft-spoken 36-year-old engineer graduate whom everyone is chasing broke his own qualifying record for sportsracing cars on the Mosport Park road course to take the pole position for the first Can-Am of the season here tomorrow.

Five months ago, following two aerial hijackings that were marked by unusual violence, the Federal Government belatedly moved to halt a long-time plague of sky piracy by ordering electronic screening of all airline passengers and searches of all carry-on luggage.

Eight men and four women have been named as Nieman Fellows in journalism to study at Harvard University for the 1973-74 academic year. Nieman fellows come to Harvard for one year to study in any area of the university they choose.

THE late Zoltan Kodaly said that music should be a refreshment and a joy. The Hungarian com poser and educator had everyone in mind when he made this statement, but he was particularly concerned about music's relationship to children. During his long life, he developed what is known as the Kodaly method of teaching, which now permeates the Hungarian schools.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I. -Voters in 28 school districts in eastern Suffolk will go to the polls on Friday to decide whether they want to spend $14,475,085 to build two centers for occupational and special education centers proposed by the Board of Cooperative Educational Services.

WASHINGTON -- President Nixon was confronted last week with new and convincing evidence of the worst peacetime inflation in the American economy since World War II, and, in agreement with several polls of public opinion, called it "the nation's number one problem." The President conferred several times with his economic advisers, but the week ended with present policies Intact and no assurance of change in the immediate future.

LOS ANGELES. On Feb. 17, Capt. Harry Jenkins stepped off a plane at the Alameda Naval Air Station, one of the first flights of returning former prisoners of war to the United States. There still are such concerts, of course, but in recent years a new variety of listener has appeared. a mutated strain that seems to enjoy music most while living on floors.

The fireflies are out and winking. You can see them almost any evening now, in city parks, in suburban back yards, and over country meadows. Entomologists call them Lampyridae, from the Greek word for a torch. They have been sparkling early summer evenings for eons, and for generations scientists have investigated them, trying to find the secret of their cold light.

The powerful, privately-sponsored Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association made public the model last week for a new southern tip to Manhattan Island. More than $5-billion has already been spent or committed to the development program, which started in 1958 and should be finished by 1980.

A group of New York Met alumni, clearly improving with age, routed a group of survivors from championship Brooklyn Dodger and New York Yankee teams, 1-0, in the annual two-inning, OldTimers Day game at Shea Stadium yesterday.

Ralph Nader, the consumer crusader, distributed 100,000 copies of a do-it-yourself handbook for would-be crusaders today. Entitled "A Public Citizen Action Manual," the 237-page book is an apparent effort to help ordinary citizen's become social activists.

EAST ORANGE--After his first full year of putting on weekly rock shows at the Capitol Theater in Passaic, 23-year-old John Scher is using the theater as the base for developing a wide-ranging, locally based music empire.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va.--For nearly 50 years, Colonial Williamsburg has been working hard at preserving its reasonably good facsimile of an 18th-century environment, so it was natural for the top executives of this great historic preservation foundation to become leaders in efforts to negotiate a fruitful marriage between the travel industry and the contemporary environment.

MONTCLAIR -- Elmer's Delicatessen, at 104 Walnut Street here, features foods from Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Greenland and Iceland. There is also a wide selection of traditional Scandinavian wooden handicraft, cookware such as Krumkake irons, Plett and Munke pans, aebleskiver (doughnut) fryers, and Disk Tdaja, an efficient, potcleaner made of straw.

WASHINGTON -- The forthcoming visit of Secretary Brezhnev gives President Nixon a unique opportunity for another important initiative in the control of nuclear weapons. Pennsylvania has its own little Watergate case, a wiretapping scandal overshadowed by its counterpart in Washington. In it criminal charges have been brought against the recently ousted state police commissioner and six other men, and a legislative investigation has begun.

Generalissimo Francisco Franco, who turned 80 last December, has been leaving the day to day running of the Spanish Government in recent years to his closest aide, Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco, 70. The era of supersonic airline travel, once expected to be flourishing by the mid-1970's, may yet arrive on schedule, but it has not been an easy passage. Two years ago Congress abandoned development of the American SST-after about $1-billion had been invested in the project-the result of bitter controversy over the aircraft's expense at a time of social needs and its possible effect on the earth's atmosphere.

Harry A. Hatry, until 1957, president of Jay-Thorpe, Inc., the women's specialty store on West 57th Street, died Friday night in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel, where he had lived for many years. He was 89 years old.

President Pompidou of France, with the backing of his top financial officials, has been pressing the United States to support the dollar in European exchange markets; the French are apparently afraid their exports will be hurt. Secretary of the Treasury Shultz has firmly but diplomatically stated that the United States intends to let the dollar move up or down in response to market forces.

The Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, one of the nation's leading health-care and medical-education complexes, announced plans yesterday for a five-year, $133-million construction and modernization program and the start of a fund drive to pay for it.

My face must have registered the repugnance I felt, for an old man in the hut took the liver from me and impaled it on a stick before handing it back.

The Columbia tennis tournament for juniors and boys is scheduled for Aug. 6 through 11 at the Columbia Tennis Center at Baker Field. Eastern Airlines will sponsor the tourney for the third straight year.

Sixteen of 18 on trial since February in Brooklyn Supreme Court on charges of taking payoffs to protect gamblers were found guilty last night by a jury that had deliberated since Wednesday. The other two officers were cleared on all five counts of the indictment.

Eight runners smashed the 4-minute barrier in the onemile run at the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships today, but it was Dave Wottle and his familiar white golf hat who flashed across the finish line first in 3 minutes 57.1 seconds.
Parliament has lifted a technical ban on wife-swapping and has eased other 19th-century laws on sex. The legislation also restricts violence on television programs, to protect minors.

Cosmetics for black women have come a long way since the days of hair straighteners and pomades. Manufacturers of beauty products have caught on to the fact that 11 per cent of their potential market is black. Samuel B. Finkel, executive vice president of Dropsie College in Philadelphia from 1947 to 1963 and a former president of the National Fed eration of Temple Brotherhoods, died at his home here yesterday. He was 85 years old.

Watching -- and thoroughly enjoying -- Noel Coward's "Nude With Violin" in a zest ful, Off Broadway revival, is plain fun. This witty, clever bundle of froth -- typical Coward -- is a welcome relief amid hot weather and grim, theatrical competition.

A sparkling Sunday and the lure of ocean breezes sent New Yorkers in full force to beaches yesterday for the first time this year. Jones Beach State Park re ported 240,000 people--8,000 short of a record crowd.
Parents have always had to live by decisions. Now one of the questions--and it's a vital one -- is going to be: Open or traditional classroom?

Mrs. Joan Tellefsen yester day eased her Dodge camper into the parking lot of Zion Lutheran Church of Staten Is land, turned off the motor, set the brake and sat back with her three children for a drivein church service.

Congress moved another step toward restoring the essential checks and balances of the American constitu tional system the other day when the House Foreign Affairs Committee voted 31 to 4 to report a measure that would require the President to terminate any mili tary action abroad in 120 days unless he receives Congressional authorization to continue.
Miss Cynthia Chambers Bishop, who is en tering her senior year at Southern Connecticut State College, was married here to day to David Vaillant Orbi son, who will be a seniorat Yale University.

The Ford Foundation's un precedented and controversial $7.7-million grant in 1963 to eight ballet organizations should now be considered a down-pay ment, according to W. McNeil Lowry, the Ford Foundation's vice president for the humanities and the arts.

For most of the 104 million Jap anese, the affluent society has arrived. They have be gun to share in the rewards of the economy after years of hard work in which the emphasis was on industrialprogress.

Crime has dropped by 42 per cent since President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law last September, according to Defense Secreteary Jaun Ponce Enrile. Mr. Enrile said yester day that the drop in crime was the result of a large-scale fire arms collection drive, which netted 523,499 guns, and the rounding up of 8,870 "criminal elements."
American B-52 bombers for the 96th day in a row joined United States tactical aircraft today in operations over Cambodia at the request of the Cambodian Government, the Pacific Military command said.

Bands blared "Sholom Aleichem" ("Peace Unto You"), and the blue and white colors of Israel were everywhere as 75,000 marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in a salute to Israel's 25th anniversary as a nation.
President Nixon plans to propose within days a new Cabinet-level Department of Energy and Natural Resources, Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton said today.
The National Consumer Congress, an outgrowth of the recent meat boycott, last week called for a weeklong na tional boycott of Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola, starting today.

William Inge, whose steady production of prize-win ning plays illuminated Broad way in the nineteen-fifties, was found dead in the garage of his home early today, apparently asuicide. He was 60 years old.

Secretariat started a two month vacation yesterday by enjoying what horsemen call "a completely lazy day" at his barn at Belmont Park. The big 3-year-old colt, who on Saturday swept to a smash ing victory in the Belmont Stakes in record time to nail down the first Triple Crown in a quarter of a century, was in retreat from the cheering and adulation that had marked his every step a day before.

In West Philadelphia the atmosphere on the streets is almost palpably tense. Gang wars are a way of life-and death. So far this year, 13 Philadelphia youngsters, sev eral in their early teens, havebeen killed in gang violence.

More than 10,000 members of the majority Hutu tribe in Burundi have fled into Tanzania in the last month ac cording to missionaries in the frontier area. The refugees speak of bru tality by troops of the ruling Tutsi tribe, which accounts for 15 per cent of the population.
A. Violette Allen, a retired lawyer who had been active in the Conservative party since its founding in 1962, was found dead on Friday in her apart ment at 215 West 75th Street.She was 73 years old.

Graham Marsh of Aus tralia scored a nine-sroke vic tory today in the individual competition, but Japanese pro golfers beat the Australian team by five strokes in a 54 hole match between the coun tires. Marsh, the 1972 and 1973 champion of the Asian golf circuit, closed with a 67 for 209. Yoshitaka Yamamoto of Japan was second at 218.
The Bank of Canada an nounced today that it had raised its bank credit rate by 1/2 per cent to 6 1/4 per cent, the third increase in two months.

To most Americans, the study of geography probably conjures up dim grade-school recollections of memorizing dreary facts about the flax production in Poland, the length of rivers in India and the location of the Torrid Zone.
Jesse Feld, actuary for the City of New York since 1961, died of a heart attack Saturday on the Split Rock golf course in the Bronx. He was 65 years old and lived at 86-15 Broadway,Elmhurst, Queens.

" Let me tell you something that we Israelis have against Moses," said Premier Golda Meir. "He took us 40 years through the desert in order to bring us to the one spot in the Middle East that has no oil."

For the first time in recent years, New York State has fallen from first place as the country's leading producer of maple syrup, as the result of a disastrously early and warm spring in the maplesugar tree belt.

The things Consumer Af fairs Commissioner Betty Furness feels have to be done are myriad -watching the utility companies more close ly, analyzing economic indi cators, finding more ways to help consumers in their daily battle with the cost of liv ing, examining how big cor porations affect people's lives, raising the level of honestyin business.
Miss Susan Ina Striar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Striar of Douglaston, Queens, was married at noon yesterday to Stewart Lee May, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry May of Rego Park,Queens.
Striking gravediggers refused to bury the dead at more ceme series yesterday as they ex tended their two-month-old walkout from three cemeteries to all 47 in the metropolitanarea.
President Nixon re turned tonight from a long weekend in Florida, where he rested in preparation for meet ings tomorrow with his chief economic and foreign affairsadvisers.

Poland, in a series of reforms aimed at uncovering and venting discontent and grievances before they explode in street violence--as in Gdansk in 1970, is testing abolition of censorship control over the press.

" We used to advise people to have their possessions re appraised about every three years. Now, with the rate of inflation as high as it is, it's a good idea to do it annually."
Fireflies darting around in your living room? It's an un likely goal, but Mildred Shul man of Luminere Creations can provide a convincing substitute in one of her Firefly Lights.

Pope Paul VI today urged Roman Catho lics throughout the world to pray for spiritual renewal and reconciliation as he opened the preparatory phase of the church's 1975 Holy Year.

Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords Jr., who on Thursday night was chair man of the huge Belmont Ball, turned from the world of the thoroughbred horse today and calmly watched the Pekingese, Ch. Dagbury of Calartha,whom she co-owns with MichaelWolf of North Babylon, L. I., win hisfourth best in show.

Secretariat will race again, probably in the $100,000 Travers at Saratoga on Aug. 18. Now, however, the home bred Meadow Stable star is enjoying a rest following a strenuous spring campaign in which he rolled to record breaking success in the 1 1/4 mile Kentucky Derby, a moot-record triumph in the 1 3/16-mile Preakness, and a quite - unbelievable record breaking score in Saturday's1 1/2-mile Belmont Stakes.

A former Florida State University reserve quarterback said today that during alleged mandatory offseason football drills at F.S.U., "everyone was so desperate to win we kicked, slugged, hit each other in the groin, did everything and anything."
What would you do if you were the head of a company and your concern was of fered a deal yielding an an nual income of $228,000 that required no investment, and practically no expenses?

Kissinger and Hanoi's chief ne gotiator, Le Duc Tho, decided to break off their talks in Paris on Saturday for a few days when "it became clear" they could not quickly resolve the last-minute reservations raised by Saigon on strengthening the Viet nam cease-fire, an Administration official said. The talks are due to resume this week after Mr. Kissinger returns to Paris fromWashington. [1:1-2.]

ITHACA, N.Y. -- Architec ture is never more clearly and purely an art than in the ' museum, a building type that has been exploding with the regularity of the housing crisis, at opposite poles of the social and cultural scene.

To the Editor: Senator Sam Ervin was stating a truism when he told John J. Caulfield that "our greatest conflicts arise when we must choose between our loyalties." The current debate raging over whether Senator Ervin's committee should con tinue his open, televised hearings represents such a choice for theAmerican people.
White-water boat racing came to Connecticut this weekend as 200 men and women battled the rapids of the upper Housatonic Riverin canoes, kayaks

WASHINGTON--The President has set the antennae of Nixon-watchers quivering by selecting Ron Ziegler to take charge of all outward appear ances, Mel Laird to call the shots on noneconomic domestic affairs, and Al Haig to be general manager of theWhite House.

The downstairs room at Jimmy's, 33 West 52d Street, which has been the scene of the weekly jazz sessions of Jazz Adventures, has gone into jazz full-time with the instal lation of Buddy Rich's big band, which will perform twice each night through Saturday.

Miss Arden Aibel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Aibel of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married here at noon yesterday to Dr. Arnold Roth stein of New York. Rabbi Arnold Belzer performed the ceremony at the Dreamwold Inn.
The first time Charlie Kemp drove his turbocharged Porsche 917-10, a bright toy acquired from Mark Donohue last November, he stuffed it into a muddy embankment in the rain at Road Atlanta.
Representatives of 53 youth oriented publications who met here this weekend seemed to agree on a new and more sedateimage of themselves.

Under a cloudless sky - a politician's best advance man -- Controller Abraham D. Beame sought out the voters in their sunny Sunday habitats yesterday and managed, in the process, to touch bases with several of the city's majorethnic groups.
WASHINGTON--Ten weeks into the Watergate siege, and the President's traditional adversaries are happilydrawing up his surrender terms.
The Yankees' 7-4 loss to the Kansas City Royals today served to point up a couple of reasons why the team isn't ready to run away from therest of the Eastern Division.

Miss Susan Trenery Hallett was married here yesterday afternoon to Nathaniel Troy Kwit Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Kwit of 470 Park Avenue. The bride is a daughter of' Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence T.Hallett of Bangor, Pa.

Miss Diana Blake Wynn and Michael Bruce Riegler were married here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Lewis Stat low performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Wynn of New York, father and stepmother of the bride, whose mother is Mrs. Karen Blake Wynn of Lewes, England.

Political murders, communal unrest and armed terrorism are afflicting Bangladesh, a nation born in violence 16 months ago. More than 2,000 killings, many of them politically mo tivated, are said to have takenplace since the war.

The com mercial banking community and financial authorities of the Western industrialized coun tries gathered in Paris last week to try to assess what's wrong with the dollar, what's wrong with the monetary system and whether anything is wrongwith world business.
The first extended drop in the state welfare rolls in more than a decade was reported by Governor Rockefeller yester day as evidence that the long cycle of "rampant" relief growth was ending.

Second-seeded Bob' Barker of Port Washington, L. I., fought back to defeat Richard Finn of White Plains, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, in the third round of the New York State men's tennis championship yesterday at the. North Shore Tennis and RacquetsClub in Bayside, Queens.

WASHINGTON-History is full of echoes, parallels and forebodings to make very good escape reading. There I was, snuggled comfortably with a memoir of the Restoration era, when out leapt a curiously timely scandal/ conspiracy that nearly toppled the English system of government in the seething seventies-the 1670's, that is.

Steel production for the week ended June 9 slipped by 1.1 per cent to 2,915,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Insti tute reported yesterday. This compared with the 2,948,000 tons poured in the holidayshortened June 2 week.

A public offering of 350,000 common shares of the Nevada Power Company at $31 a share was made yesterday by underwriters managed by White, Weld Co. The company's stock closed at32, down 5/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Sources close to President Nguyen Van Thieu said yesterday that Saigon's negotiating position would remain firm when the Paris talks on the Vietnam cease-fire were resumed today. "We are not going to yield one more inch," a high-rankingofficial said.

Local 318 of the United Rubber Workers of America became the fourth of seven locals at B. F. Goodrich plants to ratify a three-year contract agreement yesterday, thereby making. the contract effectivenationwide.
The Lukens Steel Company announced yesterday that it would raise its base prices by $5 a ton for carbon plate steels and by $10 a ton for alloy plate steels, effective Aug. 6.

The Federal Government has drafted an air-pollution-control plan for New Jersey that recommends a cut of 63 per cent in vehicular travel in the state's northern metropolitan regions to cope with a smog crisis second only to that in Los Angeles. The plan has not officially been made public yet,

Governor Rockefeller met yesterday with leaders of the criminal-justice system to emphasize that he expects a fuli summer court schedule to cut into the court backlog in advance of the toughened drug penalties that take effect in September.

Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television-Channel 9, 8 P.M.) (Radio-WHN, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland, Calif. (Radlo-WMCA, 11 P.M.).

Effective last Friday, Herbert S. Dordick resigned as New-York City's first coordinator to the Office of Telecommunica tions. Appointed by the Board of Estimate in March, 1972, Mr. Dordick was responsible for making recommendations to the board and acting as its representative in formulating and carrying out city policy with respect to cable television and the telecommunications industry.

In the last year, the Democratic party, despite losing a Presidential election, has managed to pay off more than half of its long-tenm indebtedness with some help from the Watergate scandal, according to reports filed with the General Accounting Office and made public today.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that large recent sales of American arms to Iran and other Persian Gulf countries would be a "stabiliz ing influence for peace in thisrich oil-producing area.
States cannot permit the quality of their air to deteriorate from present levels, under a decision that an equally divid ed Supreme Court affirmed today.
Ed Putnam, a catcher, singled with the bases loaded in the fifth inning tonight and gave the University of Southern California a 3-1 victory over Arizona State in the college world series.
State Senator James P. Dugan of Hudson County was named to day by. Brendan T. Byrne as his choice for state Democratic chairman.
Elie Wiesel, the author and chronicler of the Nazi holo caust, which killed six million European Jews, called last night for "an invocation of hope" to meet the challengesof today's disjointed world.

Bangaldesh, torn by economic crisis, is facing a food shortage complicated by sharp conflict among claims and growing uncertainty about the scope of the scarcities.

The bond market sagged yesterday as it contemplated the sharp 1/2-point increase in the Federal Reserve's discount rate and as it continued to nervously await official action to tighten economic controls. Wall Street appeared split as towhether Phase 4,
Communist mortar and in fantry units maintained steady pressure against Government troops along a wide front west of Phnom Penh today, and for a second day, fired rockets into the Phnom Penh airport.
Senator John C. Stennis, who was wounded in a holdup near his home last Jan. 30, underwent additional surgery today to remove a bullet and to repair abdominal wounds.

Bev Cong don, its skipper, gave New Zea land the chance for one of the great victories in cricket history today with 176 runs against England in the First Test. His performance carried New Zealand to 317 for five wickets in its second innings at the close of the fourth day, needing 162 runs to defeat England, which had 250 and 325 for eight declared.
Miss Pilar Crespi and Gabriel Echavar ria Obregon were married today in the Crespi castle of Mugnana, near Greve Chianti in Tuscany.

A fighting team from New England captured the Grand National northeastern zonal title at the New York Hilton during the week-end, and will enter the quarter-final stage of the national playoffs in Washington nextmonth. The winners,
Warren Hall, a 26-year old former Black Muslim whose testimony helped convict nine Muslims for inciting to riot, hanged himself in his jail cellyesterday.

Howard Campbell, a 7-year-old Kentucky farm boy, tackled his first black olive here today after a three-day round of adventures that included his first subway ride, his first elevator ride and his first bath in a tub brim full of water.

Patrick Gray 3d, the former acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has agreed to testify without immunity in any Watergate criminal trials about his dealings with President Nixon and other top Administration officials after the June 17, 1972, episode, sources close to the casesaid today.
The stock market settled back slightly yesterday in the slowest trading in more than eight months. There were rela tively small declines throughout the list.
Sean Kenny, the stage designer and theater architect, died today in St. Bartholomew's Hospital of astroke. His age was 43.
William Inge will be buried in Independence, Kan., his boy hoodhome where he drew inspiration for "Picnic" and otherwidely acclaimed plays.
Five hooded and silent pickets, apparently unknown to either company or union officials, temporarily halted production in the fabricating plant at the General Motors Corporation complex here today.

A Secret Service agent, one of the team that guards the two children of the late President John F. Kennedy, was arrested here yesterday after he allegedly fired his revolver during an altercation with a taxi driver.

The Securities and Exchange Commission warned all regula ted companies today that they risked penalties and possible criminal prosecution if they failed to file current and periodic reports with the agency ontime and in proper form. .

John W. Dean 3d asked a Fed-: eral judge today either to throw out a grand jury sub poena or to grant him im munity from prosecution in re turn for his testimony on the Watergate affair.

A strike by retail clerks at the Two Guys department stores widened today as workers walked off their jobs at nearly a score of additional stores, The strikers are members of the Retail Clerks International Association, AFL-CIO.

Gary Player, who recently deserted the pro golfing tour for four months to undergo surgery in South Africa, is discouraged by his recent play and said yesterday that he would return to South Africato work out his problems.

The General Services Administration confirmed reports today that $76,000 was spent on landscaping at President Nixon's house in San Clemente, Calif. The Government said the improvementswere needed for security.
WELCOME MATS The New York Philharmonic is tearing up the seats in its hall, 63d Street and Broadway (TR 4-2424), and is starting a week of rug-cut ting concerts tonight (through Sunday. all at 8.

Soybean speculators took the long side of the market yester day, pushing up the July de livery by almost $1.40 a bushel. The contract, in which there are no daily limits because of its nearness, closed at $11.55 a bushel, up from $10.17 on Friday and one of the biggestrecent jumps.

The pilot and co-pilot of a United Air Lines jet that landed at a small field used by the Coast Guard instead of at Miami International Airport, eight miles away, were grounded today. They face possible charges, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

C.-Sometime long after midnight the wind and seas picked up, the rolling of the 47-foot Martha Ellens increased, and, after striving uselessly for a half hour to return to sleep's embrace, I opened my eyes to see Capt. Eddy Haneman busily sew ing up billfish baits on the heaving afterdeck.

" Measure for Measure," which opened tonight at the American Shakespeare Theater, is the darkest and strangest of Shakespeare's romances. It is often called a "problem play," which is a fair but ineffectual description.

Dr. Alexander G. Wesman, a vice president and director of the test division of the Psycho logical Corporation, died in his sleep yesterday at his home, 84 Ralph Avenue, White Plains. He was 58 years old.
Despite nearly five years of challenges, American schools are still moving slowly to eliminate sex stereotyping inthe classroom.

JACKSON, Miss. - Gov. William Waller issued a proc lamation today declaring a statewide observance of Medgar Evers Memorial Festival Day on Tuesday, when 10 years will have passed since the assassination of the Mississippi civil rights leader.

Train service on the Penn Central's New Haven and Har lem divisions was disrupted for about 70 minutes last night when an equipment fire under a new train being tested forced officials to shut off power, arailroad spokesman said.
The leader of Libya, Col. Muammar el Qaddafi, announced tonight the nationalization of an American oil company, asserting that the time had come for the Arabs to strike at United States interests.

State Controller Arthur Levitt reported yesterday that long-term improvement in living conditions for patients at the Willowbrook State School for mental detectives would require "both a long and short-range overhaul of administrative practices and continued monitoring of progress by the Department of Mental Hygiene."

The RCA Corporation and the J. C. Penney Company, Inc., announced yesterday a preliminary agreement under which RCA would manufacture stereo equipment, television sets and possibly other electronic prod ucts that the retail chain would sell under the J. C. Penney label.

While three Yankee Quiz Kids took a side trip to Los Angeles to try and successfully field some questions on "Sports Challenge," Mike Kekich arrived here with the rest of the team today, waiting for the answer to hisfuture.

Chalk up one more spanking-new, cleverly equipped hairdressing salon for New York. In enormous orange letters, on the second-floor windows of 52 East 58th Street, Paul Mitchell is announcing his Superhair.

The Dana Corporation, a di versified concern whose sub sidiaries make power transmis sion equipment and truck frames, reported yesterday a net income of $16.7-million, or $1.24 a share, for the quarterto May 30.

The Supreme Court de clined today to review judg ments of lower Federal courts in favor of the Shell Oil Com pany in a case in which four Shell retailers in California ac used the company of antitrustviolations.

With scant ceremony and a minimum of fuss, the 3,600 members of the London Stock Exchange moved today into their new marble-walled trading floor.

The president of the Harris-Intertype Corporation told the American Newspaper Publishers Association Research Institute Monday that the United States newspaper industry was currently investing $250-million a year on newequipment.

The Treasury Department, re sponding to widespread criti cism from industry, spelled out today the relatively limited circumstances in which it wants Congress to end deferral of corporate taxes for American companies that operate overseas.
A parked helicopter in which Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany was sitting was struck by a gust of wind today and nearly pushed off the 1,200-foot mountain fortress of Masada.

Governor Rockefeller signed a bill yesterday that authorizes him to invoke mediation and binding arbitration in the cemetery strike if there is a hreat to the health and welfare of residents.

Testimony in the Albert E. Pass murder trial began here today preceded by a statement by special prosecutor, Richard A. Sprague, suggesting that per haps Mr. Pass was not the originator of the plot to slay Joseph A. Yablonski.
After three years of plans, hopes, haggling and the removal of prodigious roadblocks, New Jer sey's first health-maintenance organization is now due to open here July 1.

A sounding rocket was launched today that was expected to help scientists determine the accuracy of the Skylab space station's telescope. Cameras on board photographed a small area of the sun while the Sky lab astronauts zoomed in on the same area with their telescope. The pictures will be com pared at the end of the Skylab mission.

The Complete Works of Robert Browning With Variant Readings and Annotations, Vol. IV, general editor Roma A. King Jr. (Ohio University Press, $20). The New Tigers: The Making of a Modern Fighter Pilot, by Herbert Milloy Mason Jr. (McKay, $7.95). Revised and updated book published in 1967.
The Environmental Protection Agency ordered states today to consider the long-range air pollution im pact of proposed shopping centers, sports stadiums and other traffic-generating facilities.

In a proposal involving more than $200-million, the British owned Brown Williamson To bacco Corporation yesterday an nounced an offer to pay $23 a share for all the common stockof Gimbel Brothers, Inc.
Avery Brundage, former president of the International Olympic Committee, will marry Mariann Princess Reuss, a German princess who served as a hostess at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich.
Canada's major banks moved quickly today, in the wake of a bank rate in crease by the Bank of Canada, to raise their prime lendingrate to 7 3/4 per cent from 7 1/4.
The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court upheld State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday in his demand to see records relating to operations of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

TROMSO, Norway - Nor wegian scientists are raising and studying ptarmigans to try to find out why humans get gray hair. The color of the ptarmigan, an aggressive Arctic grouse, changes from white to brown as winter turns to spring and then reverts to white in the fall.

The trial of a suit to bar Nassau County from carrying out any plans to develop Mitchel Field that do not include the construction of low-income and middle-income housing opened in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday.
Senator Gaylord Nelson, chairman of a subcommittee investigating drug prices, charged today that the phar maceutical industry was "exploiting the American people."

The trustee liquidating Weis Securities, Inc., the New York Stock Exchange brokerage house put out of business late in May after it was charged with having fraudulently altered its books, announced yesterday that he had begun reimbursing some of the firm's customers.

Josephine Baker, fresh from her triumphs at Carne gie Hall and the Victoria Theater in Harlem, slipped quietly into Pauline Trigere's Seventh Avenue salon yes terday in a white pants suit and stole the show. It was a good show too, one of MissTrigere's best.

An acting Superior Court judge issued an order today di recting Texaco, Inc., to supply a gasoline station on the Garden State Parkway with its full quota of gasoline this month, despite the reported fuel shortage.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York asked the Federal courts here yester day to "enhance the ration ality" of their sentencing pro cedures by adopting six basicreforms.

Charles Rothenberg, a leader in the millinery industry, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Miami Beach. He was 74 years old. Mr. Rothenberg had been chairman of the executive com mittee of the Millinery Instituteof America, since 1959.
President Nguyen Van Thieu, the village cadres established as the backbone of South Viet nam's pacification program are being converted into organiz ers for Mr. Thieu's new Democracy party.

Frances Starr, an actress who scored her first Broadway tri umph as Juanita in "Rose of the Rancho," a David Belasco production that ran from 1906 to 1908, died yesterday at her home, 10 Mitchell Place. She was 92 years old and the widow of Emil C. Wetten, a Chicago lawyer.

Two thousand old people from recreation centers all over the city went to the mall at Central Park yesterday to en tertain each other with songs, dances, and puppet and art shows in a Senior Citizens Car nival sponsored by the City Department of Recreation.

Four hundred ninety-four cases of rabies in animals, most of them squnks and foxes, were reported in the United States in January and February, the United States Center for Disease Control said. This was 104.

A collection of 80 19th century paintings by 50 American artists born before 1850 titled, "The American Frontier: Images and Myths," will open on June 25 at the Whitney Museum and continue through Sept. 16. The show focuses on Westernscenes, depicting Indians,
