Bertram A. Powers, presi dent of Typographical Union 6, warned in his monthly bul letin to members yesterday that a "confrontation" with the publishers of the city's three major dailies might be necessary to achieve a satisfactory contract settlement.
Bob Purkey Jr., 18-year old son of a former major league pitcher, died from a heart defect called "athlete's sudden-death syndrome," an autopsy showed today.

At least four National Football League players, each a star, are under surveillance for traffic in illegal and dangerous drugs, according to information gathered from narcotics agents on the Federal, state and local levels.
A Soviet passenger shit sailed into New York har bor yesterday for the first time in 25 years, sounded three blasts from her horn and signaled an end to one vestige of the cold war.

The Route 280 Freeway in North Jersey will be opened to traffic on June 22, eight days ahead of the latest schedule, according to Governor Cahill. The 12-mile stretch of highway will run from East Orange in Essex County to Parsippany-Troy Hills in Morrris County. Gov ernor Cahill ordered a speed-up in work on the highway in mid-April after there were complaints about delays and meeting the previous timetable, which called for completionby Aug. 31.
Field Marshal Erich von Manstein, whose bold strategic designs carried off Germany's lightning conquest of France in 1940, died yesterday, members of his fam ily reported today. He was 85 years old.

The average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in the city rose by six-tenths of 1 per cent in the week of May 31-June 6, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday. The weekly listing, based on a survey of 150 stores, recorded a 3.9 per cent increase in the price of fresh fruits and vegetables over the week before. There were also significant increases in dairy products.

The District Attorney's office was drafting subpoenas today that it will try to serve on two former White House aides named as directors of the "plumbers squad" that has been implicated in the burglary of the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist.

Herbert L. Porter, who will be at the witness table when the Senate Watergate hearings re sume tomorrow, is expected to testify that the Nixon re-elec tion committee paid a taxi driver to photograph documents from Senator Edmund S.Muskie's Presidential campaign.
When a country has suffered dictatorial rule for decades, there is usually hope that major governmental change will restore a measure of freedom or at least lighten the repression.
The State Agriculture Depart ment said today that the New Jersey peach crop, which had one of its worst seasons ever in 1972, would rebound this year.

Crews from the Lighting Departments of the villages of Freeport and Rockville Centre, which provide their own electricity, worked yesterday to restore power to the hundreds of homes still without it as a result of Saturday night's rain and windstorm.
Eduardo Santiago of San turce, Puerto Rico scored a unanimous 10-round decision over Natalio Jiminez of the Dominican Republic before a crowd of 1,666 at the FeltForum last night.

After Henry Kissinger and Le Duc Tho broke off their second effort in Paris to restore the fractured Vietnam peace last week, an American official said that difficulties had arisen due to a "triangular argument" among the Governments of the United States, North Vietnam and South Vietnam.
When the Mikhail Lermon tov steamed into New York Harbor there was Leningrad style Rassolnik soup on the menus and cheesecake in the brochures.
Vice President Agnew declared today that the televised Senate Watergate hearings "can hardly hope to find the truth and can hardly fail to muddy the watersof justice beyond redemption."
Four of the five Borough s Presidents yesterday reaffirmed their support of City Controller Abraham D. Beame in the June 26 primary runoff for the f Democratic Mayoral nominastion.

A six-volume master plan for the development of Stewart Airport has been released by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for the "widest possible discussion" by the public. It deserves that attention.

The United States plans to re sume negotiations with North Vietnam on extending economic aid to Hanoi once agreement is reached in Paris on ways to strengthen the Vietnam cease fire accord, a high-ranking Administration official said today.

A program to end traffic congestion in midtown Man hattan by July 1 was unveiled by Mayor Lindsay yesterday. Its ultimate effect, the Mayor said, will be to drive private autos out of the central business district unless there are extremely good reasons for their being there.

ALLEN-A. Vloiette. The officers and mem hers of the New York County Committee of The Conservative Party express pro found sorrow at the passing of their es. teemed colleague and beloved friend, A. Violetie Allen, American. They extend their sincere sympathies to the bereaved members of her family.
Thirty-nine of the 420 married American prisoners of war returned from Vietnam either have gotten or are getting divorces, the Pentagon's chief medical officer reports.

Record-setting temperatures yesterday led to an 8 per cent voltage cutback for 10 million people in the New York metro politan area, to an extensive loss of water pressure in parts of the city and to the buckling of two major roadways.
Joseph N. Alviani, a Hudson County Freeholder, died, ap parently of a heart attack, Sat urday in his home here. Hewas 59 years old.
The Defense Department asked Congress today to cut the authorized personnel strength of the National Guard and armed forces Reserves by 66,044 because of a shortage of volunteers.

Greg Zorila of Briar Hall, the 1969 winner when the tournament was still held on a match-play basis, took a non-stroke lead today in the 54th annual Westchester County Gold Association amateur championship.
Mayor Lindsay proclaimed the opening of the city's Summer Festival yesterday at a party in Shubert Alley, off Broadway between 44th and 45th Streets.

Eugene Kane, 34-year-old electronics control executive allegedly shot by an employe, died yesterday at Peninsula Hospital. The police said that Mr. Kane, vice president of Amerace Esna Corporation, had been shot on May 23 by an employee who was angry over being transferred.

Bev Congdon, its skipper, gave New Zealand the chance for one of the great victories in cricket history today with 176 runs against England in the First Test: His performance carried New Zealand to 317 for five wickets in its second innings at the
Moslem members of Parliament have decided to boycott a ses sion tomorrow to force Leb anon's Premier, Dr. AminHafez, to resign.

Even President Nixon's known inclination toward hyperbole must have seemed somewhat extraordinary when he proclaimed at Florida Technological University last week: "In the whole history of the world, in all the nations of the world, there has never been a time I would rather be a graduate than in the year 1973 in the United States of America."
Britain told the Security Council today that the mission of Gunnar V. Jarring, the Secretary General's special representative for the Middle East, should be "not merely retained but be re-energized."

After 27 years or nagging, Ireland finally agreed today to grant landing rights for American commercial airplanes at Dublin. Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines have been flying only to the international airport at Shan non and passengers have hadto take a local Irish airline to Dublin.

Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, who heads the Senate Surface Transportation Committee, yesterday detailed his program for making $62.5-million of Federal funds available immediately to the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad. In an 1,800-word letter to his fellow Senators, Mr. Hartke warned that, unless Congress acted this month to provide the Penn Central with additional assistance, theoperation of its trains "can stop."

Charging that Federal grand juries have become a "rubber a stamp" for Government prosecutors, Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Pennsylvania, announced today the in production of a bill into the House to reform the Federal grand jury system.
A 23-year-old Newark woman and her male friend are being held without bail pending a hearing Friday on charges of savagely beating her 2-year-old son to death.
Thomas J. P. Craven Sr., a former White House news cameraman for United Press International, died today at the National Institutes of Health after a long illness. He was 67 years old.
Meets at 10:30 A.M. on the Middle East. GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Peace ful Uses of Outer Space, working group on direct broadcast satellites-10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

The United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn began an investigation yesterday into charges by the Lubavitcher movement that the civil rights of Hasidic Jews had been violated by the police in a clash that took place outside their synagogue at 770 Eastern Park.way on June 2.
Despite the cutbacks yesterday, Con Edison officials a maintained-as they have been maintaining for months that the supply of electricity was much better this year than in the last several years.
The first agreement for a re gional offtrack betting system tor all of Long Island was reachedd here late today in a joint meeting of the Nassauand Suffolk County Executives.
Mayor Lindsay, Controller Abraham D. Beame and the City Council majority leader, Thomas J. Cuite, met at Gracie Mansion yesterday in efforts to work out agreements on a balanced budget.
The International Business Ma chines Corporation was accused by the government Monday of "nit picking" in an effort to de lay trial of a four-year-old antitrust suit.
Qualified sources reported today that Greece's Provisional President, George Papadopoulos, planned to remove the military from the the Government and set up acivilian Cabinet.

The need for streamlined administration in all sections of the court system is highlighted by the revelation that state Supreme Court justices handling criminal cases In Manhattan at the end of last year were putting in only half of their assigned time on the bench.

Howard V. Smith, president of Caleb V. Smith Son, Inc., manufacturer of uniforms, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N. Y. He was 86 years old and lived at 27 Ridgecroft Road, Bronxville.
The president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. painted a not-too rosy picture today of New Jer sey's industrial future as he addressed 1,400 delegates at the organization's annual convention here.

A couple and their four children died of smoke inhalation here Friday in a fire that ignited in the recreation room of their two-story brick home. The victims were Norman Pinsill, 37 years old, his wife, Cheryl, 33, and their children, Laurie 4, Denise, 2, and twin boys, Dale and Jeremy, aged 1.
Volunteers in Service to America, or VISTA, is in its nintyear of existence, and in some ways the future of this Federal antipoverty program has never appeared brighter.

The Pennsylvania Jus tice Department ruled today that women may be licensed to box or wrestle in Pennsyl vania. It instructed the Depart ment of State to disregard the section of the athletic codebarring such licenses.

Members ot tile Presi dent's Council of the Big Sky place the University of Idaho one one-year probation and de layed consideration of the ap plication of Portland State University to join the conference.
Longshore union and shipping negotiators have agreed on a new contract. Pending ratification, the agreement removed the threat of a strikeon West Coast docks this year.
A trademark treaty, providing for the filing of a single interna tional application instead of many, will be signed in Viennatomorrow.
An era in South Carclina politics ended last week when 78-year-old Solomon Blatt of Barnwell announced his retirement as Speaker of the House of Representativesafter 33 years.
Despite nearly five years of challenges, American schools are still moving slowly to eli minate sex stereotyping inthe classroom.
Federal Judge Jack B. Wein stein overtook Jacob D. Fuchs berg last night to lead in the Democratic nomination forchief judge of the state.

Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, said today that Gen. Alex- t ander Haig Jr., was illegally performing top White House jobs and had compounded vio lation of Federal law by bring ing in other active duty military men to help him.

WRIGHTSVILLE BEACH, N. C.-Sometime long after midnight the wind and seas picked up, the rolling of the 47-foot Martha Ellens increased, and, after striving uselessly for a half hour to return to sleep's embrace, I opened my eyes to see Capt. Eddy Haneman busily sew ing up billfish baits on the heaving afterdeck.

The New York Mets finally scored a run last night but that was as far as the revival went because the San Francisco Giants scored two for a 2-1 victory that sent the Mets to their12th defeat in 16 starts.

Bent Larsen's string of victories snapped tonight when, in the resumption of an adjourned fourth-round game, he erred on the 81st move and had to settle for a draw with Eugenio Torre of thePhilippines.

In a new attempt to check inflation and dispel public and Congressional anxiety about rising prices, President Nixon was reported today to be preparing a package of anti-inflation measures to be announced in a television speech later this week.

A member of the City Council said yesterday that 65,000 illegal aliens were attending the city's public schools, and he demanded that school officials require parents of new pupils to furnish proof of legal residency.

Representative Herman Badillo, reiterating his theme that his opponent in the Democratic mayoral runoff, Controller Abraham D. Beame, is allied with landlords, yesterday urged the City Council to override the Mayor's veto of the maximum-base-rent law.

In a proposal involving more than $200-million, the British owned Brown Williamson To bacco Corporation yesterday an nounced an offer to pay $23 a share for all the common stockof Gimbel Brothers, Inc.

Postal inspectors of the met ropolitan region and Manhattan homicide detectives announced the arrest yesterday of the fifth member of a gang accused in a bungled mail-truck robbery on April 5 in which an armed postal guard was killed on acrowded downtown street.

The United States plans to resume negotiations with North Vietnam on extending economic aid to Hanoi once agreement is reached in Paris on ways to strengthen the Vietnam cease-fire accord, a high-ranking Administration official said today.
The United States dollar held steady today in London foreign-ex change trading. This was the only major European market to be open during the Pentecost holiday.

State universities cannot charge higher tuition to students who originally come from outside the state without giving them a chance to prove that they have become legal residents, the Supreme Court ruled today.

A representative of service station dealers suggested today that Congress break up the big, integarted oil companies to separate the crude-oil production business from the marketing of petroleum products.

President Jose Figueres or Costa Rica suggested strongly yesterday that the United States might have a long wait before Costa Rican courts ordered the extradition of Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier and one-time board chairman of a Swiss-based mutual fund organization.

Vice President Agnew declared oil today that the televised Senate tin Watergate hearings "can hardly str hope to find the truth and can esl hardly fail to muddy the watersof justice beyond redemption."
Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Gov ernmeht's weekly competi tive sale today of these shortterm securities.
Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel appealed to the world press today to permit diplomats to conduct negotiations "free from the pressures and inhibitions of publicity."
The city sweltered through the hottest June 11 on record yesterday, with a maximum reading of 95 degrees com pounded by a drastic loss ofwater pressure.
The New Jersey unemployment rate climbed above 7 per cent again in May, the State De partment of Labor and Industry reported today.
A petition in bankruptcy under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was filed yes terday in the United States Federal Court in Providence bythe Avtek Corporation.

Bob Purkey Jr., 18-year-old son of a former major league pitcher, died from a heart defect called "athlete's sudden-death syndrome," an autopsy showed today. The junior-college pitcher died early yesterday at a hos pital here, 18 days after having collapsed at a motel swimming pool.

The publisher of The Las Vegas Sun, H. M. Greenspun, began a legal battle today to prevent the Internal Revenue Service from seizing documents he has concerning the financial dealings of Howard R. Hughes, the industrialist.
Edmund Wilson's mind was so original that he probably wrote on more unpopular subjects than any other popular literarycritic in our time.

Fifteen thousand Weight Watchers and their friends or relatives celebrated the 10th anniversaryy of their organization last night at Madison Square Garden with a standing Ovation for a former Great Neck, L. I., housewife who turned big people into big business.

Lloyds Bank, Ltd., of Lon don, announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $115-million in cash for the First Western Bank and Trust Company of Los Angeles, which is 99.5 per cent-owned by World Airways, Inc.
To the Editor: It is with some distress that one reads of the possible sale by our Gov ernment of two dozen or more Phan tom jets to Saudi Arabia and of othert ypes of modern aircraft to Kuwait.
The four-day state visit of West Germany's Chancellor, Willy Brandt, which ended this afternoon, appears to have been an emotional and political watershed in Israeli-German relations.

The Federal Government has drafted an air-pollution-control plan for New Jersey that recommends a cut of 63 per cent in vehicular travel in the state's northern metropolitan regions to cope with a smog crisis second onlyto that in Los Angeles.

It takes just one, not two, to sue. Roman Gabriel, The pro football quarterback, was alone when he threw a bizarre law suit at his employers, the Los Angeles Rams, charging breach of contract and seeking $5,000 in alleged unpaid compensation. Because $5,000 is mere beer-and-wine money among the elitists of professional sports, few paid heed.

Record-setting temperatures yesterday led to an 8 per cent voltage cutback for 10 million people in the New York metropolitan area, to an extensive loss of water pressure In parts of the city and to the buckling of two major roadways.
Now that Meadow Stable's Secretariat has safely packed away thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown for 3-year-olds, another triple crown may be won next Saturday at Belmont.
Filming is under way here on a movie called "Executive Action," which deals with a conspiracy to assassinatePresident Kennedy.

Mrs. Irene Blanchard Maus, widow of William Donald Maus, former board chairman of Marsh McLennan, Inc., in surance brokers, died Sunday at the De Witt Nursing Home, 211 East 79th Street. Her age was 79, and she lived at 1165Fifth Avenue.
Reports of mysterious bur glaries of radical groups, critics of the Administration and "movement" lawyers are begining to come to light after Watergate-related revelations.
The Equitable Gas Company expects its 1973 profit to be "in the range of $4.25 to $4.35 a share," R. E. McCarthy, treasurer, said at the company's annual meeting yesterday in Pittsburgh.
The Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League an nounced the signing of Henri Richard to a two-year contract today.

Mr. Charles Colson has painted an appealing picture of a kindly President Nixon who did not press his inquiries about Watergate for fear of "making an innocent person a scapegoat," and who wanted to "reassure" his aides rather than cross-examine them.

The stifling reality of Brooklyn's Brownsville section is a world apart from the air-conditioned abstraction of the Museum of Modern Art in midtown Manhattan, but yesterday the two worlds were linked when state housing officials began work on a project in Brownsville whose full-fledged concept they then demonstrated at the museum.
A Federal judge ruled today that Howard J. Phillips was serving illegally as acting director of the Office of Economic Opportunity and enjoined him from taking further action as head of the agency.
Dmitri Shostakovich sailed into New York yesterday on his way to Evanston, Ill., where Northwestern Univer sity will award him an hon orary doctorate of fine arts on Saturday.
The New York Islanders, who needed two coaches to get through their first National Hockey League season, when they won only 12 of 78 games, hired a new one yesterday tchead the club.

The Church of England is consider ing selling its South African gold shares, a church spokesman said today. "It has always been the policy of the church to obtain the best possible return for the money put up by investors so long as this does not meet with ethical objections," the spokesman said.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation has appointed William J. Popejoy president and chief executive officer. He formerly was vice president-sales and replacesThomas Bomar,
An experimental diesel train today reached a speed of 141 miles an hour during tests in York shire, breaking a record that had stood for 34 years.
The leader of Libya, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, announced tonight the nationalization of an American oil company, asserting that the time had come for the Arabs to strike at United States interests.
The Skylab I astronauts photo graphed a menacing weather front over Texas and Oklahoma today to gather data that may help scientists better predictdevastating storms.

State Senator James M. Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, went on trial today on charges of conspiring to frame a fellow state legislator after his co-defendant, Charles Lentine of Williamstown, abruptly pleaded guilty.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday in the slowest trading in almost nine months. The Amex index closed up 0.01 at 22.58. Only 1,920,-000 shares changed hands, a low since 1,786,000 on Sept. 18, 1972.

Despite the fact that New Jersey was exporting electricity to New York today to meet a shortage there, New Jersey had power to spare, according to Eugene J. Murphy, manager of information services for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

Hilary J. Sandoval Jr., who served a rocky 22 months as director of the Small Business Administration in the first Nixon Administration, died at Sun Towers Hospital here tonight after a lengthy illness related to brain surgery he underwent in 1971 and 1972.
A delegation of 22 Chinese journalists today fulfilled its repeated desire to talk with American working men on theirjobs and in their homes.

Bob Gibson, one of major league baseball's senior citizen's (he's 37 years old), pitched a four-hitter and moved into second place on the career strike-out list as the St. Louis Cardinals scored a 12-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in RiverfrontStadium.

The United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America were named as defendants today in a Federal court suit charging the company with bias against blacks at its Fairless Hills, Pa., plant.

State Senator James M. Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, went on trial today on charges of conspiring to frame a fellow state legislator after his co-defendant, Charles Lentine of Williamstown, abruptly pleaded guilty.

Union representatives testified in a Federal Court to day that thousands of pounds of machinery and equipment were being transferred from Rhode Island Navy bases be cause of Pentagon orders for cutbacks at the bases.
Governor Rockefeller signed a bill yesterday that authorizes him to invoke mediation and binding arbitration in the cemetery strike if there is a threat to the health and welfare of residents.

Robert Taylor, a goalie for the Philadelphia Flyers, was sentenced today to 30 days in jail and fined $500 for assaulting a policeman during a brawl with fans at the Pacific Coliseum last Dec. 29. Taylor was released on his own recognizance, pending an appeal. The 28-year-old reserve goaltender was the last of seven Flyers charged after the brawl to have his case decided. Five players-Barry Ashbee, Joe Watson, Ed VanImpe, Don Saleski,

Ilie Nastase, after taking only 10 minutes to complete a semifinal victory in a carryover from yesterday, crushed Manuel Orantos of Spain, 6-1, 6-1, 6-1, to win the Italian open tennis championship today. First prize was $16,000 of the $135,000 nurse.

A special state committee set up in the wake of the 1971 Attica prison revolt reported yesterday that the state's prisons had made "some progress" since Attica, but that "change which has a fundamental impact on the day-to-day existence of the inmate population remains elusive."
Four youths carrying pistols and a rifle lined three teen agers against a wall in the South Bronx early yesterday morning g and opened fire, killing one and seriously wounding the two others.
Lord Rootes, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation's British subsidiary, said yesterday that he would retire July 1. He will be succeeded by Gilbert Hunt, managingdirector and chief executive officer.

Some 800 anti-abortionists from across the nation, de nouncing the United States Supreme Court for an "irresponsible exercise of raw judicial powers" in legalizing abortion, have voted to seek a constitutional amendment to reverse the high court decision.
The following dispatch is by the Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times, who recently completed a six-week tour of the countries of Eastern Europe.

The Supreme Court refused today to review the conviction of Justice Joseph P. Pfingst of New York Supreme Court on charges of concealing $35,600 in assets of two dairies he represented as an attorney before he became a judge.
The Health Services Administration reported yesterday that 27 food-processing establishments in the city had failed to correct first-inspection violations under the Health Code.

A man named as a Nixon campaign undercover agent in testimony before the Senate Watergate committee said today that he had infiltrated the staff of Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential candidate, at Miami Beach as a security adviser.
Trainer John Simpson Jr. announced today that he would enter Volstar Hanover in Saturday night's $100,000 Yonkers Futurity Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

Tom Gorman, the United States Davis Cup player, capped a good day for Americans today with a 6-3, 4-6, 6-4 triumph over Ismael C El-Shafei of Egypt in the second round of the $75,000 Nottingham grass-court tennis tournament, a tune-up for Wimbledon.

Western petroleum experts see a new round of leapfrogging demands by producer countries as one of the dangers in any new confrontation following Libya's nationalization of the Bunker Hunt Oil Company.
Heavy speculative liquidation depressed world sugar futures prices yesterday, a retreat following a sharp price increase recently on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

Foreign minister Krister Wickman of Sweden said today that one or two United States helicopters taking part In mineclearing in North Vietnamese waters had been blown up when mines exploded accidently.

The Consolidated Edison Company cut back its voltage yesterday as the heat wave continued, but it managed to meet a record demand for electricity because it had more generators working and was able to buy more power from outside than on Monday....
Prime Minister Gough Whitlam today rejected a suggestion that Australia mediate between Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's deposed Head of State, and President Lon Nol of Cambodia.

Organizers today announced a 13-day postponement of the Monza 500-kilometer motorcycle race, scheduled on the same track where Jarno Saarinen of Finland and Renzo Pasolini of Italy lost their lives in a crash May 20.

The United States and the Soviet Union plan to use the visit by Leonid I. Brezhnev to this country next week to announce five or six specific agreements intended to promote further cooperation between the two nations, Administration officials and Soviet diplomats said today.

The 100-year-old Park Avenue tunnel from 33d to 40th Street, which has been closed to traffic since last September, will be reopened today, according to Manuel Carballo, Acting Highways Commissioner. Eight 54-inch diameter fans, each capable of displacing 30,000 cubic feet of air a minute have been installed, a new lighting system put in, the ceiling lined with corrugated aluminum paneling and the roadway resurfaced.
Iceland formally asked the United States today for a revision of the 1951 defense treaty under which American forces are stationed at the Keflavik air base.

Carlton Fisk of Boston was the top vote-getter while Kansas City had three players among American League position leaders in early balloting for the major league All-Star Game, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.

Two members of the Lebanese Cabinet resigned today, forcing Premier Amin Hafez to ask for an indefinite adjournment of a parliamentary vote of confidence and increasing the chances that the entire Cabinet will resign.

As soon as the weather got warm, a few weeks ago, some of the soignwe, sophisticated girls who model the most glamorous clothes on Seventh Avenue began coming to work in squashy brimmed hats with their little cotton dresses or pants.
A court-martial board of three enlisted men and two officers acquitted Navy Fireman Patrick D. Chenoweth today on the charge of sabotage "in a time of war" on the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Ranger.

The city was ordered yesterday to change its written tests for applicants to the Fire Department and for promotion in the department, when a Federal judge ruled that current exam had the effect of unconstitutional discrimination against black and Hispanic candidates.

A Federal judge ordered a temporary halt today to preparations for major cutbacks at Navy bases in Rhode Island and Massachusetts. Chief Judge Raymond J. Pettine issued a 10-day restraining order in District Court to prevent further implementation of curtailment orders issued by the Pentagon April 16.
The police used clubs and water cannon today to clear a NATO bombing range here of demonstrators who had set fire to British military vehicles as a protest against excessive noise from the base.

WASHINGTON-For the last couple of years the Nixon Administration, with Vice President Agnew leading the charge, has been protesting against what it calls "instant analysis" of Presidential speeches by television commentators, and now the Columbia Broadcasting System has announced that it will abandon this practice.

Clay T. Whitehead, Director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy, said today the Administration still favored a one-year funding plan for public broadcasting despite an agreement for greater localstation autonomy reached last month.
The Soviet Union disclosed today that its main Antarctic supply ship, the Ob, became caught in ice early in April and has since been drifting helplessly off the icy continent.
New York could learn from Australia about offtrack betting, a group of American turf men agreed today after a look at how it'is done in Sydney.
Robert and Grace Pratt don't really expect to get their pension money, but, as Mrs. Pratt said, they hope "that what happened to us will help other people."

Harold P. Koenig, who resigned as chief operating officer of the Ecological Science Corporation last December, was indicted yesterday with three others on charges of conspiring to defraud creditors and stockholders of the Florida-based concern.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market rose yesterday as an increasing number of traders became convinced that some action by the Administration to control inflation was imminent.

Former State Teasurer John A. Kervick pleaded guilty in Federal Court here today to bribery charges involving an extortion conspiracy to fix a New Jersey highway contract in return for a $27,000 kickback to the Democratic party.
Southern California, seeking its fourth straight title, rallied for eight runs in the last of the ninth inning tonight and ousted Minnesota, 8-7, from the 27th College World Series.
The Copper Range Company announced yesterday that it had increased its base domestic primary copper price to 66.6 cents a pound, effective immediately.

Embedded in the third floor of the New York Public Library, a rich truffle in top soil, is the Berg Collection. With income from 'a $2-million endowment, and with gifts from friends, it grows regularly with new rare books and manuscripts.

An Arab oil expert says Arab oil-producing countries could bring the United States to the brink of a severe energy crisis within one year by merely holding production to its present levels.
Who Duzzit, Pete Fox and Last Spy are the major contenders in the $28,375 Tyro Stakes, tomorrow's feature at Monmouth Park.

A key state witness in the Yablonski murder cases said today that he had been told during the planning of the killings that W. A. Boyle, then president of the United Mine Workers, was not involved in the plot.
A spokesman for the timber industry says that supporters of the environment are selfish and that they lower the American standard of living.

The United States Attorney's office has been asked by Yonkers officials to look into the possible illegality of a private investigation initiated recently by the Democratic candidate for Mayor, John J. Morrissey, into the backgrounds of two leading figures here.
Edward H. English, a vagabond poet, jewelry maker, welfare recipient and optimist, was found dead last Friday in his home at 320 Jefferson Avenue, in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday criticized the reporting of the Watergate scandal as contributing to "intolerable breakdowns of the rule and the spirit of the law."

Mayor Lindsay's new proposals to disentangle the midtown traffic mess are in essence so sensible and so obviously needed that they immediately raise two questions: Why have such measures not been introduced years ago; will the new regulations continue to be enforced after the initial enthusiasm--and publicityhave worn off?

In the Community Church here this afternoon, Miss Gulielma Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Ashley Rogers of Old Westbury, was married to Lieut. William Edward Rosenberg, U.S.A.F., a 1973 graduate of the United States Air Force Academy and son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Rosenberg of Brookfield, Wis.
The dollar lost value in a number of quiet money markets today and some traders said the United States might have begin secret support operations.
The Securities and Exchange Commission told Congress today that it was considering the scrapping of fixed brokerage commissions "in the near future" in favor of fully competitive rates at all levels.
Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton announced today his refusal "for environmental reasons" to grant permits for the construction of a coal-fired power plant in southern Utah.

Miss Carol Minturn Collins and Livingston Ludlow Biddle 4th were married here yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More by the pastor, Msgr. James G. Wilders. A reception was held at the Colony Club.

Mrs. Walter Cooperstein, a former New York metropolitan champion, Jeannie Watson of Boston and Debbie Massey of Philadelphia scored a net best ball of partners 33, 29-62 in winning a handicap tournament today on Merion Golf Club's cast course.
Bert Marshall, defenseman for the New York Rangers, was obtained by the New York Islanders today as the first pick in the National Hockey League's annual intraleague draft.
Bond prices bounced up and down yesterday in anticipation of measures to tighten economic controls, which news accounts indicated were likely to be announced today.
A 17-year-old youth was shot and critically wounded on a South Bronx street early yesterday after he and two companions were stopped by youths who some policemen said were members of a gang.

The Senate Watergate investigation survived its first brush with the Sixth Amendment to the Constitution today, suffering little immediate damage, but the final report on this significant legal collision is not due for some time.

Fritz Kredel, an illustrator, died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 180 Pinehurst Avenue.

Anticipation by investors that President Nixon would soon disclose new economic measures to stop the inflationary spiral enabled the stock market to make a strong advance yesterday in much heavier trading.

In a rush of unusual occurrences, the Mets hit a home run, won a game and even beat Juan Marichal of the San Francisco Giants last night in Shea Stadium.
Matthew J. Troy Jr., chairman of the City Council Finance Committee, proposed yesterday that overtime be used as a means of strengthening the city's police force immediately.

The Justice Department sued yesterday to prevent Texaco, Inc., the country's largest gasoline marketer, from carrying out a deal that the Government contends would put independent gas station operators out of business.
With Communist forces increasing their pressure 13 miles west of Phnom Penh, the Cambodian Government today broadcast an appeal for calm and promised a victory in the area in a few days.

One of the 47 struck cemeteries in the metropolitan area obtained a temporary restraining order yesterday directing the 48 strikers there to return to work immediately because of the health hazard posed by unburied bodies.

From the time he walked out of Shakopee, Minn., Maury Stans was an achiever, says an admirer who worked closely with Maurice Hubert Stans when he was director of the Bureau of the Budget under President Eisenhower.

Mimi Kanarek of Hastingson-Hudson, seeded No. 3, waS upset my Mary Carillo of Douglaston, Queens, 6-1, 1-6, 7-6.

Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic gubernatorial nominee, was endorsed by the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., today and he pledged a pro-labor platform embracing workmen's compensation, job safety and security, pensions and higher employment.

The 44th edition of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show gets under way today for five days with more than 800 horses on hand and everyone wondering whether any jumper on the sprawling grounds is capable of beating Harry Gill's Idle Dice.

Its fate was sealed when nearly all the other leaders of his Christian Democratic party, including three ex-Premiers, lined up behind a resolution at the party convention for a return to the center-left governing formula, with participation by the Socialists.

A glittering array of bridge stars and social celebrities congregated at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel Monday night for the annual United Jewish Appeal charity game. The proceeds, amounting to about $25,000, will help to build a teacher's college near Tel Aviv.

The Japanese automobile industry, at the urging of the Government, has agreed to cut down on its capital investment in order to check inflation, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

The Consolidated Edison Company augmented its own capacity with electricity from Canada, New England, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware to keep ahead of a record demand that occurred between 11 A.M. and noon yesterday.

North and South Korea today opened a third round of their deadlocked political talks aimed at improving their relations and eventually reunifying the nation. A South Korean spokesman said the delegates would have Informal conversations tomorrow in hopes of narrowing differences.

The crackdown on illegal midtown parking claimed an early victim yesterday: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley. At 11 A.M., his black Mercury-license number 243 YTP-was parked on 43d Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, while Mr. Cawley was interviewed at The New York Times.

Cleaning up the polluted air and water along the Connecticut River will cost the industries and towns in the four states through which the river flows more than $1.3-billion by 1980, according to a study completed by the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York and 12 commercial banks in New England.
Simeon Golar, who has resigned as chairman of the City Housing Authority to run for City Council president, was honored last night at a dinner attended by Mayor Lindsay.

The Federal Government claimed a major environmental victory today when the chief judge of the Federal District Court in New Jersey issued a permanent injunction against any further construction of a large housing development along the inland coastal waterway in Ocean City.

One of the largest blockassociation efforts to add splashes of greenery to New York is under way on the Upper West Side, where a federation of associations has replanted 13 Broadway malls between 61st Street and 113th Street and plans to replant and landscape 17 more.
W. Stapley Wonham, a reiired executive of R. R. Shims, Wonham Co., export concern, died today in Greenwich Hospital. He was 74 years old and

President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia has offered to pay compensation to the families of two Canadian women tourists who were shot dead at Victoria Falls on the Zambezi River frontier between Zambia and Rhodesia on May 15.

A woman threw a small booklet at Pope Paul VI today as he was being carried from his regular weekly general audience on his portable throne, a witness sail. The booklet missed the Pope, hit the portable throne and fell to the floor, where it was retrieved by the plainclothes Vatican police.
A 74-year-old retired Navy Yard employee was found murdered yesterday in his Brooklyn apartment, apparently the victim of a robbery attempt.
Pof. George Vernadsky, a leading historian on Russia, died yesterday at his home. He was 85 years old.

The President's top environmental advisor sharply criticized today allegations that the nation's energy crisis is due to antipollution efforts. "This assertion is simply not true," said Russell E. Train, chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality.
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved overwhelmingly today a resolution urging a mutual suspension of underground nuclear tests by the United States and the Soviet Union.

AARONSON-Bertha Riff, beloved wife Morris. Devoted mother of Dr. Wilbur and Judith B. Cherished grandmother great-grandmother. Services Thurs., 14, 11 A.M., Riverside Memorial, and Grand Concourse, Bronx, N.Y.

The political infighting that exploded ir public today at the Senate Watergate hearings had been simmering below the surface for months. It was inevitable, according to Senators and Watergate committee staff members, that the frustrations of some of the committee's members would eventually be bared in public.

The State Investigation Commission indicated today that it would recommend legislation requiring physicians to give their patients detailed copies of bills they submit to state agencies in compensation cases.
The United States, North Vietnam, the Saigon Government and the Vietcong joined today in calling for an end of all cease-fire violations this Friday.

Bear Sterans Co. yesterday reported the corn pletion of two separate offerings involving 41,800 common shares of Lynch Communication System at 7 5/8 per share and 309,200 shares of Royal Industries at 6 5/8 per share. The former closed at 7 1/2, down 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange and the latter added 1/8 at 6 3/4 on the Big Board.
Distress sometimes makes heroes out of villains, and there's no doubt that distress has been reigning in the stock market for some time.

Police officer Thomas J. Shea was indicted in a murder charge by a Queens grand jury yesterday in the shooting of a 10-year-old boy in South Jamaica last April 28. The'officer's partner, Walter Scott, was ordered suspended, charged with "giving false answers to superiors and to members of the District Attorney's office during the investigation" of shooting.
Sharif Bishara Sirhan, 39year-old brother of the assassin of Robert F. Kennedy, was convicted in a Federal court today of writing a letter threatening Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir.
An urgent recall order has been issued by the State Board of Pharmacy, directing pharmacists to remove from sale certain shipments of saltpeter and epsom salt.
A popular feeling throughout the country is that the Watergate affair has received too much attention from newspapers, radio and television, according to the latest Gallup Poll, released yesterday.
The crackdown on illegal midtown parking claimed an early victim yesterday: Police Commissioner Donald F, Cawley.

Heavy selling and declining prices marked much of the trading in commodity markets yesterday. Observers attributed the weakness to a desire on the part of traders to sell out before the speech last night by President Nixon on inflation controls.
Chuck Rayner, who used to strap special pads over the toes of his boots, one of the many innovations of goalies, was one of five named yesterday to the Hockey Hall of Fame.

Sherman Skoinick, the freelance investigator who contends that the airliner on which Mrs. E. Howard Hunt Jr. died was sabotaged, was given a special hearing today by the National Transportation Safety Board.

Ted Cott, who was respon sible for many innovations ii radio and television in his year as a broadcaster and produced died Tuesday at St. Clare' Hospital, apparently of a hear attack. He was 55 years ol? and lived at 70 East 77t] Street.

Despite the Hanoi-Washington decision to tighten the Vietnam cease-fire, Congressional opponents of the bombing in Cambodia said today that they would continue their efforts to enact legislation cutting off funds for the air strikes.

President Nixon ordered tonight a freeze on all retail prices, including those of food, for as much as 60 days. In a nationwide television address, the President said that "prices are going up at unacceptable rates". despite the largely voluntary controls of his Phase 3 program.

Four United States players-Tom Gorman, Erick Van Dillen, Dick Stockton and Jimmy Connors - played impressively today and gained the quarterfinals of the $75,000 Nottingham grass-court tennis tournament.

Members of the City Planning Commission voiced concern yesterday over what they consider the high costs of five housing developments proposed for construction here with methods used in Operation Breakthrough,

A warship of the United States Sixth Fleet and a Soviet cargo vessel tangled anchor chains in Genoa a few days ago. Not long ago, an international incident might have ensued, with messages flashed to Washington and Moscow.
The Government today went to court against a "pyramid" sales plan involving a line of soap products that, it said, has been tricking consumers with an endless recruiting process.

WASHINGTON-If Leonid Ilyich Brezhnev were an American political leader, he would be referred to by his initials: LIB. The letters form a modish shortening of the word "liberation," and they are apt in Brezhnev's case, for he has helped spawn-if not a liberation-at least a liberalization of policy toward the West.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., reported a better than 10 per cent increase in operating income both for the three months ended April 30 and the nine months to April 30, but a $4.6-million extraordinary charge taken in the April quarter reflecting the February devaluation in the dollar caused final net income to slip from the year-ago levels.

Those who thought Americans should have done better in the track and field portion of last year's Olympic Games get a chance to assess the 1973 United States team starting tomorrow. The National Amateur Athletic Union championships open a three-day meet at Bakersfield Memorial Stadium.

In commenting yesterday on an antitrust action filed against it by the Justice Department on Tuesday, Texaco, Inc., said that its agreement with Coastal States Gas Producting Company "places no restrictions of Coastal's rights to sell to other companies."
With Tom Seaver pitching and a rookie named Ron Hodges catching in his big league debut, the New York Mets mustered enough healthy hands last night to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 3-1.

A. Sydney Herlong Jr., a Democratic member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that he would resign June 29. His departure will create the second vacancy on the S.E.C., following the resignation last month of its chairman, G. Bradford Cook.

Interstate Stores, Inc., announced yesterday that it had concluded an agreement with its bankers and other leaders to restructure its credit agreement loans totaling $69.7-million. Sol W. Cantor, chairman, said the terms of the agreement called for payments of $13.9million each on Dec. 31, 1974, and a year later, with the balance payable Dec. 31, 1976.

Following are the results of local school elections in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties. Winners in contested elections for school board seats are indicated by capital letters and asterisks indicate incumbents. Uncontested elections are not included.

The state agency dealing with drug abuse will have jurisidction over illegal users of amphetamines and other pills as well as users of heroin and similar narcotics under a bill signed into law today by Governor Rockefeller.
A federal judge ordered yesterday that a suit by Repretentative Elizabeth Holtzman to halt American combat operations in Cambodia go to trial here on June 29.

Middle-aged tennis is going on tour. Inspired by the recent victory of 55-year-old Bobby Riggs over Mrs. Margaret Court before an estimated total of 60 million television viewers, a Grand Masters Tour for players over 45, with $250,000 in prize money, was announced here yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission susended over-the-counter trading in Paragon Securities Company for 10 days beginning today. The S.E.C. said the action was taken because of "a lack of accurate public information

Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson told Justice Department employes today that uncooperative witnesses and a temporarily successful cover-up had hampered the Federal investigation of the Watergate scandal.

President Nixon has at last taken the inevitable-and right-decision in freezing prices and abandoning the "voluntary" Phase 3 program that has forced the nation to endure the worst inflationary explosion of the postwar years. Had he acted sooner, Mr. Nixon might have spared consumers months of an inflation that had begun to feed on itself, with price markups racing to keep ahead of anticipated cost increases.
Insurance premiums on 1,100,000 homeowner policies in New Jersey will be reduced by 3 per cent effective Aug. 1, Insurance Commissioner Richard C. McDonough announced today.
The State Attorney General's Office has been investigating the possibility of illegal campaign activities in connection with the Republican drive last year to retain majority control of the Assembly.

The Margaret Sanger Re search Bureau, the nation's oldest family-planning clinic, will celebrate its 50th anniversary by closing the doors of its two brownstones at 17 and 19 West 16th Street on Aug. 31. The bureau has served 250,000 patients since 1923.
Marlon Brando was in an East Side hospital last night fering from an infected right hand, less than 24 hours after he allegedly punched a freelance photographer, Ron Galella, on a Chinatown street.

The Senate Watergate Committee has secret sworn testimony indicating that Maurice H. Stans was told the full story of the bugging of Democratic party headquarters by John N. Mitchell a week after the break-in last June, sources said tonight.
Dr. Gerald F. Dederick of Hohokus, N. J., won the 13th annual Eastern Seniors Golf Association championship at Siwanoy Country Club today with a 36-hole score of 145.
The House voted today to extend the Federal debt limit temporarily after defeating attempts to attach to the bill riders that would have been sure to provoke a confrontation with the White House.
For United states Business concerns, encouraged by political detente, it is salesmanship rather than showmanship this year at the Poznan International Fair.

At the state fairgrounds here, where 10 years ago hundreds of blacks were herded into a makeshift jail because they had marched for the right to vote, a biracial crowd of 9,000 people gathered last night to honor Medgar W. Evers, the slain black leader of the civil rights movement in Mississippi.
Following is a transcript of a news conference today by Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security fairs, as recorded by The New York Times:

The fur houses, prestigious and sporty, continued their showings this week and it's a safe bet that if so many of the designs managed to look attractive to audiences wilted by 90-degree weather and paralyzed air-conditioning, the lure of fur isn't yet on the wane.

Miss Nancy Worth McCarthy and Frank E. Richardson 3d were married last Friday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building. On Sunday a religious ceremony was performed by the Rev. William McCoy at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Washington has rejected a European Economic Community contention that the United States deserves no compensation from the Common Market to make up for the adverse effects of community trade policies, a top official said today.
Although the draft is ending, registering with Selective Service is still required for 18-year-olds, but an increasing number are failing to sign up.

President Nixon ordered tonight a freeze on all retail prices, including those of food, for as much as 60 days. In a nationwide television address, the President said that "prices are going up at unacceptable rates" despite the largely voluntary controls of his Phase 3 program.

A 91-page preliminary environmental plan designed to guide the development of New York State without endangering its land, air and water was released yesterday by the Department of Environmental Conservation.
Jacques Belasco, a composer, musician and arranger, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 155 West 68th Street.

The Senate, reflecting consumer unhappiness with the energy crisis, voted today to kill, at least for now, President Nixon's nomination of Robert H. Morris, a San Francisco lawyer, to be a member of the Federal Power Commission.
The growth' in total business inventories slowed in April after strong expansion in the first quarter of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.
Laura Leonard of the home club took the lead by one shot with a 74, three over par, in the opening round of the 23d Women's Cross County Golf Association championship today at Piping Rock.

Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson said today that the Justice Department might reopen the inquiry into the Ohio National Guard confrontation at Kent State University that resulted in four student deaths during 1970 antiwar demonstrations.

Bergdorf Goodman, the Fifth Avenue specialty store, broke ground here today for is first branch store in its 73- year history. It will be a prototype for as many as four new Bergdorf stores in the New York area and New England in the next decade.

Martin Aranow, who as president of the New Jersey Tenants Organization had led one of the most effective movements in the area against rent increases, died today in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases in New York. He was 37 years old and lived at 2185 Lemoine Avenue.

The Supreme Court refused today to block, pending appeal, an order requiring the International Business Machines Corporation to turn over to the Government 1,200 documents it claims to have protected from disclosure.

Britain today announced the granting of full diplomatic recognition to the newly proclaimed Republic of Greece. This step, the first of its kind by any country since the military rulers of Greece declared the Greek monarchy abolished on June 1, was considered necessary in London on the ground that there had been a change in the form of government.
Twenty-seven restaurants, supermarkets and other food establishments are on the latest list of places charged with violations of the city's health code.

Ocean dumping of municipal and industrial wastes into the New York Bight-east of Sandy Hook - may be the least environmentally damaging means now available of disposing of the wastes, a Government expert told a Senate Commerce Subcommittee today.
President Nixon's 60-day price freeze was criticized last night by both business and labor as failing to come to grips with the nation's economic problems.

The outdoor swimming pool season begins Saturday, when the Parks Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration opens 37 pools in the five boroughs. Later this month, the agency will open 81 minipools throughout the city.

To the Editor: As a professional economist who had five years' experience in pricecontrol operations during World War II, I would like to add my two cents to the current brouhaha about next steps against inflation. The Senate Democratic Caucus has just called unanimously for a new, mandatory ninety-day wage-price freeze.

It was suggested here last week that, in line with the experience of Paris, the transfer of the Fulton Fish Market to--Hunts Point would add to the cost of fresh fish to the New York consumer and further depress the quality.

Unperturbed by occasional thunder clouds and buckets of rain, horses and riders today began the Ox Ridge Horse Show-the largest in the New York metropolitan area--in the green, understated splendor of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

David Garth, whose cinema verite style of television commercials helped put John V. Lindsay across to New York City voters, sent a crew out yesterday to film the mayoral campaign of Representative Herman Badillo.
It is our twenty-fifth Harvard reunion. Here we are, several hundred of us, meeting each other's wives and children, drinking, listening to professors again, looking to see what has happened to us.

MALE CHAUVINISM! HOW IT WORKS. By Michael Korda. 242 pages. Random House. $6.95. Perhaps it's naive of me to expect people to write reasonable books about emotionally charged subjects. But when you have to read and review two or three books each week, you do get tired of "understanding" so much personal bias.
After opening sharply higher and remaining that way until about noon, prices on the American Stock Exchange moderated late in the session and closed up 0.04 to 22.69 yesterday.
Controller Abraham D. Beame proposed an eight-point program yesterday "to solve the problem of runaway rents and deteriorating housing."
The opening game of the United States-China basketball series will be taped in Peking and telecast in prime time over a network of some 130 American stations June 27.

A convicted murderer, William J. Prater, admitting he lied at his own trial, testified today against Albert E. Pass, the man Prater says had directed a plot to kill Joseph A. Yablonski, a United Mine Workers insurgent.
Ken Holtzman, who drove the Yankees into easy submission with his near-perfect pitching the last time he faced them, was the vehicle they used to ride into first place tonight.
WRIGHTSVILLE BEACH, N. C.-Nightfall and a freshening breeze brought welcome respite from the blazing sun as we anchored some 60 miles northeast of Wrightsville Beach and prepared to bottom fish.

A witness who testified yesterday that he had suggested killing Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, a Democrat from Gloucester County, as part of a deal with State Senator James M. Turner, Republican, told the court today that he had twice threatened to kill Senator Turner.

Since January, when President Nixon disclosed in his budget message that he was requesting no funds for the Office of Economic Opportunity in the next fiscal year, the Administration has slowly been putting the agency to death. Programs have been phased out, employes fired, and money that Congress appropriated to wage war on poverty has been left unspent.
The Kuwaiti Government announced today that it was seeking a new participation agreement with foreign oil compa- n nies operating in Kuwait.

The Federal Government claimed a major environmental victory today when the chief judge of the Federal District Court in New Jersey issued a permanent injunction against any further construction of a large housing development along the inland coastal waterway in Ocean City.
Tomorrow is Flag Day and, in anticipation of the nation's bicentennial celebration in 1976, the New York Bicentennial Medal went on sale today in banks throughout the state.
The Columbia Broadcasting System television network, which a week ago said it was ending "instant analysis" of Presidential speeches, lived up to its promise last night.

John W. Lamborn, who retired in 1970 as board chairman of Lamborn Co., sugar broker with headquarters in New York, died last evening in a hospital in Vineyard Haven. He was 71 years old and had lived in Upper Montclair, N. J., before moving here.

High honor cards are always assumed to be assets in the bidding, but this assumption is not always valid in the play. Situations can arise in which a defender belatedly comes to the realization that a high honor should have been disposed of before it became an asset to the declarer.

A list of 150 policemen who are considered by their superiors to be violence-prone, extremely excitable or unstable has been turned in to the Police Commissioner by precinct commanders throughout the city, as part of a new program to weed out policemen who are apt to use unnecessary violence in the performance of their duties.

The move toward higher prices for copper and zinc accelerated yesterday. The Anaconda Sales Company, a unit of the Anaconda Company, said it had raised the price of refined copper wire bars to 65 cents a pound delivered to United States

The Costa Rican Government is being asked to extradite Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, on the basis of a secret arrest warrant issued here nearly two weeks ago by Federal Judge John M. Cannella and made public yesterday.

Philadelphia retained the Griscom Cup with 26 points in the annual Tri-City women's match-play Nassau singles at the Merion Golf Club today. New York finished second with 19 1/2 and Boston third with 17 1/2.

The Unit ed States today opened it first East-West trade center a site a few hundred yard from the colossal statue of Red Army soldier that brood over the Soviet war memorial in the heart of this city.

Faith Popcorn presented some advertising yesterday. That's nothing new for her. Being a senior vice president and co-creative director of Smith/Greenland, she' does it all the time. But yesterday the setting and the audience were unusual, the work not as polished and the temperature out of sight.
In clamping a 60-day freeze on virtually all prices, President Nixon appears to be recycling the same anti-inflation medicine he prescribed for the economy in August, 1971.

Clement B. Pollock, who retired two years ago as vice president-exploration of the American Smelting and Refining Company, died Monday in Greenwich Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 52 Fairfield Road.

Deputy Defense Secretary William t P. Clements Jr. said today that a the $85-billion defense budget may have to be increased to keep pace with Soviet weapons developments, rather than being cut as some in Congress want.

The Federal Government is working on plans to put more muscle into the six-year-old Comprehensive Health Planning programs that were set up to guide the expansion and distribution of future health services.

Bent Larsen pirated a pawn on the black side of a Ruy Lopez with Vladimir Tukmakov of the Soviet Union today and made his way safely to a pawn-ahead end game before adjourning his seventh-round game in the Interzonal Tournament.

A head varsity basketball coach with two years of experience at a Suffolk County high school receives an annual average stipend of $1,420. A head girls' basketball coach with similar experience earns $330.

SAN FRANCISCO-The great story of Watergate is not the disclosures themselves but the reaction to them. Lawless abuse of power has been a major and horrifying fact of life in America, and especially official Washington, at least since the end of World War II. Watergate has thus far exceeded earlier abuses only in the egregiousness of its blunders and the fact that it was directed against the Democratic party rather than an unpopular minority.

Of the 118 breeds registered by the American Kennel Club, in 1972, the puli rated No. 64, with 869 of them listed. A leader in keeping this little Hungarian dog in the public's eye has been Leslie Bemis, who has imported from 60 to 70 from his native Hungary.

Dr. Martin D. Davis, a psychiatrist and former treasurer of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York, died Tuesday in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, after a stroke. He was 53 years old and lived at 4430 Tibbett Avenue, the Bronx.

" Murder in America," an hour-long documentary presented Tuesday on the National Broadcasting Company network, had Fred Freed as both executive producer and writer. Not surprisingly, given Mr. Freed's impressive record in news and public affairs programing, the N.B.C.

Five people died and 20 were injured when an explosion rocked an outdoor movie theater in the Mekong Delta province of An Xuyen, the South Vietnamese command said today. A spokesman said that five of the injured were policemen.
Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis signed today a bill that eliminates the state's criminal penalties for knowingly being present where marijuana is kept.
HAND IN HANDEL Louis Zukofsky is a modern movement poet who has written many words, and starting tonight, he's harnessing a good part of them to run simultaneously with Handel's Harpsichord Pieces.

Legislation that would drastically curtail formal Presidential campaigns, including a national election in October, was approved today by the Senate Rules Committee and sent to the Senate floor for consideration.

Three Delancey Street stores on the Lower East Side and two retailers at Kennedy International Airport are among eight establishments accused of overcharging customers, Consummer Affairs Commissioner Betty Furness announced yesterday.
The White House announced that retired Maj. Gen. John C. Bennett of the Army had become chief deputy to Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's new chief of staff.

Four United States players-Tom Gorman, Erick Van Dillen, Dick Stockton and Jimmy Connors - played impressively today and gained the quarterfinals of the $75,000 Nottingham grass-court tennis tournament.
One person was indicted on four charges today involving the false listing of 32 contributors to a Salute to Ted Agnew fund-raising event held during the 1972 Presidential campaign.

Israel today directly challenged Egypt's contention that any settlement in the Middle East would have to include the establishment of a new and separate Palestinian nation.
Francis W. Fitzpatrick, a forner Government official, died yesterdayy in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 125 Carpenter Avenue.

KIKUNA, Sweden -- one midnight sun that shines for 24 hours a day now brings planeloads of tourists to this remote mining town that lies some 80 miles above the Arctic Circle. But a model system of medical care that serves the town's 35,000 residents is also acting as a magnet for many of the visitors.

Seeking a new goal with a bag of old clubs, Jack Nicklaus begins his quest for his fourth United States Open title tomorrow. A triumph at the Oakmont Country Club would give golf's Golden Bear his 14th major championship thus exceeding Bobby Jones's record of 13.

The state's claim to thousands of acres of valuable riparian land was bolstered today when the infra-red aerial photographic technique used to map portions of the state's claim was approved by a Federal agency.
President Nixon's 60-day price freeze was criticized last night by both business and labor as failing to come to grips with the nation's economic problems.
With sad irony an exceptionally fine revival of "Natural Affection," William Inge's Broadway disaster of 10 years ago, has coincided with the death of the playwrieht.

Successive observations of Kohoutek Comet, discovered by accident on March 7, indicate that late this year it will circle unusually close to the sun, producing what may be the most dramatic night sky display of the century.

Two men charged in a series of shooting deaths in Illinois in 1972, including the slaying of a wealthy suburban family, were found dead today in the Lake County Jail where they were awaiting trial. They were identified as Nathaniel Burse, 23 years old, and Edward Moran Jr., 23, both of Chicago.

Britain announced today her worst monthly loss in trade with the rest of the world in nearly three years. The Department of Trade and Industry said that during May the country suffered a foreign trade deficit of over $522-million. It was the 10th straight month that Britain's foreign trade has been in the red, and the nation's worst monthly deficit since the $554.4-million loss in August, 1970.
The United States, North Vietnam, the Saigon Government and the Vietcong joined today in calling for an end of all cease-fire violations this Friday.

Henry A. Kissinger said today that "there was one fleeting moment" before the new Vietnam cease-fire agreement was signed when "Saigon had our position, we had Hanoi's position and Hanoi had Saigon's position."

A wildcat strike by members of the Paramus Public Works Department paralyzed services including garbage pickup, road repair and cleaning up city parks. Mayor Charles Reid said 70 department employes had picketed Borough Hall to dramatize contract demands and stalled negotiations.

Jaye P. Morgan, the singer, has been cleared of marijuana possession charges on the grounds the drug had been found through an illegal search. Miss Morgan and her manager, Peter A. Donald. were arrested March 14, 1972, after an airport search turned up marijuana in their luggage.
Mrs. Ngo Ba Than, imprisoned by the South Vietnamese Government for anti-government activities; today demanded her release so that she can accept a teaching post at Columbia University in New York.

The United States, North Vietnam, the Saigon Government and the Vietcong signed an agreement in Paris calling for an end to all cease-fire violations on Friday. The 14point document, containing provisions to improve observance of the basic cease-fire agreement, reaffirmed the mutual pledge to withdraw foreign troops from Cambodia, but made no mention of American bombing there. Southern California scored four early runs to defeat Arizona State, 4-3, tonight to win its fourth consecutive college world series title. It was the second time in the series the Trojans have beaten the nation's No. 1 ranked club.

John M. Mortimer, vice pres ident for industrial relations at The New York Times, said yes terday that it had been difficult in the current round of contract talks to have productive nego tiations with Typographical Union No. 6 on "importantitems," such as automation.

A Federal judge has dis missed a suit by six West Point cadets who charged that the Cadet Honor Committee had de prived them of their constitu tional rights in finding them guilty of honor violations with out giving them the right to legal representation, to pre pare a defense or to know the nature of the evidence againstthem.

President Hector J. Campora of Argentina began an official visit to Spain today and found his political mentor, Juan D. Peron, ailing but ap parently well enough to re turn home after 18 years inexile.

Murry Bergtraum, chairman of the Board of Educa tion's finance and budget committee, has taken a sensible and humane position in opposing the mean-spirited de mand that school officials ferret out children of illegal aliens and expel them from the city's classrooms. In replying to pressures by members of the City CouncilFinance Committee, Mr. Bergtraum held that the school
Lord Melchett, a Conservative peer chosen by the former Labor Government to run the nation alized steel industry, died to day at his seaside home on theSnanish island of Majorca.

Former Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher was sentenced to two years in prison and a $10,000 fine today on an income-tax evasion charge after an hour and-15-minute plea in which he asked for "leniency" and an op portunity to put his life "back together again without beingput in an institution."
A magistrate's hear ing for Palestinian guerrillas accused of killing three diplo mats, two of them American, has been postponed the Sudanese Government said today.
An electronic system that was patented this week finds people in an office or plantwithout paging them.

The public offering of 2,895,750 common shares of the Communications Satellite Corporation at 441/2 per share yesterday was reported to be over subscribed and the books closed by Salomon Brothers, Merrill Lynch and the First Boston Cor poration. The company's stock, traded on the NewYork Stock Exchange, closed at 431/4, down 114.

At noon today, when the newly reaf firmed cease-fire was to go into effect, an army private sat at the wheel of a pickup truck in this village in the Mxkong Delta intently listen ing to the thunder of artilicry in the distance.

Corning Glass Works said yesterday that it had agreed to build and operate joint-ven ture electronics facilities in South Korea on an equal own ership basis with South Korea's Samsung group. Plans include the annual production of 2 million television tubes.
Many New Yorkers, unfor tunately, are familiar with Puerto 'Rican music only through an occasional popular strain on radio or records. The Commonwealth has a treasuretrove.

The initial public reaction to President Nixon's new price freeze and its coming successor, Phase 4, has been far more cautious, skeptical and critical than that which greeted his first freeze of Aug. 15, 1971. This time the stock market went down. The dollar weakened against most foreign currencies. Many foreigncritics said: "Too little and too late."
Efforts to reach a settlement between India,. Pakistan and Bangladesh over .three groups of political "hostages" have turned into a stalemate marked by confusion and violentrhetoric.

The Security Council voted 14 to 0 today to extend for six months the United Na tions peace-keeping force on Cyprus, which for nine years has acted to prevent renewed fighting between the island's Greek-speaking and Turkishspeaking communities.

Michael Augugliaro was lay ing the dust in his driveway with a garden hose yesterday afternoon, down the block from a park in the outlying Old Mill section of Brooklyn that has be come a maneuvering ground for hostile white and black youthson recent hot evenings.
George Burns 3d, the 1972 winner, moved into the quarterfinals of the Long Island Golf Association amateur charm pionship today at the Mill RiverClub.

To the Editor: The New York Stock Exchange and its member firms are currently being attacked by Senator Harrison A. Wil liams Jr. of New Jersey and Repre sentative John Moss of California, who plan to present bills for theoreticalreformation.

The quartet that Keith Jarrett, the jazz pianist and soprano saxophonist, is leading at the Village Vanguard this week is so strong in each of its individ ual members that the elemen tary nature of its occasional weaknesses is more startlingthan might otherwise be.
The Soviet Union, in an evident effort to demonstrate it is still com mitted to a manned space pro gram, today launched a Cos mos spacecraft with the char acteristics of a man-relatedtest mission.
Harland Reynolds of the Army and Columbus, Ga., cap tured the standard pistol event by a point today in the 13th United States internationalchampionships.
Proposals to "decriminalize" the use and possession of marijuana in New Jersey ran into solid opposition today from legis lators studying the possibility of amending the state's narcotics laws.

A difficult area that has been neglected by most au thorities is the four-three trump fit. As Alphonse Moyse Jr. used to point out regu-. larly in the Bridge World, many excellent contracts are missed by partnerships that refuse to consider the advantages of such fits.

A New Haven man writes that while he believes impeachment of the Presi dent might be an excessive reaction to the scandals known as Watergate, some lesser response is certainly called for. He proposes impoundment of thePresident.
Parma is a tidy town, a city really, with lawns so trim they could have been hand plucked and row on row of modest frame-and-brick houses that all look freshlyscrubbed.

HARTFORD - The appear ance last August of that ex traordinary book, "American Painted Furniture 1660-1880," by Dean A. Fales Jr., not only brought a wealth of fine ex amples into the marketplace and made some antiques col lectors and dealers think twice about stripping paint from vintage chairs and chests, but also resulted in a small but stellar exhibition here at the Connecticut Historical Society.

RENAISSANCE Years back, a Columbia student named Allen Ginsberg and a dropout named Jack Kerouac discussed life, art and all that stuff day in and day out at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, near 114th Street (864-8817), which made it, if not the birthplace, at least a gestation compartment forthe Beat Generation.

The 15-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today to review its poli tical, economic and military ar rangements in the light of the vast changes in the international situation in recent years.
With investors continuing to be unimpressed by the Admin istration's efforts to halt infla tion, prices fell again yester day on the American Stock Ex change and in the over-thecounter market.

The State Attorney General's investigation into a suspected vote-siphoning scheme to protect the Assembly Republican majority was reported yesterday to have reached the point of deciding whether local district attorneys should be notified for possible criminal prosecution.
Nixon Administration officials and Soviet diplomats sought to day to smooth over remaining problems in the schedule and agenda for the visit here of Leonid I. Brezhnev.

One crewman was killed and five others were rescued by nearby vessels from the Lower Bay of New York Har bor after their 94-foot toug boat capsized and sank while escorting a disabled tankerinto port.

Scores of industrial price in creases were rushed through in the days and hours imme diately preceding President Nixon's 60-day price freeze after speculation that the White House was planning to take action circulated throughthe business community.

HINSDALE, Mass. - The First Congregational Church of Hinsdale (there is no Sec ond) is buying a pipe organ, and it was a pleasure to contribute toward it. Espe cially since in return you got a supper cooked by the ladies-all you could eatfor $2.50.
