The Passaic County Prosecutor, Jo seph D. J. Gourley, announced today that a grand jury inves tigation would begin next month into an allegedly fraudu lent stock sale involving the president of the Passaic ValleyWater Commission.
Two gunmen forced their way into the home of a leader of the militant Protes tant Ulster Defense Association in Belfast today and killed hisbedridden brother-in-law.
Brooklyn-born Tommy Davis, one of baseball's "Have Bat, Will Travel" hitters, pro duced the only run as the designated hitter last night to give Baltimore a 1-0 triumph over the Texas Rangers.
The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury bills fell to 7.0268 per cent (7.1539). This week's [Pound]60-million offer of 91-day bills met applicationsof 236,895,000 pounds.
The Nastase of Rumania increased his lead in the Commercial Union Grand Prix of Tennis standings with two recent international competition victories.

John J. Kelly, a Democratic leader in New York and a pow er in Tammany Hall in the nineteen-thirties and forties, died Wednesday in NorwalkHospital. He was 88 years old.

ASAU, Western Samoa An American timber enter prise on this heavily wooded tropical island, though mod est in size by industry stand ards, is one of the most widely discussed foreign in vestments in the Southpacific.

Scattered fighting continued throughout South Vietnam yesterday after the reinforced cease-fire went into effect, but reports from the field indicated that the en counters were fewer and on a far smaller scale than those that accompanied the originalcease-fire last January.

A lawyer here says that when Richard M. Nixon acquired his San Clemente, Calif., estate in 1969, The Title Insurance and Trust Company paid the sellers $400,000 by its check and gave its $1-million promissory notefor the balance.

After eight days of debate - occasionally acrimo nious, at times evidencing a measure of goodwill-the Se curity Council today completed the first phase of its most com prehensive review of the Middle East since the 1967 war.

HONG KONG - The blond American girl, wearing loose fitting pajamas, looked some what incongruous in the Kore an street scene built on the set of the latest production of Hong Kong's Golden HarvestFilm Studios.

A local favorite, Jocelyne Bourassa, birdied the final four G holes today and finished with a five-under-par 68 to take a two-stroke lead after the first round of the $50,000 Montreal Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

The Radcliffe College eight oared shell, stroked by Char lotte Crane, sped to a three foot victory over the Vesper Boat Club in a qualifying heavyweight heat of the eighth annual national women's row ing championships today on the muddy Schuylkill River amidideal weather conditions.

The White House has confirmed that a secret list of President Nixon's pre-April 7 campaign contributors, which had been thought destroyed, has been in the possession of the President's personal secretary.
Citing "serious practical prob lems," Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a bill aimed at avert ing school bus crashes like the one that took five lives in Rockland County last year.
Silver futures contracts rose yesterday, indicating, according to observers of the market, that European speculators did not think President Nixon's price control plans would curbinflation.
Grania O'Malley, a dramatic actress known for her Irish roles, died Thursday at Poly clinic Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 325 West45th Street.

Faced with its first schism since its founding more than a century ago, the general as sembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S. (Southern), adopted this week a policy of firm but restrained resistance to dissident elements within itsranks.
The appointment of Dr. Rob ert W. Berliner, deputy di rector for science of the Na tional Institutes of Health, as dean of the Yale School of Medicine was announcedtoday.

The Penn Central Railroad said today that it was immedi ately reducing the frequency of freight service in the New Eng land area in an effort to con serve fuel. A Penn Central spokesman said the amount of traffic would not be cut back, only the number of days a weektrains will run.

It usually happens in the first round. E. Z. Shank from Big Slice, Okla., shoots a 65 for the early lead in the United States Open golf cham pionship, then disappears in the rough somewhere. But, today it happened in the second round. Gene Borek shot a six-under-par 65, a competitive record for the ominous Oakmont Country Club, and the headlines in most newspapers will refer to him as an unknown.

WASHINGTON, June 15--Scientists have found that the woman who uses birth control pills is likely to have slightly higher blood pressure, a higher pulse rate and somewhat more acute hearing than the woman who does not use the pill.

Another triple crown climax will be on the program at Bel mont Park today with the run ning of the Coaching Club American Oaks. This 1l/2-mile test is the third part of the triple crown for fillies, and hasattracted a field of 13.

George Hearing received today a maximum one-year prison sentence on charges of distributing a fake letter in Florida in the Presidentialcampaign of 1972.
The Government today appointed Takeshi Yasukawa, counselor' of the Foreign Ministry, to suc ceed Naruhiko Ushiba as Japa nese Ambassador to the UnitedStates.

The California Angels scored a run off Mel Stottlemyre tonight the first in two years, but they fell short of beating him for the first time in six years when the Yankees won 4-3, on Felipe Alou's run-scoring fly in the10th inning.

Dorothy Carew, who was the first woman journalist to be come a financial writer for The Associated Press, died Thursday of cancer at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 63 years old and in recent years had lived in Washington.

The International Skating Union Congress voted today to prohibit speed and figure skaters from displaying commercial brand names during international championships and the Olympic Games, and to take the frills out of figure-skating costumes. The delegates adopted a proposal that dresses must be "simple, modest and dignified, and not showcostumes."

Brig. Gen. Richard Malcolm Cutts, U.S.M.C., retired, whose 23-year military career encom passed inventing, serving in the White House and battle field combat, died yesterday at Bethesda Naval Hospital. Hewas 70 years old.
The cheering, predominantly youthful audience that greeted the first of the New York Phil harmonic's "Rug Concerts" on Tuesday night was not an isolated phenomenon.

Gene Shue, who says he likes challenges and believes in hard work, assured him self of both yesterday when he signed a two-year contract to coach the Philadelphia76ers.
The Manhattan District At torney's office said yesterday that it might present to a grand jury the case of a Black Muslim newspaper seller who usedkarate to injure six policemen.

Benguet Consolidated, Inc.,' reported yesterday that first quarter net income rose to $4.5 million, or 21 cents a share, on revenues of $24.4-million. This compared with restated earn ings of $2.6-million, or 12 cents a share, on revenues of $24 million in the comparable 1972quarter.

The Federal Government yes terday approved New York's stringent traffic-control pro gram, which is designed to meet clean-air standards through such measures as bans on taxi cruising in midtown Manhat tan, restrictions on parking and tolls on East River bridges to cut traffic in the heart of thecity by 50 per cent.

Angelo Bevacqua, the Hudson County Road Supervisor, was indicted today for allegedly having public records altered to conceal the fact that public employes and equipment had been used illegally to fulfill a private contract with a countyagency.

Twenty-five students and faculty members from Staten Island Community College and two members of the city's Board of Higher Edu cation will spend three weeks traveling and studying inChina this summer.

The struggle over member ship restrictions at the New York Stock Exchange has turned out to be one of the monumental conflicts in WallStreet history.
Folke Rogard, former pres ident of the World Chess Fed eration, died Monday. He was73 years old.

One record was set in the weight-lifting competition yes terday as the 17th annual Na tional Wheelchair Games got under way at the Henshel Gym nasium of the Bulova School of Watchmaking, in Woodside,Queens.

Authorities said yesterdays that a third suspect had been captured in connection with the shooting of Police Officer Rob ert Laurenson, who was slain while off duty in a West Sidebar on June 3.

A former staff member of the state Liberal party recount ed yesterday how he and other members worked out of the office of a Republican Assem blyman on Long Island to make calls on behalf of a Liberal candidate in an unsuccessful attempt to help the Republicandefeat his Democratic opponent.
A Los Angeles Superior Court judge levied a $1.85 million judgment against a soap distributor today for vio lation of state laws restrictingso-called "pyramid" sales.
Jonas Aistis, a Lithuanian poet and essayist, died Wednesday of abdominal cancer at the George Washington University Hospital here. He was 65 yearsold.
Federal regulatory agencies advised airlines, railroads, truckers, bus lines and tele phone and telegraph companies yesterday that President Nixon's 60-day price freeze applied totheir rates.
Investors' disappointment over President Nixon's new eco nomic program sent the stock market down sharply yesterday in lighter trading.
H. R. Haldeman's attorney denied today that the former White House chief of staff had learned of the Watergate cover-up plot in January at a meeting withJeb Stuart Magruder.

The House passed and sent to the Senate today a multi billion-dollar appropriation bill that includes a $20,000 ceiling that any one grower of cotton, wheat or feed grains can receive as a farm subsidy.

Leonid I. Brezhnev arrives in this country today. Gen eral Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, he is to all appearances the most powerful single individual in the Soviet Union, the contemporary successor of Lenin, Stalin, Malenkov and Khrushchev. His arrival is a sign of the very substantial thaw in the cold war, a thaw that has progressed with gratifying rapidity since President Nixon's visit to Moscow last year.

At a secret City Hall meeting yesterday, Mayor Lindsay accepted Controller Abraham D. Beame's budget package, which is expected to reduce "substantially" the proposed property tax increase and provide funds for 3,000 new policemen.
Two policemen in the village of Malika near here spotted a theft suspect this week and gave chase.
Missions are to go to six areas in the Pacific in an attempt to collect the remains of Japanese killed in World War II, the Welfare Ministry has announced here.

THE threat of gasoline shortages continues to confront motorists like a slow-blinking yellow caution light, but severe Inconvenience for travelers this summer appears unlikely. The American Automobile Association, which makes weekly surveys of gasoline stations throughout the country, has reported that only a small percentage are rationing fuel and it says that shortages will probably be encountered "only in occasional local instances" in the Southeast and Northwest.

A plaque was dedicated here today at the birthplace of Henry J. Raymond, who founded The New York Times in 1851 and was its first editor, in a ceremony attended by officials of the newspaper and local civic leaders. Mr. Raymond was born in 1820.
Col. James L. Lamar took his 16-year-old son to a baseball game for the first time last night, and few such outings have ever been so fervently anticipated or so genuinely appreciated.
The country's newest new town will be a product of the space age. The General Electric company announced today that its re-entry and environmental systems division, based here.

Hundreds of Jewish dead were buried in cemeteries in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island last week despite the strike by gravediggers in the metropolitan area, now going into its second week.

More than 20,000 members of the Hutu tribe of the tiny Central African nation of Burundi who have fled to Tanzania in the last month are painting a grim picture of slaughter taking place in the southern part of Burundi.

The engagement of Miss Darlene Meryl Diamond to Samuel K. Kleiner, son of Mrs. Sidney Kleiner of New York and the late Mr. Kleiner, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. J. George Diamond of Plainfield.

John W. Dean 3d has told Government investigators that a high White House aide informed him early last January that the orders for the burglary of files belonging to Dr. Daniel Elisberg's former psychiatrist came "from the oval office" of President Nixon, sources close to the Watergate case said today.
People educated in mixed schools are more likely to have happy marriages than those from single-sex schools, according to the results of a survey in a Government-backed publication.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I.--In an effort to end what was described as the "honky-tonk" atmosphere that surrounds many of the gasoline stations in the Town of Hempstead, a committee that has been studying the problem for the last 18 months proposed last week a new law that would enable the town to order the demolition of some stations and block the construction of others.

A proposal to build a super port and oil refining complex capable of transshipping a million barrels of crude oil daily to United States ports and refining 600,000 more barrels has run into opposition from environmentalists and pro-independence groups here.

More than 115,000 tourists a year troop past a portrait of Betty Crocker on their way to visit her kitchens at General Mills headquarters. With her chestnut hair and red suit, Betty bears more than a vague resemblance to Mercedes Bates, a vice president and the company's only female operating officer.

PERHAPS no one can make the American dream seem deader than he who dreams it still. John Wayne, the Duke, dean of patriotic action flicks, turns out to be their biggest casualty: even now, at this point in history, he continues to believe-a faith that he has now committed to vinyl in America, Why I Love Her (RCA LSP-4828).

HOW fast times move. It seems only yesterday that the newer forces of moderndance, Paul Taylor, Alvin Alley, Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis, were moving forward to join the Martha Graham and Jose Lim6n companies as a new moderndance establishment.

Antioch College seniors and their parents gathered on the campus this morning for an informal graduation ceremony but the bitterness associated with a 45-day student strike that ended June 6 was not forgotten.

NEWARK - The Newark Boys Chorus is scheduled to leave today for Rome, where, together with Leonard Bernstein, it will appear next Saturday in a special performance for Pope Paul VI.

The Watergate case has broadened from a rivulet to a riptide, leaving serious political, governmental and constitutional issues bobbing in its wake.
Soldiers have been assigned to help Jamaica's hardpressed policemen combat a wave of robberies and other crimes by gangs of gunmen. Last week 10 persons were shot, six fatally.
The marriage of Miss Jane Rebecca Hammond, to Alfred Hoyt Corbett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Corbett of Washington and Portland, Ore., took place here this afternoon.
Holmesburg Prison, where the warden and deputy warden were stabbed to death two weeks ago by inmates jailed for earlier police killings, is losing 235 of its most troublesome prisoners.

SEWAREN - Mrs. Fred Klopsch is facing a gasoline shortage, and she is quite happy about it. A year ago, Mrs. Klopsch could draw, from a well drilled in the yard beside her home at 76 Holton Street, gasoline pure enough to run her lawn mower.

This tiny central Idaho community, little more than a collection of summer homes, motels and service stations set around a 50-year-old post office, has suddenly found itself facing possible extinction.

To the Editor: In his May 20 Traveler's World column, entitled "A New Legal Umbrella for Tourists?," Paul J. C. Friedlander reported on the case in which Mrs. Helen Buchholtz of Bayside, Queens, won . her "negligence" suit against Sirotkin Travel, Ltd., and was awarded a partial refund of the cost of a threeday weekend in Las Vegas.
To almost everyone at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, tomorrow's Boyden International Grand Prix for jumpers, the final- event of the five-day horse show, is the most important equine happening of the year.

Dr. F. Leroy Foster, director of Lowell Institute at Massachusetts Institute Technology for 14 years, will retire June 30. He will be succeeded by Dr. Bruce D. Wedlock, a former faculty member in the department of electrical engineering.

Overcast skies and 12-to-15knot winds provided perfect conditions as the Annapolis, Md., Newport, R. I., yacht race got under way today.

THE BLACK PRINCE, by Iris Murdoch. (Viking, $7.95.) Fifty-eightyear-old Bradley Pearson tries to cut himself off to write the big novel that is in him and finds that he is inundated by life and eros; it all adds up to a major new Murdoch.

A showdown is finally approaching on how to deal with tennis players guilty of unsportsmanlike conduct. Among the rule changes to be proposed by the United States Lawn Tennis Association at the annual meeting of the International Lawn Tennis Federation in Warsaw July 11, is one that would allow the umpire to penalize a player one or two points any time he commits an offense. or to disqualify him.

If political tyranny ever comes to America, it is likely to arrive not in the guise of some alien ideology such such as Communism or Nazism but as a uniquely American way of preserving this country's traditional values. Instead of tyranny being the dramatic culmination of radical protest and revolution, it can come silently, slowly, like fog creeping in "on little cat feet."

Emmet Kay, a civilian pilot working in Laos for a concern on contract with the Central Intelligence Agency, has become the first confirmed American prisoner of the Communists since the January agreement on ending the war in Vietnam.
In the world's great tropical jungles, appearances can be deceptive. The vast and luxuriant vegetation is "a facade, an outward magnificence cloaking the poverty beneath."
A suspected prowler fatally shot a police sergeant and a 4-year-old girl hostage today, and then was critically wounded by policemen as he emerged from a house where he held two other persons.
The Thai Government has requested that U Nu, the former Burmese Premier who has been living here in political asylum, leave the country early next month, the Thailand radio reported'.
ROME, N.Y. - Zbigniew L. Pankowicz, who came to this country from Poland in 1950, speaks English with the exquisite correctness only a non-native can muster.
The Jersey Shore Tennis Classic, third stop on this summer's Virginia Slims Circuit, has been scheduled for the Allaire Racquet Club, Aug. 13-19.

A State Liquor Authority Commissioner, a Manhattan Democratic district leader and a businessman recalled with enthusiasm yesterday how they had chased, grappled with and captured two suspects in a doorway mugging Friday night in Washington Heights.
WASHINGTON-There was one thing worrying Soviet correspondents in Washington in advance of Leonid Brezhnev's arrival.

Jacob D. Fuchsberg has achieved an apparent victory in the Democratic primary for chief judge of the state without the help of any of the assets that traditionally have been considered mandatory for successful judicial contests.
Shea Stadium was a glorious playland for the Mets and 24,452 of their fans last night as they went on an offensive orgy and routed the hapless San Diego Padres, 10-2.
A law authorizing voluntary retirement of Federal employes From agencies undergoing major personnel cutbacks was signed Wednesday by President Nixon.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and its four major unions reached a tentative agreement on a new 37-month contract today, averting a strike by 68,000 workers. The old contract expired one week ago but had been extended on a day-to-day basis as negotiations continued.

Hotel rooms are at a premium in Eastern Europe this summer. American businessmen, excited by visions of vast markets once beyond their reach, are crowding Moscow, Warsaw, Bucharest and other capitals behind an Iron Curtain that appears to be rusting rapidly.

BRUSSELS-The White House decision to call this "The Year of Europe" for American foreign policy is unfortunate. The slogan implies the "Europe" everyone talks about but which doesn't really exist-a community of Common Market nations with some semblance of unified administration. It also implies that major improvements in relationships between the United States and this community can be accomplished in 1973-not likely.
Vandalism, muggings and "mindless aggression toward property and persons" rose substantially in England and Wales during 1972, the Home Office said this week.

Capt. Joe Tacker of Honolulu, who has been flying planes for the Hawaiian Airlines for 23 years, is a man accustomed to making fast decisions. Be that as it may, I feel certain that "The Visionary Girls" will need no favorable predisposition in order for it to enthrall readers.

This is an important book on an important subject. Since the early 1960's the New Left historians have caused a great stir. Almost no period or aspect of the American past has escaped their attention, and none has received more than the origins of the cold war.

Foreign Minister, Tran Van Lam is temporarily withdrawing from the Saigon Government to run in the Senate elections in August, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

For the first time since the city started its marketbasket reports in May, the cost of food for a family of four declined. In the week of June 7 to June 13, the cost was $52.30, compared with $52.68 in the week of May 31 to June 6, a decline of 38 cents.
"I don't want to be a flash in the pan, but I don't think I will be," said Johnny Miller, the new United States Open golf champion, yesterday.
The newest Federal regulatory agency is gearing up for what its chairman describes as a "reasonable, rational and responsible" effort to reduce unreasonable risks to users of consumer products.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation said today that it had sued the Air Force in Newark Federal Court to upset the award of an engine overhaul contract to the Southwest Airmotive Company of Dallas.

Heavy fighting was reported yesterday around two towns only 13 miles from Phnom Penh as a Communist offensive continued in the area. American planes struck at Communist positions near the market town of Bek Chan, which was attacked by Communist troops on Saturday, and Ang Snuol, which has been surrounded since last week.

Former Under Secretary of State George W. Ball warned Congress today against allowing euphoria over progress toward improved East-West relations to lead to an early withdrawal of some American troops from Western Europe.

Governor Cahill, who once charged that the nomination of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. would be a disaster for the Republican party in November, announced his support of Mr. Sandman for Governor today.

Georges Bonnet, who as French Foreign Minister in 1938 was a signer of the Munich agreement that precipitated World War II, died here today at his home. He was 83 years old.

With no desire to seem opposed to healthy fun, this writer must, nonetheless, register his disapproval of a new recreational vehicle that has been described as a "motorcycle for the water."

Juliette Hamelecourt describes herself as a painter who uses embroidery as a medium. "I use my needle as a brush, my thread as a medium," she said. "Every stitch becomes a brush stroke, not flat, as with paint, but three-dimensional for its textile matter."

H. R. Haldeman, the former White House chief of staff, has moved his family back home to California. As far as Mrs. Haldeman is concerned, "she's moved back for good," Mr. Haldeman's attorney, John J. Wilson, said in an interview today.

The stock market declined again yesterday as investors increased their concern over the growing pressure on the dollar and on the effectiveness of the Administration's new economic measures to combat inflation.
A compromise money bill that includes a proposal to cut off funds for American bombing in Cambodia was cleared today by a Senate-House conference and sent to the House floor.

The USLIFE Corporation has reached an agreement to acquire the All American Life and Financial Corporation of Chicago, it was announced yesterday by Gordon E. Crosby Jr., chairman of USLIFE, and John M. Gardiner, president of All American.

The Bank for International Settlements warned today that no end was in sight for world inflation, and that floating exchange rates have helped the inflationary process along by removing an element of discipline.
The First National Bank of Chicago posted yesterday a quarter-point increase-to 73/4 per cent, effective today in its base interest rate on loans to corporations.
A high state law enforcement official testified today that State Senator James M. Turner "practically ordered" him to raid the home of Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz last fall in search of drugs.

The Board of Higher Education last night approved plans for the City University's first law school, to be opened by 1976 at Queens College. In announcing the plan, which still must be approved by the State Board of Regents and the Governor, the board noted a dramatic growth in the demand for lawyers over the last decade.

Navy rescue vessels today ripped a research submarine, containing four men, from the grasp of a scuttled destroyer whose rusting hulk had held the tiny vessel prisoner for more than 30 hours in the Atlantic Ocean off Key West.

Under current plans, the Navy's renewed minesweeping in North Vietnamese waters will leave numerous deactivated mines at the bottom of Haiphong Harbor, according to a high-ranking military commander here.

Although the aircraft carrier Wasp picked up her quota of battle stars in the Pacific during World War II, she was never known as a lucky ship and she lived up to that reputation on her last voyage today.
The five Roman Catholic bishops of Rhodesia have threatened a civil-disobedience campaign to protest legislation that, they maintain, prevents whites and blacks from worshiping together.
A Federal judge was urged today to clamp severe restrictions on the International Business Machine Corporation to guarantee "free and open competition" in the computer industry.

An 11th crewman of the United States Navy vessel who was charged with disobedience while minesweeping off North Vietnam pleaded guilty today and was sentenced to three months' imprisonment at hard labor, the Navy reported.
Jocelyne Bourassa, the hometown favorite, sank a 15-inch putt on the third hole of a three-way, sudden-death play off today to win the $10,000 first prize in the La Canadienne golf.championship.

Leaders of the south Saharan African nations struck by a fifth year of drought will meet in August in Ouagadougou, the capital of Upper Volta, in an attempt to formulate longrange plans to deal with the disaster.

When Dock Ellis is right, he walks few batters, and the Pittsburgh Pirates hope he is right at last. Dock hurled a three-hitter to help them defeat the Chicago Cubs, 3-1, last night.

Rosemary A. Gorskie, an assistant vice president of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, died yesterday while attending classes in banking at Brown University in Providence, R. I. She was 46 years old and lived at 37-31 73d Street, Jackson Heights. Oueens.
Two Pennsylvania men were killed early today when a car going in the opposite direction jumped the divider along the Southern State Park way and landed atop their vehicle, the police reported.

A, $10.3-billion expense budget for 1973-74, calling for a real-estate tax increase of 36 cents per $100 of assessed valuation, was adopted informally yesterday by the Lindsay administration, Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Board of Estimate and City Council leaders.
In the winter of 1957, Ralph Terry, a right-handed pitcher for the Kansas City Athletics, fractured his hip in a car crash. As a result of that mishap, Terry was introduced to golf.
Housing starts rebounded in May after a three-month decline and new building permits stabilized, the Commerce Deapartment reported today.

Arthur Berk, a taxi broker, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home, 1950 Hutchinson Parkway, the Bronx. He was 54 years old. He leaves his wife, Sandra; two sons, Michael and Stewart; his father, Herman Berk, and two broth. ers.
Seven Madison Avenue stores and hotels, including Abercrombie Fitch and the Roosevelt and Biltmore Hotels yesterday endorsed the proposed Madison Avenue mall.

Thousands of Penn Central riders, most of them homebound commuters, were stranded in their trains last night when equipment problems and a fire aboard a train forced the railroad to shut down power on its Hudson Division line from Marble Hill, Manhattan's enclave in the Bronx, to Glenwood in Westchester County.

The Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, conceded today that his office was studying the questions of whether a President might be subpoenaed in a criminal case and whether a President might be indicted prior to impeachment.

Rejecting pleas from the Department of Justice, the Supreme Court affirmed today a lower court decision permitting a Texas bank holding company to acquire four legally separate but economically allied banks in the El Paso area.

A recently organized council to promote cultural events in Lower Manhattan will begin operations this month. The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, sponsored by businessmen and city officials was initially funded by a $10,000 grant from the Chase Manhattan Bank according to Florence Barnett, executive director.
The president of Air Canada says the airline will restore full service by Thursday after tentative settlement of a contract dispute: with the company's 6,400 machinists.

The Senate Watergate committee today canceled its hearings this week so that they would not detract from the talks here between President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

Thousands of Penn Central riders, most of them homebound commuters, were stranded in their trains last night when equipment problems and a fire aboard a train forced the railroad to shut down power on its Hudson Division line from Marble Hill, Manhattan's enclave in the Bronx, to Glenwood in Westchester County.

Sadick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Michael Sadick of Providence, was married here at noon today to Peter Anthony Jablow of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Jablow of New York and a grandson of the late Maurice Rentner, founder of the Fashion Originator's Guild.

Appearing fit but tense and carrying a briefcase upon which the word "Champ" was emblazoned in faded gold lettering, Joe Frazier arrived in London yesterday to prepare for his fight against Joe Bugner on July 2.
About 20 members of the Stafford Springs Crusaders drum and bugle corps were treated in Johnson Memorial Hospital in Stafford Springs last night for food poisoning, authorities said.

A $35-million complex of city, state and county offices was dedicated today in this city, whose reputation for comfortable tidiness has worn a bit since the days when it was known as "the Parlor City."

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: BANKS Affirmed a decision permitting a Texas bank holding to acquire the largest bank in El Paso and three smaller banks, all of them linked by a common "control group," over government objections that reduced competition would result (No. 72-1565, United States v. Trans Texas Bancorporation Inc.).

The White House stated today that no one with authority or access to the facts had said that President Nixon was preparing to say he was misled in the Watergate case by two former aides, John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman.
Procter Gamble, the country's largest national advertiser, this week pulls out the stops in its efforts to introduce Sure, an antiperspirant.

A year after the Washington police caught five burglars redhanded in the offices of the Democratic National Committee, the most burning questions in the public mind still seem to be: Did Richard Nixon know that the Watergate Five were hired hands of the Committee for the Re-election of the President? Did he help cover up the committee and White House involvement? Whatever he knew, how will it all turn out?

The Cost of Living Council's freeze group announced today that all sellers would be required to maintain freeze-price records and post notices that such records are available starting next Tuesday at 11:59 P.M.

Two Columbia players advanced today at the start of the National Collegiate tennis championships. Henry Bunis defeated Michael Quintin of Southern California, 6-3, 6-3, and Rick Fagel posted a 7-5, 6-2 victory over Greg Jablonski of Irvine.
Brazil's military leaders have chosen Gen. Ernesto Geisel, the 64-year-old head of the state oil monopoly, to become the nation's next President.

The leaders of the world's two most powerful nations, President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezh. nev, met on the lawn of the White House today in a swirl of military pageantry and pledged to strive together for peace.
A tornado spun out ot a massive storm raging through southwest Oklahoma tonight and slammed into a nursing home, injuring at least 45 persons.
Harry M. Mountain, re ired president of the Aetna insurancee Company of Hartford, died Saturday at Tri-City Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Lake San Marcos.
It all began when Tom Seaver, tonight's scheduled starter for the Mets, complained of an aching back just before the opener of a three-game series with the Phillies.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, working group on direct broadcast satellites- 10:30 A.M. and 5 P.M. Special Committee on Colonialism-10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.
The Amstar Corporation has agreed to a Federal Trade Commission order requiring it to "correct" allegedly deceptive advertisements for Domino sugar.

Beauty, of course, is in the eye of the beholder. And when Roland Michener, the Governor General of Canada, contemplated the pickets dogging Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India, he advised her to regard such demonstrations as "a compliment."

To the Editor: The President's temporary price freeze and future control program may be helpful in gaining time. In an excess-demand situation, however, the main job has to be done through fiscal and monetary policy.

Judge Charles E. Stewart Jr. ruled in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday that he would exercise jurisdiction over Vesco Co., Inc., a family corporation formed in Delaware last year by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier and former chairman of the International Controls Corporation.
Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis disclosed yesterday it is withdrawing from an active "dealer role" in Treasury securities but will continue operating

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market fell sharply yesterday in continued light trading, although volume was slightly higher than on Friday. Traders continued to act negatively to the Administration's efforts to curb inflation.

A $10.3-billion expense budget for 1973-74, calling for a real-estate tax increase of 36 cents per $100 of assessed valuation, was adopted informally yesterday by the Lindsay administration, Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Board of Estimate and City Council leaders.

The Senate today passed, 85 to 3, a bill specifying that institutional investors such as mutual funds may trade on stock exchanges for their own accounts so long as the exchanges maintain a system of fixed brokerage commissions.
The Nixon Administration reportedly indicated willingness today to accept some limitations on the sweeping bargaining powers sought in his proposed international trade legislation.

Although the aircraft carrier Wasp picked up her quota of battle stars in the Pacific during World War II, she was never known as a lucky ship and she lived up to that reputation on her last voyage today.
The demand that overtime be made voluntary has become a key and decisive issue in the up coming negotiations for a new contract between the United Automobile Workers Union andthe auto companies.

WARSAW - In Poland, which so far as is known has the world's only museum devoted exclusively to poster art, posters must promote Marxist consciousness as well as sell toothpaste or announce the arrival in townof a three-ring circus.

The Federal grand jury in Newark investigating allegation of payola in the record indus try has subponeaed Kal Rud man, a leading pop music tip sheet publisher, to appear this week, Mr. Rudman's lawyeracknowledged yesterday.
AUTHOR, AUTHOR What with everyone talking about directors and actors, there's a feeling in some quarters hat there should be a word n behalf of the people whowrite movies, too.

Genesco, Inc., yesterday omitted its regular quarterly dividend payable July 31 on common stock and announced it was considering setting up a reserve of up to $60-million against potential losses due to discontinuation or restructur ing of several operating divisions.

Thomas B. Adams, chair man of Campbell-Ewald, yes terday joined that growing list of agency executives who are trying to promote public service advertising support ing the American way, American business and theAmerican profit system.

The Gateway National Re creation Area at the mouth of New York Harbor came a step closer to fruition yester day when Governor Rockefel ler signed a bill authorizing the City of New York and the state to cede 26,000 acres to the Federal Government fordevelopment of the park.
Mrs. John N. Mitchell came out of her luxury apartment building yesterday and charged that the news media had madeher a prisoner on Fifth Avenue.

When she was appointed Fairleigh Dickinson University's vice president for development last September, Evelyn..Terhune was urged by friends to quit as the women's fencing coach. "They tried to tell me that the two jobs would be too much for one person," said Miss Terhune, who was a mem ber of the United' States Olympic fencing team in Rome in1960.

The Federal Trade Commis sion said today it had ruled that the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation and eight oil-re fining companies had engaged in anticompetitive practices through their long-term, full output contracts for petroleum coke used primarily in the chemical and metal-refiningindustries.

George Karl of North Caro lina and George Pennell of South Plains College led a United States basketball team to an 88-59 victory over the Chinese Physical Culture Insti tutes combined team in Peking tonight, Hsinhua, the Chinese government press agency reported.
The de mand that overtime be made voluntary has become a key and decisive issue in the up coming negotiations for a new contract between the United Automobile Workers Union andthe auto companies.
United States oil and gas re serves decreased almost 5 per cent last year as consumption continued to out-strip new dis coveries, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

Shortly after he was traded from Oakland to the Indians this year, George Hendrick made a big impression on Cleveland's pitching coach, Warren Spahn. No doubt he made an even bigger impression on Detroit last night as he led the Indians to an 8-7 victory over the Tigers that snapped a six-game losingstreak.
The state Lottery Commission said today that six winning tickets, each worth $50,000, had not been claimed this year and that one top weekly prizefor 1972 remained unclaimed.
A Bronx woman who says the city has recorded a 1971 marriage that never took place wants the record expunged, but will have to go to court todo so.

The Vietcong denied today that any of their troops fired on two helicopters of the international peace-keeping force on Sunday and accused the Canadian delegation of "in accurate reporting" of the incident.

The Watergate special prosecution force presented a sealed folder of evidence to Federal District Court today in a move to pro tect any future criminal case that it might bring against JohnW. Dean 3d.
The Hartford police have been handed a new code that re quires them to be more con siderate of the rights and feel ings of citizens, especially black and Spanish-speakingones.

A menu half in French and half in English? A Cabernet wine with beef? Paris newspapers, charg ing "gastronomic heresies," reproduced photographs to day of the menu for the din ner offered by President and Mrs. Nixon to Leonid I.Brezhnev yesterday.

Lots of things happen on the floor of the Senate, but rarely a birth announcement. Nevertheless, yesterday it was the place where Senator Rober C. Byrd of West Virginia announced the birth of a grandchild-not his, but the first for Senator Mike Mansfield.
At 2:30 yesterday after noon, the grand ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel was filled with 500 people, most of them dreaming dreams ofa renovated firehouse.

The Senate Watergate committee plans to investigate the per sonal finances of the partici pants in the bugging and cover up episode to determine whether large sums of Republican campaign money were misap propriated or in other ways wrongfully used, Senate sourcessaid today.
On three occasions within a week, New Yorkers who were chance witnesses to street crimes have taken an active part either in apprehending the suspects or inassisting the police in making the arrests.
A four-count indictment charging violations of state elec tion laws was served today on Blagden H. Wharton. treasurer of a Salute to Ted Agnew fundraising committee.

The State Supreme Court today gave the Legislature 18 months to approve a new constitutional method of financing public school education in New Jersey. If the Legislature fails, the court said it would impose anew system on its own.
A man slipped and fell four floors to his death yesterday in the Bronx as he tried to open a window for a woman who hadlost her key, the police said.

When George Shearing, re cording with a quintet in 1949, stumbled upon an at tractive and slightly different sound by using a unison of piano, vibraphone and elec tric guitar, he had the key that opened the door to popularity and fortune.

The measures before Congress re quiring the President to terminate any military action abroad within a pre determined period such as thirty or 120 days reveal that the Congress is still under a spell of subservience tothe President.

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, who ran last in the four-way race for Demo ratic nomination for Mayor, believes Abraham D. Beame has the best chance of winning the runoff, based on statistics, but believess also that Representa Live Herman Badillo "can pullan upset."

The Securities and Exchange Commission terminated today the suspension of the over the-counter trading in securities of the Westgate-California Corporation and its majority-owned subsidiary, Air California, effective at midnight.
Two major real-estate groups were charged by the Government yesterday with fixing commissions for the sale and the management of cooperative apartments in Manhattan.
A crackdown on crime in the Times Square area through the use of closed-circuit television is due to begin nextmonth. Under plans being made by the Police Department,

Lew Worsham didn't swing a golf club in the United States Open at the Oakmont Country Club but was quoted on television as having said he might surpass the $35,000 Johnny Miller took home for winning the championshipSunday.
MOLLY'S DREAM, by Maria Irene Fornes; "Chicago," by Sam Shepard. Performed by the New York Theater Strategy. At the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street, 7:30, through Sunday.

A ballroom full of chanting taxi drivers - whose parked vehicles made a vast yellow splotch on the western edge of Union Square-the officers of the Patrolmen's Benevolent As sociation and City Council President Sanford D. Garelik, who tried briefly to run for Mayor himself, all endorsed Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday in the Democraticmayoral runoff.
Voters in three Nassau Coun ty communities who rejected proposed school budgets ear lier returned to the polls last night and turned down two revised outlays. The third wasapproved.

The nation's scheduled air lines announced today that they planned to continue their anti hijacking program of searching all baggage and of screening all passengers. "We have an antihijacking system that is working successfully," said Stuart Tipton,

A street peddler with 1,050 unanswered sum monses received for operate ing without a license was ar rested last night at 14th Street and the Avenue of Americas, where officers of the Manhattan warrant squad said he was selling two boxes of cherries.

About 25 youths, believed to be members of a gang called the Seven Crowns, stoned a private house on Linden Boule vard in the South Jamaica sec tion of Queens last night and, according to the police, threatened to burn it down.
The first group of American specialists who will renew minesweeping arrived yesterday in the port of Haiphong, the official Vietnam press agency said today.

Twenty years to the day after the execution of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg for wartime espionage, the couple's two sons yesterday sued Doubleday Co. and Louis Nizer, the law yer, for $3-million in connec tion with Mr. Nizer's book "TheImplosion Conspiracy."
A 21-year-old coed was found dead today of multiple stab wounds in her second floor room in a dormitory at the C. W. Post Center of LongIsland University.

Two of the Skylab 1 astronauts went outside their space station to day to retrieve exposed film from solar telescopes and, in a return engagement as orbital repairmen, to hammer a batteryback into action.

Clarence M. Kelley, the Kansas City, Mo., police chief who has been nominated by President Nixon to head the Federal Bu ??u of Investigation, said to day that he had "never bowed to political pressure and I don'tmean to start."
Equation, a 68-foot ketch as loaded with modern technology as an' Apollo spacecraft, won today the Annapolis-to-Newport race, the leading offshore yacht ing event on the East Coastthis year.

The destroyer U.S.S. Fred T. Berry, in which the minisub marine Johnson-Sea-Link be came entangled, was one of two naval vessels that were sunk about 20 miles south of Key West, Fla., 13 months ago, according to a spokes man for the Navy's AtlanticFleet in Norfolk, Virginia.

In a retreat from his hard-line ef forts to hold down spending for domestic programs, Presidem Nixon announced today the signing of three bills that the White House said would exceed his budget for the programs involved by $671-million.

Leonid I. Brezhnev presented his case for a major expansion in Soviet-American trade to leading members of Congress and urged them not to let quarrels about the emigration of Soviet Jews to stand in the way of broad scale cooperation. The Soviet party leader was host to 25 Senators and Representativesat a luncheon. [Page 1, Column 1.]

Leonid I. Brezhnev took his case for a major expansion in Soviet-American trade to lead ing members of Congress today and urged them not to let quarrels about Jewish emigra tion stand in the way of broadcooperation.

Lucien Laurin, trainer of Sec retariat, the Triple Crown win ner, said last night he was considering running his colt in an invitation race at Chicago's Arlington Park June 30. But he emphasized that arrangements had not been completed, TheAssociated Press reported.

Top-seeded Steve Ross of Brook lyn opened the defense of his New Jersey State men's tennis championship with two victories today at the Arlington Players Club. He ousted Steve Sinoway of South Orange, 6-1, 6-3, and Bob Zeckhauser of East Orange, 6-1, 6-2.

Michael Davie of The London Ob server, Eric Sevareid and other pun dits are spreading the libelous notion that the roots of Watergate can be traced to the politics and sociology what they call the "peculiarities"-of Southern California, more particularlyOrange County.
Long Island's first woman Mayor, Mrs. Sandra Swenk of Port Jefferson, won re-election yesterday, and two of her Unity party running mates de feated incumbents for VillageTrustee posts.
Federal Bureau of Inves tigation agents found 50 pounds of dynamite last night in the home of Jesse Stephens, an extremist right-wing leader whodied last week.
It's hardly a landslide and not even its stanchest sup porters dream it will dom inate the way women look next fall. Many retailers tend to close their eyes and wishit would go away.

Oil companies offered a record $6.2-billion today to ob tain drilling rights to 104 sec tions of offshore territory south of Texas and Louisiana. The Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management, which conducted its third Gulf of Mexico lease sale in nine months, took all bids under study and will accept the high bids provided they meet or sur pass the Government's advanceestimate.
Sad to relate, but for me the worst moment at the new geriatric show, "Antiques," which opened at the Mercer O'Casey Theater last night, came with a simple announcement.

Janet Lynn of Rockford, Ill., the 20-year-old figure-skating star, signed contracts today that will pay her more than $2-million. One contract, with the "Ice Follies," will pay her $1.455-million over three years as a special guest star. Negotiations are under way for television specials and a motion picture. The contracts were signed in the office of Arthur Wirtz, ownerof the Chicago Stadium and the Chicago Black Hawks.
A new exhibition open ing today at the Brooklyn Musem might appropriately have been called "Make Way for William Trost Richards"if it didn't sound funny.
Pele scored on a corner kick and a penalty shot to night, then played the last nine minutes as the goalie, as Santos of Brazil beat theBaltimore Bays, 4-0.

An Anglican bishop ana sections of the Methodist Church in Rhodesia have joined the protest of the five Roman Catholic bishops of Rhodesia against legislation that they contend restricts the freedom of religious worship by mixedblack and white congregations.

A long-standing battle with occasional comic-opera overtones broke into the open here last week between remnants of the largely Irish and largely Reform Democratic groups that ran this city and its Police Department for many years and the largelyDemocratic regulars who have supplanted them.

In a retreat from his hard-line ef forts to hold down spending for domestic programs, President Nixon announced today the signing of three bills that the White House said would exceed his budget for the programs involved by $671-million.

President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to day called for talks between Arabs and Israelis for "a just and lasting peace" based on a recognition of the rights of all in the area, among them the right of Israel "not to be ex terminated and cast into thesea,"

Vincent M. Guglielmo, a vice president of the Flygt Corpora tion, a subsidiary of the Inter national Telephone and Tele graph Corporation that manu factures pumping equipment, died in Copenhagen on June 9,apparently of a heart attack.
The English Bridge Union has for many years organized a tournament for schools in which more than 60 teamscompete.
John Mclnerney, a member of the staff of Travel Trade, a business publication in the travel field, died, apparently of a heart attack, Sunday at his home, 99 McLean Street. Hewas 41 years old.

Senator Stuart Symington, the acting chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, complained today that the F-14 interceptor had been "shoved down the throats" of the Marine Corps to lower the costof the plane to the Navy.
Luis d'Antin Van Rooten, an actor whose voice and face were more famous than his name, died here Sunday at the retirement home he had de signed himself, He was 66 yearsold.
Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley is disbanding the de partment's controversial stake out squad, which has killed about 25 holdup men since itwas organized in May, 1968.

Thirty - two settlement houses are getting together for the first time to raise money and to let people know what they are doing. Their meeting ground is the Armory at 67th Street and Park Avenue where theyopened a fair Monday.

A fire in a transmission line at the Consolidated Edison Company's Ravenswood plant in Queens caused the shutdown of two generators yesterday, but posed no problem for customers, a Con Edison spokesman reported. The 3 A.M. blaze, of undetermined origin, damaged a circuit breaker, which tripped out generators at the Ravenswood plant and at the Arthur Kill station on StatenIsland.

Michael S. Green, 35 years old, of Washington, D.C., was convicted by a Federal jury today of hijacking a Na tional Airlines jet carrying 113 passengers and a crew of seven last June 12. The jetliner was pirated over Kennedy International Airport by two gunmen.
The Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday for mally approved a $10.16-billion expense budget for 1973-74 in the basic real-estate tax rate Informal agreement had beenreached Monday.

Police officials disclosed today that an American executive had been kidnapped on Monday in what appeared to be a guerrilla operation. The disclosure came as thousands of Argentines poured into Buenos Aires for what organizers hoped would be a large-scale but peaceful homecoming celebration for former PresidentJuan D. PerOn.

The College of Medicine and Den tistry of New Jersey and the American Association of Uni versity Professors have ratified a two-year contract that is re ported to be among the firstof its kind in the country.
Four days before the Wim bledon tennis championships, the top professionals announced this morning they would boycott the event.

An American-Japanese, joint venture company, Hitachi Singer, Ltd., will be started here this week to sell point-of-sale products and systems and free standing cash registers for use in department stores and supermarkets, Hitachi, Ltd.

A Summer Health Fair featur ing free medical tests and edu cational exhibits will be held Saturday at the Brookdale Hos pital Medical Center inBrooklyn.

Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz has invited the grocery industry, and by inference all industries, to let the Govern ment know at once what rules and standards should be ap plied in Phase 4 of the pricewage control system.
An exhibition of Picasso's 347 "erotic" prints ended a six day run here today, a show perhaps less erotic than theartist might have planned:
An 8-year-old girl believed at. first to have scored an upset victory in a District primary election did not win, an official tabulation shows.

Walter C. (Tiny) Swift, who won the nickname "Angel of Attica" for administering to the injured during the 1971 Attica prison riot, died last night. He died in the same hospital room where he was marriedthe night before.

You wouldn't expect table legs sold without a top to be wildly popular items. But the legs, designed by Francois Arnal and called "Tablemak ers." have been proving sale able beyond expectations, according to Bonniers.

John W. Dean 3d has told Sen ate investigators that President Nixon asked him to keep a list of newsmen who were giving the President "trouble" during last year's election campaign,according to Senate sources.

A special offering of 34,200 common shares of Saunders Leasing at 9 5/8 per share was made yes terday by Bear Stearns Co. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, closed at 9 5/8, down 3/8. A special offering of 41,000 common shares or the Wynn Oil Company at 11 was terminated by Bear Stearns yesterday. The company's stock closedat 10, down 1 on the Amex.

The City Health Department yesterday released the names of a record total of 53 food-proc essing establishments it has charged with violating the Health Code. Commissioner Gordon Chase said the previous record was42, set on March 9, 1972.
"For a thousand years, ever since King Mieszko, we have lived; in conflict with the Germans to our west. But we must think now of the next thousandyears."

The College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and the Ameri can Association of University Professors have ratified a two year contract that is reported to be among the first of itskind in the country.
Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Donald F. Caw ley yesterday applauded an evident new willingness on the part of New Yorkers to get involved and to try to stopcrimes of violence.
A crackdown on crime in the Times Square area through the use of closed-circuit television is due to begin next month.

Federal savings and loan associations will be permitted to increase to 80 per cent from 75 per cent the maxi mum loan-to-value ratio on cer tain specified construction loans, the Federal Home LoanBank Board announced today.

A State Supreme Court jus tice yesterday ordered that the city hold off implementing a new law that repeals the maxi mum-base-rent formula of the local rent control program, which permits rent rises of up to 7.5 per cent a year in manycontrolled apartments here.
The House Appropria tions Committee today proposed spending $820-million that Pres ident Nixon left out of his 1974 budget for city improvementprojects.

Mrs. Beverley Becker and Mrs. Nancy Meade finished one, two, respectively, today to lead the American Yacht Club to vic tory in the Morgan Cup, emble matic of the women's interclub sailing championship of LongIsland Sound.

The Jim Walter Corporation had record sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended May 31, reflecting con tinuing high demand for vir tually all product lines, James W. Walter, chairman and presi dent, reported yesterday from the company's Tampa, Fla.,headquarters.
Federal Bureau of Inves tigation agents found 50 pounds of dynamite last night in the home of Jesse Stephens, an extremist right-wing leader who died last week.

Senators who listened to an after-lunch monologue by Leonid I. Brezhnev today said later that they were impressed by his preparations, his charm, his eagerness for better Soviet American relations-but not necessarily by his defense of his country's policy toward Jews.
Two persons, one a policeman, were killed and three others wounded in a burst of gunfire on a downtown street today as crowds returning from lunchlooked on.
The crealt markets continue yesterday to reflect a belief that no major progress against inflation would occur through the freeze in prices and that interest rates must rise stillfurther.

In dealing with the prob lem of fire hazards in Cham pionship Trail races, the United States Auto Club may have created another problem equally serious. At least that's the way it appears to Dr. Joseph Mattioli, president of Pocono International Raceway at Long Pond, Pa.

Marshall G. Sampsell, a senior part ner of Isham Lincoln Beale one of this city's oldest law firms, died today in North western Memorial Hospital atthe age of 69.

George Donald Billock, secre tary-treasurer of Vulcan, Inc., a nationwide manufacturer of steel ingots, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital in Pitts burgh. He was 64 years old andlived in Greensburg, Pa.

Jet fighters howled overhead and snarling tanks shook the streets of Saigon to day as the South Vietnamese Army staged the biggest armed forces day parade in the his tory of the country. only five days after the reaffirmation ofthe cease-fire.

Tile dollar rallied strongly to day as a degree of stability re turned to European currency ex changes. Dealers said demand for dol lars built up steadily during theday after a slow opening.

Lew Worsham didn't swing a golf club in the United States Open at the Oakmont Country Club but was quoted on television as having said he might surpass the $35,000 Johnny Miller took home for winning the championship Sunday.

The proposed merger of Slater Walker Securities and Hill Samuel Co., the merchant bankers, was called off to day because of incompati bility of "work style and personalities" of the men who shook hands on the dealless than eight weeks ago.

Thomas M. Macioce, presi ent and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation, New York, told the annual meeting here yesterday that "it is difficult to comprehend" how prices can be controlled when rent, interest and wages are exempt from the President'slatest price freeze.
An unfamiliar face ap peared in Brazilian news papers today as, after months of censorship, Brazilians learned that Gen. Ernesto Geisel had been chosen by the military to be the nextPresident.

Five fishermen caught a pig in the ocean yesterday. Mike Leadley, of Hialeah, and his friends say they hooked a badly sunburned, salt-encrusted pig who was tired but apparently as happy as a porker can be to see thefishermen.

Mrs. Austin Straub of Roll ing Hills, the defending cham pion, moved into the quarter final round of the 70th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf As sociation championship today. The 30-year-old m o t h e r moved through the first round this morning by eliminating Mrs. Roger McWilliams of Rockaway River, 7 and 5.
The World Hockey Associa tion, grappling for recognition and box-office dollars, reached into the National Hockey League's past yesterday forGordie Howe.

Administration spokesmen told Congress today that the energy crisis could be met largely by voluntary measures but that the gasoline shortage might call for new or increased Federaltaxes to discourage waste.

The Dairylea Cooperative, Pearl River, N. Y., one of the country's largest dairy organi zations, is entering the bottled water business. In cooperation with the National Water Cor portion, Dairylea has formed D. L. Nawco, Inc., which will be equally owned and controlledby the founding companies.
Representative Herman Ba dillo promised yesterday that if he became Mayor he would have independent certified pub lic accounting firms conduct continuing audits of all cityagencies and programs.
With its final questioning apparent ly calculated to show that the defendant's motive was political rivalry, the prosecution rested its case today in the trial ofState Senator James M. Turner.
Miss Debora Susanne Dworkin and Daniel Judah Lasker, graduates of Brandeis University, were married last evening at the Deauville in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. Rabbi Arnold A. Lasker of Orange,
Albert E. Pass, a former assistant to W. A. Boyle, the United Mine Workers president, was convicted of first-degree murder today in the Yablonskislaying.

George Karl of North Caro lina and George Pennell of South Plains College led a United States basketball team to an 88-59 victory over the Chinese Physical Culture Insti tutes combined team in Peking tonight, Hsinhua, the Chinese Government press agency reported.

Twenty-nine persons, including the former president and the former vice president of the Steel City National Bank, were indicted here today by a Fed eral grand jury on criminal conspiracy charges involving a loss to the bank of funds totaling a minimum of $2.8-million.
Invitations have gone out to 40 American business leaders to meet with Leonid I. Brezh nev, the Soviet Communistparty leader.
Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Donald F. Caw ley yesterday applauded an evident new willingness on the part of New Yorkers to get involved and to try to stopcrimes of violence.
A high Government official told. the French Senate today that Gov ernment wiretapping was none of its affair. He reaffirmed that the taps would continue in awide variety of cases.

Kenneth Hari, whose portraits of world-famous people are growing to the proportions of a book, has been sketching and painting virtually since he could walk. Gen. Omar N. Bradley is the latest to sit for the 26-yearold portraitist.

Mrs. Margaret Van Hamlin Haddad, wife of Jerrier A. Haddad, a vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation who directed development of the company's first electronic computer, died today in Memorial Hospital, New York.

The four Soviet-American agreements signed in Wash ington yesterday had been prepared previously and rep resent consequences rather than causes of improved Moscow-Washington relations. Dealing with such differ ent areas as oceanography, transportation, cultural ex change and agriculture, their very diversity is evidence that the present thaw in political relations is having auseful impact on other fields of mutual interest.

The two crew members remain ing locked aboard the research submarine Johnson - Sea- Link failed to show any signs of life today, 24 hours after the vessel was pulled from the ocean floor, and were pronounceddead.
Cambodian troops today regained control of a section of a supply road southwest of here that had been in Communist hands fortwo weeks.
Jim Lonborg, who came to the Phillies last November in a seven-player trade with Mil waukee, showed tonight that he may be ready to make himself right at home as a NationalLeaguer.

The Liberal party's candi-E date for the Assembly in West chester County's 87th Assem bly District last year was hired as a consultant to the Repub lican Assembly majority after he became the Liberal candidate, he disclosed yesterday.

Continuing the game of musi cal chairs as composed by the American League's Eastern Di vision, the New York Yankees outplayed the Baltimore Orioles last night by the tune of 5 to 4 and climbed back into secondplace.

The National Broadcasting Company fared rather poorly in this year's Emmy Awards for news, but the network apparently is determined to make the competition stiffer the next time around. Last week N.B.C. Reports offered the producer Fred Freed's "Murder in America."
The appointment of an American to head the Aus tralian branch of the General Motors Corporation was sharply criticized yesterday in Canberra by Prime Minister Gough Whitlam.

The renewed United Nations debate on the Middle East has recessed, still deadlocked on the issue that has been blocking progress toward peace since Ambassador Gun nar Jarring tried to break the Arab-Israeli impasse by submitting questionnaires to the parties in early 1971. The crucial issue revolves around the withdrawal "from territories occupied in the recent conflict," as called forin the Security Council resolution of November 1967.

Kenneth Fundus, former busi ness manager of Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, was convicted yesterday of arrang ing to accept a $10,000 bribe in return for granting a privatedetective union membership.
The top favorites ad vanced through the second round of the annual National Collegiate tennis championshiptoday.

In a municipal election year, budget-making becomes an exercise in political hero-making for those in control of the Board of Estimate and City Council. In line with that dubious tradition, the dominant Democrats have sought to advance the fortunes of their mayoral favorite, Controller Abraham D. Beame, by pushing onto future taxpayers part of the bill for the services New Yorkerswill receive in the new fiscal year.

Highway and wildlife offi cials say they will advertise for bids next month on a free way overpass for deer. The overpass is to be built in a part of Beaver County where offi cials say 67 deer have been killed by motorists so far thisyear.
ADELSTEIN-Bessle. The officers and mem bers of Temple Sinal of Roslyn record with sorrow, The passing of our member. Condolences to the family. Rabbi NORMAN KAHAN ALVIN R. MILLER, President

Richard A. Newhall, emeri tus professor of history at Williams College and inter nationally known as an author ity on medieval English military history, died last night at North Adams Regional Hospital. Hewas 85 years old.

BUFFALO--Signed John Ford, Henderson State fight end, seventh-round draft choice, to multiyear contract. HOUSTON--Signed George Amundson, Iowa State quarter back-running back, second-round draft choice, to multiyear contract;
John W. Hanley, president of the Monsanto Company, said here last night that he expected the company approximately to double its net income for th second quarter over the 1972period.

The World Hockey Associa tion, grappling for recognition and box-office dollars, reached into the National Hockey League's past yesterday for Gordie Howe. The former Detroit Red Wing, the most prolific scorer in N.H.L. history, signed a four year, $1-million contract with the Houston Aeros, bringinghim out of retirement.

A gunman took over the emergency room of the Newnan Hospital early today and held three nurses hostage for nearly three hours. Police Chief Jerry Helton said the gunman, Billy Trivett, about 30 years old, of Coweta County, was finally talked into surrenderingby a friend. No one was injured.

Mutual fund redemptions con tinued to outpace sales by a wide margin, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. May sales fell to $284.6-mil lion from $377.8-million a year earlier while redemptions fell to $445.9-million from $584.6million.
When an undistinguished claimer named Portangle ran six furlongs in 1:104/5 at Aqueduct yesterday, hardly anyone in the crowd of21,195 raised an eyebrow.

J. Paul Carey, retired chair man of the board of the Carey Cadillac Renting Company, which his father, James P. Carey, established in 1923 along with other concessions at Grand Central Terminal in New York, died today at his home here.He was 74 years old.
Dr. Charles W. Lester, a chest surgeon and a teacher of sur gery, died yesterday at Roose velt Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 320 East 72dStreet.
A new Pavlova, at 17 Russia's latest dance prodigy, was awarded the grand prize today in the Inter national Ballet Competition as Soviet dancers collected 11 ofthe 17 medals offered.

Melvin R. Laird, who was named Presidential Counselor for Domestic Affairs less 'than two weeks ago, went to the Capitol today to improve White House relations with Republican Senators and apparently succeeded.
Joseph L. Carter, manager of the American. Red Cross in Greater New York since the citywide headquarters was established in 1959, is retiringtoday.

For the last week, reports have been circulating that the military members of the Greek Govern ment would be replaced by civilians after the referendum of July 29 endorses, as ex pected, the recent abolition ofthe monarchy.

The stock market was on a roller - coaster yesterday. A sharp rally in the last half-hour enabled it to finish mixed in stepped up trading. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange opened higher. By 10:30 A.M. the Dow-Jones in dustrial average was up 10.08 points, its high for the session. Advances outnumbered declinesat that point in a 2-to-1 ratio.
The New York and Albany County District Attorneys be gan their own inquiries yester day into a suspected Repub lican scheme to siphon votes from Democrats in Assemblyelections.

The State Supreme Court today gave the Legislature 18 months to approve a new, constitution al, method of financing public school education in New Jersey. If the Legislature fails, the court said it would impose anew system on its own.

Daily index numbers and spot primary market commodity prices for June 5, 1973 to June12, 1973, follow:

BELFAST, Northern Ireland-The quintessential aim of President Nixon's foreign policy has been arrangement of a sensible deal with Moscow, bal ancing off the interests of the two superpowers while at the same time protecting United States commitments to West Europe and reassuring China against any conceivable threat of Soviet force.
The Senate Watergate hearings are tentatively set to resume Monday with John W. Dean 3d, ousted White House counsel, scheduled tobegin his testimony.
After six consecutive quarters of losses, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company today dis closed a three-month profit, estimated at more than $2-million.
The House Banking Committee approved legislation today that apparently will give President Nixon the authority he seeks to control exports of grainsand oilseeds such as soybeans.

American Reform Judaism, faced with the breakdown of the Jewish family unit as the dominant force in the survival of Judaism, moved today to arrest this con dition through a comprehensive series of family-centered programs.
