Before long the prosecutors in the Watergate case will start investigating the big financial contributions to the Nixon re-election committee, and this is likely to open up a whole new chapter in the current political scandals.
Two major real-estate groups were charged by the Gov ernment yesterday with fixing commissions for the sale andthe management of cooperative apartments in Manhattan.
At 2:30 yesterday after noon, the grand ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel was filled with 500 people, most of them dreaming dreams ofa renovated firehouse.
Two of the leaders in the Interzonal Tournament tak ing place here in the Dzerjin sky Palace of Culture suf fered setbacks today in the12th round.

An escaped westchester country convict who had eluded the police since Friday night was captured today in a White Plains apartment after holding a woman and four young children hostage for four hours.
The Government took new legal action yesterday to delay further payments to Litton Industries on its $1-billion contract to build five long-delayed
Reversing the direction that prevailed during the morning, prices dropped during the after noon to close lower in quiet trading on the American StockExchange yesterday.
Two major real-estate groups were charged by the Government yesterday with fixing commissions for the sale and the management of cooperative apartments in Manhattan.

William B. Colsey 3d, the head of a Republican fund-raising opera tion that helped Governor Ca hill and President Nixon, was disbarred today by the State. Supreme Court for his part in a bribery extortion conspiracy involving Gloucester Townshipofficials.
President Nixon today re moved all Federal tariffs from 1973 imports of petroleum prod ucts from Canada, in a move to increase those imports if theCanadians agree.
The Senate approved today the most austere space budget since 1962, voting a $3 billion authorization for the program in the fiscal year1974.

Minoru Segawa, chairman of the Nomura Securities Company, Ltd., one of Japan's lead ing brokerage houses, predicted yesterday that Japanese in vestors would put $4-billion to $5-billion in American stocks in the next few years.
Exxon stations on New Jersey's two major toll roads are limit ing gasoline sales. By direction of the parent company, stations on the New Jersey Turnpike are limiting individual sales to 12 gallons.

John W. Dean 3d has told Sen ate investigators that President Nixon asked him to keep a list of newsmen who were giving the President "trouble" during last year's election campaign,according to Senate sources.
Walter C. (Tiny) Swift, who won the nickname "Angel of Attica" for administering to the injured during the 1971 Attica prison riot, died lastnight.

The five-domed Victorian glass consevatory of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, long destined to be dismantled and replaced, is now a candidate for a $2 million restoration as a re sult of a new engineering evaluation and the rising pride of the borough's civicgroups.
The bodies of two oceanographers were removed late tonight from the research submarine Johnson-Sea-Link, 29 hours after the vessel was rescued from the ocean floor off Key West.

A $27-million cut in its pro jected $106 - million school lunch budget has forced the Board of Education to dismiss 665 employes in the program and abandon plans to start providing full-course. hot mid day meals instead of soup and sandwiches in 180 elementarypublic schools.

Leonid I. Brezhnev took his case for a major expansion in Soviet-American trade to lead ing members of Congress today and urged them not to let quarrels about Jewish emigra tion stand in the way of broadcooperation.

SPY IN THE VATICAN 1941-45. By Branko Bokun. 259 pages. Illustrated. Praeger. $7.95. Most of us know something about the tragedy of war: in "Spy in the Vatican 1941-45," Branko Bokun shows us its incidental comedy.

The union representing 1,235 professional and nonprofession al employes of seven social service agencies affiliated with the federation of Jewish Philan thropies said yesterday that it was seeking arbitration of its six-month-old contract disputewith the agencies.
Herbert S. Schlosser was ap pointed president of the Na tional Broadcasting Company television network yesterday, replacing Don Durgin, who has been named an executive vicepresident of N.B.C.

Marshall Ganz, a top aide to the United Farm Work ers leader, Cesar Chavez, was on arrested today when he at tempted to prevent non-U.F.W. workers from packing grapes in boxes bearing the union'slabel.
A 40-year-old construction worker was killed yesterday when he fell 400 feet into an excavation in the East River subway tunnel being built be tween Queens and Manhattanat 61st Street.

Charles W. Colson, a former White House aide, told a Sen ate panel today that he had personally asked John D. Ehrlichman to help E. Howard Hunt Jr. establish "liaison with the C.I.A." in the summer of1971.

Charging that the city admin istration's highly prized com puter operation for processing welfare and medical assistance cases was not working, the state issued a stop-order yes terday on further expendituresto develop the system.
The marriage of Miss Ingrid Anne Heenan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Heenan of New Ca naan, to Ogden Haggerty Hammond 3d, son of Mr. Hammond Jr. of West Palm Beach,
The Leonid I. Brezhnev who came to Washington this week is a different man from the one who met President Nixon a year ago in Moscow.

Sam McDowell strode through the portal at the Yankee Stadium, headed down the stairs to the catacombs beneath the stand and then hesitated in puzzlement. "I don't even know where the clubhouse is," he said.

Four businessmen who deal in foreign trade and investment told Congress today some of the difficulties of living in a world of floating currency exchange rates, but none of them condemned the new system outright.
The American Civil Liberties Union, charging "multiple frauds upon the court," argued today that the convictions of seven Watergate conspirators should be set aside and a new trial ordered.

West Germany today passed a milestone in its policy of establishing relations with the Communist states of Eastern Europe, initialing a treaty with Czechoslovakia and putting into effect its basic treaty with East Germany.

In days gone by it was no big news when a pitcher struck out, but in this year of the designated hitter in the American League it was news yesterday when Cy Acosta got not only a victory but also a time at bat (he struck out) in an 8-3 White Sox triumph over the California Angels in Chicago.
President Nixon has accepted "with regret and with admiration and gratitude for his splendid service" the resignation of Robert Gottschalk as Commissioner of Patents, effective June 29.
Record earnings and revenues were announced yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the quarter ended May 31.

SPRINGFIELD, Va.-America needs an Army. Not a small, "professional" cadre, nor an undermanned organization which requires extensive filling before it is ready to fight, nor a collection of combat units which must rely on reserve mobilization for their logistical support.
As far as accounts go it was an in day and an out day at Doyle Dane Bernbach yesterday. And since the in business was bigger than the out business, it added up to a happy day as well.

By the narrow margin of eight votes, the United States Senate has unfortunately rejected a proposal by Senator Jackson of Washington that would have greatly strengthened his own bill to promote land-use planning in this country.
The State Commission of Investigation accused a workmen's compensation judge today of illegally practicing law and also charged that he had lied in private testimony before the commission.

Police Chief Clarence M. Kelley of Kansas City, Mo., said today that he would not, under any circumstances, make confidential F.B.I. information available to anyone at the White House except the President.
The odds were estimated at 324 trillion-to-one, but that didn't stop Don Heasley. The 40-year-old Levittown, Pa., service station owner
Leo C. Zefferetti has been re-elected to a third two-year term as president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, representing 3,000 members of the City Correction Department.
Two white foreigners and four South African blacks were sentenced to long prison terms today on charges in an alleged conspiracy to overthrow the Government.

Following is a list of names in the Senate Watergate Committee's staff summary prepared after the interview with John W. Dean, 3d: H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff and assistant to the President.

PARTIAL RECALL Back in the good old nineteenthirties when there was nothing more serious to worry about than the Great Depression and the impending horrors of World War II, yes, way back then there was a lot to gladden the moviegoer's heart.

Manuel Orantes of Spain, the top-seeded player, limped out of the South of England lawn tennis championships today with a knee injury. He was hurt during his secondround match with Ian Fletcher of Australia, who led, 7-5, 2-1. Other second-round results:

Soaring oil revenues are spurring "a parabolic rise" in Middle Eastern export markets with a consequent burgeoning of multi-billion-dollar sales opportunities for American companies, an International Executives Association symposium was told yesterday.
State Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Spiegel defied a higher court and ruled for the second time that women receiving abortions should not have their names and addresses on fetal death certificates.
Governor Rockefeller's decision to cancel plans for the Rye-Oyster Bay bridge was greeted jubilantly today by the organizations and officials who have been fighting the project for nearly a decade.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell was ordered by State Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam yesterday to answer questions about whether he leaked Federal Bureau of Investigation and Justice Department reports to magazine article writers.

Since the members of the New York Philharmonic work on a year-round basis now, the management of the orchestra is constantly faced with the problem of finding productive things for the musicians to do.
An unemployed man who the police said tried unsuccessfully to blame a friend was charged today with the ax and knife slaying of two young men who were training to be missionary teachers.

Camp David, President Nixon's retreat, is perched atop a heavily wooded 1,880-foot peak in the Catoctin Mountains near the western Maryland village of Thurmont. Helicopter is the preferred means of getting there, a 30minute trip from the White House.

Japan's giant Sumitomo Group of banking, mining and manufacturing interests has given $2-million to Yale University and $1-million to the Japan Society here to promote Japanese-American cultural understanding.
Dave Wottle of Bowling Green became tonight the third fastest miler in track history, charging past Oregon's Steve Prefontaine to lead six men under the 4-minute mark with 3:53.3.

A robust production of "Fiddler on the Roof," its words and music reworked to fit the life-style of blacks and Puerto Ricans living in East Harlem, was put on by a cast of 64 fifth- and sixth-graders yesterday at Public School 108.

Following are excerpts from a White House account of conversations between President Nixon and John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel, which was sent to the Senate Watergate committee this week and was made available to The New York Times by a person with access to it:
Israel is using a combination of public statements and private diplomatic contacts to plumb the seriousness of repeated offers by President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to open peace talks.
One ticket-holder won $22,799.20 in the big exacta at Shenandoah Downs Race Course tonight. The winning combination for the fifth and sixth races was 5-4 and 6-3.

Joseph Luparelli, a Mafia informant, said under oath yesterday that Vincent Aloi, reputed head of the Joseph A. Colombo Sr. crime family, had ordered the murder of his rival, Joseph Gallo, more than a year before Gallo was killed.

" Antiques" opened Off Broadway on Tuesday evening at a cost to the producers of about $70,000. The musical about elderly citizens received generally disastrous reviews and is scheduled to close this Sunday.

To the Editor: It is hardly to be expected that newspapers will probe into their own culpability for the climate which produced Watergate. We shall continue to be treated with tedious self-praise of a valiant, free press.
Has the agony of Watergate taught us nothing about how to handle scandal? The Columbia Broadcasting System, a corporation active in many businesses, earned $82 million last year.
The executive vice president of the Bangor and Aroostook Railroad in northern Maine was appointed today as executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

The secret of the designated hitter lies in designating the right hitter in the right spot at the right time. As Manager Ralph Houk's choice for last night, Jim Ray Hart came up with two men on base in the seventh inning of a scoreless game and doubled them home.

Phil Grippaldi no longer carries the weight of the world on his back. It once seemed that way for the 26-year-old Belleville resident, who has won every major weight-lifting title except the Olympic and world championships.
The House Select Crime Committee approved a report today concluding that the Emprise Corporation of Buffalo, a nationwide sports vender, had done business with designated organized crime figures.

In a major reversal, Governor Rockefeller yesterday ordered an end to all plans for the Long Island Sound bridge project that he had demanded for several years in the face of growing opposition from residents and environmentalists.

For almost 28 years, Milovan Djilas, the Yugoslav political dissident, has either been in prison or living in isolation from most of his countrymen, rarely moving far from his apartment on Belgrade's treelined Palmoticeva Street, in the shadow of the Federal Assembly.

Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks in Westbury, L. I., and Mrs. Austin Straub, the defending champion from Rolling Hills in Wilton, Conn., reached the semifinal round of the 70th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.
A three-judge Federal court reserved decision today after hearing arguments concerning a man seeking the same Social Security benefits a woman would receive in the event her spouse died.

Hard to Be a God, by Arkadi and Boris Strugatski; Memoirs Found in a Bathtub, by Stanislaw Lem; The Invincible, by Stanislaw Lem (Continuum Books: Seabury Press, $6.95 each). Stories in the European Science Fiction in Translation series.

A White House account of President Nixon's conversations this year with John W. Dean 3d charges that Mr. Dean, despite constant pressure from the President, withheld from Mr. Nixon all information about White House involvement in the Watergate burglary and cover-up until March 21.

The question of. whether or not to have best-in-show competition is raised periodically. Only one major allbreed fixture in the United States currently has no top award-Saw Mill, held every March at the Westchester County Center.

Japan's giant Sumitomo group of banking, mining and manufacturing interests has given $2-million to Yale University and $1-million to the Japan Society here to promote Japanese-American cultural understanding.
Newly elected officers of the United States Conference of Mayors officially opened today an attack on the Nixon Administration's major special revenue-sharing proposal for urban development.

President Giovanni Leone today asked former Premier Mariano Rumor to form a new government, Italy's 35th since the fall of Fascism. Mr. Rumor, 58 years old, has been Interior Minister in the departing cabinet of Premier Giulio Andreotti.
Juan D. Peron returned to gentina today, ending almost 18 years of exile, and violence among the more than one million people gathered to welcome him left at least 13 dead and more than 250 injured.

The Department of Justice asked a Federal judge today to hold the International Business Machines Corporation in contempt of' court for failure to produce some 12,000 documents that the Government wants as potential evidence in its longstanding antitrust action against I.B.M.
" Right now, the score is man 3, space nothing. I'm tremendously encouraged about the future of long-duration flight."

The New York Stock Exchange filed yesterday formal disciplinary charges against five former executives of Weis Securities, Inc., a brokerage house now being liquidated at the instigation of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.
A former Tunisian Government minister who escaped from prison here in February and is now reported living in Belgium has been sentenced in absentia to a new term of five and a half years.

West Germany today passed a milestone in its policy of establishing relations with the Communist states of Eastern Europe, initialing a treaty with Czechoslovakia and putting into effect its basic treaty with East Germany.

The staff of Archibald Cox, special prosecutor in the Watergate case, is considering a grand jury investigation to determine whether the President Nixon's re-election organization used extortion and other illegal forms of fund-raising while collecting more than $50-million in campaign contributions last year, sources close to the case said today.
The lowly Phils tonight downed the New York Mets for the third straight time to increase their winning streak to five games as they produced a 4to-3 victory.
The Festival Casals of Puerto Rico, which closed its 17th season in San Juan last Friday, transplanted itself to Carnegie Hall Tuesday night.

Although he is golf's newest star and the United States Open champion, Johnny Miller will not represent his country as a Ryder Cup team member against the British professionals at Muirfield, Scotland, in September.

The Soviet Union suggested strongly today that the limitation of strategic arms and the mutual reduction of forces in Europe would progress more rapidly if United States-Soviet trade could be expanded.
A Federal judge refused today to allow eight antiwar defendants to interrogate Government lawyers about the Watergate case and quashed seven of eight subpoenas issued for top Florida law officers.
The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized scheduled and nonscheduled United States and foreign airlines for the first time yesterday to negotiate minimum fares for trans-Atlantic charter flights.
A small, 125-year-old liberal arts college here is expected to abolish the tenure system, one of the most entrenched traditions in higher education.
Twelve-year-old Carolyn King, one of the nation's first female Little Leaguers, filed suit in Federal Court yesterday against the National Little League organization.

Owning up to something akin to a factual gutter ball, Helen McCain Smith, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon's press secretary, has revised her account of the finances behind that newly revealed bowling alley under the North Portico of the White House. Mrs.

Fasco Industries Inc., a Rochester-based, familyowned manufacturer of fractional horsepower motors and other electrical products, said yesterday it had delayed, temporarily, a planned public offering of 400,000 shares of common stock. The company said the delay was being made until "such time as Fasco feels the market has achieved at least a stabilized condition."

New York City's Democratic voters will go to the polls Tuesday to decide whether Representative Herman Badillo or Controller Abraham D. Beame will be their party's nominee for Mayor in November. Since Democrats so dominate the total electorate in this city, the decision in the runoff primary may well determine for the next four years the occupant of this office of supreme importance to the people of New York.
Negotiations resumed here this afternoon in an attempt to end a strike by the United Rubber Workers Union against the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company that began early today.

George Baylis has been appointed president of Bonwit Teller, the 13-unit specialty store. Mr. Baylis, who is 57 years old, resigned last December as executive vice president and general merchandise manager of Neiman-Marcus of Dallas following the appointment of Richard Marcus as its president.

China has appointed Liu Hsiang-pin to be Minister of Public Health. She is the first woman to hold ministerial rank for many years. Confirming unofficial news of the appointment today, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Miss Liu was the widow of Public Security Minister Hsieh Fu-chih.
Assemblyman Vito P. Battista filed suit in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday in a bid to overturn his 173-vote defeat in the Republican primary for Councilman at Large.

Top aides of Representatives Herman Badillo and Mario Biaggi met four days after the June 4 Democratic mayoral primary and discussed the possible endorsement of Mr. Badillo by Mr. Biaggi in Tuesday's runoff.

Charles L. Ross, board chairman of the Charles L. Ross Son Company of Hauppauge, a manufacturer of chemical and food-processing equipment, died today at the Southside Hospital in Bay Shore. He was 78 years old and lived at 60 East Bayberry Road.
Four Black Panthers who pleaded guilty to killing a member of a rival faction of their party were sentenced yesterday, to three years in prison.

The Soviet Union and the United States Export-Import Bank were reported close to a final agreement today on the extension of $180-million in credits to help finance the construction of a Soviet-American fertilizer complex in the Soviet Union that could lead to as much as $8-billion in trade over 20 years.
Cash-laden investors decided yesterday to loosen their pursestrings and purchase large blocks of bonds from a huge supply of nearly $500-million of fresh corporate and taxexempt issues..

Pullman, Inc., which moved out of the sleeper-car business some time ago, proved to be something of a sleeper itself in the stock market this week. On Monday, it was the only issue on the New York Stock Exchange to register a 1973 high.

Mrs. Lucretia Reiner Herbert, widow of John K. Herbert, who had been a vice president of Hearst Magazines, Inc., and president of the Magazine Publishers Association, died, apparently of a heart attack, today in Southampton Hospital.
A dozen children squealed with delight under showers of water as the newest concept in "adventure" playgrounds was unveiled yesterday afternoon in Central Park.
Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. reaffirmed his "firm opposition" to a state income tax today in a gubernatorial and legislative campaign platform released here by New Jersey's Republican party.
Israel is using a combination of public statements and private diplomatic contacts to plumb the seriousness of repeated offers by President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to open peace talks.

Robert L. Hershey, a director of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and a retired vice president and member of the company's executive committee, died yesterday at the Chester County Hospital in West Chester. Dr Hershey, who retired in 1966, was 71 years old and lived here.
The Republican National Finance Committee, its treasury depleted by the Watergate scandal, is quietly appealing to its largest contributors for "funds to keep the party alive."

United States officials were reported upset by today's decisions of the Common Market agriculture ministers that will make it harder for Americans to export oranges, canned juices and other farm products.

In designating another Army general as the country's next President, Brazil's military leaders were merely serving formal notice of the obvious: they expect to continue indefinitely an authoritarian rule, marked by repression and censorship, with no recourse to the voters in a genuinely free election.

EL TUR, Israeli-Occupied "Tout Sinai" was there-Bedouin sheiks in long white robes, Israeli generals in fatigues and combat boots, a Greek Orthodox priest from St. Catherine's Monastery in black cassock,

A service station operator from Levittown, Pa., set a New Jersey lottery record yesterday by winning $1 million and $10,000 on the same day. Don Heasley, 40 years old, the only person with two chances in the 23d millionaire drawing, hit on both of them. He had qualified by having the last two numbers and the first two numbers on the same ticket.

In a major reversal, Governor Rockefeller yesterday ordered an end to all plans for the Long Island Sound bridge project that he had demanded for several years in the face of growing opposition from residents and environmentalist.

The staff of Archibald Cox, special prosecutor in the Watergate case, is considering a grand jury investigation to determine whether the President Nixon's re-election organization used extortion and other illegal forms of fund-raising while collecting more than $50-million in campaign contributions last year, sources close to the case said today.

An act of personal kindness by Ely Culbertson many years ago turned out to be a permanent benefit to bridge in New York City. At the world championship in 1937 he met a young bridge organizer of obvious ability and was later able to help him to leave Germany and enter the United States.

In an effort to provide more activity and more prestige for United States boxers, along with more business for Madison Square Garden's boxing program, Teddy Brenner announced yesterday a plan to create American championships in each of 10 weight divisions, with recognition by the New York State Athletic Commission.

With the Democratic mayoral runoff primary only five days off, City Controller Abraham D. Beame and Representative Herman Badillo have drastically shifted their campaign strategy from the one they used in the initial primary two weeks ago.

Peter E. Pratt, associate general secretary of Stanford University, died yesterday at his campus home of throat cancer. He was 56 years old. Mr. Pratt was secretary of the Harvard Alumni Association from 1949 to 1956.

Not all worthy causes are lost at the United Nations. From' the beginning, one of the notso-fringe benefits of life at the big house on the East River was the morning croissant, warm, buttery, not quite so flaky as the very best in Paris but better than many found in boulevard cafes these days.
The Vatican warned Roman Catholic bishops everywhere today against publicly voicing any dissent from the views held by the Pope and by their fellow bishops.

The Urban. Mass Transportation Administration in Washington announced a grant of more than $23-million for improved mass-transit facilities in the Philadelphia area that officials expect will divert 8,000 auto commuters from the highway corridor between Philadelphia and Camden.
The deficit in the United States balance of international payments declined further in the first quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Disabled American Veterans is seeking a permanent injunction to enjoin the Federal Government from closing in March the 1,500-bed St. Albans Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens.

More than 50 agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation seized approximately 5,000 "bootleg" pop-music tape cartridges and more than $500,000 worth of duplicating equipment yesterday in raids on 10 New Jersey bootleg-tape factories, United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern announced today.
Thousands of physicians, teachers and students went on strike today to protest against the Allende Government's handling of the 63day copper workers' strike at the nationalized Teniente mine.

Pat Bradley of Florida International University broke a 43-year-old course record with a one-under-par 73 despite a two-stroke penalty today to take the opening-round lead in the Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women's national gold championship.
Traders in grains and soybeans decided to take profits or pay up on their losses yesterday as they awaited some action by Washington on the problem of how to deliver commodities under a price freeze.

James Reardon, former general superintendent of the Universal Terminal and Stevedoring Company, died today at his home. His age was 72. Mr. Reardon had been a prominent figure on the Brooklyn waterfront since 1933, when he joined the company.

A 12th crew member of the amphibious transport dock Ogden charged with disobeying orders while minesweeping off North Vietnam pleaded guilty today and was sentenced to 45 days' hard labor, United States Navy officials reported.

Jose Rivera, who is 12 years old and is here to sing for Pope Paul VI with the Newark Boys Chorus in the Vatican on Saturday, has had a look at the Eternal City and has found it exactly the way he had imagined it.

Intensive Soviet news coverage of the Washington summit meeting appears to be generating an ill-defined air of expectancy that the BrezhnevNixon camaraderie on the television screen may ultimately translate into a better life for the average Russian.

Governor Rockefeller promised yesterday to try to restore the state's death penalty for murderers of peace officers and prison guards. Capital punishment, he said, is "vital" as a deterrent to such crimes.
H. P. Hood, Inc., will invest about $9-million in expansion over the next two fiscal years, John M. Fox, president, said in the company's annual report sent to stockholders yesterday.

Melvin R. Laird, the former Secretary of Defense who has become President Nixon's chief domestic adviser, asked aides to seek information about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of the Florida East Coast Railway at the behest of the railroad's chairman, according to testimony at a closed hearing in Federal District Court here last Friday.

The Ducks Hockey Club, owner of the Long Island Ducks of the Eastern Hockey League, filed a $7.5-million antitrust suit yesterday alleging that certain major and minor hockey leagues have conspired since 1958 to monopolize ice hockey. The suit, filed in Manhattan Federal Court, also claims that the National Hockey League, along with the American, Central and Western Hockey Leagues, have attempted to prevent the Ducks from competing.

College students are not strangers to death--not in a time of drug abuse, not a few years after Kent State. But the campus murder of Patricia Sullivan has shaken her friends at C. W. Post College in a way they never imagined.

Intense fighting, the heaviest since the reaffirmation of the cease-fire last Friday, was reported yesterday in three areas of South Vietnam. While the fighting was heavy, the Saigon command said that the total number of incidents dropped yesterday.

Laird, the former Secretary of Defense who has become President Nixon's chief domestic adviser, asked aides to seek information about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of the Florida East Coast Railway at the behest of the railroad's chairman, according to testimony at a closed hearing in Federal District Court here last Friday.

The Los Angeles Dodgers have taken to growing mustaches and they say it has nothing to do with the success of last year's mustachioed Oakland A's.

The Leonid I. Brezhnev who came to Washington this week is a different man from the one who met President Nixon a year ago in Moscow. At home, among his Politburo colleagues, he was cordial but rather restrained and serious.
Egypt's proposal that a Palestinian state be created as part of an Arab political settlement with Israel drew strong opposition today from the Palestine Liberation Organization.

The lawyer for State Senator James M. Turner opened the defense case today with efforts to impeach the credibility of witnesses against the Gloucester Republican, who is accused of attempting to frame Assemblyman Kenney A, Gewertz with a narcotics charge.

Frederick C. LaRue, a Nixon campaign aide, accepted rent money and airplane rides from a failing housing company for which he interceded unsuccessful with the Administration, according to public records and interviews.

I wouldn't defend the people who are responsible and who took part in Watergate. I do think that it is being vastly overplayed. It was wrong but it should not be blown out of proportion. It was a stupid act and in violation of law.
We have here, in Paul Spike's "Photographs of My Father," an excellent example of why it sometimes pays for an aspiring young fiction writer to write nonfiction.
After many years of struggling with the problem, the American Reform rabbinate officially went on record today in opposition to Reform rabbis officiating at mixed marriages.

The question of whether or not to have best-in-show competition is raised periodically. Only one major allbreed fixture in the United States currently has no top award-Saw Mill, held every March at the Westchester County Center.
FROME, England-Through the slightly bowed Regency windows of Anthony Powell's living room comes the unchanging radiance of the Somerset countryside, and an occasional boom.

The suit, filed in Manhattan Federal Court, also claims that the National Hockey League, along with the American, Central and Western Hockey Leagues, have attempted to prevent the Ducks from competing.

The charge of "bail-but"--one that causes shudders in the Pentagon hierarchy--was injected today into the Congressional debate over the Defense Department plan to raise the price for continued production of the Navy's F-14 plane by the Grumman Corporation.

This discussion between Dan Rather, C.B.S. White House correspondent, and Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, was part of a C.B.S. News special report on the anniversary of the Watergate break-in.

A British Army major drove a postal truck containing a 150-pound bomb 600 yards along the dockside in the center of Londonderry today and pushed the vehicle into the River Foyle. Thirty seconds later, as the water short-circuited the timing device, the bomb exploded, sending the vehicle's doors 300 feet into the air.

A part-time assistant protessor of psychology who is also a student at Staten Island Community College and a divorced mother of two children were charged yesterday with the illicit manufacture and possession of amphetamine.
A Soviet diplomat's car, parked outside his summer home near the ocean in Far Rockaway, Queens, was destroyed by fire shortly before dawn yesterday.

Dmitri M. Segal is a young Soviet scholar of extraordinary brilliance and breadth of interest. His field is linguistics, but he has worked also on folklore and anthropology. He has written on language theory, on mythology, on the structure of Edward Lear's limericks.

The bright blue waters off this port were calm today, but oil was still troubling its citizenry. Monday night, Maine's Board of Environmental Protection put off for 180 days a decision on whether or not a huge oil refinery can be built in this harbor-an operation that some here see as the economic savior of a depressed city and others as the pillager of an unspoiled shore.

The Health Services Administration made public yesterday the names of 52 food-processing establishments it has charged with violations of the Health Code. The number is one less than the record total of 53 establishments cited on Tuesday for violations.
Controller Abraham D. Beame went into the subway yesterday morning to urge riders to put pressure on Governor Rockefeller to help the city maintain the 35-cent fare.

Following is the statement by Governor Rockefeller on his decision to discontinue planning for the Rye-Oyster Bay Bridge: After long and careful consideration and review of all the factors concerned, I have decided to discontinue plans for the construction of the Rye-Oyster Bay Bridge.
The rate of growth in personal income in the United States slowed in May for the third month in a row, the Commerce Department said today.
Advances exceeded declines for the first time in several sessions yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices closed slightly higher in dull trading.
The decade-old Battle of the Bridge will undoubtedly go down in history as one of the region's longest and hardestfought controversies over public works.
In the rush of business before the Connecticut General Assembly adjourned on June 1, a bill was lost. The bill provided for stiff, cumulative penalties for builders who violate local housing codes.

The Postal Service and all but one of four unions representing its 600,000 union employes have reached a tentative contract agreement providing for a 14 per cent wage increase over a two-year period and barring layoffs.

The appointment by the state of an arbitration board to rule impartially on the issues in the gravediggers' strike removes any excuse for prolonging this grisly tie-up. The State Legislature rightly recognized, by its passage of a compulsory arbitration law last month, that indefinite extension of such strikes menaces the public health and creates intolerable anguish for the bereaved.

Mrs. May Daniels Sandford of Fair Lawn, an assistant professor of home economics at Montclair State College, was married here this noon to Abner Gold of Springfield, editor of The Springfield Leader and The Mountainside Echo, weekly newspapers of the Suburban Publishing Corporation of Union.
A small, 125-year-old liberal arts college here is expected to abolish the tenure system, one of the most entrenched traditions in higher education.
John B. Connally, special unpaid adviser to the President, called a news conference at the White House today to deny reports that he was unhappy with the way he has been treated.

Chanting "Let my people go now," 800 people from Long Island interfaith groups staged an hour-and-15-minute vigil tonight outside the iron-barred gates of Killenworth, the Soviet Mission's residence here.
The Administration had already taken steps to nullify provisions of an important health bill before President Nixon signed it this week, a Congressional leader in health affairs charged today.
Commuting expenses for the average businessman and woman who tote briefcases to work every day have never been tax deductible since the Income Tax Act of 1913 went into effect.

Thomas J. Mackell, who resigned as District Attorney of Queens after he was indicted on charges of covering up a criminal investigation, was honored last night by 500 people at a dinner attended by two District Attorneys and several politicians.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation expects to be awarded contracts for new vessels running at an estimated $600-million to $750-million, John T. Gilbride, president, told shareholders at the 57th annual meeting here yesterday.

The stock market finished slightly higher yesterday in very dull trading after moving in a narrow price range throughout the session. The Dow-Jones industrial average reflected the trend of the market.

Melvin H. Osterman Jr,, the state's Director of Employe Relations, urged the members of the Legislature's Select Committee on Public Pensions here yesterday to adopt the agreement worked out between the state and the Civil Service Employes Association for all public employes.

The City Council has approved, without a dissenting vote, an amendment to the 1972-73 budget calling for the expenditure of $2,191,750 to pay for the city's first runoff primary, scheduled for next Tuesday. The vote, taken two days ago, was 35 to 0.

Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks in Westbury, L. I., and Mrs. Austin Straub, the defending champion from Rolling Hills in Wilton, Conn., reached the semifinal round of the 70th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.
Ess Eff, ridden by Jack 0. Sturgeon, broke from the inside post and held the lead all the way in winning the $27,975 Regret Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

The Annapolis-Newport yacht race concluded today as winners in the remainder of the five classes were determined and the slowest, most unlucky sailors dragged into port at the end of their 473-mile voyage that began Saturday.
The Administration had already taken steps to nullify provisions of an important health bill before President Nixon signed it this week, a Congressional leader in health affairs charged today.

The defending champion, Steve Ross of Brooklyn, defeated Bill Foreman of Belle Meade, 7-6, 6-2, and advanced to the round of 16 in the New Jersey state tennis championship today at the Arlington Players Club. Ross is seeded No. 1.
Edward L. McKeany, who established in 1949 the sugar brokerige company now known as McKeany-Flavell Company, Inc., lied Sunday at the age of 72.

Juan D. Peron returned to Argentina today, ending almost 18 years of exile, and violence among the more than one million people gathered to welcome him left at least 13 dead and more than 250 injured.
Prince Vsevolode of Russia, second in line to the Imperial throne, died here Monday of cancer. He was 59 years old. The Prince was smuggled out of Russia by his English governess when he was 3.
Because of repair work, the southbound Cross Island Parkway in Queens, between Bell and Northern Boulevards, will be closed weeknights between 9 P.M. and 5:30'A.M. beginning today.

The foods division of Anderson, Clayton Co., Houston, Tex., will curtail operations at two of its plants due to the price freeze, beginning next Wednesday. The move will result in some layoffs but the extent of the cutback and the number of layoffs has not yet been decided, the company said.

Max Barshis, an artist and designer, died following a heart attack May 28 on the Italian island of Ischia. He was 78 years old. Mr. Barshis's last work, a book of costume drawings called "The Common Man Through the Centuries," was published Monday.

The Soviet Union and the United States Export-Import Bank were reported close to a final agreement today on the extension of $180-million in credits to help finance the construction of a Soviet-American fertilizer complex in the Soviet Union that could lead to as much as $8-billion in trade over 20 years.

The outgoing school board in District 1 on the Lower East Side adopted two changes in its bylaws last night in the hope of making it more difficult for the newly elected board to remove Luis Fuentes, the controversial superintendent of the district.

The Literary Guild of America and Nelson Doubleday, Inc., owners and operators of some 32 book clubs and reading programs, have agreed to discontinue false advertisements stating that hooks offered for sale can be purchased at nominal charge without fulfilling any other conditions or obligations.

Representative Shirley Chisholm, working behind the scenes with uncharacteristic anonymity, supervised a Congressional office that served as the command post in the successful fight to extend the House's minimum-wage legislation to include domestic workers.
A 24-year-old Air Force officer from New Hampshire has been ordered discharged as a conscientious objector by a United States District Court judge.

Gov. Edwin W. Edwards said today that he had signed a bill restoring the death penalty in Louisiana, but added: "I have serious reservations in my mind as to whether or not the United States Supreme Court would hold any bill which provides for capital punishment constitutional."
Borden R. Putnam, who retired in 1963 as vice president and executive director of the overseas operations of Newsweek magazine, died yesterday at his home here. He was 78 years old.
At 9:01 A.M., Eastern Daylight Time, today the sun will reach its most northerly point, relative to the earth's surface, and summer will commence.
A 7 1/2 per cent Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company price increase on polyvinyl chloride packaging films was suspended today in line with President Nixon's price freeze, the company said.

Egypt's proposal that a Palestinian state be created as part of an Arab political settlement with Israel drew strong opposition today from the Palestine Liberation Organization. The proposal was made last week at the United Nations by Egypt's Foreign Minister, Dr. Mohammed H. el-Zayyat, during the Security Council's debate on the Middle Eastern situation.

Mrs. John N. Mitchell said today that she was urging her husband to disclose whatever he knows about White House involvement in the Watergate scandal, no matter who is concerned, and that she still thinks President Nixon should resign.

Following, in unofficial translation from the German, is the text of the treaty initialed here today by West Germany and Czechoslovakia and the texts of accompanying letters on criminal law and on the status of Berlin.
First-ranked Alex Mayer of Stanford defeated David Richardson of Appalachian, 6-2, 6-3, in today's fourth round of the National Collegiate tennis tournament reducing the field to 16.

Hank Aaron, the Atlanta outfielder, 23 shy of tying Babe Ruth's record of 714 career home runs, had a cyst on his abdomen lanced tonight and is expected to miss all three games of the Braves series against the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. reaffirmed his "firm opposition" to a state income tax today in a gubernatorial and legislative campaign platform released here by New Jersey's Republican party.

The Senate investigating committee has received sharply divergent reports about when President Nixon first knew about White House involvement in the Watergate burglary and cover-up. A White House account asserts that John W. Dean 3d withheld all information from the President until March 21.

There is a slightly loony streak running through Gay Delanghe's choreography that gives it special distinction. She manages to be earnest and flighty, humorous and dead serious, strict and permissive by unexpected turns. She presented her witty, evening-long "Limb Literal" on Monday at the Cubiculo.

A huge lake dammed up by an advancing glacier in a remote Central Asian mountain valley broke through its ice barrier today, producing a flash flood that caused heavy damage but apparently no casualties.
With a men's boycott in force at the devalued Wimbledon tennis championships starting Monday, the women now are turning militant.

An important New York City source of Afro-American history will be augmented under' a bill signed into law today by Governor Rockefeller. It is the Schomburg Collection in the Countee Cullen Branch of the New York City Public Library, in Harlem.

Feminist leaders and professional writers' groups met yesterday at the Drake Hotel to rally support for three women writers in Portugal who are facing trial next month because of their book "New Portuguese Letters." Sales of the book were prohibited by the Lisbon Government early this year.

The Annapolis-Newport yacht race concluded today as winners in the remainder of the five classes were determined and the slowest, most unlucky sailors dragged into port at the end of their 473-mile voyage that began Saturday.
An autopsy revealed today that the two men who died aboard the Smithsonian Institution research suomarine Johnston Sea-Link were killed by carbon dioxide poisoning.

Alex Rose, vice chairman of the Liberal party, yesterday characterized as "perhaps not illegal but certainly immoral" reported Republican attempts to subsidize Liberal candidates in key Assembly districts last year in efforts to draw off votes from Democratic candidates.

Where does the system break down," he continued, "when concern for what is right... is never asserted?"
High-school dropouts here who earn a state equivalency diploma will now also be entitled to a city high school diploma under a measure adopted last night by the Board of Education.

The National Genetics Foundation announced yesterday the development of a laboratory test to detect acute intermittent prophyria, an inherited disorder of body chemistry whose symptoms are brought on by some commonly used drugs.
A Greek freighter sank off the coast of Lower California in northwestern Mexico today after colliding with another vessel in dense fog, the Coast Guard said. No casualties were reported.
Lucien Laurin is "ready, able and willing" to send the Meadow Stable's champion, Secretariat, into a proposed three-horse race at Arlington Park near Chicago a week from Saturday.
With the reopening of Route 4 from Cambodia's seaport, Kampong Som, to Phnom Penh, the first truck convoy in 18 days arrived here today without incident.

Nikki Pilic, a man made famous by "tennis politics," went home to Yugoslavia today. The player at the center of the Wimbledon boycott, said, "I would be ready to return to London at a moment's notice and play if this thing could be resolved.

Justice Theodore B. Kupferman, of the Appellate Division yesterday granted a request of four commercial landlords and continued in effect a stay that bars the press and public from examining income and expense statements filed by landlords seeking tax reductions.

A White House account of President Nixon's conversations this year with John W. Dean 3d charges that Mr. Dean, despite constant pressure from the President, withheld from Mr. Nixon all information about White House involvement in the Watergate burglary and cover-up until March 21.
On June 8, a fire broke out in a hotel linen closet here near rooms occupied by a Soviet delegation that helped plan the current visit of Leonid I. Brezhnev.

In the coming week, Governor Rockefeller will act on a bill that would allow Mae Neustadt to sue the state for her allegedly wrongful confinement in Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane for 40 years.

E. Howard Hunt Jr. has told the Senate's Watergate investigating committee that a White House aide ordered him to fly to Milwaukee and search the apartment of Arthur H. Bremer shortly after Bremer had made an attempt on the life of Gov George C. Wallace of Alabama last year, according to a source close to Hunt.
The investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers said yesterday that it had opened a representative office in Tokyo to capitalize on the ties in the Far East.

A special commission of the Democratic National Committe charged with reforming the selection of Vice-Presidential candidates met here today and selected an 18-member executive committee to review reform proposals.

MANCHESTER, Vt.-Forty years ago, armed with a clumsy, :floppy bamboo rod and a thin braided line intended for baitcasting, I set forth to master the art of flyfishing. At the end of my first day I was singularly depressed.

After two years of study and reports of some adverse reactions, the Food and Drug Administration has proposed that labels for all vaginal deodorant sprays carry warnings on usage and possible problems.
United States crop production will probably rise substantially this year while net farm income leaps to another record of more than $22-billion, Agriculture Department economists said today.

Bad debt losses of United States corporations are approaching the $6-billion mark, Dun Bradstreet, reported yesterday. For all incorporated industries, losses averaged 0.38 per cent of sales in the fiscal year ended July 1, 1970, or a total of $5.87-billion. The estimate is based on data from recently released Internal Revenue Service reports covering a sample of Federal tax returns filed by 1.7 million corporations.
June A Mexican DC-9 jetliner flying from Houston to Mexico City with 27 persons aboard struck a mountain peak on Mexico's Pacific Coast lastnight and exploded.
Circuit Judge William Herin has upheld the conviction of Ber nard L. Barke. a Watergate burglar, on charges of misusinga notary public seal.

Lawrence Mitchner died a few days ago. The death certificate said heart attack. His old friend, Bill Neeld, who managed the Xenia Funeral Home, said "he just wore out," and privately speculated about the effects of stress and unnaturalness hissolitary protest as the last man of New Burlington brought him.
Herman N. Liberman Jr. has recently completed a sev en-year walking tour of Man hattan. Mr. Liberman, who is a 62 year-old member of the New York Stock Exchange, haslived in the city all his life.

The Nixon Brezhnev agreements on the limitation of strategic offensive arms and the joint development of peaceful atomic energy promise a great deal more than they deliver, but at least they maintain the spirit of cooperation.
Gunmen shot a Protestant teen-ager be tween the eyes and dumped his body on a Belfast street late last night hours after booby trap bombs killed two Britishsoldiers.

Three men and a woman were arrested yesterday on charges of running what Dis trict Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn called a "drug bou tique" in an expensively fur nished home in the Mill Basinsection.
Harry W. Marsh, a former Commissioner of Public Wel fare and Civil Service Commis sioner under Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died Tuesday at the James C. King Home here.His age was 85.
The element lithium, which in, compounds has proved valu able as a drug for some psy chiatric problems, has also proved useful in treating some alcoholics, a scientist reportedhere today.
Four Nassau County commun ities last night approved library and school budget proposals. The Sewanahaka school dis trict approved a $25,897,083 education budget by a vote of2,753 to 1.551.

A former high-ranking pris oner of war, Adm. James V. Stockdale, has filed miscon duct charges against two-other officers who were with him in North Vietnamese prison camps, Pentagon sources saidtonight.

Fairleigh-Dickinson University has rejected a proposed exchange of 100 acres of Meadowland for its present 15-acre campus in Rutherford. Town leaders had hoped to take over the college campus and use it for its high school. Henry Becton, a university trustee, told representatives from the Town Council and the Board of Education that the "financial exigency" that existed at the university hadforced the decision.

An initial public offering of 1,000,000 common shares of Circle Income Shares, Inc., a new closed end diversified management investment company whose investment adviser will be the American Fletcher National Bank and Trust Company, a sun sidiary of the American Fletcher Corporation, $15 a share was made yesterday by Goldman Sachs; Hayden Stone; Thomson McKinnon Auchincloss; Robert W.Baird; and the Ohio Company.

A swift-moving attend ant at a busy all-night serv ice station on the north-south Motorway of the Sun filled a gas tank early this morning, checked the oil, wiped the windshield and with a grin told the traveler: "This is thehottest spot in all Italy."
The dollar weakened slightly in Europe today, while gold inched ahead. Trading was light, partly be cause Frankfurt and some other markets were closed forthe Corpus Christi holiday.

Pat Dobson made his second start as a Yankee last night as the Detroit Tigers tried to slip a Mickey (Lolich) past the first-place New Yorkers in the opener of their five-game series at Yankee Stadium before 14,940 paid fans.
The Board of Estimate, after nearly three hours of public hearing last night on a proposal to establish a mall on Madison Avenue, agreed to postpone a decision on the controversialplan until July 10.

President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev pledged the United States and the Soviet Union to day to accelerate negotiations so that a permanent treaty on limiting each side's offensive strategic weapons could be achieved by the end of nextyear.

Stanford placed two men today in the California dominated semifinals of the Na tional Collegiate Athltic Asso ciation tennis tournament. The fifth and quarterfinal rounds were played on Princeton University's indoor courts.
Trading in soybeans and soy bean meal for delivery over the next three months was halted yesterday by the Chicago Board of Trade following a request bythe Government.

The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn announced yesterday that it would close 10 of its elementary schools next fall. The parish schools--nine in Brooklyn and one in Queens-have a combined enrollment of 4,000 pupils and will be merged with 20 of the other 191 elementaryschools in the diocese.

Former President Juan Domingo Peron tonight called for unity in his movement and in the country in the wake of the serious shootings that broke out yesterday as throngs hailedhis homecoming.

Corrections Commissioner John O. Boone resigned under fire to day and Gov. Francis W. Sar gent ordered the state policeinto Walpole State' Prison.
Consumer prices continued to rise steeply in May, although the increase was a little less than in the two preceding months, the Labor Departmentreported today.

The board of directors of the striking Writers Guild of Amer ica voted unanimously today to accept a contract offered by the Association of Motion Pic ture and Television Producers. It will be submitted to themembership Sunday.

Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr, of Connecticut, a Republican member of the Senate Water gate committee, defended today the credibility of John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel, and charged that the Nixon Ad ministration had "stepped on" anyone willing to search forthe truth about Watergate.
Mrs. John N. Mitchell, left her Fifth Avenue apartment yesterday in a station wagon loaded with suitcases. She has complained of being besieged by newsmen.
As part of a new crack down on midtown parking violators, 20 police officers, each accompanied by a su perior, were directed to issue 2,000 summonses yesterdayand 2,000 today.
The ship's bell on tiny Pitcairn Island in the South Pacific tolled 77 times today marking the passing of another descendant of themutineers of H.M.S. Bounty.

While more than 1,000 school lunch workers demonstrated outside the Board of Education offices yesterday, school and union officials reached a con ditional agreement that will ap parently save the jobs of 48 "annual" employes who face dismissal today because olbudget cuts.

Shortly after the June 1967 Arab-Israeli war, President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia called for an end to the Arab countries' state of belligerency against Israel, denouncing the Arab position as a "dead-end policy." His was a voice in the wilderness. A few days later at the Khartoum Conference, which Mr. Bourguiba boy cotted, other Arab leaders proclaimed a continuing policy of "no peace with Israel, no negotiations with Israel, norecognition of Israel...."
The State Welfare Inspector General assailed the Human Re sources Administration's wel fare reform program yesterday as a "myth" and a costlybungle.
The British Land Company, Ltd., announced yesterday that its United States subsidiary would make a cash tender offer for all outstanding common stock of the Uris Buildings Corporation.
Jan Mactier's Chris topher Robin, who had a brief career with the United States Equestrian Team, was a double winner today at the opening session of the four-day Middlesex County Horse Show.

Under the new atoms-for-peace agreement signed today at the White House, the United States and the Soviet Union plan to broaden their cooperation in the peaceful development of atomic energy with particular emphasis on new types of nuclear power plants.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has chosen Sally Quinn, a Washington Post reporter with no previous television ex perience, to co-anchor its forth coming revamped morningnews program.

A Thai citizen was convicted here yesterday of smuggling more than 44 pounds of pure heroin, with an estimated street value of $14.4-million, Sukit Benjatarupong of Bangkok was found guilty by United States District Judge Manuel L. Real.Sentencing was set for July 16.

George Hendrick is for real. The Cleveland outfielder proved it again yesterday by smacking a two-run home run, his 10th in the last 14 games and fifth in his last 10 times at bat, to lead the Indians to a 9-1 victory overthe Brewers in Milwaukee.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a receipe. Dilled cabbage rolls Glazed carrots Waldorf salad

The reminders of Patricia Sul livan's murder were everywhere on the C.W. Post College cam pus today--from the electric sweeper being used to seek clues in the shrubbery to the detectives who questioned her friends and eavesdropped on conversations about the. 21year-old junior.
a 22-year-old housewife who was raped yesterday by a fugitive pretending to be a po liceman shot him to death when he threatened her children, according to the police.
Mrs. Patricia Allen Short, a stockbroker with White, th Weld Co., Inc., was married here yesterday afternoon to Philemon Edwards Truesdale, president of the TruesdaleChemical Sales Company, Inc.

Testimony given to State Attorney Gen- A eral Louis J. Lefkowitz names two top assistants to the Assem bly Speaker and the Assembly majority leader as Republican officials who aided in the print ing and mailing of campaign material portrayed as Liberal, a source close to the investigation said yesterday.
The National Broadcasting Company has requested a full Federal Communications 'Com mission review and reversal of the agency's staff ruling that the N.B.C. News special "Pensions:
The rabbinic body of American Re form Judaism has called for unconditional amnesty for Viet nam war resisters. It was the first such action taken by amajor Jewish religious group.

Nikki Giovanni, the black poet who wrote that she "used to dream militant dreams of taking' over America to show these white folks," took over Phil harmonic Hall last night to celebrate her 30th birthday and "share some joy-let the young take over the burden of that kind of confrontation."

After a postponement of more than a month, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority hopes to be able to bring a bond issue of more than $200 million to market next week, but' underwriting officials doubt that the move can be made thatquickly.
The Ulster County Social Services Department today de cided to let a white couple keep two black foster children, averting a planned demonstra tion in this Catskill Mountaincommunity.

Stanford placed two men today in the California dominated semifinals of the Na tional Collegiate Athltic Asso ciation tennis tournament. The fifth and quarterfinal rounds were played on Princeton University's indoor courts.

President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev agreed to accelerate negotiations on a Soviet American pact limiting offensive strategic weapons so that a permanent treaty could be achieved before 1975. After signing the agreement setting guidelines for delegations meeting in Geneva, the two leaders joked and clinked champagne glasses at the WhiteHouse ceremonies.
New orders for durable goods rose by $525-million, or 1.3 per cent, to $41.86-billion in May after seasonal adjustment, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The Midsummer Night's Quilting Bee, billed as the bee to produce the longest quilt in the world, almost pro duced the shortest yesterdayafternoon.

The temporary injunction issued by a state Supreme Court justice is admirably designed to safeguard the interests of tenants, landlords and building service employes in the mess created by City Council's repeal of. the formula for establishing fair rents in 1.2 millionrent-controlled apartments in this city.

A high official of the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare described today as "totally false" the charge of a Con gressional leader in health affairs that Administration poli cies would doom several im portant health programs forthe poor.

The Na tional Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, which has been go ing into the aluminum business in recent years, is quietly con ducting negotiations with the Soviet Union for a Russian process that may help open up newly discovered mineral de posits in the Western United States for the making of aluminum.
A shipper from the Middle Atlantic circuit, Pamela Fir man's Nalees Folly, registered a smashing upset in the fea ture race at Aqueduct yesterday.
The Skylab 1 astronauts were making final preparations early today to leave their orbiting space station and return to earth, ending their record 28day mission.

Operations of General Mills, Inc., in the fiscal year ended May 27 resulted in record sales and earnings and the largest annual gains in the company's 45-year history, the unaudited preliminary statement disclosedyesterday.
As part of a new crack down on midtown parking violators; 20 police officers, each accompanied by a su perior, were directed to issue 2,000 summonses yesterdayand 2,000 today.

Four matted artists called The Disciples - nobody explained whose, but definitely not Beethoven's-hit it, like wow, with two electric guitars, piano and traps. A trotting horse named Sound of Music standing immediately in front of them bared his teeth and drooled.

Mrs. Austin Straub of Roll ing Hills, the defending cham pion, and Mrs. Walter Cooper- in stein of Glen Oaks, the 1962 titleholder, will meet in the 36 hole final of the 70th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament tomorrow at theEssex County Country Club.

A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Pay Board erred last year in cutting back a de ferred cost-of-living wage in crease for 120,000 aerospace workers and ordered the Cost of Living Council to reopen thecase.

Sweeping recommendations de signed to quiet the din of jet aircraft at airports around the country were made public to day by an Environmental Pro jection Agency study group. The proposals were quickly as sailed in statements by pilots and airport and airline execu tives as potentially unworkableand, in some cases, unsafe.

Leo Marder, president of the Matson Manufacturing Com pany, Long Island City, Queens, until his retirement in 1967 died today at the Hollywood Memorial Hospital. His age was 79, and he lived in Hallandalenear here.

The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase all So cial Security benefits by 5 1/2per cent, starting next Jan. 1.

Mobil Oil announced yes terday that, because of the energy situation, it was stop ping all of its gasoline ad vertising. So long, Mr. Dirt. Mobil will, however, con tinue to advertise but it will be "toward broad public-serv ice and public-information programs covering the con servation of gasoline and specific suggestions on more efficient use of availableenergy."

The Na tional Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, which has been go ing into the aluminum business in recent years, is quietly con ducting negotiations with the Soviet Union for a Russian process that may help open up newly discovered mineral de posits in the Western United States for the making of aluminum.

Edward E. Fitzgerald has been named president and chief operating officer of the Book-of-the-Month Club, Inc. Mr. Fitzgerald, a 53-year-old former president of the Mc Call Publishing Company and editor-in-chief of the Literary Guild of America, joined Book-of-the-Month asa vice president in 1971.
Johnny Winter stopped his Madison Square Garden show last Saturday to upbraid the audience for throwing things at him-cardboard hotdog holders, items of clothing andthe like.
The Government's Committee on In terest and Dividends announced today a significant relaxation in the amount of dividends that many companies can pay totheir stockholders.

In the five months since the signing of the Vietnam cease fire, the United States has bombed Cambodia as heavily as it did in the preceding three years, according to Pentagonstatistics just made public.
The 1974 target date that Presi dent Nixon and Leonid I. Brezh nev have set for a permanent treaty on offensive-arms con trols seems the key to their efforts to put limits on thecostly arms race.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials rose to 172.1 from 171.3-R last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stoodat 118.7 on June 20, 1972.
Dave Wottle, known for his habit of running with a white golf hat, ended up with skinned legs Wednesday night after chasing and catching a souvenir hunterwho grabbed his cap.

Hornblower Weeks-Hemp hill, Noyes, a large member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, demanded yesterday that the exchange's board of directors investigate and take disciplinary action against Ed wards Hanley, another mem ber firm, for spreading false rumors about Hornblower's financial status.

The beginning of construction of a Transit Authority substa tion has threatened to under mine months of sensitive nego tiations between the city and 37 families being relocated in the Northside section of Brook lyn to allow a manufacturer to expand so that he can remainin the city.
Thomas L. Perkins, a lawyer and cor porate executive, died today in United Hospital, Port Chester, after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 603Purchase Street.
Edgar Woog, who helped organize Communist parties in Mexico and in this country, died yesterday. Hewas 75 years old.

To the Editor: Thirty-four states, with the United States and Canada participating, will meet to discuss peaceful coexistence next month in Helsinki at the Confer ence of States on European Security and Cooperation. The importance of this conference for world peace can-if successfulbecome momentous in this century.

Three defense witnesses testified to day that State Senator James M. Turner, who is on trial on charges of conspiring to frame a fellow legislator on a nar cotics offense, has a reputationfor honesty and truthfulness.
Frank Leahy, coach of many of the University of No tre Dame's winning football teams, died shortly after noon today at Good Samaritan Hospital. He was 64 years old.
An F-14 Tomcat fighter plane shot itself down over the Pacific on Wednesday with a Sparrow air-to-air missile that evidently was erratically launched, the Navy said yesterday.

The bankrupt Penn Central Railroad is back on Capitol Hill, rattling its tin cup for Federal cash to keep the trains running. The acuteness of the Pennsy's financial crunch is beyond argument, but giving its trustees a big bundle of Government funds would merely unlockthe Treasury vaults for an endless drain.

Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., moving quickly to gain a foothold with the Republican leadership in north ern New Jersey that has traditionally opposed him, has asked Webster B. Todd, the party state chairman during the nineteen-sixties, to become chairman of the Republicanstate finance committee.

One day after a proposal by Teddy Brenner, the director of boxing for Madison Square Garden, that would create American championships in 10 weight divisions, the New Jersey State Athletic Commission got into the act yesterday. Commissioner Abe J. Greene announced that the bout on Saturday night in Atlantic City between Ernie Terrell and Chuck Wepner would be for the Americanheavyweight championship. Under the designation,

The Supreme Court today re versed a lower court and up held a New York State law that requires able-bodied wel fare recipients to demonstrate that they have sought employ ment or be put to work onpublic-works projects.

Joseph G. Abramson, a prom inent lawyer in this city for more than 65 years and a direc tor of the Sterling National h Bank and Trust Company, died yesterday at his home, 710 ParkAvenue. He was 89 years old.
Security guards at Moun tainside Hospital, where 300 nonprofessional workers are on strike, are checking visitors to the institution's parking lot as a result of two tire-slashing incidents there.
Winning numbers drawn on June 21 were: NEW YORK 281913 Tickets matching the num ber above win $50,000. Tick ets matching the last fivenumbers win $5,000.

Donn Barber, who for more than 40 years had been with the American Mail Line of Seat tle and its predecessor, the American Hawaiian Line, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 62 years old.
Street battles broke out tonight be tween leftist militants hurling gasoline bombs and riot police men who were protecting a right-wing meeting. At least 76 policemen were injured, onecritically.

Senator Harrison A. Wil liam Jr. Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the Securi ties subcommittee, said today he would introduce a bill calling for the elimination of stock cer tificates in inter-broker transactions by 1976.
President Pompidou and Chan cellor Willy Brandt began a de tailed two-day review of Com mon Market problems and other European issues today atGymnich Castle near here.

Gunfire, bombings and fighting, along with strikes supporting and opposing the Marxist-led Government, threw Chile into new turmoil today. President Salvador Allende Gossens, a Marxist, said in a speech: "Civil war must beavoided."
Andres Gimeno of Spain, the defending South of England tennis champion, lost today, 9-8, 9-7, to Onny Parun of New Zealand in the quarterfinals.

Leo Marder, president of the Matson Manufacturing Com pany, Long Island City, Queens, until his retirement in 1967 died today at the Hollywoo Memorial Hospital. His age was 79, and he lived in Hallandalenear here.

Elizabeth J. McCormack an nounced today that she had submitted to the board of trustees her resignation as president of Manhattanville College, to take effect at the end of the the 1973-74 academic year.

Nine member firms have been placed under special, intensive surveillance by the New York Stock Exchange because of fi nancial difficulties and some of them probably will have to be liquidated, a Big Board official disclosed yesterday.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's hard-line approach toward Chile has been sharply disputed within the company, according to sources knowledgeable aboutthe internal situation there.

Critics of the extended investigations of the Water gate scandals have largely based the case for a speedy end to the proceedings on their fear that the Presidency might be dangerously weakened. A most persuasive reply to such arguments has now been made, however unin tentionally, by Mr. Nixon himself as he has publicly retreated from his earlier tough stand on the fundingof at least some domestic programs.
Governor Rockefeller today vetoed bills passed by the Legislature that would have increased benefits for a variety of New York City employes and for employes of other local governments.

There are only about 200 members of El Molo, a tribe in Kenya, and there are approximately the same number of solar astronomers in the United States.

Donn Barber, who for more than 40 years had been with the American Mail Line of Seat tle and its predecessor, the American Hawaiian Line, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 62 years old.

Standing in their neat blue columns, their faces solemn, their posture proud and stiff, hundreds of New York City policeman lined both sides of the street in front of Our Lady of the Snows Church in Floral Park, Queens, yes terday morning for the funeral of Officer Ralph Stanchi.
George Washington won the Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship yesterday by defeating Cardozo, 4-3 at the Yankee Stadium.
Rican sportsmen reportedly have offered the heavyweight champion, George Foreman, $1 million to meet Jose Manuel Urtain, a Basque from Spain,a title bout here or in Madrid.

For some it may seem as incongruous to invite the present writer to a Shaw festival as to in vite a Montague to a Capu let ball, a poacher to a game preserve or a Mets fan to the mysteries of the Mary lebone Cricket Club Lords in London.

The investigation of election time alliances between Republi cans and Liberals to insure the election of Republican Assem blymen points up the increas ingly close ties between the G.O.P. and Liberals despite the ideological gulf between the parties.

Frederick E. Bell, a former vice president and executive as sistant to the president of Prentice-Hall, Inc., the publish ing company in Englewood Cliffs, died yesterday at his home, 2100 Linwood Avenue.He was 79 years old.

A New Jersey man who was asked to resign from the United States Naval Academy a week before graduation when he applied to be a conscientious objector may be unable to accept a fellow ship at New York University Law School because the Navy has refused for two years to grant him his undergraduate degree.
Theodore W. Kheel yesterday complimented Governor Rocke feller for dropping his efforts to build a Long Island Sound bridge between Rye, in Westchester, and Oyster Bay, L. I.

Dr. Walter Eckstein, a leader in the American Ethical Union, a federation of Ethical Culture societies, died Tuesday at Midtown Hospital. His age was 81, and he lived at 3900 Greystone Avenue, the Bronx.

AREA A -- All-day party boats are enjoying great suc cess chumming for blues off Barnegat Ridge. Catches have been averaging 10 to 12 pounds, with a few 15 pounders hauled in. Half day boats report good fluke fish ing around Sea Girt, N. J. Bunkers and butterfish have attracted fluke in the seven pound range. In Barnegat Bay and in the ocean along the beaches flounders are being taken.
Interest rates continued to sweep higher yesterday in re sponse to the surging economyand resulting inflation.

Retail prices for the goods and services bought by people in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose again in May. But the rate of increase declined for the second consecutive month and was a shade less than the national increase, according to the Bureau ofLabor Statistics.

The United States yesterday gave its strongest indication that it was interested in some form of union of oil-consuming countries in light of the present and possible future tightness ofworld energy supplies.

Howard J. Samuels, who ran for Lieutenant Governor of the state in 1966 and who is ex pected to seek the Democratic nomination for Governor next year, urged yesterday that the state government help financepolitical campaigns.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose 82, 636 shares to 18.742 million in the period ended June 15, itwas reported yesterday.
The young set in fashion received recognition from the old guard as Calvin Klein, age 30, and Stephen Burrows, 29, were announced winners of the Coty American Fashion Critics' Awards for 1973.

President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev pledged the United States and the Soviet Union to day to accelerate negotiations so that a permanent treaty on limiting each side's offensive strategic weapons could be achieved by the end of next.year.

Era-less and perky, a girl in her late teens or early 20's paused with a start of surprise in front of Controller Abraham D. Beame, who was shaking hands the other day amid the calculated cacophony of a street stop outside the Church Avenue BMT station in Flatbush.
