The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judg ment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable estab lishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three asexcellent and four as superb.

A bleary-eyed House voted late tonight to create an independ ent corporation to provide legal services for the poor. But as passed-by a vote of 276 to 95-the bill bore only a faint resemblance to the bi partisan compromise that had reached the floor 11 hoursearlier.

Joseph G. Abramson, a prom inent lawyer in this city for more than 65 years and a direc tor of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, died yesterday at his home, 710 ParkAvenue. He was 89 years old.

E. Howard Hunt Jr. received a final cash payment of $72,000 in mid-March after he had warned John D. Ehrlichman that he was ready to "tell all" about the White House opera tions against Dr. Daniel Ells berg in 1971, sources close tothe Watergate case said today.
Thomas L. Perkins, a lawyer and cor porate executive, died today in United Hospital, Port Chester, after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 603Purchase Street.

For both Messrs. Nixon and Brezhnev, the commitment to Soviet-American cooperation came only in politicalmiddle age.
Dave Wottle, known for his habit of running with a white golf hat, ended up with skinned legs Wednesday night after chasing and catching a souvenir hunterwho grabbed his cap.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yester day after trading in a desultory fashion within a narrow rangefor most of the day.

Walter E. Amberg, who in vented more than 100 products and machines for the railroad, automotive and paper-products industries, died here yesterday at the age of 85. Mr. Amberg was the founder of the Universal Paper Products Company,
Robert S. Strauss, the Demo cratic National Chairman, has, for the first time, provided de tails about a mysterious burg lary at his Dallas home two weeks after the Watergatearrests.

The City Club of New York accused Jacod D. Fuchsberg yesterday of conducting a "de liberately misleading" adver tising campaign in his recent--and apparently successful--primary fight for the Demo cratic nomination for chiefjudge of the state.

Representative Herman Ba dillo conceded yesterday that he had asked Representative Mario Biaggi about possible support in the Democratic may oral primary runoff, but he de nied that he was seeking Mr.Biaggi's endorsement.

In this space on June 8, a favorable report appeared on a bill to finance Federal elections partially with Federal funds. A modest note from Senator Charles Mathias, Republican of Mary land, to whom authorship of the bill was attributed, states that Senator Adlai Stevenson, Democrat of Illinois, is in fact primarily responsible for developing the measure, of which Mr.Mathias is a co-sponsor.
It took one run that was dis puted and another that was a gift to send the New York Mets tumbling to their fourth straight defeat tonight as they bowed to the cellar-dwellingPittsburgh Pirates, 2-1.
This is the time of year that Dave Mercier used to love best:the beginning of summer.
The Midwest Stock Exchange said today that it and six Chicago banks had signed a memorandum of understanding to use the Midwest Securities Trust Company as a comprehensive securitiesdepository.
An air-traffic controller at MacArthur Airport was ar rested last night for trying to sell fireworks to a customer who turned out to be a SuffolkCounty plainclothes policeman.

The Supreme Court handed down today a new set of guide lines on obscenity that will en able states to ban books, mag azines, plays and motion pic tures that are offensive to local standards, even if they mightbe acceptable elsewhere.

The Michigan amateur champion, Bonnie Laurer of Michigan State, took the lead at the halfway mark in the national women's inter collegiate golf tournament to day with a 36-hole total of 151at Mount Holyoke Golf Club.

Bearish economic news helped weaken the stock mar ket yesterday as prices droppedsharply in sluggish trading.

The Evening Standard, an afternoon daily here, said today that the British publishers of Norman Mailer's biography of Marilyn Monroe had agreed to halt pub lication following an allegation that large sections were plagi arism from two earlier biographies of the actress.

The First National City Bank disclosed yesterday that it was trimming interest rates 15 per cent for the next month and a half on both personal and auto loans in a move it said was designed to make it "fully competitive with other banks"in the New York area.
Art Lefelar of Glen Ridge scored three straight birdies and finished with a 36, 37-73 to win the 46th Metro politan seniors championship today at the Mountain RidgeCountry Club.

Andres Gimeno of Spain, the defending South of England tennis champion, lost today, 9-8, 9-7, to Onny Parun of New Zealand in the quarterfinals.

The Soviet Union has bid "nearly $200,000" for an estate of several acres in the wooded, affluent suburb of Woodside on the San Francisco Peninsula. George Meriwether, realtor with Coldwell, Banker Co. of Atherton, confirmed the bid yesterday.

Johnny Miller is still hot. The man who shot a record 63 four days ago to win the Unit ed States Open, scored a hole in-one today and shared the first-round lead at 67 in the$160,000 American Golf Classic.

In an apparent counterattack in the current controversy over campaign practices, Governor Rockefeller has disclosed that state Republicans are filing charges that Democratic cam paigners failed to live up tothe law.

OXFORD, England-Breaking into embassies, as a White House official urged doing in papers leaked recently, is not new. During World War II, Great Britain slipped a safecracker into the Vichy French Embassy in Washington withthe help of an attache there.

A British Overseas Airways Corporation Boeing 747 jet car rying 153 passengers and a crew of eight skidded off a run way after landing at Kennedy Airport last night. Officials saidthere were no injuries.
Consumer prices continued to rise steeply in May, although the increase was a little less than in the two preceding months, the Labor Departmentreported today.

New York itself is still the best show in town, and one of its more appealing byways is the South Street complex of vintage ships and water front buildings, with enter tainment as an added, pierattraction.

Those countries which have not yet recognized the East German Democratic Republic areexpected swiftly to do so.

What no one knows, and many were wondering aloud this week, is just how the shattered pieces that remain can be reassembled into the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Precisely on time and on target, the three Skylab astronauts returned to earth Friday after having spent a record 28 days in space. These consequences of their 28 days under conditions of weightlessness were not unexpected.

Without New York's liberalized abortion law, there would be 24,000 additional children on the city's welfare rolls, according to a study of the impact of abortion reform released yesterday by the Health Services Administration. Retail clerks and the management of Two Guys discount department stores reached a tentative agreement yesterday to end a two-week-long strike at 48 stores on the East Coast. The pact was agreed upon after more than 13 hours of negotiations in the latest round at the Ramada Inn, in Clifton. n.

Eamon de Valera ended his public career this evening where he began it 57 years ago: at Boland's bakery, just across from the gasworks.

The Justice Department obtained yesterday a Federal Court order for the International Business Machines Corporation to show cause next Thursday why it should not be declared in contempt of a Federal Court order to hand over almost 1,200 business documents as pre-trial material in the Government's antitrust suit against I.B.M.
SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., June 25 (UPI)--George Hamilton Westmore, head of makeup at Universal Studios for 24 years, died of a heart attack Saturday night at his home here. He was 55 years old.
Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union overtook his compatriot Viktor Korchnoi today to share the lead in the Interzonal Tournament. zonal Tournament.
Leader of the largest Orthodox rabbinic body in the country today criticized "duplication, rivalry and wasteful fragmentation" in the institutions and programs of American Orthodox Judaism.

In a joint announcement Fiat Auto Works of Italy, the world's largest auto maker outside Detroit and Citroen of France, said today that Fiat had sold its 49 per cent interest in Pardevi, the holding company which controls Citroen, to the Michelin Tire Company, which held the remaining 51 per cent.

A special theater, rigged unlike any other in the city, will open here by mid-September to house a new form of entertainment in which most of the senses will be saturated with effects, beyond their capacity to take them in.
Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist party, U.S.A., yesterday confirmed reports in Moscow newspapers that he met with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, in Washington last week.
Raising the ceiling price on such products as chickens and eggs is one possible course of action if serious shortages develop, members of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers said today.
Senator James J. Buckley, the New York ConservativeRepublican, called yesterday for a four-part Federal investigation into charges of drug use and payola in the recording industry.

Italian authorities have issued a warrant for the arrest of Robert E. Hecht Jr., the American expatriate who sold a 2,500-year-old Greek vase to New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art last year for $1 -million.

Italian authorities have issued a warrant for the arrest of Robert E. Hecht Jr., the American expatriate who sold a 2,500-year-old Greek vase to New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art last year for $1-million.

Agents of the Internal Revenue Service fanned out through supermarkets, gasoline stations, pizza parlors and other stores in the city yesterday to check on compliance with the price freeze, which officially went into effect throughout the country at 11:59 P.M. Sunday.
Senator William Proxmire entered the dispute over the Navy's new F-14 fighter plane today by charging that the program had become a 'fouled-up mess" that should be terminated immediately.

Henry E. Petersen, while head of the Justice Department's criminal investigation of the Watergate case, passed information on grand jury testimony to the White House and arranged for high White House aides to be questioned outside the presence of the grand jurors, the Senate's Watergate committee was told today.

Gaylord Perry, the ace of the Indians' pitching staff, scattered nine hits and trumped the New York Yankees, 4-2 tonight to snap their longest winning streak since 1969 at eight games before a crowd of 18,670 in Cleveland Stadium.
The Soviet Embassy has been presented with 200 field-study grants by the Citizens Exchange Corps, an American nonprofit organization, it was announced yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today revoked the broker-dealer registration of Sanford Securities, Inc., New York, on charges the firm conducted business while insolvent without disclosing this to the public.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., yesterday reported a net loss for May of $1.8-million after a tax credit of $2.2-million, compared with a loss of $2.2-million after a tax credit of $2.7-million in May, 1972.

Minutes after 32-year-old Jose Diaz threatened in open court to kill the prosecutor, State Supreme Court Justice Harry Gittleson yesterday sentenced him to a minimum 35-year prison term for the attempted murder of three police officers and a love rival.

The Greyhound Leasing Financial Corporation, a unit of the Greyhound Corporation, said yesterday that it intended to make a cash tender offer of $4.50 a share for shares of its subsidiary, the Greyhound Computer Corporation.

In today's runoff primary, New York Democrats have the choice between Representative Herman Badillo, with his promise of a dynamic, socially progressive mayoralty, and Controller Abraham D. Beame, with the probability of four years of governmental stagnation at City Hall.

Herbert J. Relkin, the former Queens Liberal whose role in a suspected vote-siphoning scheme is under investigation by New York State officials, was suspended yesterday from his job as an accountant with the New Jersey State government.
Other former insiders have vaguely spoken of an "almost paranoid" mood in the Nixon White House and a fight-firewith-fire reaction that undercut respect for law.

State Athletic Commissioner Abe J. Greene directed today that a rematch be held "within short order" between Ernie Terrell and Chuck Wepner, whose heavyweight battle Saturday ended in a widely disputed decision for Wepner.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday announced the appointment of Almerin C. O'Hara, Commissioner of General Services, as over-all coordinator of the state's new program to deal with illicit drugs through toughened prison terms and enlarged treatment facilities.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands--Every day at 10 A.M., Dr. Vincent van Gogh enters a gray cube-shaped building on Amsterdam's broad Museum Square. He goes straight to work, which at the moment is editing the letters written between his uncle, also Vincent van Gogh, and a fellow artist, Paul Gauguin.

The Penn Central Company, parent company of America's biggest railroad that threatens to shut down this summer if it does not get massive financial help, wants to sue the United States for taking private property for public use.
More than 15,000 commuters were delayed today after eight cars and an engine of a Penn Central shore-line train derailed here early this morning.
Communist forces attacked Government positions in a wide arc around Phnom Penh today in some of heaviest fighting that the countryhas seen in weeks.

An agreement on plans to exchange military and civilian prisoners was announced today by the on Vietcong after a meeting with Saigon Government representatives. But a new deadlock soon developed, and further talks on the issue were scheduled for tomorrow.

The Congress of the United States has now served unequivocal notice on the President that it considers the continued warfare of American forces in Cambodia to be illegal, unjustified in the national interest and contrary to the will of the American electorate. This is a stirring and courageous gesture. It will stand as a turning point in the tragic saga of American military engagement in Southeast Asia.

The Agriculture Department announced today it has proclaimed a "deficit" in the 1973 sugar supply quota for the West Indies and Haiti and has reallocated to other countries the 67,891 tons of quota sugar which the two Caribbean countries will be unable to ship.

The White House attempted to cover up the relationship between high Presidential aides and Donald H. Segretti, a young California lawyer who reportedly led a broad campaign of political sabotage during last year's primary elections, John W. Dean 3d said today.

On a savagely hot patch of desert in Mexico's Baja California, the energy needs of nearly half a million people are being met without the use of gas, oil or coal and with virtually no pollution. For the people of Baja and the Mexicali Valley, the energy crisis has become someone else's problem.
The house passed and sent to the White House today a bill to authorize the Atomic Energy Commission to spend $2.43-billion in the next fiscal year, nearly half of it for military purposes.

Leonard Bernstein choked back tears under a barrage of congratulations tonight after the European premiere of his provocative Mass. His blend of burlesque, rock opera and traditional liturgy delighted most of the first-night audience at the sedate Konzerthaus, but it left many others perplexed.

Herman Badillo, the Bronx Congressman who looked like an unpromising fouth when the race for the Democratic nominiation for Mayor began, has received campaign contribution of $426,172 since May 25, according to reports filed with the Board of Elections.
The captain and two crewmen of a Philippine oil tanker were killed and two sailors were missing after explosions set fire to the vessel early today, port officials said here.

The Supreme Court struck down today as unconstitutional four programs of Governor Rockefeller and the New York Legislature to provide financial assistance to private schools, principally those of the Roman Catholic Church.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market tumbled yesterday in dull trading as reasons for traders to be optimistic continued to be scarce.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended June 19.
As John W. Dean 3d testified before the Senate Watergate committee today, the Senate by voice vote doubled to $1-million the money it had authorized for committee expenses.

The Pittsburgh Pirates, who had skidded to the bottom of the National League's Eastern Division standing, blasted four Montreal pitchers for 11 hits that produced an 8-6 victory in Montreal's Jarry Park last night.

Leading glamour stocks were pounded yesterday as the general market produced another drab showing amid the Watergate hearings and inflation jitters. The Dow-Jones industrial average, declining steadily through the session, fell 10.69 to finish at 869.13- its lowest close in 18 months. Transportation and utility issues also declined.
The port rolled out the welcome mat yesterday for a luxury liner fro the second time in her career. She was the 23,372-ton cruise liner Veendam of Holland America cruises.
The national Order of Elks will be destroyed, said Clifford R. Gasparini, head of the state association, unless the "whites-only" membership clause is removed.
Intellectual Rome is thrilled these days by the rediscovery of an artist whom many had condescendingly pigeonholed as "that painter of bottles."

OUTSIDERS The Metropolitan Opera returns today for its seventh year of free opera concerts in the city's parks. This year it will be doing Johann Strauss's "Fledermaus" and Giacomo Puccini's "Tosca" in concert version, without costumes or staging. Each opera will have four performances, and all boroughs will be visited.

A member of the Securities and Exchange Commission warned stock exchanges and third-market makers today against duplicating existing hardware and communications equipment for reporting last-sale prices in the projected central market system.

Leonid I. Brezhnev arrived here from the United States last night for two days of talks with President Pompidou. According to official French sources, Mr. Brezhnev took the initiative in arranging the meeting with President Pompidou immediately after his week of talks with President Nixon.

Canada's balance of payments showed a seasonally adjusted deficit of $293-million in the first quarter, up from a $53million deficit in the fourth quarter last year and a deficit of $304-million in the year-ago period, Statistics Canada reported today.

The profits of buildings products and materials concerns rose 64 per cent and sales increased 27 per cent during the first quarter of 1973, compared with a year ago, according to the F. W. Dodge Division of the McGraw-Hill Company.

Sir Lloyd Dumas, journalist and newspaper executive, died last night in Calvary Hospital, Adelaide, at the age of 81. As a young reporter in Adelaide, he helped to found the South Australian branch of the Australian Journalists Association.

The American swimmers and divers who toured China did not receive approval from the International Swimming Federation, which prohibits even exhibitions in non-member countries. France today fought for a harder Common Market line toward the United States on the reform of world trade and monetary systems.

CRANFORD, N. J. - Donald Ellenberg sipped a diet soda in the recreation room of his seven-room split-level house. The street outside, with its panoply of neat lawns, was almost as quiet as the noiseless air-conditioning.

State Senator James M. Turner, a Republican, denied on the witness stand today that he had lied, accepted money or conspired to frame Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, a Democrat, with a narcotics possession offense.

U.S. car sales in the June 11-20 period totaled 311,044 units, a record for the period and reversing a decline in the previous two selling periods. Sales in mid-June were up 55,324 from the 255,720 cars sold in the 1972 period.

The McDonald's Corporation postponed yesterday a secondary offering of about 600,000 common shares announced on May 17, with a market value of about $36.1-million, due to general market conditions. The hamburger chain's stock closed at 53 7/8, down 2 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

To the Editor: Food boycotts failed to bring down high prices. Price controls are a needed stopgap. But this and pressure on the Federal Reserve to tighten credit and raise interest rates are of only temporary benefit-palliatives, not a cure. It is time we dig deeper to find what is behind high prices.

Edward R. Mitton, former president and board chairman of the Jordan Marsh Company, died today at his home here. He was 77 years old. His father, George W. Mitton, and uncle, Richard Mitton, also had been president of the Boston based retail trade company.
Both candidates in the Democratic mayoral runoff predicted victory in public and exuded confidence in private yesterday. Some 600,000 Democrats will nominate one of

A state appeals court declared part of the 1918 Workmen's Compensation Law unconstitutional because it denied benefits to illegitimate grandchildren. The Appellate Division of the Superior Court said the law that provided benefits for illegitimate children, but not grandchildren, violated the equality clause of the 14th Amendement to the United States Constitution.

The Duro-Test Corporation introduced yesterday a new light bulb called "WattSaver," that consumes up to 10 per cent less watts of electrical energy yet provides the same amount of light as the conventional-wattage bulb of the same life.
Many of the most pointed accusations made by John W. Dean 3d today before the Senate Watergate committee fit neatly into the mosaic of direct and indirect evidence on the scandal.

President Nixon and his top White House aides, expressing fear of the "uncontrollable, if not hostile, forum" of the Senate, repeatedly attempted to obstruct and delay the proposed Senate Watergate investigation early this year, John W. Dean 3d testified today.
The future of the Jerusalem skyline-that natural ampitheater of undulating hills that encircles the walled Old City-has become a focus of a major debate here.

The wife of Andrei A. Amalrik, an imprisoned Soviet historian, has appealed to East and West European leaders to consider her husband's case at the European Security Conference opening in HelsinkI July 3.

As John W. Dean 3d testified at the Senate's Watergate hearing today, his wife, Maureen, whom he married eight months ago, sat behind him.

The Government reported today its first price rollbacks under President Nixon's June 13 freeze. The cost of Living Council said that 1,106 filling stations were found last week to be overcharging for gasoline, by an average of two cents a gallon, and had reduced their prices.

The Senate Judiciary Committee, winding up its hearings on the nomination of Clarence M. Kelley as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, heard witnesses today describe Mr. Kelley as both superbly qualified for the job and as "a bureaucratic machine insensitive to human compassion."

Thousands of people have been questioned by the police in six states in the search for the slayer of Patricia Ann Sullivan, a student at the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University, Edward F. Curran Nassau County chief of detectives, said today.

So much have Soviet-American relations improved in three years that the harmonious summit meeting of President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev in the last week is being taken as only a modest success, more important for promoting the climate of detente than for providing practical results.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who admitted he used influence last year to get himself paired with Arthur Ashe, will appear in the second annual Robert F. Kennedy pro-celebrity tennis tournament at Forest Hills on Aug. 25.

John L. Loeb Jr., a general partner and member of the management committee of Loeb, Rhoades Co., will become a limited partner in the investment firm at the end of this week so that he can devote more time to public affairs, especially environmental matters, he said yesterday.

Despite President Nixon's price freeze, food prices here resumed their upward climb last week. Consumer Affairs Commissioner Betty Furness's "market basket" of 37 foods would have cost $52.58 for a family of four for the week ended June 20, an increase of 28 cents over the week before.
Italians are once again savoring the familiar joys of having no cabinet-well, almost noneand hardly seem eager to get a new one quickly.

Prices of cattle, hogs, poultry and their by-products rose sharply yesterday on the big Chicago commodities exchanges. Traders attributed the strong markets in large part to the President's latest price freeze as well as to actions taken or planned by militant consumer groups.

In general,

John E. Dahlquist, former president of the Swedish American Athletic Club in Brooklyn and secretary of the John Ericsson Society, died Sunday at the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 74 years old and lived at 209 Underhill Avenue, Brooklyn.

In an affidavit filed in United States District Court today, an official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said that the bureau had not engaged in illegal wire tapping, burglary, sabotage, provocateurism or any other "unauthorized" activity while investigating Weatherman radicals now on trial here.
The Secret Service said today it was seeking a former Miami hotel worker with a history of mental illness for threatening the life of President Nixon.

A 14-foot bronze statue of Prospero and Miranda, two characters from Shakespeare's "The Tempest," was dedicated last night in Central Park to Joseph Papp, founder-producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

Livingston L. Wingate, executive director of the Urban League, told the graduating class of the Urban League Street Academies yesterday that they were "symbolic of the myth and lie that black kids cannot learn."

Miss Marion Elisabeth Modley was married here last Saturday afternoon to Max Schling 3d. The Rev. John Beaver performed the Episcopal ceremony at the lake's edge on the property of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Haken.

Steel production for the week ended Saturday totaled 2,881,000 tons, a decline of 1.7 per cent from the 2,932,000 tons in the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The index of production during June 23 week dropped to 118.1, against 120.2 in the preceding week.

A coalition of New Jersey antipoverty groups filed a Federal Court suit today in an attempt to force the Nixon Administration to release $270-million appropriated by Congress to operate summer Neighborhood Youth Corps programs around the country.

A 9-year-old Bronx girl was tossed to her death last night from the rooft of a 20-story tenement, according to the police. Shortly afterward, the arrested two 13-year-old boys on charges of juvenile delinquency involving rape, attempted robery and homicide.

Ten American swimmers and divers, who learned to use chopsticks and narrowly avoided an international incident, have returned after a three-week tour of China.

Larry Ellis, coach of track and cross-country at Princeton University, and the Ivy League's first black head coach when he was appointed in 1970, has been named head coach of the United States track team in the second annual Pacific Conference games in Toronto on Wednesday and Thursday. The Pan-Pacific competition involves teams from countries whose borders touch on the Pacific Ocean, and includes Australia, Canada, Japan, and Mexico and the United States.

The Times Square Theater Center, a nonprofit sales facility for last-minute distribution of unsold tickets on a "day - of - performance-only" basis, opened yesterday under what appeared to be auspicious beginnings.
Ed Ballinger of New York became the national foil champion last night by winning all his bouts in a six-man round-robin final. Ballinger scored 5-1, 5-2, 5-4, 5-1 and 5-0 victories.

Paddy Wilson, a leading Roman Catholic politician, was assassinated early today and his body left in a car beside that of a murdered woman. The Ulster Freedom Fighters, a newly emerged extremist Protestant underground organization, claimed responsibility for the double slaying and said, "There will be more deaths."
A team of top British officials left Salisbury today at the end of a surprise mission to determine the Rhodesian Government's attitude toward a settlement of the independence dispute with Britain.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who admitted he used influence last year to get himself paired with Arthur Ashe, will appear in the second annual Robert F. Kennedy pro-celebrity tennis tournament at Forest Hills on Aug. 25.

After a decade of now-up, now-down fortunes, the domestic furniture industry is on the crest of an up cycle. The symptoms are heavy factory backlogs, sharply increased prices instituted before the recent freeze, and, unfortunately for the consumer, longer delivery delays than ever.
A 37-year-old mother of 10 is being held in what officials say may be the largest single case of welfare fraud yet uncovered in the state.

An evening as Uncle Vanya might provide enough challenge and work for any usual actor, but Nicol Williamson--star of "Nicol Williamson's Late Show," which opened last night at the Eastside Playhouse, as well as a star of the Chekhov play at the Circle-in-the-Square - is far from the usual actor.
Twelve and a half years ago President Kennedy rode along Pennsylvania Avenue in his inaugural parade and, shocked by the thoroughfare's deteriorating appearance, vowed to transfrom it.

The city administration declared yesterday it would proceed with its welfare and Medicaid computerization "as rapidly as possible" and challenge a state notice that last week barred state reimbursement for future computerizing expenditures.

BUCHAREST - After an absence of a few years, a visitor's first impressions of this part of Europe indicate little change. When the Hungarian immigration official at the Budapest airport takes a passport through his teller's window, it immediately disappears from the traveler's view. The passport windows in Communist countries are arranged to provide an angle of vision that leaves the working part of the desk out of sight.
Every devotee of the stock market has seen it happen again and again. The market gains a little momentum only to fall back further than before.

The Commerce Department will appeal to the Senate to reverse a decision made by the House Appropriations Committee to scrap a program designed to update the population data collected in the 1970 census.

Douglas Dillon, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said yesterday that museum officials had concluded on the basis of available evidence that the Eupilronios vase bought last year for $1-million had not been smuggled out of Italy as contended by Italian authorities.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)--The Department of Labor, under pressure by farmers' groups and representatives from farm states, issued today revised pesticide regulations narrowing the scope of required safeguards for farm workers.
Robert T. Wieringa has been named president of the Warner- Lambert Company, effective on Sunday. He succeeds E. Burke Giblin, who will become chairman and continue as chief executive officer.

How the Senate Watergate committee handles its investigation in the coming days-particularly who it calls to the witness stand immediately after it finishes with John Dean-can be of critical importance to the opinion of the nation and the reputation of the President.
Egypt's President, Anwar elSadat, met the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Quaddafi, for seven hours today to discuss their plans to merge their nations by September, Government sources said.
A law reducing Superior Court juries in criminal cases in Connecticut from 12 members to six has come under renewed criticism from trial lawyers and civil libertarians here.
Four chemical companies accused by fishermen of contaminating the sea with mercury pledged today to suspend operations at the offending plants until fishermen's compensation demands are settled.

The Manhattan District Attorney's office disclosed yesterday that it had pulled front its raft of tax-assessment reduction applications the files of a number of commercial landlords that had aroused its curiosity.
In its second antiwar action in two days, the House of Representatives voted today to extend through Sept. 30 a proposed ban on the use of funds for United States bombing in Cambodia.

Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, said last night that President Nixon had violated his oath of office by ordering creation of an extralegal intelligence unit directed by the White House.

Four Senators and four House members and their wives will visit China July 2 to 16 to discuss "trade and other matters." The eight legislators, led by Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, will be the guests of the Chinese People's Institutefor Foreign Affairs.

An increase in military attacks by Communist forces was reported yesterday by the Saigon Government, but most of the actions were described as small.

" We're in a situation where the more we produce, the more we lose," said George Allen, farmer, after smothering 20,000 chickens. He said that soaring feed prices and a 60-day retail price freeze had forced him to destroy the chicks.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos has called on the Filipino people to convene in village assemblies beginning July 27 to discuss vital issues related to developments hare and abroad.
In the early hours of June 17, the resident of Room 533 of the Manhattan Towers Hotel staggered from the ninth floor into the elevator, his throat slashed open with a knife.

The Senate, 50 to 42, passed a scaled-down foreign military aid authorization bill today after rejecting a mandatory four-year phaseout of the program.
Mayor Lindsay formed a city task force yesterday for what was described as a last chance for his administration to plan the development of South Richmond.

A 20-year-old Bronx youth who said he was a student at New York University and "wanted to see how easy it was to rob a bank," succeeded once but was caught on a second try, according to the police. They reported that Michael Merchant of 1760 Bruckner Boulevard at 9:35 A.M., handed a note to a teller and fed after receiving $2,000 in cash, including $500 in marked bills.

The Lenox Arts Center, the production group directed by Lyn Austin that gave the premiere of Stanley Silverman's "Dr. Selavy" at the Music Barn in the Berkshires last summer, is moving to luxurious quarters for its coming summer season.

Those hot, thirsty days when the American people do most of their annual 30-gallonper-capita soda pop sipping are a comin' in. And this year the new factor-spreading out from test markets 'in the Southwest--is Mr. Pibb, a Dr Pepper-like entry from CocaCola.
C. Roderick O'Neil, the chief trust officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, said yesterday that the stock market "is now down at the low end of any sort of normal evaluation for 1973."

A special legislative committee studying possible revision of public-employe pensions in the state received a report yesterday from the City Controller's office that said increased investment of pension funds in corporate bonds arid common stock would yield a $40-million surplus this fiscal year for the city's five pension systems.
James C. Miller 2d of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L. I., won the 22d annual men's sailing Championship of Long Island Sound for the Hipkins Trophy today.

Barnett Banks of Florida, Inc., announced yesterday that it would file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the exchange of up to 1,149,950 of its common shares for all the outstanding shares of seven Florida banks it has agreed to acquire.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, embroiled in controversy over its handling of bequests, its policies on deaccession and disposal and its acquisitions, yesterday made public new procedures governing the removal and sale or exchange of works from its collections.

The North Korean Government of President Kim 11 Sung today harshly denounced a South Korean proposal that both states enter the United Nations at the same time.

Three physicians and an organization representing doctors in private practice filed suit yesterday in Federal court in Chicago challenging the constitutionality of a Federal law requiring peer review of medical practice.

The contested annual meeting of the Empire National Bank ended inconclusively here today as both factions seeking to control the half-million-dollar upstate bank appeared likely to elect some directors to the 19-man board. The results of the voting will be announced Thursday.
Outwardly, Mayor Lindsaythe most conspicuous noncandidate in town yesterday-appeared to be not overly interested in the progress of the Democratic primary runoff.
A bill designed to preserve and rehabilitate housing in New York City has been signed by Governor Rockefeller, his office said today.
Alexander Calder, the artist well-known for his mobiles and stabiles, has been commissioned to paint a jet for Braniff Airways, The Associated Press reports.

The Soviet Union's chief astronaut insisted today that the Soviet space program was proceeding smoothly and painted a rosy picture of future United States-Russian space cooperation.

THE NEW JOURNALISM. By Tom Wolfe. With an introduction edited by Tom Wolfe and E. IV. Johnson. 394 pages. Harper Row. $10.95. There's no arguing with one thing: as an anthology of journalism written during the last dozen years or so, Tom Wolfe's and E. W. Johnson's "The New Journalism" is just fine. It's a pleasure to read.

Salt is corroding part of the Tower of London, and scientists are seeking to prevent the collapse of the section. The stonework in the 700year-old tower is crumbling slowly because of the salt that its limestone structure absorbed 500 years ago.
The Nixon Administration is preparing to impose a mandatory allocation system for gasoline and other petroleum fuels, informed Government sources said today.
For any of the 40,000 highschool pupils who took the State Regents examination in physics earlier this month and just missed passing, there is still a slim hope.
The documents that John W. Dean 3d submitted with his testimony before the Senate Watergate committee give a rare insight into the White House and related 1972 Presidential campaign activities.
Consumers were bubbling with confidence in the economy at the end of 1972, but inflation has burst public confidence, according to a study by economists at the University of Michigan.
Norman Mailer, in an angry statement issued through his literary agent yesterday, threatened unspecified revenge against those who called him a plagiarist.
New Jersey's private colleges are in a financial crush because of a tight money market, rising operating costs, a change in youth attitudes and the end of the draft, The Associated Press reports.
Ramsay Clark, former United States Attorney General, today was accepted as a defense attorney for one of the inmates accused of killing a guard during the 1971 Attica prison uprising.
The House Select Crime Committee recommended today wide-ranging prison reform to lower the high rate of repeat imprisonments and to help prevent prison riots.
The Health Services Administration has announced the names of 42 more food-processing establishments charged with having violated the health code.

Hundreds of the Midget Mets who were admitted free to Shea Stadium yesterday began filing out quietly around the seventh inning with the Mets trailing the Chicago Cubs by four runs.
If the allegations that John W. Dean 3d has made against President Nixon over the last two lays could be proved, they would constitute felony offenses, according to experts in criminal law.

Joe Frazier appeared jazzy in a silk outfit and red platform shoes yesterday when he arrived in London's Leicester Square for the official signing of his work permit for Monday night's fight with Joe Bugner. Dressed in matching silver, gray and black knickers and soft peaked cap, with a short black shirt at the waist, Frazier appeared as if he might have been more at home on a golf course.

Ron Blomberg of the Yankees, the major leagues' only .400 hitter, has moved into the top six in balloting for the firstbase position on the American League All-Star team, but still has a long way to go to catch the leader Dick Allen.
City Controller Abraham D. Beame won the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday with an overwhelming 3-to-2 victory over Representative Herman Badillo in the city's first runoff primary.
The General Cable Corporation announced yesterday that it was terminating "certain uneconomic operations."

Eightcartons of documents from the office of E. Howard Hunt Jr. may have been locked in the trunk of a Junked car for six months and then burned at a city dump, a Watergate witness told United Press International today.

A 13-year-old girl who was not allowed to go through eighth grade graduation because she did not have the right kind of dress has been deluged with sympathy and offers of help, including the payment of four years' college tuition.

Assistant State Fire Marshal Timothy A. Driscoll said today that he did not suspect arson in the fire that raced through a three-story apartment-bar building in the French Quarter Sunday night, killing 29 persons.

The tragically sudden death of John Cranko will have considerable reverberations all over the dance world. He was not only the director, and in effect, the founder of the Stuttgart Ballet, he was also one of the acknowledged major classic choreographers in the world today.

Roy Innis leader of the Congress of Racial Equality announced yesterday that 50 black American technicians would leave for Uganda Aug. 1 to start filling the void left by President Idi Amin's expulsion of Asians.

Two of New Jersey's finest high school athletes, Bill Paterno of Christian Brothers Academy in Lincroft and Rich Allocco of New Providence High School, will attend Notre Dame in the fall. Each has received a full athletic scholarship valued at $16,000.

" Abe Beame is a nice fellow, but he's an anachronism-his experience is narrow-gauged," State Senator John J. Marchi said last night as he sat in a hotel suite and watched the votes pile up for Controller Abraham D. Beame.

Mrs. Marie Maloney, a performer with the "Ziegfeld Follies" who in later years oprated a talent agency, died of cancer on Monday at the French and Polyclinic Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived with her husband, Charles Maloney. at 55 Tiemann Place.
Government efforts to compel the key witness to testify in a fatal-bombing case were blocked by the United States Court of Appeals here yesterday in a decision vehemently assailing illegal wiretaps.
West Berlin authorities today ordered a 17-year-old student nurse returned to East Germany to stand trial on charges that she had murdered her father.
Philip C. Scott, a member of the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer Wood, died of a heart attack here yesterday. He was 63 years old and lived at Willow SDrings Farm.
Commissioner Pete Rozelle announced yesterday a strengthened program to prevent drug abuse among the National Football League's 1,300 players.

Vincent Aloi, the reputed head of the Joseph A. Colombo Sr. crime "family," was convicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan last night of lying to the grand jury that investigated the murder of the gang leader Joseph Gallo. He faces a seven-year prison sentence.
The Senate Judiciary Committee unanimously approved today the nomination of Clarence M. Kelley, the chief of police in Kansas City, Mo., as the new director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Walter Dunbar, executive deputy commissioner of the State Department of Correctional Services, has been appointed State Probation Director, Governor Rockefeller's office announced yesterday.

The designation of Controller Beame by a margin of three to two as the Democratic nominee for Mayor reflects the regard in which he is held by large numbers of New Yorkers as an intelligent, dedicated public official of long experience. The competence he has shown as the city's chief fiscal officer evidently convinced many voters in the runoff primary that he was well-equipped to provide the prudent management he had promised if elected Mayor.

Harry L. Lurie, a social worker, scholar, author and a founder and executive director of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds, died yesterday at his summer home here. He was 81 years old and lived also at 325 Central Park West, New York.
Congress and the White House took steps today to keep the embattled Office of Economic Opportunity in business, at least temporarily.

Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that the Senate's Watergate investigation never came up at a December meeting he had with President Nixon.

The United States Court of Appeals, rejecting the arguments by some publishers and mail order companies, upheld today the 1972 rate increases for third and fourth-class mail.

Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, the Lion of Kashmir, now dreams of death. The ailing 68-year-old Moslem leader dreams of seeing his friend Jawaharlal Nehru in a scented garden and of resolving the enduring conflict over this divided state.

President Johnson ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate Spiro T. Agnew shortly after Mr. Agnew was elected Vice President in November, 1968, reliable Government sources said today.

Declaring the use of different standards for sentencing men and women to be "unconstitutional on its face," the New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered that in the future women be sentenced to state prison on the same terms as men.

Prices of grains and soybeans were battered here today after the President's Cost of Living Council announced that it would not ease its rules to permit food prices to rise.

An iron rod that apparently had been tossed by a vandal came hurtling through the window of a Penn Central commuter train in North Tarrytown, N.Y., late yesterday afternoon, showering several passengers with broken glass and striking one commuter in the face, cutting his nose and forehead.

The H. J. Heinz Company achieved its 10th successive year of record sales and earnings in the year ended May 2, but a $25-million extraordinary charge reduced the net income by 49 per cent. Fourth-quarter profit also set a new high, according to the annual report.
A federally mandated ignition-seat belt interlock system for 1974 model cars has been put on display by the Ford Motor Company. Included is a button to by-pass the device in event it fails.

Three physicians and an organization representing doctors in private practice filed suit yesterday in Federal court in Chicago challenging the constitutionality of a Federal law requiring peer review of medical practice.

It is a large troupe of Bolshoi dancers., led by Raissa Struchkova, and including a number of the company's greatest stars, chiefly in highlights and excerpts from the repertory.
The biggest controversy this year in Pine Plains was how to stop students from smoking cigarettes in the local high school.
City Controller Abraham D. Beame won the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday with an overwhelming 3-to-2 victory over Representative Herman Badillo in the city's first runoff primary.

John Cranko, the British choreographer and director of the Stuttgart Ballet who led the West German company to international acclaim, collapsed and died yesterday on a flight from Philadelphia to Stutgart. He was 45 years old.
President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania began a five-day visit today to shop for foreign investments during the first official trip to West Germany by a head of state from the East bloc.

A man carrying a rifle went berserk in a quiet, wooded neighborhood of this southwest Chicago suburb today. Seven persons were shot to death in three homes within a two-block area.

Mrs. Marlitt Bruske Dellabough, widow of Walter Grant Dellabough, a real estate man, died yesterday in the Hudson Manor Nursing Home in North Bergen. She was 84 years old.

American planes, including B-52 bombers, again raided Cambodia today as heavy fighting continued near Phnom Penh. In recent weeks American air support has saved many beleaguered Government strongpoints that otherwise would probably have fallen.

Fanny Bradshaw, a speech and dramatic coach and an expert on Shakespeare, died yesterday at her studio at 45 West 55th Street. Her age was 76 and she lived at 49 West 12th Street.
The strangling on Monday of a 3-year-old Brooklyn boy, allegedly by a 14-year-old mentally disturbed youth, was the third child murder reported here recently.

France's apparent determination to conduct nuclear tests in the South Pacific in defiance of a request from the International Court of Justice is a blow not only to nations that are threatened by fallout from the tests but to the World Court.

State Senator James M. Turner acknowledged today that a statement dated Jan. 6 and ostensibly introduced at his trial to absolve him of wrongdoing had never been mentioned to the state police, the State Attorney General's office or to the state grand jury that indicted him.
Producer Joseph Papp's much-publicized contract to produce dramatic specials for the CBS television network was reported ended yesterday by both Mr. Papp and the network.

A 25-year-old man was stabbed to death and his roommate was wounded last night in what the police said was a knife attack by a third man at the Hotel One Twenty Three on 44th Street east of Times Square.
A soviet pilot fleeing to the West made an emergency landing in a Turkish cornfield today after a five-hour flight that almost ended in disaster.

A dozen students, most of them from Boston University, arrived triumphantly at Battery Park yesterday after an exhausting 310-mile land and water trip from upstate.
Workers have seized France's best-known watch factory and are continuing to operate it and sell its wares in a struggle to head off a job cutback ordered by the Swiss owners.

Child abuse is believed to be the most common cause of death among small children in this country, a medical symposium was told last night. Dr. Vincent J. A sale of 2,500 "collectors' item" nautical charts was announced today by the National Ocean Survey.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, embroiled in controversy over its handling of bequests, its policies on deaccession and disposal and its acquisitions, yesterday made public new procedures governing the removal and sale or exchange of works from its collections.

The major American Orthodox rabbinic body today agreed to "pressure" Jewish secular and religious organizations to bar from its leadership ranks those who marry out of the a faith and those who officiate at such marriages.

Outraged over a season's delay in resurfacing the Central Park tennis courts and over deteriorating tennis facilities throughout the city, about 75 tennis players demonstrated and met with Parks Commissioner Richard M. Clurman at the Central Park tennis house last night.
Eight persons died and 97 were missing after an Indian vessel was abandoned in heavy seas off Cape Guardafui in neighboring Somalia in the northeastern corner of Africa, the ship's agents said.

The 17-day cemetery strike was marked yesterday by a fracas at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Queens between a picket and a young man seeking to enter to dig a grave. The police reported that there were no serious injuries but that the men filed assault charges against each other.
Viktor Korchnoi retained the lead in Round 16 of the Interzonal Tournament here by defeating Guillermo Estevez, who played White against his French Defense.

Blaring trumpets from the balconies of the New York Stock Exchange, a parade through Manhattan and a cannonade of fireworks will highlight the city's Fourth of July celebration.

Leonid I. Brezhnev reported to President Pompidou at length today on his week-long talks with President Nixon. The Soviet party leader told Mr. Pompidou that there had been no decisions by the Russians and Americans "on behalf of partners or third countries."

Ernest Truex, the versatile actor who made hundreds of appearances here and abroad in the theater, films and television, died on Tuesday at his home in Fallbrook, Calif. He was 83 years old.

The Pillsbury Company had lower earnings in the fourth fiscal quarter caused by an extraordinary charge, according to the annual results announced yesterday from the company's Minneapolis headquarters.

Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, said today that it might be necessary for President Nixon to appear before the Senate Watergate committee "to repel" charges by his former counsel, John W. Dean 3d, of complicity in the scandal's cover-up.

Of all the musical organizations that perform outdoors in the summer, none appears more unlike its usual self than the Metropolitan Opera. Stripped of stage action, costumes, sets and most of its principal singers, the company takes on an anonymity that would make it unidentifiable if the name were not announced or printed on programs.

Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States in the years of its largest membership and greatest influence, died yesterday in Princeton, N. J. He was 82 years old and had been in frail health for years as a result of a stroke.

Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, during last year's investigation of a major business merger.

A state grand jury investigating alleged corruption among lawenforcement officials in Passaic County handed up five sealed indictments here this afternoon that were reported to name a county law-enforcement official and another one from Paterson.
