There were 20 names culled from the list of "enemies" submitted to John W. Dean 3d, then counsel to the President, by Charles W. Colson, then White House special counselor.

Wimbledon nearly lost its star today. Top-seeded Ilie Nastase, a prohibitive favorite, was trailing Ivan Molina of Colombia at a set-all and 2-4 and there was no resemblance in his performance to that of the Nastase who won the United States Open championship at Forest Hills last year and the French and Italian this year.

Dr. Frank Guy de Furia, assistant professor of pediatrics and medicine at Cornell University Medical College and assistant attending physician at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died home Monday after a brief illness. He was 34 years old and lived at 435 East 70th Street.

No sooner did Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, announce adoption of some new procedures in the league's drugabuse program than the two most valuable players of last season stood up to object.

Bob Charles of New Zealand made a 40-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today for a one-shot first-round lead in the $37,500 Scottish open golf championship. He had a five-under-par 67. The British Ryder Cup captain, Bernard Hunt, was second.

The director of the Secret Service told a House subcommittee today that most of the $1.9million in public funds spent on President Nixon's private homes in San Clemente, Calif., and Key Biscayne, Fla., had been requested by his agency to assure the President's security and safety.

An 18-year-old youth, convicted of raping a 21-yearold teacher at knifepoint in a Paterson school cloakroom, was sentenced to 18 to 20 years in prison. "The charges you have been convicted of are horrible," Passaic County Court Judge Joseph M. Harrison told Harold Stancil, the defendant, prior to sentencing. Stancil, of Paterson, was convicted April 11 of the armed rape and assault, with intent to rob, of a fourth-grade teacher at School 12 here.
A 29-year-old patrolman, scribed by law enforcement sources as a "moonlighting hit man," was charged yesterday with the murder last August of a reputed drug dealer in Manhattan.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, accused the Nixon Administration today of "hoarding for some unknown future purpose" $256.5-million that was appropriated by Congress for summer jobs for lowincome youths.

How can one criticize a life-saving effort? Time was when the family doctor (yes, son, there used to be family doctors) would say: "George, you've got to cut down on the beer and hard stuff, the bread and potatoes and desserts."
The machinists union and the publishers of the city's three major dailies, The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times, reached agreement yesterday on a new two-year contract.
At a picturesque oasis deep in the Sahara whose fort was once defended by the French Foreign Legion,
The text for today's sermon is Job 31:35, in which the bedeviled Job, who cannot understand why everything in his life has suddenly gone wrong, cries out: "Oh that mine adversary had written a book!"

David Clyde, the Houston schoolboy who had pitched nine no-hitters for Westchester High School, made his major league debut for the Texas Rangers last night in Arlington Stadium. The 18year-old left-hander allowed one hit in his five-inning stint as the Rangers beat the Minnesota Twins, 4-3, before a sellout crowd of 35,698.
A Manhattan grand jury has refused to return criminal charges against the two policemen who shot Police Officer Irving Wright March 5, the Manhattan District Attorney's office disclosed yesterday.
The chief surgical resident of the Nassau County Medical Center was indicted today on a charge of "willful murder" the Nassau County District Attorney described as a "mercy killing."

A state grand jury investigating alleged corruption among lawenforcement officials in Passaic County handed up five sealed indictments here this afternoon that were reported to name a county law-enforcement official and another one from Paterson.
John W. Dean 3d told the Senate Watergate committee today that the White House lists of political enemies filled a file "several inches thick."

Following is the text of President Nixon's message to the House of Representatives today vetoing. a $3.4-billion supplementalappropriation bill that included a ban on United States bombing in Cambodia:

A Federal judge ruled today that the Greyhound Corporation was guilty of criminal contempt for failure to comply with an earlier order regarding competition with Pacific Trailways, Inc., in the Pacific Northwest.

State Senator Nicholas Ferraro was chosen yesterday to be the Democratic nominee for Queens District Attorney. He was selected at a meeting of district leaders at county Democratic headquarters 72-50 Austin Street, Forest Hills, by a vote of 51 to 3 with two abstentions.

President Pompidou and Leonid I. Brezhnev today ended two days of talks in which the French leader apparently warned that France would not be bound by "bilateral" Soviet-American accords affecting European security.

Mrs. Margaret Cartwright Hooker and Alberto Mejia Hernandez were married here yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Edward-Gordon Hooker, mother of the bride. Justice Owen McGivern of the State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, performed the ceremony.

The Anaconda Company and American Metal Climax, Inc., completed negotiations yesterday and signed agreements creating the Anamax Mining Company, a 50-50 partenrship to operate and expand the Twin Buttes open-pit copper mine in Pima County, Ariz.

The selection of a new elementary-school principal in Brooklyn's Community District 18 led last night to a sit-in at the school and charges that two members of the local board had been working illegally in district schools.
Top Democrats, including Senator George McGovern and Howard J. Samuels, endorsed City Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor yesterday in a rare display of Democratic

Janovic/Plaza, the East Side paint and wallpaper store that has been in business for 85 years, recently opened a branch on the West Side, Customers will find here the usual wide selection of materials, plus an innovation for Janovic--carpeting.

Awakened by the sound of his own voice on a clock radio-a replay of his victory statement in the Democratic mayoral runoff - Controller Abraham D. Beame hastened to his desk in the Municipal Building yesterday.

It was as unlikely and as spectacular a finish as ever was produced in the National Football League, an organization with a predilection for preposterous finishes, Six months have passed since the bizarre ending of the playoff game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Oakland Raiders, a game that the Steelers apparently had lost with 65 seconds left to play, but reclaimed with only five seconds showing on the clock.

The United States has had many Presidents who took a broad view of their power under the Constitution but never before has any President sought to amend the Constitution by himselfbrazenly, defiantly, by fiat.

WASHINGTON, June 27--An accountant for the Nixon reelection committee, in a sworn deposition, has described in detail the alleged use of a secret bank account, spawned by jealousies within the organization and kept secret for a time from top officials.
The South African-born Italian, Marcello Fiasconaro, set a world record of 1 minute 43.71 seconds for the 800-meter run tonight during an Italo-Czechoslovak track meet.

The White House, in a counterattack against testimony by John W. Dean 3d that President Nixon was deeply enmeshed in the Watergate cover-up, declared today that Mr. Dean was the cover-up "mastermind."

Kenya, India and some other Security Council members are trying to have the Middle East debate shifted next month from New York to Geneva. The proposal is running into strong opposition from the United States and Britain.

The United States Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday that Federal District Judge Orrin G. Judd overstepped his authority last May when he tried to limit the number of cases that Legal Aid Society lawyers could handle in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

The city's Human Resources Administration, through its welfare arm, is placing hundreds of drug addicts, mental cases and other unstable people into some 20 seedy hotels in the Times Square area, creating sanctuaries for thieves, pimps, prostitutes and muggers who, the police say, prey on pedestrians in the theater district.

Acting under intense military pressure, President Juan Marfa Bordaberry and two Cabinet members abolished the Congress today, ending constitutional Government in this republic for the first time in 40 years.
The Soviet Union orbited the unmanned Cosmos 576 satellite today, with characteristics of a series of military reconnaissance and surveillance missions identified by Western experts.

Dr. Seymour P. Lachman, who nearly gave up his memnership on the city's Board of Education n last year and who again considered the possibility in recent weeks, is now expected to be elected president of the board.

Roland Redmond, a member of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said yesterday that he had voted against approval of a report issued Tuesday by a special committee of the trustees, titled "Report on Art Transactions 1971-1973."

For more than three weeks the egos were strung out in pairs across the broad stage of Leningrad's Dzerzhinsky Palace of Culture, as 18 of the world's best chess players struggled for supremacy in the Interzonal Tournament to pick three candidates for a chance to challenge Bobby Fischer for the world title.
After a brief policy review, the Nixon Administration has decided to maintain its cordial relations with Greece's military-led Government despite growing pressure from Congress for cooler ties.
The Storm Trysail Club was hoping to resume racing tomorrow after a two-day layoff in Block Island Week.

Members of the Nixon White House staff made repeated attempts to get the Internal Revenue Service to conduct "political actions and investigations" but were often balked by the President's own appointees to head the agency, according to a document submitted today to Senate investigators.

John Benedict Wilson is one of the youngest directors of athletics in the nation, but the 25-year-old executive is not overawed with his new position at St. Peter's College. Wilson, who identifies himself as J.B. when be's answering the phone, was offered the job earlier this month by the Rev. Edward J. Heavey, S.J., the college's dean of students.

A 25-year-old former mental patient from New Hyde Park was arrested by Nassau County detectives today and charged with the June 18 murder of Patricia Ann Sullivan, 21, a student at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University.

What ails the stock market-and how can it be cured? Unfortunately, the doctors-on Wall Street, in Washington and in the universities-are not agreed even on the symptoms of the disease, let alone its cure.
Advance planning can sometimes enable taxpayers to save money on legal bills, provided they have their lawyers' cooperation in itemizing types of work handled.

Although involved in an unusual accident at his Colt's Neck, N. J., farm this morning, which required 50 stitches in his mouth, Carmine Abbatiello appeared on schedule at Yonkers Raceway tonight and captured individual intercity driving honors.

President Nixon today vetoed a bill that would have cut off all funds for the bombing of Cambodia. He said a total halt in American air operations would undercut diplomatic efforts for a cease-fire, jeopardize the Paris agreement for peace in all of Indochina and strike a blow at America's credibility.
The American city that makes the right moves -- to check or cash--could be the site of the chess world championship quarter-final match between Robert Byrne and his foreign opponent.

In their first full term on the bench together, the four Supreme Court Justices appointed by President Nixon have formed a cohesive and effective power bloc that voted as a unit on 70 per cent of the cases that the Court heard and decided in the last nine months.

Cheerful and self-effacing, State Senator John J. Marchi of Staten Island slipped into his second Republican campaign for Mayor yesterday with a characteristically low-key handshaking stop at Lexington Avenue and 86th Street.

The Rabbinical Council of America called on Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay today to prohibit the showing of "sex and nudity" motion picture films, which, the council held, were undermining "the very moral fabric of our society."

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the Liberal party candidate for Mayor, opened his campaign yesterday by attacking his three opponents as conservatives, "each is tied in his own way to the past and each either unable or unwilling to confront the problems of the future."
The confusion that has gripped the commodities industry since President Nixon's latest price freeze, imposed two weeks ago, was compounded today.

Leaders of the United Church of Christ, a liberal Protestant denomination that two years ago officially acknowledged it was deeply involved in the contemporary "faith crisis," expressed optimism this week that the church now has the means to move creatively out of that crisis.
Members of an international cease-fire observation team were caught in a barrage of Communist mortar fire east of Saigon yesterday during an inspection of the site of an alleged truce violation.
When the haggling was go ing on recently over the Coty Awards, some candidates for the designers' honor were put down for being too European influenced.
The St. Louis Stars rallied from a 1-0 half-time deficit tonight to slip past the New York Cosmos, 2-1, and into the North American Soccer League Southern Division lead.

WASHINGTON, June 27--The Defense Department told a Senate committee today that the Indochina cease-fire agreements would permit a reduction of at least $500-million in planned military aid to South Vietnam and Laos in the fiscal year beginning next Sunday, July 1.

Mrs. Walter Cooperstein, the metropolitan titleholder, drew away from the field today as she added a 78 for a 154 total in the 35th women's Long Island medal championship over the water-logged par-72, 5,919-yard Meadow Brook Club course.

In a move to prevent food shortages and hold down prices, the Government imposed export controls late today on soybeans and cottonseed and the meal and oil produced from them, with an embargo on export shipments at least until Monday.

The Government declared a state of emergency tonight in the Province of Santiago-including the capital- because of disorders resulting from an incident in which the Commander in Chief of the Army allegedly fired a shot at a car driven by a woman who had insulted him.
In New Jersey, both parties have prepared draft versions of campaign platforms in this gubernatorial election year, which party members at state conventions are expected to debate and to adopt today.

In the year beginning next Sunday, residents of 300,000 rent-stabilized apartments here will be able to renew expiring leases under the same rent-increase limitations that prevailed since last July 1, the Lindsay Administration announced yesterday.

Dr. Henry Edward Garrett, professor emeritus of psychology at Columbia University and president of the American Psychological Association in 1946, died yesterday at Martha Jefferson Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived here.
Arthur P. Jacobs, the film producer, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 51 years old. He leaves his widow, the former actress Natalie Trundy.

The Senate approved today, 86 to 7, a 5.6 per cent acrossthe-board increase in Social Security benefits to take effect next January. The increase, the first since a 20 per cent rise in 1972, was approved as part of legislation extending the $465-billion national debt ceiling through November.

A United States Navy special force cleared mines from five main channels in the Haiphong area of the North Vietnamese coast and has begun minesweeping around Vinh, to the south, the Defense Department said today.

The White House, in a counterattack against testimony by, John W. Dean 3d that President Nixon was deeply enmeshed in the Watergate cover-up, declared today that Mr. Dean was the cover-up "mastermind."

In late spring and early summer, when striped bass and bluefish make their appearance along the East Coast from New Jersey to Cape Cod, this writer receives many requests from those who would like to try surf casting for the first time.

France is having poodle trouble. Mrs. Robert Monod of Paris, one of the top Gallic fanciers, who has had 24 international champions in the two decades she's been active with the breed, expressed concern about the poodle in her native land.
Richard A. Gordon, president of the Independent Investor Protective League, said yesterday his group hopes to find out the names of New York Stock Exchange member firms under intensive surveillance.

In what local newspapers have dubbed a "cultural offensive" to compete with the Chinese Communists, Taiwan has arranged to send a fullscale Peking opera theater troupe on a tour of the United States this fall for the first time.

Mayor Lindsay, on a twohour walking tour of midtown traffic yesterday, chuckled when a policeman gave out a parking summons, told a meter maid to show "no mercy" and declared the city was going to have to "tighten up" on parking by diplomats, the press, the handicapped and physicians.

Cooper Union, New York City's last tuition-free private college, has decided to sell most of its 1,000-acre Green Camp in Ringwood, N. J., which had served as a retreat for students, faculty and alumni for more then 30 years.

Following is the original list of 20 names of White House "enemies" submitted with comments to John W. Dean 3d, then counsel to the President, by the office of Charles W. Colson, then special White House counselor, and released today by the Senate Watergate committee.

Bombing charges against two Jewish Defense League members were dismissed in Federal Court here yesterday because two essential witnesses refused to testify despite an angry judge's warning about criminal contempt.
Clarence M. Kelley, President Nixon's nominee as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was confirmed by the Senate today, 96 to 0.

" Coriolanus" is not merely timely but pressing-dealing with what we make of our heroes and what they do to themselves. Coriolanus is an upright man of action who considers himself far above the common people, and is tragically victimized by his own pride.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it had issued formal disciplinary charges against Shaskan Co., Inc., alleging that the brokerage firm had filed erroneous financial reports with the Big Board and had violated netcapital and other rules.

Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged today an end to the price freeze well before 60 days and an "immediate" end of the freeze for many food products. Dr. Burns told a Congressional committee that "rigid controls can do very serious damage to the economy," adding, "There are already signs of it."
Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, denied today any intention to cut off health programs for the poor by insisting that the programs become financially self-sufficient.
A 29 year-old patrolman, described by law enforcement sources as a "moonlighting hit man," was charged yesterday with the murder last August of a reputed drug dealer in Manhattan.
A 28-year-old man arrested last month on a 1968 robbery charge was indicted yesterday in the murder of a Roman Catholic priest in St. Albans, Queens, last May 13.
The first political party to be formed in Greece since 1967, when the military seized power and banned political activity, was introduced to the press in Athens today.
The stock market extended its rally into a second consecutive session yesterday in a display of strength that dispelled some of the gloom hanging over the investment community.

UNION, June 27--Reacting to mounting on-campus crime, security representatives from 20 colleges and universities met here today to form the Campus Security Association, the first organization of its kind in New Jersey.

Dr. Harold S. Diehl, a former director of research and medical affairs at the American Cancer Society, died yesterday of heart disease at United Hospital in St. Paul, where he was visiting. He was 81 years old and lived at 11 Riverside Drive.
The Government's index of leading economic indicators rebounded with a strong increase in May after a sharp decline a month earlier, the Commerce Department said today.

Rolls-Royce, Ltd., will pay off all it's debts in full, Rupert Nicholson, the liquidator, said today. There will also be a surprise $15-million to $45-million for shareholders who once thought that they had lost all their money, the statement said.

The importance of the Metropolitan Museum's "Report on Art Transactions 1971-1973," prepared for its members and issued to the press at a conference on Monday morning, lies less in its potential effect on this one museum's policy than in its reflection of a change in the relationship

A Federal Court judge in Houston cleared the way yesterday for Hilmar Reksten, a Norwegian shipowner, to make an official offer to buy the stock of the Zapata Corporation, a Texas-based company with extensive shipping interests.
Confronted with a challenge by farmers to the right of newsmen to photograph migrant labor camps, civil rights attorneys here announced plans today to take legal steps to clarify the issue.

The Justice Department filed today a civil suit against the General Electric Company seeking $21,322,759 in damages for alleged breach of a contract with the atomic energy Commission. Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson said the suit was filed at United States District Court in Spokane, Wash.

There is still one round to be played in the Interzonal Tournament, but the top three finishers, who qualify for the elimination matches to pick Bobby Fischer's challenger for the world title, are already decided.

Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, the conservative former police chief here, is the strongest candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania next year, according to a private statewide telephone poll taken in Auril and May.
Frederick D. Watkins, president of the Aetna In surance Company, believes that every company ought to do what it can to ease the nation's gasoline shortage.

The Blue Shield medical and surgical insurance plan has asked for a 36.9 per cent rate increase to renew its contract with the city administration for 140,000 public employes and their dependents. It said it was under a state Insurance Department mandate that the contract become "self-supporting."

The Appellate Division of the United States Federal Court in New York has upheld a jury's finding against Dun Bradstreet, Inc., which in June of 1969 awarded the plaintiff more than $6-million, it was learned yesterday.
Philip Glass, the avant-garde composer, has been making an effort of late to broaden his audience beyond the "in" crowd that attends concerts of new music in this city.
China announced today that she successfully conducted a hydrogen bomb test in the atmosphere yesterday for reasons of defense and to break a "nuclear monopoly" by the "superpowers."

Acting under intense military pressure; President Juan Maria Bordaberry and two Cabinet members abolished the Congress today, ending constitutional Government in this republic for the first time in 40 years.
A 28-year-old man arrested last month on a 1968 robbery charge was indicted yesterday in the murder of a Roman Catholic priest in St. Albans, Queens, last May 13.

Six girl models in jockey attire rode through midtown yesterday to symbolize the opening day of ticket sales in the New York State Lottery's $3 Summer Special. Tax Commissioner Norman Gallman said the new $3 Special would combine features of the lottery's two previous specials and also add new features.
A route for a natural gas pipeline south from the Mackenzie Delta and the North Slope in Alaska has been agreed upon by the 26 participating concerns in Canadian Arctic Gas Study, Ltd.

A class action lawsuit filed yesterday in United States District Court alleged that during the first half of 1972 Liggett Myers, Inc., issued optimistic statements about its future earnings, but failed to make available to the public "materially adverse information."

State officials withheld comment on a congressional committee's criticism of the methods used to qulel the Attica prison rebellion in 1971. The State Correctional Services Department explained that officials had not received a copy of the report from the House Select Committee on Crime.

The House voted today to trim $46.3-million from the Nixon Administration's budget for the arts and humanities. The sharp cutback prompted a stern rebuke by Representative Peter A. Peyser, Republican of Westchester.

Following are two memorandums on how the White House could use the Internal Revenue Service for political advantages, submitted to the Watergate committee today by John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel. Mr. Dean told the committee that the memos are undated, it is the request of H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff, for the Secretary of the Treasury.
With Northern lieland due to vote tomorrow on its new assembly and its future, one part of the British plan to restore normality to the province is clearly succeeding.

State Senator James M. Turner, Republican of Gloucester, underwent cross-examination today in his conspiracy trial on charges that he attempted to frame a Democratic Assemblyman in a drug case. Testimony in the trial ended today and the case may be given to the jury tomorrow or Friday.

President Nixon today vetoed a bill that would have cut off all funds for the bombing of Cambodia. He said a total halt in American air operations would undercut diplomatic efforts for a cease-fire, jeopardize the Paris agreement for peace in all of Indochina and strike a blow at America's international credibility.

The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, rebuffed four times in lower courts, asked the State Supreme Court today to block the construction of a tourist tower at Gettysburg because it would "desecrate" the environment in violation of thei public interest.
Miss Isabel Goldsmith, daughter of Jimmy Goldsmith, who heads one of Britain's largest stores and food conglomerates, was married here today to Baron Arnaud de Rosnay.

The head of a federally funded family-planning clinic accused of ordering the sterilization of two teen-age black girls said today. that their mother had been briefed on the operation before she consented to it.

Agreement on a $400,000 price rollback was announced today between Filigree Foods, Inc., here and the Cost of Living Council. The agreement requires Filigree, a major food wholesaler, to return the money to about 6,000 groceries and supermarkets over the next 11 months.

Teams of investigators from the Essex CountyProsecutor's office, the police and members of the detective division of Montclair Police Department have been seeking an answer to a question that has doggedly disturbed this busy and affluent community for more than a month:

The American Heart Association yesterday strengthened its recommendation that Americans curb their consumption of some of their most beloved foods-prime ribs, ice cream, butter, bacon, sausages, cold cuts and the like-and switch to a leaner diet containing less saturated fat and cholesterol.

A Federal Court of Appeals here has reversed the conviction on six of seven counts of smuggling letters into and out of a Federal prison levied against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and Sister Elizabeth McAlister who is now Mrs. Berriganin 1972.

Dick Simon, a Salt Lake City businessman who holds championship trophies in both sky and parachute jumping, was the top qualifier today as a field of 33 starters was completed for the Schaefer 500mile auto race.

The jaw may have been broken, but Muhammad Ali's mouth continues to work. The former heavyweight champion started talking at 10 A.M. yesterday, when a day-long whirlwind tour began of theaters here that will televise his next bout.

A Federal judge dismissed today a suit by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, that had sought to close 20 of the nation's nuclear power plants. Mr. Nader alleged that the installations posed a danger of radioactive contamination.

Howard Hughes has picked up London's option. The reclusive industrialist slipped out of The Inn on the Park hotel, made his way to Stansted Airport, boarded a chartered aircraft and flew to Ostend, Belgium.

A Monmouth County grand jury returned an indictment of murder today against Lester Zygmaniak in the apparent mercy killing of his paralyzed brother, George, at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune last week.

The five-year-old controversy surrounding the winner of the 1968 Kentucky Derby having died quietly this week, Bob Gorham, resident manager of Churchill Downs, said today the gold winner's trophy would be engraved and presented to Calumet Farm, owner of second-place finisher Forward Pass, as soon as some paperwork was finished. The deadline passed this week for further court appeals by Peter Fuller, owner' of first-place finisher Dancer's Image.
A prolonged lawsuit by Edward M. Gilbert against Andre Meyer and Lazard Freres Co. was dismissed yesterday by Judge Charles H. Tenney in Federal Court here.
The Health Services Administration has announced the names of 17 more food processing establishments charged with having violated the health code.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday upheld a lower-court order directing 1,700 striking cemetery workers to return to their jobs. The decision of the five-judge bench thus opened the way for State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to press for criminal contempt action against the union and its officers.
The Bell Helicopter division of Textron, Inc., received a $395.4-million Army contract for UH-1 and AH-IJ helicopters for delivery to Iran, it was announced yesterday.
" We were at a party at Mildred Bailey's and Red Norvo's house in Forest Hills," Teddy Wilson was saying. "I was playing the piano. Benny got out his clarinet. Somebody else
The State Human Rights Appeal Board was ordered yesterday by the Appellate Division to hold a new hearing for a discharged New York Post reporter, William Artis.
Walter Snow, a newspaperman and author, died yesterday at Windham Community Hospital in Williamantic, apparently of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

The nation's trucking industry and the teamsters' union agreed today to a new 33-month master freight contract providing wage and benefit increases averaging 7 per cent a year to 400,000 truck drivers.

A player who cannot bid at his first turn is almost always wrong to throw himself into the fray later without hearing from his partner, unless the opponents' auction dies at a low level. Inexperienced players would be welladvised to treat this as a strict rule, thereby avoiding trouble.

An omnibus bill, which would create the United States Sports Board and bring about sweeping changes in amateur sports, passed its first hurdle in the Congress yesterday. The Senate Commerce Committee favorably approved the 35-page bill, entitled the Amateur Athletic Act of 1973.

State Republican sources say Governor Rockefeller has been informally discussing with associates the possibility of not running for re-election next year so he can gain more time for national politicking should he decide to try again for the Presidency in 1976.
Thirty-eight athletes, including Willie Mays, Muhammad Ali and Wilt Chamberlain, were named yesterday to the National Black Sports Hall of Fame.

A man wanted in an investigation into the slaying of seven people in Washington - five of them children - was arrested here today and identified later as a suspect in the murder of Major B. Coxson, a flamboyant former convict who ran unsuccessfully for Mayor of Camden, N.J.. last month.
The joint tax committee of Congress ordered today an investigation of allegations that the Nixon Administration has used tax audits to punish its enemies and help its friends.

Donald E. Weeden has been elected president of the City Club of New York to succeed Robert Conrad, who will continue as a trustee. Mr. Weeden, who is chairman of the board of Weeden Co., a bond house,

The Supreme Court has emphatically reaffirmed the vital principle of church-state separation. In a 6-to-3 ruling, the Court has declared unconstitutional the New York statute which provided state subsidy for parochial schools' repair and maintenance and offered tax relief for tuition reimbursement to parents whose children attend these schools.

The International Whaling Commission approved a moratorium today on the hunting of fin whales in the Antarctic. The moratorium, in effect, served notice on the two largest whaling nations, the Soviet Union and Japan, that the commission would no longer be a rubber stamp for the needs of their whaling industries.

If you are doing 100 miles an hour when you head into the banked, mathematically exact turn that sweeps up a hill and sharply to the right at the southern end of the north-south straightaway, and if you hold the accelerator steady,

The army announced the arrest today of several lowranking military men and the crushing of a "barracks revolt" against their commanding officers. Announcement of the arrests followed what the Government said was the attempted assassination yesterday of the army's commander in chief, Gen. Carlos Prats.
Act II in the continuing saga of the longer skirt for fall, 1973. Scene: opening of Adolfo fashion collection at St. RegisSheraton yesterday.

Heroin addiction in the United States doubled between 1965 and 1969 but is now on the decline, according to the White House Special Action Office for Drug Abuse. In its first annual report, to be released next week, the agency said it had been unsuccessful in its two-year effort to categorize the number of heroin users,

Senate-House conferees reached agreement tonight on a bill containing -a provision cutting off present and future funds for the bombing of Cambodia while efforts were made in other quarters to reach a compromise in the Congressional confrontation with President Nixon.

Back in the piping times when Knute Rockne coached football at Notre Dame, the 22 players on the first and second teams took their meals at two tables in the dining hall on the ground floor of the Administration Building. (That's the one with the golden dome always shown in photographs).
Monetary expansion has accelerated in recent weeks, data published yesterday by the Federal Reserve System showed.

Bjorn Borg, the 17-yearold Swedish wonder boy, advanced to the round of 16 in the Wimbledon tennis championship today, but it took all his startling speed of serve and the pinpoint accuracy of a heavily spun forehand to subdue Karl Meiler of West Ger many, 6-4, 6-4, 3-6, 2-6, 6-3.

A local insurance agent has signed assault and battery complaints against the singer Frank Sinatra and three other men in connection with an alleged beating at a restaurant in Palm Springs, Calif., an attorney, Bruce E. Coke, said today.

Housewives searching their supermarket shelves this coming week will find most of what they want still there. But a widening circle of food processors and retailers are caught in a profit squeeze resulting from

Experts of the United States Public Health Service believe they may have identified one species of African house rat as the source of the deadly Lassa fever virus. The mysterious virus, which can produce fevers up to 107 degrees, severe muscle aches and swift death,
A Federal program to assess literacy among the nation's 17year-olds was announced here last night by Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

A Federal judge dismissed today a suit by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, that had sought to close 20 of the nation's nuclear power plants. Mr. Nader alleged that the installations posed a danger of radioactive contamination.

A United States District Court judge, Winston Arnow, yesterday ordered CBS News to show cause why it should not be held in contempt of court for sketches that an artist made after the artist had been banned from Judge Arnow's courtroom last week.
Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. charged today that supporters of President Nixon had tried to intimidate him since he became a member of the Senate Watergate committee.

The chairman of the Senate's Aviation subcommittee yesterday assailed tha agreement to increase airline service between the United States and the Soviet Union, arguing that the Russians should have been compelled first to stop selling illegal cut-rate tickets.

The Environmental Protection Agency may not enforce pollution abatement plans for Ohio and Kentucky until public utilities have a chance to file objections, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today.

The Appeliate Division ruled yesterday that some of the city's regulations concerning where street peddlers may sell products were unconstitutional. The court struck down the prohibitions on selling "within 500 feet of any public market or enclosed market under the jurisdiction of the Department

Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano, the chief resident surgeon at the Nassau County Medical Center, who yesterday was indicted for "willful murder" in connection with an alleged mercy killing, has become the focus of a storm of protest and debate at the center and in the medical community.

Voters in the Bellmore-North Merrick Central High School District in Nassau County last night again rejected a proposed school budget of $23,609,569 by a vote of 2,964 to 2,659. Approval would have increased the average tax rate $1.21 for each $100 of assessed evaluation, or from $7.40 to $8.61.
Spokesmen for President Nixon attempted today to dissociate the President from any personal involvement in or approval of the statement before the Watergate committee charging that John W. Dean 3d
The general services Administration reported to Conress today that it spent $124,587 on protective measures in April, May and June of this year at the residence of Vice President Agnew.

Four regulatory agencies reached agreement here today on a plan to free some $145million in cash they had blocked to protect the assets of five mutual funds managed by Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the once powerful mutual fund complex founded by Bernard Cornfeld.

Prices rose on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market yesterday in sluggish trading. The Amex index finished at 22.31, up 0.06 on the sale of 1,901,210 shares, compared with 2,334,580 shares the day before. Advances outnumbered declines by 429 to 283,

Contracts covering nearly 10,000 uniformed employes and 20,000 other city workers are scheduled to terminate at midight tomorrow, but there is to threat of job action or expectancy of imminent crisis.
E. Howard Hunt Jr., one of the convicted Watergate conspirators, was quoted today as saying that he had sought and received disguises and other equipment from the Central

A Federal grand jury tracing money used to pay the Watergate burglars has suspended its investigation without reporting. Federal prosecutors said that any action the grand jury might take would be announced in Washington.
Ted Gross, former Comm,ssioner of the city's Youth Services Agency, was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison for having taken kickbacks on city contracts during his 16 months in office.

Following are excerpts from a transcript of the testimony of John W. Dean 3d on the 15th day of hearings on the Watergate case today before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities.
Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, said today that his faith in President Nixon had not been shaken by the Watergate testimony of John W. Dean 3d.

Selective buying among bluechip issues spurred the stock market to another strong gain yesterday in moderate trading. The Dow - Jones industrial average moved steadily higher throughout the session and closed at its best level, up 10.01 points at 894.64. Other leading market indicators also closed at their peak levels of the day.

Israeli Air Force plianes were fired on over the Israeli-occupied Sinai Peninsula today, the military command here reported. It said none of the planes were hit, but the Cairo radio reported that Egyptian antiaircraft defenses along the-Suez Canal had shot down..a F-4 Phantom jet.
Ted Gross, former Commissioner of the city's Youth Services Agency, was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison for having taken kickbacks on city contracts during his 16 months in office.

William E. Simon, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, yesterday urged oil exporting nations to make investments and handle their burgeoning wealth in "a way that achieves the industrial development goals of producing countries and promotes international monetary cooperation."

David N. Dinkins, president of the Board of Elections, charged yesterday that the new state law raising the membership of the board to 10 would impede its efficiency and election reform and said that he would no longer serve on the board.

To the Editor: Many people (and most governments) believe that they have the moral right, if not obligation, to control the thought and behavior of others. The rationale is that imposition of certain views upon others is essential for the society's existence or well-being.
The arrival of the Newport Jazz Festival puts such a spotlight on jazz in New York that it's easy to forget that jazz is a hardy city perennial, one that seems to be getting stronger.
Aleksandr I. Bezymensky, an important poet of the early Soviet period, is dead, it was reported in the Soviet press today. He was 75 years old.

The United States picked up two medals in today's first two events of the Pacific Conference Games. Mac Wilkins, a recent graduate of the University of Oregon, took the gold medal in the discuss with a throw of 200 feet, 11 3/4 inches, a Games record.
AREA A -- "Fishing is pretty thin," says John Falkiewicz at Surf City, N. J., who adds that a few striped bass and fluke, but no kingfish, are being caught in the surf. In Barnegat Bay,
The nations of the Atlantic Alliance and the Warsaw Pact announced agreement today on the goals of negotiations for East-West troop cuts in Central Europe, scheduled to begin here Oct. 30.
Richard Joyce Smith, trustee of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad, filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission a proposal for reorganization of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad.
Dr. BOSTON, Snedeker, former assistant director of the Children's Hospital Medical Center in Boston, died Tuesday in New London, N. H. He was 69 years old.

The directors of the Chicago Board of Trade suspended trading in soybeans, meal and oil for future delivery today in the wake of the Government's embargo on exports of oil seeds, issued after the close of business yesterday.

The United States decision to ban exports of soybeans, a vital world source of protein, caused wide concern today. The United States produces some two thirds of Western supplies, and the move was seen as a potential threat to international livestock production and a wide range of other industries.

The "Cod War" that recently has precipitated dangerous encounters between Icelandic patrol vessels and British frigates in disputed fishing areas off Iceland is threatening to move west and escalate into a far more serious confrontation between the United States and foreign fishing fleets operating off this country's East Coast.
The Legislature should set up a bipartisan committee to look into "Watergate fallout" on the New York State level, the Democratic state chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, said yesterday.

When the major banks talk about their investment portfolios-portfolios heavily laden with some 30 highgrowth companies like Avon Products, Xerox and International Business Machines they let you know that they have been smart in managing their billions.

Mrs. Gertrude Ellis Moore, widow of the concert pianist and teacher Francis Moore, and herself a teacher and leader in musical affairs in southern Westchester, died last evening at a nursing home in New Rochelle. She was 82 years old and lived at 572 Manor Lane.

The director of the Federal program that provides health services for crippled children and low-income pregnant mothers resigned today, charging that the Nixon Administration was "not interested in the problems of children."

The nation's trucking industry and the teamsters' union agreed today to a new 33-month master freight contract providing wage and benefit increases averaging 7 per cent a year to 400,000 truck drivers.

From Maine to the Carolinas, an ill wind has been blowing in recent years for weather-vane owners. As prices for remarkable examples of folk art vanes skyrocketd, so did the number of thefts by nimble-footed ladder-scalers and, some suspect, helicopter-borne purloiners.

Although he had previously vetoed similar bills, Governor Rockefeller has this week inexplicably signed into law a measure that threatens totally to politicize New York City's electoral machinery and to make desperately needed reforms even more difficult to achieve.
Space program doctors will recommend strongly that the next Skylab crew spend twice as much time doing exercise as did their predecessors on the record 28-day mission that ended last week.

A 50-year-old Queens man, whose release in $500 cash bail last December on charges that included attempted murder touched off a heated controversy, was convicted in' State Supreme Court yesterday of assault and robbery.
House and Senate conferees agreed today on a 5.6 per cent increase in payments for the 30 million Social Security pensioners, virtually assuring that Congress will pass the legislation.

Two iconoclasts on the House Armed Services Committee--Representatives Otis C. Pike of Suffolk and Les Aspin of Wisconsin -- took on the military establishment on the House floor today and won on the issue of flight pay for deskbound admirals and generals.
A Navy enlisted man from Groton, Conn., died at sea yesterday in an electrical accident on board the Garcia, a Newport-based destroyer.
Strategy aimed at making it increasingly difficult for President Nixon to refuse to testify on his own behalf before the Senate Watergate committee unfolded during the committee's hearings today.
Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell "definitely has no information implicatiing" President Nixon in the Watergate bugging or the cover-up, William G. Hundley, his lawyer, said tonight.
Joe (King) Roman of Puerto Rico tuning up for his world heavyweight championship bout against George Foreman, knocked out little-known Elmo Brown of Memphis, Tenn., in the third round here tonight.

Oxford Street is the biggest shopping center in England, and until six months ago it was so crowded that shoppers kept falling off the sidewalks and being hit by buses. Passengers were sometimes hurled to the floor when the buses were braked.

The five-member City Council and the City Clerk of the suburban steel town of Lackawanna were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of conspiracy and extortion said to involve kickbacks in the construction of a $900,000 City Hall annex.

Anatoly Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi won their finalround games to share first prize of 1,750 rubles-about $2,100 - each in the Interzonal tournament that ended tonight in the Dzerjinsky Palace of Culture.

Lysander and Hermia and Demetrius and Helena were with us again, courtesy of the New York City Ballet, at the State Theater on Wednesday night. Lysander loves Hermia, and Hermia loves Lysander, but Demetrius also loves Hermia, and Helena loves Demetrius.

The French Government today banned two extremist groups--one rightist and one leftist--of little political weight but large capacity for stirring trouble. The move was apparently prompted by street fights a week ago, the most violent in Paris since 1968, if not the biggest.
Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks regained the women's Long Island medal championship today with a 54-hole total of. 234 in the 35th tournament at the Meadow Brook Club.
Long before the Watergate' hearings were scheduled, the Congressional leadership determined that Congress would take a 10-day recess over the July Fourth Holiday.

Willie Stargell, who claims the Pittsburgh Pirates are just too good a ball club to remain in the lower regions of the National League's Eastern Division, added impetus to his words with his bat last night in Three Rivers Stadium.
The bond market, which has been moving toward higher interest rates since early May, paused yesterday to decide if the trend had gone far enough.
Saigon said today the South Vietnamese should hold elections on Christmas Day and make it "a day of joy," but the Communist Vietcong rejected the suggestion as "phony."

The transfer of the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday to a mile on the dirt instead of the originally scheduled 11/6 miles on the turf proved quite beneficial to Zulu Tom of the Cragwood Stable. The 4-yearold colt came along just in time to win, by a neck over Dundee Marmalade.

Esmark, Inc., directors approved yesterday the acquisition over a 2-year period of up to 1 million shares of the company's common stock, to be held fo use on conversion of preferred stock and the exercise of stock options. The stock of the world's largest meat packer closed at 23 3/8, down 1/4, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The American Stock Exchange released yesterday a study showing that the average company registered a 38.9 per cent gain in the number of shareholders within five years of listing.
Mrs. Blanche Chenery Perrin, a novelist and writer for children, died here yesterday. She was 79 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla., and Thetford Center, Vt.
A proposal to shift the Security Council's debate on the Middle East from New York to Geneva was shelved today after failing to muster the necessary support of council members.

Patrick L. Carty, who retired in 1946 as president of Media Records, Inc., a newspaper advertising measurement and statistical organization, died here Tuesday at Doctors Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 131 Bedell Street.

The disorders and shootings on Wednesday night along a five-block stretch of Fifth Avenue in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn were the most violent in a long-standing hostility that has pitted the Puerto Rican
Most of the 31 gasoline stations on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway are limiting sales to 10 gallons or $5 a customer, R. Burdell Bixby, Thruway chairman said today.

Bernard M. Hanafin, who retired this year as president of the W. A. Baum Company, Inc., maker of blood pressure equipment in Copiague, L. I., died here yesterday at his summer home. He was 76 years old and lived at 119-11 80th Road, Kew Gardens, Queens.
The government of Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau today urged Canadians to think seriously about husbanding their vast energy resources in order to assure their country's own economic growth.

Winning numbers drawn on June 28 were: NEW YORK 785944 Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

Ohime II bel viso, Monteverdi; Ariadne; Overture, Handel; Violin and Harpsichord Sonata in A (Op. 2 No. 2), Vivaldi; La Cenerentola: Nacqui all' affanno, Non Piu mesta, Rossini; Brandenburg Concerto No. 6, Bach; Italian Arias, Various; Concerto for Clarino trumpet, Two Oboes and String Orchestra, Telemann.

A State Supreme Court justice dismissed today an appeal by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court for a new Democratic primary election to determine the party's nominee for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.

Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, described the state of pro football yesterday as "healthy" but afflicted with problems. He made the remarks as the annual spring meeting of the club owners ended here.
The chief of Paterson detectives, a Passaic County detective and three others were charged by a state grand jury today with bribery, misconduct in office and gambling.

Uganda has reconsidered plans to recruit black Americans into her civil service, Radio Uganda reported today. The radio, monitored here, quoted President Idi Amin as having said that the recruitment of black Americans and the arrival of a first group of 50 was being postponed until further notice.
The joint tax committee of Congress ordered today an investigation of allegations that the Nixon Administration has used tax audits to punish its enemies and help its friends.

WASHINGTON--Phnom Penh will one day fall. If the United States bombing stops, the end will come quickly. If the bombing goes on, the collapse will occur anyway, but some time later. After the Communists have taken the city-whether by storm, by barter, or by default--United States intelligence will hold its post-mortem.
Msgr. Francis W. Walsh, pastor emeritus of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel in Riverdale, the Bronx, died yesterday at the FrancesSchervier Home in the Bronx. He was 84 years old.

E. Howard Hunt Jr., one of the convicted Watergate conspirators, was quoted today as saying that he had sought and received disguises and other equipment from the Central Intelligence Agency to investigate Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

After eight unspectacular years in the major leagues, Rick Reichardt is apparently through playing baseball. The Chicago White Sox yesterday requested waivers on the 30year-old outfielder for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.
The Federal Maritime Administration approved yesterday a contract calling for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to build two 265,000-ton tankers costing $162.9-million for the Gulf Oil Corporation.

State Senator James M. Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, was found guilty today on all three counts of conspiracy, bribery and giving false information to law enforcement officials in a plot to frame Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, a Democrat, on narcotics charges.

As pleasant summer entertainment and a dollop of relief during the rerun glut, "The Helen Reddy Show" provides the National Broadcasting Company with an attractive new series for its 8 to 9 time slot on Thursday evenings.

The renewal of a $2-million contract from the Human Resources Administration to operate an antipoverty training program will be deferred pending an investigation by the agency' of the Queens contractor running the program.
" Sand is the problem," declared Nancy Browne as she carefully dusted a camera.yesterday. "It seeps into everything--it has already put one of my cameras out of commission."

May contracts for future construction work ran 4 per cent higher than the year-ago level but this was interpreted as being a negative factor, according to George A. Christie, vice president and chief economist for the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company.

American troops joined units of five other Atlantic Alliance countries today in honoring Greece's Provisional President, George Papadopoulos. The occasion was a military review at the end of a North Atlantic Treaty Organization exercise.

David E. Guerrant, president of the Nestle Company, Inc., will become chief executive officer of the food producer, effective July 1. He will succeed Gerard J. Gogniat, who also had been chairman-a post that will not now be filled.
Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. charged today that supporters of President Nixon had tried to intimidate him since he became a member of the Senate

Miss Alice Jackson Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dudley Myers of Baltimore, was married in London yesterday to Michael Rodkey Lyall, son of Mrs. Joan ,Lyall of Bradford-onAvon, England, and the late Maj.. Rodney. Lyall of the British Army.

Housewives searching their supermarket shelves this coming week will find most of what they want still there. But a widening circle of food processors and retailers are caught in a profit squeeze resulting from the price freeze, and this is beginning to curtail production of some foods.

One wonders if many Americans realize what a Russian felt when an agreement on avoiding a nuclear war was signed in the East Room of the White House June 22. At the moment of signing I was standing near the Soviet group which accompanied Mr. Brezhnev and saw veteran diplomats and politicians from Moscow who could scarcely conceal their profound emotions.

CHICAGO--I have had a mixed reaction to being named on a long "master list" of enemies of Richard Nixon and his Administration, and on another list of "less than twenty" particular enemies that Mr. John Dean forwarded on Sept. 14, 1971, to an aide of Mr. H. R. Haldeman.
President Juan Maria Bordaberry, who closed down Parliament yesterday in a move backed by the military, today dissolved Uruguay's 19 municipal councils.

The windows of the big air-conditioned car were rolled up, so an explosion three blocks down Monivong Boulevard sounded like muffled thunder. "Ah, it's not thunder, but it seems to be a bomb or something," said the driver, a Cambodian Army colonel.

The State Commission of Correction has given the city 60 days to enroll every inmate at the New York City Reformatory on Rikers Island in a rehabilitative program or face loss of the reformatory's certification.

The restaurant on Third Avenue smelled of freshly waxed floors and its low lights, checkered table cloths and mellow wood paneling gave a feeling of hospitality as two city health inspectors came through the door.
The cruise shop Skyward broke off a Caribbean tour and steamed full speed back to Miami because its 1,020 passengers and crewmen were suffering from severe diarrhea, the Coast Guard said.

The five-member City Council and the City Clerk of the suburban steel town of Lackawanna were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of conspiracy and extortion said to involve kickbacks in the construction of a $900,000 City Hall annex.
American planes struck repeatedly today at rebel forces advancing toward the Cambodian capital from the north on Routes 5 and 6. Cambodian troops were retreating on Route 6,

An airman was arrested today in the slaying of a medical corpsman and a patient who were killed when a gunman burst into the emergency room at Seymour Johnson Air Force Base last Sunday, the police said.
A former Vietnam war prisoner today denied charges of mutiny and aiding the enemy, saying he had repeatedly exposed himself to punishment from the North Vietnamese during five years' captivity.
Two Canadian truce observers are missing in an area of east of Saigon after making contact with Vietcong forces,, a Canadian delegation spokesman said today.

KISSINGER: Portrait of a Mind. By Stephen R. Graubard 288 pages. Norton. $7.95. I'll admit I brought a special perspective to Stephen R. Graubard's "Kissinger: Portrait of a Mind." And from that perspective I found reading the book rather like allowing a dose of cod-liver oil-horrible tasting but probably good for me once it was down. Let me explain.

What would summer in New York be like without Joseph Papp giving us Shakespeare at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park? Well, if the question is not entirely rhetorical, let me say that it certainly would not be any better.

After eight unspectacular years in the major leagues, Rick Reichardt is apparently through playing baseball. The Chicago White Sox yesterday requested waivers on the 30year-old outfielder for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

John F. Kennedy College, the United States women's champion, gained its second basketball victory in China today. The Nebraskans defeated the Kirin Provincial team, 62-59, in Hangchow, the Peking news agency reported.

Japan's five-man team won the "kumite" or free-style sparring world karate team championship yesterday by defeating Italy, 5-0. Italy had defeated South Africa, 3-2, and Japan had eliminated the United States, 5-0, in the semifinals.

Bruce D. Bromley, one of the nation's best known corporate lawyers, yesterday asked the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York to hold him in contempt for his failure to provide some 1,200 documents sought by the Justice Department in connection with its four-year-old antitrust action against the International Business Machines Corporation.

A five-game home stand this week gave the limping Mets a chance to take a breather, win a few and get some laundry done. They got some laundry done, but they gave up 32 runs and lost four of the five games.

A Federal judge in Newark ordered the United States De. apartment of Labor yesterday to release $239-million budgeted nationwide for the Neighborhood Youth Corps summer program.

A group of women editorial employes at Newsweek magazine announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement: with the publication's management under which at least onethird of Newsweek's writers' and reporters will be women by Dec. 31. 1974.

Running Tide, owned and skippered by Albert Van Metre of Alexandria, Va., posted her second straight Division A victory today in Block Island Week. The 60-foot sloop finished approximately six minutes ahead of Norm Raben's La Forza Del Destino in a race counterclockwise around the island.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments.
Twenty-three years ago, Joseph Fred Buzhardt Jr.'s career was advancing on course. In World War II he had served in the Army Air Corps for two years.

Holiday Magic, Inc., a multimillion-dollar, door-to-door cosmetics company that has come under sharp attack in recent months for its pyramid marketing plan, was charged yesterday with fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Three teen-age brothers and their 4-year-old sister underwent successful two-. at-a-time operations today to repair the same inherited defect-holes in valves in their hearts.

Through thirteen of the most fateful years in Amencan history, Samuel I. Rosenman served as an influential White House adviser. He did more than coin the name for Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal and help draft scores of memorable speeches for both F.D.R. and Harry S. Truman.

Miss Lynda Shirley Rothenberg of Long Beach, L. I., and Harvey Stephen Rilander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Rilander of Rockville Centre, L. I., were married yesterday evening in Temple Torah, Little Neck, Queens, by Rabbi Morton L. Gordon.

Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner, in an unusual farewell message, charged yesterday that there was a "clear conflict of interest" when members of the central Board of Education had close relatives working in the school system.
Finance ministers of the European Economic Community resolved today to curb the rate of inflation in their nine countries and outlined a series of measures that they hoped would do the job.

Charles W. Colson, in a letter to the Senate Watergate committee, today denied that he was the author of the White House list of political enemies. "I do not know who prepared that document," he said.

George P. Shultz, the Secretary of the Treasury, recommended today that the Emergency Loan Guarantee Board, established in 1971 to stave off bankruptcy of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, be abolished at the end of this year.

The Senate unanimously confirmed today the nomination of James R. Schlesinger to be Secretary of Defense, thus filling a vacuum in the top Pentagon leadership created by the reshuffling of the Nixon Cabinet in the wake of the Watergate affair.

The Antrim glens are green and lush, cutting through the hills in nine parallel sweeps to the sea. Sunlight falls through the trees, salmon streams rush along the bottoms, yellow gorse and cottages climb the steep sides.

ANDERSON-Cornella L. The Colonial Dames of America record with deep regret the death on March 26, 1973 of Mrs. Cornelia L. Anderson, a loyal and most Interested member of our Society. Mrs. John J. Trask, Pres.-Gen. Mrs. George Griswold, Jr., Recording Sec.

While lauding the progress of community mental-health services, Dr. Martin H. Weinberg, recently appointed director of the New Jersey Division of Mental Health and Hospitals,. said today that "to infer or suggest that the state hospitals should be completely eliminated or dismantled is unrealistic."

" Jazz," remarked the disk Jockey Gerry Bledsoe last summer, "is our greatest music, but it doesn't get played because it isn't popular enough and it's not popular because it doesn't get played."
A technicians' strike at four television stations owned by the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company went into its fourth week yesterday with no prospect for settlement in sight.

The American investor should be given the chance to buy "inflation-proof" bonds that would be guaranteed by the Government against the loss of the dollar's purchasing power, a Yale University professor, who also acts as an adviser to the Treasury, suggested here today.

The American Medical Association beat down yesterday an attempt to move itself in the direction of doctors' unions whose creation and expansion in recent years has served to undermine the A.M.A.'s influence.

A man wanted in an investigation into the slaying of seven people in Washington - five of them children - was arrested here today and identified later as a suspect in the slaying of Major B. Coxson, a flamboyant former convict who ran unsuccessfully for Mayor of Camden, N.J., last month.

Governor Cahill has signed legislation to authorize such car-safety devices as air bags as alternatives to seat belts. The measure states that cars must be equipped with "seat safety belts or other suitable restraining device." It gives the State Motor Vehicle Director discretion to determine if the safety devices meet proper standards.
Auctionitis, a disease that seems to have reached epidemic proportions in recent seasons, is being spread increasingly, under the spell of women's voices.
Secretariat, the first Triple Crown winner since 1948, arrived here this afternoon to all the pomp and ceremony this city reserves for visiting heads of state.
The wife of a former prisoner of war who fatally shot himself yesterday charged today that his countrymen had killed him with harassment and torment.

A proposal for a huge shopping center in northern Yonkers received a major setback last night when Mayor Alfred B. DelBello said he would oppose it.

No matter for whom he pitches, Sam McDowell can't seem to beat Baltimore. The Orioles got their seventh straight victory over the left-hander, 6-3, before an encouraging crowd of 26,012 in Memorial Stadium tonight to move-within one game of McDowell's new club, the first-place New York Yankees.

Spokesmen for President Nixon attempted today to dissociate the President from any personal involvement in or approval of the statement before the Watergate committee charging that John W. Dean 3d was the chief architect of the White House cover-up.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 171.6 from 172.1 last week. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 118.8 on June 27. 1972.

The Police Department, in a continuing effort by Commissioner Donald F. Cawley to augment precinct patrol forces, will assign more than 1,000 members of the Detective Bureau to precinct work in the next few months.
Alfredo Valente, curator of the New York Cultural Center until illness forced his resignation several years ago, died yesterday at his home here. He was 74 years old.

Only chain stores and larger food and merchandise stores are obeying Federal regulations requiring them to post price-freeze information, according to the heads of the Internal Revenue Service districts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Newark, which cover the metropolitan area.
A United States Air Force F-4 Phantom jet crashed into a house in northeastern Thailand, causing serious injuries to a village chief, the police reported today.
The White House domestic adviser, Melvin R. Laird, said today that the country could not afford to let itself be distracted by Watergate and, in the process, neglect problems and challenges it faces.

CHICAGO-Much has been said of the world population explosion and the concomitant rise in the demand for protein. What is now becoming apparent is that the craving for protein has resulted in an exploding world livestock population that is competing with the human race for foodstuffs, particularly grains and soybeans.

The framers of the Constitution considered accurate population data of such importance that they provided for a decennial census. At that time, the information was needed primarily for allocating membership in the House of Representatives and for apportioning taxes. The Constitutional Convention assumed that population growth and change would be slow enough that freshdata every decade would be adequate.

Col. Yoser Alon, an Israeli military at tache, was shot to death just after parking his car in the driveway of his home in a Washington suburb early yesterday morning. His murder aroused deep concern in security conscious Washington. President Nixon pro vided a military plane to bring Colonel Alon's body and family back to Israel, and he ordered the Secret Service to increase protection of Washington's diplomatic community. Fullam authorizing trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad to file their plan of liquidation with theInterstate Commerce Commission.
Mrs. David Eisenhower says that her father, President Nixon, considered resigningover Watergate, but his family talked him out of it.

Italian-American residents of a Lower East Side housing de velopment and black and Puerto Rican members of a youth gang blamed each other yesterday for two nights of disorders that shattered a long period of relatively peaceful coexistence.
A stubborn brush and timber fire burning since Satur day on the steep slopes of Mount San Jacinto may take several weeks to control, forestry officials said today.

The dollar's value again sank to new lows against Europe's leading cur rencies today, but then re covered most of its loss, as pressure on the United States intensified to support the dollar with reserve assets.
American crews, deprived of the top sculler, Jim Dietz, still managed to row to a string of victories today in the Henley Royal TRegatta.

In front of Castle Clinton -at the Battery, in Trinity Church, at the South Street Seaport and at the Federal Hall National Memorial, New Yorkers marked the 197th birthday of the United States yesterday with music, dancing, theater and demonstra tions of Colonial crafts as they participated in the city-spon sored "July 4th in Old NewYork."
A group of civic leaders opposed to the military-backed Government asked today for guarantees that the referendum of July 29 on the abolition of the mo narchy would be conductedfairly.
The story of two of Gerrit Thomas Rietveld's decades old pace-setting chair designs has a familiar ring-both made it to museums long be fore they were accepted inthe marketplace.
Police Chief John Inman has been asked in a letter from the Justice Department to expedite the hiring of blacks for the citypolice force.
SEOUL, South Korea - A United States export drive to overcome an imbalance in trade with South Korea has begun to show some success-but it stillhas a long way to go.

A "status report" from the original Watergate prosecutors to the special prosecutor, Archi bald Cox, recommends the in dictment of four former White House and Nixon campaign aides for conspiring to obstruct justice, CBS News reportedlast night.

The president of the National Federation of the Blind vowed yesterday that the organization would not "falter or back up" in its campaign to stop dis crimination against blind peo ple solely because they couldnot see.

Publishers beware. A hap py entry into the crowded cookbook field offers a zest that will be hard to beat. The new publishers are the fourth, fifth and sixth graders of Public School 9,on West 84th Street.

If man's inhumanity to animals were not almost as great as his inhumanity to man, Congress would unhes itatingly pass two measures now before it which should have been passed literally decades ago. One is designed to save two to three million birds from needless death each year, not directly at the hands of hunters, but indi rectly, senselessly, slowly and agonizingly from ingestingthe lead shot that hunters have already expended.

The Cambodian command announced today that the road connecting Phnom Penh with the sea had again been cut by Communist troops. The road, Route 4, had been clear for passage of supplyconvoys for only two weeks.
In "The First and Essen tial Freedom," on the Ameri can Broadcasting Company network tonight at 8 o'clock, A.B.C. News reviews the his tory, past and present, of freedom of the press in thiscountry.

Unless the Mets and the Braves reach the playoffs this season-and a quick glance at the standings will show you how ridiculous a supposition that is-Henry Aaron will be paying his last visit to Shea Stadium over the weekend. I can't think of anyone in baseball right now who is more important than Henry, because he keeps advancing with painstaking steadfastness toward a date with destiny: thebreaking of Babe Ruth's home run record of 714.

Almost 100 of the jazz musicians who are gathered here for the Newport Jazz Festival went out to Queens yesterday afternoon to take part in the official dedication of Louis Armstrong Memo rial Stadium, formerly the Singer Bowl, on what would have been the trumpeter's73d birthday.
The military-controlled Gov ernment of President Juan M. Bordaberry took firm action to day to try to end the general strike that has paralyzed thiscapital for a week.

A broad effort to end the "irrational and disparate sen tencing" of defendants in the Federal courts in New York, Connecticut and Vermont - in part by experimenting with such innovations as three-judge sentencing panels - was an nounced yesterday by the chief judge of the United StatesCourt of Appeals here.

The Army, after going back to the drawing board, has come forth with plans for a new battle tank that will cost almost as much as a tank Congress can celed in 1971 because it wasconsidered too expensive.

For those whose complaint about jazz has been "I can't hear the melody," the New port Jazz Festival offered a four-hour "Salute to the American Song" on Tuesday night at Philharmonic Hallthat was melody in excelsis.

William A. Bremer, whose brother, Ar thur H. Bremer, was convicted of the attempted assassination of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, pleaded guilty yester day to 178 counts of fraud in the operation of three weightreducing salons. William Brem.

Francis H. Dunne, senior vice president in the Chase Manhat tan Bank's bank operations department- owner securities handling group, died yesterday, apparent of a heart attack. Hewas 43 years old and lived here.

Five hundred and forty Americans celebrated the 197th birthday of the United States today by running down Peachtree Street under a blazing sun. An estimated 523 of them finished an allotted course 6.1 miles, and ended the dayin triumph.

Former State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst of Suffolk County, convicted of bankruptcy fraud, has charged in an application for a new trial that he could have purchased his freedom from prosecution for $50,000 by dealing with "certain intermediaries" who represented themselves as act ing on behalf of a former United States Attorney Generaland deputy attorney general.

Herbert Hill, labor director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has challenged recent reports of black economic progress and charged that minorities have lost ground in skilled jobs in the buildingtrades.
A May decrease of 3,362 per sons in the city's welfare rolls--the eighth consecutive month ly decline-was announced yes terday by Jule M. Sugarman, Human Resources Administrator.
Whether virtue is its own reward at the bridgetable is a debatable point. The virtu ous declarer, for example, works hard to uncover a line of play that will give him aslight extra chance.

The second largest meat packing company in Michigan closed to day and the head of the biggest packing plant in the state said that it might also shut down because "our company is being caught in an impossible squeeze."

William T. McCarthy, who re tired in 1971 as a news editor of The Daily News in New York after 28 years on the news paper's staff, died today in the Benedictine Hospital. He was 65 years old and had lived inPhoenicia since his retirement.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday plans for 13 one-hour early evening prime-time family cials on major themes of American history as its contri bution to the nation's bicentennial celebration in 1976.

An off-duty probationary officer was suspended from duty yesterday after shooting and wounding a man during a fightoutside a Harlem bar.

Government officials and oil industry executives celebrated the Fourth of July this year with a slight sigh of relief as the threat of summer gasoline shortages across the nation ap peared to be less severe than feared during late May andJune.

A Federal District Court said yesterday that a school system could not refuse to hire women merely because theywere unwed mothers.

Howard of Chicago, was mar ried here this afternoon to Gary Edward Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rubin Rob inson of Chicago and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Louis Binstock performed the cere mony in the Grand Ballroomof the Drake Hotel.

An expedition of oddly as sorted explorers will leave New York by plane tomor row for the Gulf of Cadiz, southwest of Spain, where they believe that psychic vibrations out of the void of milleniums will guide them to the Lost Continent of Atlantis.
Julius Kessler, a retired mas ter electrician, died of emphy sema on Monday at his home, 48-53 44th Street, Woodside,Queens. He was 70 years old.
