Pierre Lardinois, the European Eco nomic Community commission er responsible for agriculture, will fly to Washington this weekend for talks on the United States Government's temporary 50 per cent reduction in ex ports of soybeans and derivi tive products. He is expected to discuss future prospects with Earl Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, and George P.Shultz, Treasury Secretary.
Shelby G. Fell, a retired indus trial engineer and a former Mayor of Westfield, died yes terday in Princeton Medical Center. He was 80 years oldand lived here.

The city administration car ries $7-million as a cash re serve in 22 banks, usually long untouched but without bearing interest, in what city officials said this week had been in part a tradition, recognizing bank services for the city, and inpart a community aid.

Sixty Jews now living in an overcrowded slum tenement in Vienna have petitioned Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin to let them return to the Soviet Union. They are disillusioned with their attempt to build a new life inIsrael.
Dr. Julius Hollo, an internist specializing in pulmonary dis eases, died Tuesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 141 East 88thStreet.

Jerry Sturm, a retired National Foot ball League player, said today he expected to be called before a Federal court grand jury to testify about a $30,000 bribe offered him to shave points onthree games.

Jacob A. Wingerter of West Orange was elected Imperial Potentate of North American Shriners at the organization's annual convention in At lanta. A professional engineer with offices in Newark, Mr. Wingerter is a member ofTemple Salaam in Livingston.
David K. Gottlieb, presi dent of Lee Enterprises, Inc., and nationally known in the newspaper-research field, died at his home here today. He was59 years old.

Emaciated bluefish are at tracting a good deal of at tention from New Jersey to Cape Cod this summer. When hooked, 'some of these lean fish fight as well as their full-fleshed counter parts; others, however, donot.

A revolting thing happened to the New York Yankees yesterday before 41,693 persons bent on reviving "the good old days" in Yankee Stadium: They lost a double header to the Boston Red Sox by the hair-trigger scores of 2-1 and1-0.

The annual "Evening at the Pops" series, beamed in from Boston by the Public Broadcasting Service, got off to an excellent start last night at 9:30 over WNET/Channel 13 with an hour of Cole Porter's music.

Harold Pinter's "The Care taker," as unrelenting and as haunting as ever, is back in an Off Broadway production by the Roundabout Theaterat 307 West 26th Street.

David Selden, president of the American Federation of Teach ers, said today that he wel comed a proposal by the lead ership of the rival National Education Association for talks on merger between the twoorganizations.

More than 800,000 divorces--a record number - split American families into two households in 1972. Janice Clinthorne, a re search associate for the Com munity Council of Greater New York, became intrigued with research on how mod erate-income families manageafter such a split.

Westchester County commuters stranded by the closing of Grand Central Terminal between 1:30 A.M. and 5:30 A.M. can get taxi service at group rates beginning July 10, the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade announced yester day. Licensed medallion tax service will be available onlyto railroad stations in Westchester County.
A fire that heavily damaged black Israelite synagogue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday was the work of arsonists, according to Thief Fire Marshal Edwin H.Sheppard.

Riva Ridge became a million aire yesterday. The 4-year-old star in the Meadow Stable moved into the real big money by taking the winner's share of $67,200 of the $112,000 Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct.

William S. Scherman, a re tired executive of Carl Henry, Inc., a New York mail-order concern, died here today. Mr. Scherman, who lived at 42 Glen orchy Road, was 88 years old. He was a brother of the late Harry Scherman, founder of theRook-of-the-Month Club.

Three years after assuring Colorado officials that it would move or destroy all nerve gas at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal, the Army now says it plans to stockpile quantities of the deadly chemical agents there indefinitely.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy flew into the Deep South today to portray Gov. George C. Wal lace and himself as fellow war- C riors against those "who used the people's power to strike atthe rights of the people."

President Salvador Al lende Gossens today called off emergency decrees giving the armed forces the job of policing the country and returned it to full civilian rule. The emergeny situation followed the abortivemilitary uprising Friday.
The Senate Watergate committee has reportedly dropped a hint that Mrs. John N. Mitchell not attend the Watergate hearings next week when her husband, the former Attorney General,testifies.

The first Japanese-owned ho tel in the city will open next Wednesday, aimed at the steadi ly increasing numbers of Japa nese businessmen, art buyers and tourists who are making a growing impact on the American travel market.

The rescue of a ship wrecked English couple who drifted for 117 days in a life boat in the Pacific was re ported by the Coast Guard today.

The Italian Socialist party announced today that it would take part in a center-left coali tion Cabinet led by Premier designate Mariano Rumor. The decision virtually ended Italy's government crisis, which beganthree weeks ago.
Paul Lynner and John Dunn, the first-seeded team, defeated Joe Struhl and Alan Berk, 7-6, 6-3, in the semifinals of the Long Island senior doubles championship at theShore Tennis Club today.
Several big stores, including Korvette, Arnold Constable and S. Klein, made holiday hay yes terday by staying open and drawing large crowds to special Fourth of July sales.

President Nixon's margin of victory over Senator George McGovern in the 1972 Presi dential election would have been "far smaller" if the con test had been held in late June this year, a Gallup Poll releasedyesterday indicates.

The floor mounted and gold-trimmed American flag stands in the middle of the snug, West To ronto office of the Retail Clerks International Union, which has its headquarters in Washington. David Pearson drove his 1971 Mercury to a six length victory over Richard Petty in the 15th annual Fire cracker 400 race today. The two, in a duel of stock car stars, had a four-lap lead over the third-place finisher,Buddy Baker, in a 1973 Dodge.

The referendum scheduled by Greece's military rulers for July 29 will give voters an even narrower choice than first indicated. Retail business in New York City had one of its better months of the year in June as sales of summer goods reflected soaring temperatures. Short-term interest rates are skyrocketing. On Mon day the nation's largest banks boosted their prime rate -the minimum charge to their best business customers -from 73/4 per cent to 8 per cent. When 1973 began, the prime rate ranged from 53 to 6 per cent-while the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Bensinger's Full Pocket thrilled many in a crowd of 15,169 at Liberty Bell Park today when he defeated Dan Lasater's Brick Door by a neck in the third running of the$58,750 Firecracker Handicap.

Queen Elizabeth led a rich and colorful 100th birthday celebration for the Royal Canadian Mounted Po lice today at a time when the venerable force finds itself newly a center of some controversy.

A man renovating his house in suburban Balmain has found more than $250, 000 (Australian) from the ransom paid two years ago by Qantas Airlines in a bombhoax, the police said today.

The Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday that the nation's electric utilities should have a 20.4 per cent margin of generating capability over demand this summer, compared with the 19.6 per cent margin last summer. The trade association predicted that the 1974 summer marginwould rise to 22.3 per cent and then to 24.5 percent in 1975.

President Zuifikar Ali Bhut to indicated tonight that he would ask President Nixon to resume the sale of mili tary supplies to Pakistan. The flow of the Euphrates River was halted to day by a dam for the first time in its history. Tons of cement blocks, re leased electrically by Presi dent Hafez al-Assad of Syria, plunged into the brown waters and sealed off a diversion canal that has permitted construction of a dam three miles across the riverbed here in northeastern Syria.

Bob Goalby scored two eagles on his way to a seven-under par 65 and the first-round lead in the 130,000 Greater Milwau kee-open golf tournament to day. The 42-year-old Goalby played the four par-5 holes six under par and established a one-stroke lead over Larry Ziegler, Buddy Allin and.MikeMorley.
John Cranko, ballet impresario, died accidentally last month and not from a suicidal overdose of drugs as some German news papers said, Coroner Patrick Bofin ruled at an inquest yesterday.

Just as Enrico di Giuseppe was ready to begin singing "E luce van le stelle" at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park on Tuesday night, a roof of um brellas went up over the audi.. ence assembled for the Metro politan Opera's concert performance of Puccini's "Tosca."

President Nixon's main re-election finance committee and officials of a Republican finance com mittee in Maryland were ac cused today of five "apparent violations" of the Federal campaign spending law.

The state bar association of Cali fornia, in a move that could lead to disbarment proceedings, has asked the Senate Water gate committee for information, "at an appropriate time," that could link John D. Ehrlichman or four other lawyers to theWatergate scandal.

The mauled Mets return to New York today after a week of nightmares and will face Henry Aaron, the Atlanta Braves and new questions about Yogi Berra's job which the management in sisted yesterday was safe forthe time being.

A series of decisions by Fed eral Judge Mark A. Costantino of the Eastern District of New York has prompted Government lawyers to complain to the Jus tice Department about the judge's performance, Federalsources said yesterday.
Americans bought a record of 6.1 million new cars in the first six months of 1973 and made June the fourth consecutive month in which buying has topped the 1million mark.
Liseter Gold Coin, the defend ing national high point cham pion, barely won the small pony title from his stablemate, Chantilly, today at the CapeCod Horse Show.
Attacking behind planes, Cambodian infantrymen fought today to dislodge the insurgents who cut Phnom Penh's road to the sea yesterday.

In a move to protect domestic sup plies, the Government imposed export controls today on a list of 41 additional agricultural commodities in the categories of livestock feed, edible oilsand animal fats.

Joseph L. Myler, long-time Washington science writer for United Press International until his retirement last December, and a pioneer reporter on atomic energy, died here todayof cancer. He was 68 years old.

Bill Lee, Boston's 26-year-old left-hander, scattered eight hits and the Red Sox broke out with seven runs in the fourth, their biggest inning of the season, on the-way to a 9-4 triumph over the Yankees before 15,503 spectators at the Stadiumyesterday.

Leonid Stein three times Soviet chess champion, died here yesterday at the age of 39. He succumbed, apparently to a heart attack, at the Rossiya Hotel, off Red Square, as he prepared to leave for the European chess championshipsin Bath, England.

A railroad tank ar caught fire on a siding here today, setting off an explosion in a butane plant that the police said killed ta least four persons and burned 75 others. Flames from the butane plant destroyed the Doxol bulk plant, a nearby tire sales company and a service station in thisnorthwestern Arizona town.
Former Representative J. Irving Whalley, Republican of Pennsylvania, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on one count of mail fraud and two counts of obstruction ofjustice.

Four members of a Newark family, ranging in age from a woman in her late 50's to a 6-year-old great-grandson, were found dead of multiple stab wounds yesterday afternoon. A fifth victim, a young woman believed to be a visitor from Philadelphia, was also foundstabbed to death in the house.

Relations between the Governments of the United States and the Chinese People's Republic are now rou tinely marked by such outstanding examples of recip rocal courtesy that observers must feel they are watch ing a stately and graceful minuet rather than the normalgive and take of contemporary diplomatic relations.

GEOGRAPHY-Rwanda is a small, landlocked central African nation bounded by Zaire, on the West, Uganda onthe north, Tanzania on the east and Burundi on the south.

A food products company owned by the family of United States Treasurer Romana A. Banuelos was disclosed today to be fac ing Government court action for alleged reprisals against em ployes who joined a 10-monthstrike by the teamsters union.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judg ment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable es tablishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and fouras superb.
Lawyers for President Nix on's campaign finance commit tee promised today to provide a full disclosure of the cam paign's financing that tookplace before April 7, 1972.
BEDFORD, N. Y. -Three years to build and three days to raze tells, in brief, the tale of Randal B. Chinnock's do it yourself triangular treehouse.

The Government of the small central African country of Rwanda was overthrown to day in a military coup d'etat after months of tribal unrest between the governing Hutu majority and the Tutsi minority.
Chile's Marxist g President, Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, tonight named seven s new 'Ministers in one of the f biggest cabinet reshuffles since ehe took office in 1970.
Prince Norodom Sihanouk, chief of the Cambodian government in ex ile, said here today that he had no intention of meeting with Henry A. Kissinger when hecomes to Peking.

John H. Ryder, former presi dent of Norm Advertising, Inc., and of Local Trademarks, Inc., died in the Columbia-Presby terian Medical Center on Tues day. He was 82 years old and lived at 274 College Road in theRiverdale section of the Bronx.

A captured Argentine airliner with 28 people aboard landed here today, ending a hijacking drama that began yesterday morning. The aircraft, a Boeing 737 of the state-owned Aerolineas Ar gentiria, touched down at Havana Airport at about 6:30 A.M.

Debbie Campbell of Old Grenwich, Conn., and Sheila McInerney of Rome, N. Y., reached the 18-years final of the Eastern junior tennis cham pionships at the Port Washing ton Tennis Academy today. Miss Campbell defeated Barbara Goldman of Fort Lee, N. J.,

The stock market drifted sideways yesterday in slow trading and closed with minor price changes. The Dow-Jones Industrial average finished at 874.32 up 0.15, after recording losses formost of the session. However,

Ronald D. Nicholson was hired by the University of Texas po lice and planted in a dormitory to act as an undercover agent to find drug users and pushers. Now Mr. Nicholson has been arrested and charged as a deserter from the Navy.

In a major victory for critics of the juvenile-justice system here, the state Court of Appeals has struck down the practice of placing children who are accused of no crime in reform schools with children who have been convicted of such crimesas murder and robbery.
District Attorney Joseph P. Busch said today that he would seek indictments against former White House aides for conspiracy to break into the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former|psychiatrist.
The Environmental Protection Agency announced today a pro posted list of toxic pollutants that would be the basis for limiting discharges of these substances into United Stateswaters.

John R. Ruppel has been named president of Fashion Fabrics, Inc., a fabric retail er with 126 stores in the United States and Canada. He. succeeds John W. Boud, who continues as chairmanand chief executive officer.

Four men and a woman al legedly involved in an under ground weapons-supply ring were arrested yesterday in the East Village after one of them allegedly sold 11 hand grenades to an undercover detective on the sidewalk in front of 390East 10th Street.

The bankrupt Penn Central railroad wants to hire a Los Angeles businessman to handle more than $1-billion in nonrail real estate assets. A proposal to pay Victor H. Palmieri $150,000 annually to manage and market those as sets will be considered July 20 at a hearing before United States District Court JudgeJohn P. Fullam.

Sham, the 3-year-old colt who chased Secretariat in the Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Belmont Stakes, will be out of the running for six months following surgery yesterday for a fracturedright foreleg.

Dr. Joseph Turner, who was director of Mount Sinai Hos pital from 1928 to 1948, when he became a consultant to the board of trustees, died yester day, apparently of a heart at tack, at his home, 1150 ParkAvenue. He was 81 years old.
American Ballet Theater rightly numbers among its select treasures the ballets of Antony Tudor, and among them "Lilac Garden," with its desperately muted pas sion, has a special place offavor.

A man who has been spending his days off in jail in an unusual sentence for assault and rob bery was charged here today with raping a 53-year-old woman while on his dinner break from the all-night job that his jail term was designedto allow him to keep.

The sharply reduced foreign military aid bill as passed recently by the Senate represents a timely attempt to exercise some restraint over a new Administration drive to boost sales of sophisticated military equipment to nations in the Middle East, Latin America and perhapselsewhere.

The Environmental Protection Agency laid down air-pollution standards for aircraft engines today that are less stringent than it originally proposed inDecember.
Gov. Sherman Tribbett has signed into law one of the toughest measures in the na tion against unaddicted heroin and cocaine pushers, but the statute may be difficult toenforce.

The specter of a lox shortage looms over the country, according to retailers, curers and packers, who agree that most prepared salmon may soon be in extremely short supply as a result of heavy buying by Japaneseand Europeans.

The Consolidated Edison Company would be allowed to build relatively small fossil fueled power plants of 200,000 to 300,000 kilowatts within city limits under a new program backed by the Lindsay Administration and the Public Service Commission.

Soon after Mary Jo Kopechne drowned in Senator Edward M. Kennedy's car on Chappaquid dick Island on July 18, 1969, an illegal wiretap was placed on the phone in the Georgetown house where she had lived with three other girls, according to a source close to the Senate Watergate investigating committee.
A former prisoner of war who was charged by a fellow prisoner with conspiracy admitted today that he voluntarily made antiwar broadcasts in captivity and said that hewould "do it again."
In a couple of weeks the British Steel Corporation is expected to announce that it has made its first profit since it beganoperations in 1967.

Contro versy over the direction of Arizona's public education has flared again, with the State Board of Education announcing a tentative policy that would force publishers to delete sec. tions of -textbooks intended foruse in the state.
The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the state law prohibiting suspicious loitering was unconstitutional because it was vague enough to "depend upon the whim ofthe policeman."

Thunderous drumbeats made heads turn this morning on the busy streets of Tokyo's crowded Chuo Ward, where more than 45,000 lower - middle- class households occupy cramped apartments above a welter of family shops, small business offices and one-room factories.
Claude Mouton, the pub lic address announcer at Mon treal's Jarry Park, has al ways taken special delight in pronouncing the name of one of the Expo's catchers,John Boccabella.

Turmoil broke out on the foreign exchange markets today as the dollar fell to new lows for the ninth consecutive day. Officials in Zurich, Brussels, Paris and other centers called on the United States to support the dollar, and there were rumors that a new currency re alignment or other major devel opment to end the monetarycrisis was imminent.

The Consolidated Edison Company would be allowed to build relatively small fossil fueled power plants of 200,000 to 300,000 kilowatts within city limits under a new program backed by the Lindsay Admini station and the Public ServiceCommission.

American Airlines admitted to day that it illegally contributed $55,000 in company funds to President Nixon's re-election campaign early last year. The airline thus became the first corporation voluntarily to ack knowledge an illegal political contribution in the Watergateinvestigation.

A petition seeking the re opening of WXUR, the Rev. Carl Mclntire's radio station, was denied here today by Fed eral Judge Clifford S. Green. The conservative minister's sta tion, in Media, Pa., went off the air at midnight yesterday under orders of the FederalCommunications Commission.

Martin B. Friedheim, who recently had been appointed director of Plan ning and Coordination for the state of Vermont, died last Sat urday at his home here. He was 35 years old and recently hadmoved here from New York.

New York State's environmental picture has brightened considerably as a result of four recent actions in Albany. Most important were Governor Rockefeller's successful sponsorship of land-use planning in the Adirondacks and his renunciation of the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound, on both of which we have already com.mented in these columns.

The Transit Authority, which abandoned coin-operated sub way turnstiles 20 years ago, put one in operation yesterday in a Queens station in a test that it hopes may speed theway for rush-hour passengers.
Dr. Wallace Gobetz, director of the Testing Center at New York University since 1952, died of cancer Thursday. He was 56 years old and lived at540 East 22d Street, Brooklyn.
The police investigating the murders of five persons here uncovered a bloodstained butcher's boning knife today that they said could have inflicted the kind of punc ture wounds found on the bodies.

WASHINGTON, July 6--Mrs. Margaret Woodbury Hotchkiss, formerly of Flushing, Queens, and Saltaire, L.I., widow of George Burton Hotchkiss, professor of marketing at New York University from 1927 to 1950, died here Sunday at the age of 87. She lived in Cleveland.

Interest rates on certain, long-term savings accounts moved as high as 7 per cent yesterday as banks and thrift institutions across the nation moved quickly to take advantage of the new higher rate ceilings for these deposits announced on Thursday by theGovernment.

A Federal grand jury today in dicted a 24-year-old Long Branch man for allegedly rob bing a Deal bank. The man, Robert W. Huffert, was charged with the robbery of the Deal Branch of the New Jersey National Bank on June27. He allegedly took $2.656

The Ronson Corporation, fighting a take-over bid, dis closed yesterday that a New Jersey Federal court had grant ed the company a preliminary injunction to prevent Liquifin, A.G., of Liechtenstein from pro ceeding with a tender offer to, buy up to 52 per cent of Ronson stock.
" We are really angry at Nixon-san," Hiroshi Higashimorl, Secretary General of the Japan Oilseed Processors Association, said today.

The Soviet Union, which prides itself on having one of the world's best school systems, conceded today that rural children, who make up half the school population, were often getting asubstandard education.
Skip Moorhouse of Mantolo king, N. J., was leading the North American Penguin Senior Championships, after winning two races today at the Rich mond Yacht Club in StatenIsland.

The General Services Administration said today that six expensive golf carts and a house trailer, for changing clothes at the beach, had been purchased at the order of the Secret Service for use at the Western White House at SanClemente.

The 235-strong American team in the Maccabiah Games arrived today aboard two airliners The contingent is the biggest foreign entry in the games, in which some 1,800 athletes from 30 countrieswill compete in 20 events beginning Monday.
The starting outfield for the National League in the All-Star game is sure to include Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, but there's a wild race in the balloting for the other twospots.
William B. Tippy, a retired con sultant and utility-company ex ecutive, died of a heart attack yesterday near his home in sub urban Greece. He was 64 yearsold.

Representatives of the Legal Aid Society and the Associ ation of Legal Aid Attorneys met late yesterday afternoon for their first negotiating ses sion since a strike by the so ciety's 400 lawyers began lastMonday.

A 5,000-gallon oil spill be gan washing ashore yesterday in the Smithtown Bay area on the. North Shore of Long Island, along a 13-mile stretch between Eattons Neck Point and Crane Neck Point, the Coast Guardreported.

Six hand grenades were found in two lockers in the Port Authority Bus Terminal here yesterday, and the police said they were part of a ship ment from which an under ground weapons-supply ring sold 11 other grenades to a police undercover man in theEast Village on Thursday.
The police investigating the murders of five persons here uncovered a bloodstained butcher's bon ing knife today that they said could have inflicted the kind of puncture wounds found onthe bodies.

Addressing his countrymen in a soccer stadium Sunday on the 1lth anniversary of Rwan da's independence, President Gregoire Kayibanda said: "I know that some of you are plotting a coup d'etat. Well,here I am if you want to do it."

Beginning today, utility companies will be barred from manhole and street-opening work during the busy daytime hours in the city's central business districts, Acting Trans portation Administrator Manuel Carballo announced. He said new regulations specified that such work, with the exception of emergencies, or for round-the-clock work, would have to be done between 7 P.M. and 7 A.M. on weekdays.

President Nixon met today with Huang Chen, China's representative in the United States, in what appeared to be an effort to reassure Peking that the recent summit meeting with Leonid I. Breznnev did not disturb the building of better relations with Peking.

Among the cultural and en tertainment purveyors in the Berkshires, the Lenox Art Center is an infant just now beginning its third season. But what a lusty infant! Last year it offered among other things the premiere of "Dr. Selavy's Magic Theater" and a splendid production of "TheMother of Us All."

The 27-day strike of ceme tery workers in the metropoli tan area was ended yesterday with a settlement reached only a matter of hours before the leader of the 1,700-man strik ing union was to be jailed forcontinuing the walkout.

Negotiators for the General Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers tenta tively agreed on a new three year contract late last night, it was announced today. A strikehad been set for midnight.
Amie Amizich, re laxed "because I don't need the money that badly," shot a seven-under-par 66 today to take the first-round lead in the$35,000 Marc Equity classic.

Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic nominee for City Council President, announced yesterday his support of Controller Abraham D. Bearne, the party's mayoral nominee, and urged all who backed him in the primary to vote for the Controller.

ULAN BATOR, Mongolia,--Communist governments usually take care to preserve the most damning evidence left behind by the rulers they overthrow. In Moscow they have the Kremlin to demonstrate the opulence and decadence ofthe czars.

Part of the reason is attributed to the contro versy over whether or not Gaylord Perry of the Indians uses saliva or a greasy sub stance to make his pitchesdo strange tricks.
A funny 'thing happened to 75 children on their way to Jones Beach-they wound up outsidethe Nassau County Court here.
Superior Court Judge Charles S. Joelson today ordered off-duty police men and firemen here to stop interfering with traffic while they hand out leaflets about acontract dispute with the city.
Sir Dalrae, winner this year in 10 of 13 starts, heads a field of nine tomorrow night in the opener of the $160,000 United States Pacing Championshipseries at Sportsman's Park.
The Maryland Court of Special Appeals upheld today the 53 year sentence of Arthur H. Bremer, who shot Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama and three other persons at a political rally May 15 last year.
While the Government and McGraw Hill Publications agree that spending for capital out lays will increase this year, they disagree on the degree ofthis increase.

With Fred Beene pitching at his best and his worst and Jim Ray Hart benefiting from a taste of Minnesota magic, the Yankees defeated the Twins, 5-2, tonight and halted their longest losing streaking in twomonths.

Stephen Caldwell, who with his parents and four men was ar rested March 13 at the Ridge wood home of the late Robert N. Caldwell, an assistant editor of The Record of Hackensack, was placed on probation yester day after pleading guilty todistributing marijuana.

A Federal District Court Judge today took the passport of Glenn W. Turner, whose embattled empire is under fire at home and abroad. Judge George C. Young banned any travel by Mr. Turner not approved in advance by the court, ordered him to keep his legal address in the middle district of Florida and ruled that Mr. Turner could not have his passport back except for specific trips, approved by the court throughapplication.
The Pentagon virtually killed today a program on which $67.5-million had been spent to develop a decoy to enable B-52 bombers to confuse Soviet radar.

The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials rose to 173.3 this week from 171.6 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stoodat 119.5 on July 3, 1972.

The Kroger Company, the na tion's third largest supermarket chain, showed some improve ment in earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended June 16, according to the report issued yesterday from its Cincinnati,Ohio, headquarters.

Unemployment declined in June but wholesale prices continued to rise rapidly, the Labor De partment reported today. Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Ad visers, noted in a statement that the increase in wholesale prices, which amounted to 2.3 per cent, took place mainly be fore imposition of the latestfreeze on June 13.

The Mets straggled back to New York last night after their memorably bad trip and were greeted by a Shea Stadium crowd of 37,266 persons and a right-hander from Kansas named Ron Schueler- who depend their woes by pitching the Atlanta Braves to a 2-0 victory.
Dave Stockton shot the best round of his career, a nine under-par 63, to take the sec ond-round lead today by three strokes in the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament.
Mrs. Diane B. Ward's Traveler won the first amateur-owner jumper class by just one knockdown today at the Cape Cod Horse Show.

Joe E. Brown, the beloved elastic-mouth comedian, died at his home here today. He was 80 years old. Mr. Brown was incapacitated by a stroke several years ago, and he had also suffered fromsevere arthritis.

Twenty-five thousand copies of guidelines that a physician says might have headed off the ster ilization of children by an Ala bama clinic were discovered to day in a Federal warehouse. The Federal Office of Economic Opportunity had insisted theywere distributed in 1972.

James Farmer, founder and for mer director of the Congress of Racial Equality, announced to day the formation of a train ing institute for the study of public policy and its relationship to minority problems.

Maj. Gen. Aharon Yariv, adviser to Pre mier Golda Meir on countering terrorism, said today that more than 70 per cent of Arab over seas terrorist plots during thepast 15 months had failed.

Redman Industries, Inc., has signed an agreement under which Pacific Western Mobile Estates, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Hallmark Group Companies, will acquire all of Redman's Mobile HomePark properties.

More than 700 blind people from across the country parti cipated in a demonstration and march yesterday in midtown de manding a greater voice in de ciding which training schools for the blind should receive accreditation.

The United States may withdraw from a 24-year-old international fishing commission as a sym bolic protest over the growing encroachment by foreign fisher men off the American coast, a high official in the CommerceDepartment said last week.

An alleged offer to fix bank ruptcy-fraud charges against former State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst of Suffolk County for $50,000 has been "under review" since last July by the Justice Department, a Federal prosecutor disclosedyesterday.
Pekingese, was named best in show in a field of 1,183 dogs at the fourth annual all-breed event of the Kenilworth Ken nel Club of Connecticut at theFairgrounds today.

One year and 40,000 words ago, Wine Talk began on an experimental basis. Was there enough going on to sustain a weekly column? Would there be any reader interest? No one was sure. Fifty-two weeks later it appears thatthose fears were groundless.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped slightly yes terday, while those in the over the-counter market showed a slight rise. The Amex index finished the day down .01 to 22.24, afterhaving opened unchanged.

A $500,000 renovation of the Lion House at the Cen tral Park Zoo - with simu lated natural habitats and glass windows replacing the barred cages of lions, tigers, baboons and gorillas - is being planned by the Friends of the Zoo, a volunteer com mittee of the New York Zoological Society.

Turmoil broke out on the foreign-exchange markets as the dollar dropped to new lows for the ninth consecutive day. Officials in Zurich, Brussels, Paris and other centers called on the United States to support the dollar and there were rumors that a new currency realignment or other major development to end the monetary crisis was imminent. The Government of South Korea has moved wisely to accept the idea that both Korean states should be al lowed to participate in the deliberations of the United Nations General Assembly this autumn. Korean representation has been an abrasive anomaly at the United Nations for much of the past two decades. South Korea was permitted to have an observer mission at U.N. headquarters while the North has been technically under censure as an aggressor.

Exactly 20 years after the subway token system was in troduced in New York City, the Transit Authority, in an effort to speed service, has embarked on an experiment that could lead to the rein statement of turnstiles thataccept coins.

Today--American Motorcycle Drag Racing Association races at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtown, N. J. Gates open at I P.M., eliminations at 4. Regular weekly pro stock drag races start at 6 P.M.

Miss Catherine Doten Lewis, a research assistant at Rockefeller University in New York, plans to be married here Sept. 1 to Owen Robert Floody, who is studying for a Ph.D. in physiological psychology at Rockefeller as a graduate fellow.

The engagement of Miss Kristen HazelTalbott to Thomas Kittredge Sawyer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Wilbur H. Sawyer of Scarsdale, N. Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Talbott Jr. An August wedding is planned.

A major change in the status of two 'horse shows on the fall indoor circuit was announced yesterday by the American Horse Shows Association. The Washington International show has been made an official, or C.S.I.O.

Edie Witzler of Boonton, N.J., swept the equitation division and rode the winner of the junior working hunter championship today at the Hilltop Horse Show. Miss Witzler captured the Medal Class, the Maclay Trophy and beat out Stevie Stocovocz of Yardley, Pa,, for the horsemanship championship.

Dave Stockton, seeking his first victory since 1971, turned back the challenge of Bob Goalby with a 71 and retained a twostroke lead after the third round of the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament today.

An adventurer's plan to make a solo, five-day flight across the Atlantic in a balloon had to be scrapped yesterday when the 90 by 52 foot balloon escaped from its gondola and sailed off into the sky over Williamson, N. Y., where Bob Sparks was preparing to make a last test flight before setting out for France.

The demise of the proposed Rye-Oyster Bay bridge was good news in Turtle Bay. With second-story tools as sophisticated as an electronic short-circuiter and as unsubtle as a sledgehammer, a team of burglars broke into a supposedly burglar-proof preciousmetals supply house in Queens before dawn yesterday and made off with $500,000 in gold.

Peter Albinski of Baldwin, L. I., will defend his state men's archery championship on July 14 and 15 at Eden, a suburb of Buffalo. His main cornpetition is expected to come from A. Richard Hunter of Wallkill, who finished 14 points behind Albinski last year.

And as he spoke there was no question that Dr. Abderrahman Khene, an Algerian who was recently appointed secretary general of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), knew the business of oil.

To the Financial Editor: The illustration accompanying William D. Smith's "Detroit's Dilemma: Gas Hogs or Fuel Savers" (June 24) showing fuel consumption differences between large and small cars is most telling. Some of the small cars get even better gas mileage.

As soon as he stepped off the team bus outside Shea Stadium, the kids surrounded him. He walked among them, signing autographs. But quickly Henry Aaron was inside the players' entrance. Another few steps and he was inside the Atlanta Braves' locker room. Waiting for him were five newsmen.
Reggie Cleveland held the San Francisco Giants hitless for six innings to pace the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-1 victory today.

IT was just a year ago today. She danced up a storm as Odette/Odile in "Swan Lake." Midway through the third act, stunned by her virtuosity, the audience burst into cheers and applause and stopped the show for several minutes. Afterwards, her fans, some hearing gifts, serenaded her at the stage door of the New York State Theater with "Happy Birthday."

EAST HAMPTON, L. I.--When it comes to sibling rivalry, William, Robert and James Bain are experts. Identical triplets, the youths recently graduated as the top three scholars from the local high school with Jim and his 94.550 average barely edging Bob (94.500) and Bill (94.388) to lead the 160-member senior class. They finished elementary school in the same order.

Patrick McVey, a character actor, died Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 435 East 77th Street. On television, Mr. McVey had played Steve Wilson in "Big Town" and also acted in "Boots and Saddles" and "Manhunt."

The partly decomposed body of a child about 2 or 3 years old and clad only in a diaper was found yesterday in the Hudson River near the 79th Street marina. The police of the 20th Precinct said it was not possible to determine immediately the child's sex.

IRIS CARE If the iris garden has been sluggish and not up to standard, division is probably what is needed plus a good old-fashioned replenishing of soil. There is no better time than the present to begin. From now until late July, the rhizomes can be dug, divided, and replanted.

Louise Denison, who as "L. Denison" was assistant editor of Field Stream Magazine at her retirement in 1967 after 41 years with the magazine, died in a nursing home here today. She was 78 years old and lived at 30 Weston Avenue with her husband, Willard S. Neefus, a retired farmer.

HELSINKI -- The Foreign Ministers of 35 nations gathered in a modern concert hall here last week. They all made speeches about how important it was to end the cold war and lay the basis for Europe's future security. But they disagreed fundamentally about how to accomplish this.

The engagement of Miss Lisbeth Fenton to Robert S. Grossman has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Arnold N. Fenton of Great Neck and Montauk, parents of the future bride. Mr. Grossman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Grossman of Scarsdale, N. Y.

The America Ned Calmer portrays in THE AVIMA AFFAIR (Doubleday, $6.95) is definitely pre-Watergate. more than 100 American Peace Corps volunteers were camping out at the Entebbe, Uganda, Airport tonight after their charter flight from London to Bujumbura, Burundi, was ordered back to Entebbe after a refueling stop there.

Mrs. Eunice Fung Lewis, a social worker and the founder of the Evangel Mission at 29 East Broadway, in Chinatown, died yesterday at her home in Rego Park, Queens. She was 83 years old, Mrs. Lewis and her late husband, Francis H. Lewis, established the mission in the mid-nineteen-fortics.
THE 1974 edition of "A Guide Book of United States Coins"-- better known as the "Red Book"--is now being distributed to coin dealers, book shops and coin and hobby counters in department stores.

The engagement of Miss Francesca Florence Waring Schager to Arthur Brewster Lawrence 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Franz Schager of Oyster Bay and Key Biscayne, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. L. Hadden Merriman of Bailey's Bay, Bermuda, and A. Brewster Lawrence Jr. of New York and St. James, L. I. A fall wedding is planned.

Committees of the City Council will hold the following public hearing and open meeting this week at City Hall. TUESDAY--The Committee on Finance will hold a public hearing at 10 A.M. on certain expense-budget modifications.

Dr. Roger G. Mazlen likes to write letters. But, while he probably does his best to keep in touch by mail with aunts, uncles, cousins and friends, his most prolific correspondence is directed at elected public officials.

Rabbinic and lay leaders of American Orthodox Judaism have called on Jewish federations and welfare funds throughout the country to give more financial aid to education because of the recent United States Supreme Court decision that barred any Government aid to parochial schools.

In St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Marion Colette Platt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Platt, was married to Scott F. Russotto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Russotto of East Greenwich, R. I.
Ray H. Sullivan, a retired vice president of the Ford Motor Company, was found dead here today in his room at the Mohican Hotel, where he had lived for about a year. He was 84 years old.

Dr. Philip Handler, president of the United States National Academy of Sciences, said here this week that American science was "a cut ahead" of Soviet science but the distance between them was not very great.

Rear Adm. Henry S. Morgan Jr., U.S.N., of Seoul, Korea, and Mrs. Morgan of Washington and Stonington, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Morgan, to Peter Lincoln Folsom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lincoln Folsom of Delray Beach, Fla., and Centerville, Mass.

The Kentucky Colonels of the American Basketball Association, sold to a Cincinnati group less than a month ago, have been resold to Kentucky business interests for an estimated $2-million, it was announced today.

A growing practice of transferring vessels of the American tuna fleet to foreign registry has prompted new Government measures aimed at combating large scale overfishing and out-of-season fishing in international waters of the eastern Pacific.

Inflation is beginning to roll back living standards in many countries. The pinch is greatest on food as consumer demand continues high on nonessential items and some countries are experiencing a new economic upsurge. A canvass of the state of inflation in major world regions, completed by New York Times correspondents, indicates that the malady is getting worse and apparently becoming chronic in most of them.

Miss Barbara Louise Long, who is studying for a Ph.D. in anthropological biology at Harvard University, plans to be married in October in Cambridge, Mass., to Donald William Baker Jr., a candidate for a master's degree at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

The United States collegiate all-star men's basketball team beat the Kwangtung Provincial team, 101-82, but the American national women's champions from John F. Kennedy College lost to the Chinese, 63-55, in the Americans' farewell games in China played in Canton yesterday, Peking reported today.

From its sloping aerodynamic front end to the wind spoilers in the rear, the racing car brought here this week by Richard Burman, a California truck driver, looked as if it had been created to run against A. J. Foyt or Bobby Unser at Indianapolis.

Fred Auby, 36 years old, of Rockford, Ill., had a heart transplant today at University Hospitals here, a hospital spokesman said. Mr. Auby, who is a criminologist, suffered from degenerative heart muscle disease.

EAST BRUNSWICK--The East Brunswick Women's Caucus has filed a complaint against the local Police Department, charging that its hiring practices exclude women. The complaint was filed late last month with the State Division of Civil Rights.

Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, is giving the leaders of Egypt a foretaste of how difficult it may be for them to live with him if the planned merger between the two countries takes place.
Jupiter-bound spacecraft Pioneer 11 has crossed the orbit of Mars, only the second spacecraft to perform the feat, control headquarters say.

Cambodian Government troops under heavy attack by Communist forces with drew from two positions and left a third unit isolated in the crumbling defensive perimeter south of Phnom Penh, reports from the area said today.

Benjamin Kimlau, a Chinese-American funeral director here from 1930 to 1971, died Friday at his home, 28 Mulberry Street. His age was 81. Mr. Kimlau was the father of Lieut. Benjamin Ralph Kimlau, Army Air Forces, in whose honor the first Chinese-American Legion Post was named.

Veronica Lake, one of the screen's leading box-office favorites of the early nineteen forties, instantly recognizable for her long blond hair falling over her right eye, died yesterday in Burlington, Vt. She had been hospitalized there since June 26 for treatment of acut?? hepatitis.

At this spring's showings of fall ready-to-wear in Paris, the accent was on the word blousonn." to French designers, that meant bloused jackets to be worn over the new thicker sweaters. American manufacturers have made blousonn" mean anything from an overblouse to an offshoot of the Levi jacket.
Mayor Lindsay is drafting a protest to the White House concerning alleged delays, mismanagement and cutbacks in the Nixon Administration's financing of antinarcotics treatment programs.

TRENTON -- The state's Health Department has adopted guidelines to regulate hygiene end safety in the perorning of abortions. The rules, which cover the first 12 weeks of pregnancy, are not mandatory and they avoid the sensitive questions of Medicaid support for abortions and whether hospitals can be required to provide the service.

A 15-year-old suspected purse snatcher was caught on the Upper East Side early yesterday by a passer-by who chased him four blocks in a car and then grabbed him as the police converged on the scene.

Mayor Lindsay charged yes terday that the Rockefeller ad ministration had not yet forged a practical plan for implement ing the state's tough new drug law, although the law is ex pected to cause thousands of extra trials after it goes intoeffect Sept. 1.

The Whitney Museum's new summer exhibition which runs until Sept. 16, is sort of daring in its way. Called "The American Frontier - Images and Myths," it accepts the 19th-century notion that a painting is a picture of some thing and that what it is a picture of is the mostimportant thine about it.
The 112 Peace Corps men and women who were freed yesterday after two days of anxious detention in Uganda are among the luckier targets of President IdiAmin's erratic xenophobia.

A Public Service Commission examiner recommended yester day that the New York Tele phone Company be allowed to charge 7.1 cents for an informa tion call if the number is listedin any directory in the state.

Only 361. summonses were issued to illegal parkers yester day in the city's new get-tough program between 30th and 66th Streets, compared to as many as 1.200 tickets a day issued in the same area last week when the drive officially gotunder way.
The ninth Maccabiah Games, bringing Jewish sportsmen here from 27 coun tries, opened tonight under tight security as a precaution against a possible Arab at tempt to disrupt the competition.

Harold Weston Jr. of Green wich Village snapped the un beaten string of Vito Antuofer mo of Brooklyn at 18 last night at the Felt Forum when the referee, Herbie Kronowitz, stopped his fight with the Ital ian-born middleweight at 2 min utes 53 seconds of the fifthround.

Fifteen food establishments in the city were cited yesterday for violating the Health Code after their owners had failed to provide "valid reasons" for not meeting the standards durine two inspections.
The Japan Communist party registered strong gains in Tokyo's munici pal election yesterday but, with their leftist allies, failed to gain a joint majority in the Metropolitan Assembly.
An off-duty patrolman was shot and wounded late last night after he interrupted a burglary in the home of a neighbor, a police sergeant whowas away on vacation.

A while ago, a reader com plained that a famous and expensive restaurant here would honor only one brand of credit card - not, pre sumably, one of those he was carrying. An inquiry reveals that the restaurant had itsreasons.

Watergate investigation.

Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that he would seek to restore a requirement that can didates disclose the occupa tion and place of business of contributorss when campaign reform legislation reaches theSenate floor later this month.

In a fresh effort to block a trans Alaska oil pipeline, the Can adian Government has told Washington that if such a line were built the likelihood of a line- ever being laid through Canada's Mackenzie River Val ley to the upper Middle Western states would be slim.

Officials of North Vietnam's Communist party and Govern ment leaders arrived today for their first official visit to the Soviet Union since the signing of the Vietnam peace agreement with the United States in January.

Two physicians reported en couraging results today from the first known American use of a technique developed in Japan to correct a congenitalliver defect in babies.

Robert H. Simpson cele brated his 93d birthday and his 234th arrest yesterday. Mr. Simpson has been picket ing the state Capitol for a dec ade over a variety of causes. He was arrested yesterday under an antipicketing law passed several years ago in aneffort to keep him away.
Attorneys for John N. Mitchell moved yesterday to dismiss an indictment against the former Attorney General on the ground that the prose cution was "guilty of persistentand deliberate misconduct."

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's judgment of quality in rela tion to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may he translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four assuperb.

College students are streaming into this city to learn how the Government works. These sum mer interns, numbering about 5,000, come from more than 300 schools to spend one week to three months here. Some are paid and some are not for working on Capitol Hill, in the White-House and Federal de partments or for public interestgroups.

With the Democratic-held Governor ;hip and a Senate seat to be killedd next year, Republican politicians across Alaska are waiting to see what former Gov. Walter J. Hickel will do. Among other things, he seems to have at least a comer of his mind on the Presidency andVice-Presidency.

It was a bad day yester day to be dressed up as Br'er Bear in a thick fur costume and to dance in the sun in front of Alice Tully hall, but the occasion called for it, and so it was done with. a goodwill that perhaps only an employee of Walt Disney, Productions could muster forthe stint in 90-degree heat.

Directors of the National Detroit Corporation approved yesterday a plan to purchase from time to time up to 400,000 shares of its common stock. The stock of the holding company for the National Bank of Detroit closed at 41 7/8, up 3/4, on the NewYork Stock Exchange.
Dwight F. Davis Jr., a for mer vice president of the Mets, the New York National League baseball club, died today in Southampton Hospital after a short illness. He was 66 yearsold and lived here.
A noted Soviet Jewish scholar, Dmitri M. Segal, 36 years old, and his wife, Yelena, a granddaughter of the Soviet novelist Aleksei N. Tolstoi, ar rived here today as new immigrants.
A homosexual lawyer can not be denied admission to the New York State Bar solely on the grounds of his homosexual ity, the State Court of Appealshas ruled.

The small-framed lawyer who arrived in Florida in December of 1971 resembled in style countless other young bachelorson a brief winter's fling.

Six telephones were ringing at once on Dieter Henke's desk in the Frankfurt currency exchange. But today, not too much to the surprise of Mr. Henke and his colleagues, the dollar stopped sinking and instead made a fairly healthy recovery closing this afternoon at 2.3750 marks to the dollar from a start of 2.33.

A rally by the dollar in overseas currency markets relieved some of the upward pressure yesterday on short-term interest rates, or money rates, and generated demand for securities of the United States Treasury.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the world's biggest broker and underwriter, confirmed yesterday that it was cutting the base salaries of some 140 top executives in an effort to reduce costs.

SHOE-IN Summertime and the living has moved out to Southampton and points east in the art world, so what to show that's seasonable in town? Up at the Kornblee Gallery, 58 East 79th Street (UN 1-4245), they are doing a show called "Speakers."
Ann Klein, unsuccessful candidate in the Democratic gubernatorial primary says she will not run to retain her Assembly seat.
Henry G. Greenfield, a certified public accountant, was drowned on Sunday in Bermuda, where he had been vacationing. He was 80 years old and lived at 80 Central Park West.

" Have you been a victim of a robbery in the past year?" residents of the West Side were asked. "Yes," replied 34.4 per cent of the women who answered, 19.4 per cent of the men and 44.4 per cent of young people.

Reginald Denenholz, a theatrical press agent for nearly four decades, died yesterday at his home, 130 West 47th Street, where he had been recuperating following abdominal surgery. He was 59 years old.
In an effort to stymie wouldbe burglars, the State University at Albany is preparing for a widespread change in locks that will cost $100,000, a university spokesman said.

John N. Mitchell swore today that he had deliberately withheld information from President Nixon about the Watergate bugging, the cover-up and "White House horror stories" to prevent any damage to the President's bid for re-election.

The United States has a new neighbor, the independent state of the Bahamas. Scarcely fifty miles off the Florida coast, visited by a million and a half American tourists every year, the Bahamas have ties almost as intimate with this country as Canada and Mexico, though obviously on a lesser scale. It is important to both the Bahamas and the United States that these ties remain close.

Secretary General Waldheim said today that public debate in the Security Council would not lead to an immediate solution of Middle Eastern problems. "I think that we are realistic enough to understand this," Mr. Waldheim said.

Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley said yesterday that he was planning a major reorganization of the detective force that would put about half of the detectives back in the precincts and make detectives responsible for the first time to uniformed precinct commanders.

The Department of Justice broadened tonight the investigatory mandate of a special Federal grand jury that will be convened July 20 to study the illegal Government drug raids on two families in Collinsville, III.

TRW, Inc., a diversified industrial producer, had a 32 per cent rise in second-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 28 per cent, bringing the half-year increases to 34 per cent for both sales and earnings, the Cleveland-based concern reported yesterday.

The six recently elected members of the District 1 School Board on the Lower East Side have voted to curb the powers of Luis Fuentes, the controversial District 1 superintendent, and are looking into the legality" of his employment contract, which has two years to run.
The Federal National Mortgage Association said today the average yield on both Government-backed and conventional mortgages rose sharply at the latest auction.
New York's newest and most spectacular hotel moves closer to construction with the expected announcement of the project today by Mayor Lindsay and architect-developer John Portman of Atlanta.

In a meeting at the White House, John D. Ehrlichman may have tried to jockey former Attorney General John N. Mitchell into a seat close to a hidden microphone, Mr. Mitchell told Senate Watergate investigators today.

The office of Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. made public today the text of a letter from Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, retired, former Chief of Staff of the Army, praising the Connecticut Republican for having "the moral courage to re-state Americanism at its best."

A series of explosions ripped through a prefabricated "blowout" assembly bunker and a van loaded with hand grenades today at a north Texas munitions plant. Four persons were killed and 35 injured-most of them women.

Senator James H. Wallwork, Republican of Essex County, asked the State Board of Institutional Trustees today "to reconsider its ill-timed and ill-advised dismissal" of Archibald L. Alexander Jr. as chairman of the State Board of Prison Trustees.
Mayor Lindsay and the man most likely to succeed him, Controller Abraham D. Beame, clashed head on yesterday in a confrontation that jeopardized a pet Lindsay project, the Madison Avenue Mall.
Mrs. David Eisenhower, accompanied by her husband, carried her role as her family's main public spokesman to England tonight.

John Gentile, an assistant professional at the Round Hill Club in Greenwich, Conn., won the Westchester County Golf Association's 51st open championship by two strokes today with 209 at Sunningdale Country Club.

Fred C. Ikle took over as head of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency today, determined to rebuild confidence in the organization-badly demoralized by one of the Nixon Administration's most severe personnel shake-ups.
About 50 American Peace Corps volunteers flew to their training camp in eastern Zaire today on the final stretch of a journey interrupted by a two day detention in Uganda.
New York and London have one great thing in common. With a monotony that can only be termed regular, every year they both enjoy, as much as possible, their worst theater season ever.

John N. Mitchell swore today that he had deliberately withheld information from President Nixon about the Watergate bugging, the cover-up and "White House horror stories" to prevent any damage to the President's bid for re-election.
The players of the American Symphony Orchestra will have to be careful from now on when they complain about the management. They are it.

A $10-million contract under which the Cleveland Crane and Engineering division of the McNeil Corporation of Akron, Ohio, will provide the materials handling system for the foundry of the Soviet Union's huge Kama River truck plant was announced yesterday.
The nation's Young Republicans were urged today to take a formal stand supporting President Nixon in the Watergate controversy and declaring that "the Republican party is not the party of Watergate."

BERKELEY, Calif.-A senior citizen of my acquaintance who lives in a mobile home park in the FullertonSanta Ana-Whittier area of Orange County, the heartland of Western American conservatism, has just provided me with an unexpected reaction to the Watergate affair.

Marco A. Rigau Jr. said yesterday that he had been "fired" as national director of the Puerto Rican Migration Division for his efforts to enforce wage and working conditions for the 15,000 farm migrant workers employed on the mainland through Puerto Rican government contracts.
State Senator John J. Marchi of New York, the Republican candidate for Mayor, toured northern Israel today as part of an unabashedly political pilgrimage.

The stock market posted its broadest advance in six weeks yesterday in response to renewed strength in the dollar overseas and to indications here that the Nixon Administration was rapidly moving toward Phase 4 of its economic program.
The Nixon Administration said today that it "unequivocally" opposed any unilateral American withdrawal of troops from Western Europe.
John N. Mitchell's version of events in the Watergate affair varies drastically and irreconcilably from the testimony of other key witnesses heard by the Senate investigators.

Conservatives in the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod took majority control today of the governing board of Concordia Seminary of St. Louis, the largest Lutheran - and the third largest Protestant - theological school in the country.

To the Editor: For the last twenty years I have lived in New York Times country (specific locales being too varied to list) but I am a product of Senator Sam Ervin's North Carolina. And while, given that opportunity, I would certainly vote contrarily to most votes cast by that singular gentleman, I take enormous pride these days in sharing a state with him.
Jean Beliveau has turned down a reported million-dollar deal to play for the Quebec Nordiques of the World Hockey Association. Beliveau,

United Financial Corporation of California announced yesterday that it intended to acquire up to 200,000 shares of its common stock on the open market or through unsolicited private transactions at prices not higher than the then current price on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock closed at 7 3/4, up 3/8. The company has 6,497,000 shares outstanding and is the parent of the Citizens Savings and Loan Association.
The Senate voted today to expand the powers of the Federal Trade Commission to combat unfair methods of competition by businesses.

Following are excerpts from a transcript of testimony of John N. Mitchell on the 17th day of hearings on the Watergate case today before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:...

Samuel Dash, the chief counsel of the Senate's Watergate committee, said tonight that the panel might consider taking some action in reply to President Nixon's refusal to supply voluntarily certain White House documents that the committee has asked for.
The great dam across the Euphrates River 20 miles downstream from here will soon drown this agricultural village in a lake that will force 60,000 peasants to find new homes.

One of two major strikes that crippled Puerto Rico's basic services, causing the Governor to mobilize the National Guard, was settled today when the island's largest electric workers union agreed to return to work immediately.

The Suffolk County Legislature today passed a controversial resolution authorizing construction of six jetties to prevent further erosion at Westhampton Beach, but County Executive John V. N. Klein immediately vowed to veto the legislation.

About 150 slogan-chanting cab drivers and owners of taxi companies in Newark picketed City Hall yesterday to dramatize their opposition to city regulations. Members of the Airport Taxi Management Association were demonstrating against a city regulation to go into effect on Aug. 1 ordering all Newark cabs over five years old off the road, no matter what their condition.
Assistant District Attorney Carl B. Feldbaum of Philadelphia was named today to the staff of Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor in the Waterate case.

Plans for constructing a $20-million O'Hare Sports Arena northwest of Chicago to house the Chicago Cougars of the World Hockey Association were announced today by Donald E. Stephens, Mayor of suburban Rosemont. He said groundbreaking for the Chicago area's first new major sports facility since 1934 was expected within 90 days. It is hoped, he said, the arena will be ready for the Cougars' 1974-75 season.
A Roman Catholic priest said today that he had received reports from Spanish missionaries in Mozambique of Portuguese Army masacres of Africans comparable to the My Lai killings in South Vietnam.

John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, reported yesterday that operating income before extraordinary items for the second quarter was $29.4-million, or $1.07 a share, up 47 per cent over operating income of $20million, or 73 per cent a share, a year earlier.
The Nixon Administration's top economists said today that what appeared to be pure discrimination reduces the average earnings of women to 80 or 90 per cent of what men make for the same work.

More than 80 firms have failed since a new Government agency began operations designed to protect investors vis-a-vis brokers back in 1971 But the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, the agency charged with this responsibility, has found itself involved almost exclusively with over-the-counter firms.
A three-alarm fire destroyed the Good Fair Meat Market at 1729 Broadway, near Rockaway Avenue in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, last night.

An American Congressional delegation paid a brief visit today to this East China city, the site of the last United States Embassy in China and capital of the country before the Communist take-over in 1949.

" Our Government has no intention of killing the goose that lays the golden egg." The line is from a speech by Lynden 0. Pindling, Prime Minister of the Bahamas, which became independent of Britain today.

The final count of the July elections gave the ruling Institutional Revolutionary party 189 of the 194 direct election seats in the Chamber of Deputies, the federal electoral commission announced today.

Wallace (Bud) Smith, 44 years old, a former lightweight boxing champion, was shot and killed today when he attempted to act as a peacemaker between a man and a woman who were arguing on a city street.
At least a half-dozen lawyers are working at the White House on President Nixon's defense in the Watergate case, either full time or nearly full time.
The National Academy of Record Arts and Sciences has announced the establishment of a Hall of Fame "to honor recordings of lasting, qualitative or historical significance."
Two Eastern Shore state Senators won their party nominations today in a primary race preceding a special election to fill the seat of Representative William O. Mills, a Repubican.

The terrace of Saigon's Hotel Continentale is one of the few constants in the capital's kaleidescopic physical and human landscape. In the late afternoon and on into the evening, the good and the evil sit cheek by jowl sipping and nibbling, buying and selling, drinking and brooding.

COBLESKILL, N.Y.--Frank Ambrosano, a 40-year-old dairy farmer, stood outside his barn next to a wagon filled with bales of rainsoaked hay. He looked out over a field of ankle-high corn, planted two weeks, after rain washed out his first planting, and a silo whose top had been blown off by high winds.
Jimmy Wright of Inwood won the annual 54-hole Long Island Professional Golfers' Association championship today over the 6,850-yard Indian Hills
Pakistan and India dead locked for two months, are set to begin a crucial effort to resolve the tangled issues divided the subcontinent.
The Soviet Union and France today adopted a 10-year program of cooperation in industry, providing for the construction of industrial complexes in the two countries.

John D. Ehrlichman, once one of President Nixon's closest advisers, has told Senate investigators that he believed shortly after the Watergate burglary that high officials of the President's re-election campaign had been involved in the operation.
President Nguyen Van Thieu today announced sweeping changes in the organization of South Vietnam's civil service aimed at increasing its efficiency and stamping out coruption.

The board of directors of the Recording Industry Association of America, the trade organization of the record business, met secretly yesterday to discuss formulation of a "positive plan of action" to combat the mounting allegations of payola and drug use in the industry.

The nineteen-thirties are now so far in the past that the sifting process of passing time has left Billie Holiday and Ella Fitzgerald and Mildred Bailey as the obviously great female vocalists of the decade.
Robert P. Brewer, a retired Navy commander, has been promoted to the post of executive director of the United States Naval Institute.
Twelve young tigers escaped last night from a wildlife reserve near this community, 35 miles south of Montreal, and nine were recaptured today near the reserve's grounds.

Darrell Evans, Atlanta's young third baseman, lists stamp collecting as his principal hobby, according to the Baseball Register. He might have added home-run hitting. He shares the National League lead with 25.
With undiminished fervor, the 99-year-old Women's Christian Temperance Union is girding itself for a second 100 years of war against alcohol.
State Senator Robert Garcia, a close associate and campaign aide of Representative Herman Badillo, said yesterday that there was a 50-50 chance the Congressman would run for Mayor as an independent.

The Agriculture Department reported today prospects for strong increases in soybean, corn, wheat and feed-grain crops this year. Nevertheless, various Government officials warned consumers that food prices would climb still higher before 1973 is over.

A 25-year-old Brooklyn man was fatally shot and another man was wounded last night when a shootout erupted between two Hispanic groups outside a social club in the Williamsburg section, the police reported.
Stuart Cohen, a 20-year-old member of the Jewish Defense League, was sentenced in Federal Court here yesterday to five months in prison for the illegal purchase of three rifles.

Anton Jungherr, Newark's director of Finance, resigned today. Opponents of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson charged that the resignation was another example of his administration's inability to retain high-level officials.

Buses, trucks and automobiles were burned in Belfast last night in a new wave of terrorist violence.
The military-backed Government and the opposition have hardened their positions, confronting Uruguay with her worst political crisis in decades.
The beach at Sandy Hook State Park was closed today until further notice because of the presence of the "red tide," millions of small marine microrganisms that irritate the eyes and noses of bathers.

A sanitation worker was shot on a South Bronx street yesterday when he stopped his truck to chastise a group of youths who sprayed the windshield with water from an open fire hydrant, the police reported.
A Senate Armed Services subcommittee challenged today a major new strategic program of the Administration by voting against accelerated develop. ment of the Trident missilelaunching submarine.

United States Attorney Paul J. Curran disclosed here yesterday that a Federal grand jury had returned an indictment against a New York stockbroker and four others on charges of bribery and stock fraud.

The French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center filed a petition under the Federal Bankruptcy Act yesterday to postpone repayment of nearly $6-million owed to creditors.
A report on the shooting deaths of two Southern University students last November says the entire confrontation between law enforcement officers and students was unjustified.
The crafty optometrist was fitting a customer with eyeglasses. As he spoke, he studied the customer's facial expression for a clue to how far he could go. "That will be $20," the optometrist said.

Continuing the rally that began late Monday, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market closed higher yesterday. The Amex index finished up 10 to 22.36. Advances far outdistanced declines-573 to 229 -while 271 issues were unchanged.

Starting today and continuing for a month, public television station WNET/13 and the New York Unversity School of Law will jointly operate a Consumer Help Center at the station. The resultant findings will be used in a weekly affairs program.
NEWPORT, R. I. - "These rich are very star-struck," said one of the technical men, herding what he called "the socials" off the set of The Great Gatsby.

Agriculture Department reported today prospects for strong increases in soybean, corn, wheat and feed-grain crops this year. Nevertheless, various Government officials warned consumers that food prices would climb still higher before 1973 is over.

Abram Chasins, author, musician and former music director of WQXR, radio station of The New York Times, has been appointed director of a twoyear music and drama educational program for KUSC-FM under the auspices of the University of Southern California's School of Performing Arts.

Everything is looking upand down-for the Thurston family. Robert N. Thurston and his wife, Jessica, have a trampoline in their driveway and also have four daughters who are champions in the sport. When there is any free time around the Thurston home, either one or more family members can be found on the trampoline, improving their skills.

Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell testified today that he opposed the "Huston plan" for expanded domestic intelligencegathering because of its illegal aspects, and that he had made his objections known to President Nixon and H. R. Haldeman, the former White House chief of staff.
Mayor Lindsay and the man most likely to succeed him, Controller Abraham D. Beame, clashed head on yesterday in a confrontation that jeopardized a pet Lindsay project, the Madison Avenue Mall.

The dollar got off the floor this week, but on legs that remain rubbery. After the pounding the currency had taken during the preceding two weeks, however, the news of the dollar's ability to rise at all was enough to spark a rally in Wall Street.

Jean Beliveau has turned down a reported million-dollar deal to play for the Quebec Nordiques of the World Hockey Association. Beliveau, 41-year-old vice president and director of corporate relations for the Montreal Canadiens, met with Paul Racine, president of the Nordiques, and Jacques Plante, the general manager, to discuss what he called "a very generous and attractive offer."

A search for the two missing Canadian truce observers who disappeared in Communist-held territory on Juine 28 was delayed again today by continued disputes between Canadian officials and Vietcong representatives.

Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, said today it was "debatable" whether President Nixon could be impeached for not knowing of the role of his staff in the Watergate affair, even if he had no personal knowledge of the breakin.
The Nixon Administration's labormanagement advisory committee declared today with a single vote that "all wage and price controls should be eliminated as soon as possible this year."

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.
What folks had wondered most about John N. Mitchell, a former strong man of the Nixon Administration, was how he would bear up before the Senate Watergate committee.
A 4-year-old girl playing with matches set off firecrackers and a fire that killed a 10-month-old baby girl in an apartment at 5 West 137th Street yesterday morning, the police reported.
State Senator Robert Garcia, a close associate and campaign aide of Representative Herman Badillo, said yesterday that there was a 50-50 chance the Congressman would run for Mayor as an independent.

The rather synthetic good fellowship and less than fully credible mutual cordiality that President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev exhibited toward each other during the latter's visit here last month are apparently symptoms of a contagious diplomatic disease.

A large real-estate concern with extensive holdings in Times Square said yesterday that it would convert the Aristo Hotel, formerly a prostitute's hangout, into housing for artists as part of a new effort to upgrade the tawdry area.

Justice Samuel R. Rosenberg ruled yesterday in the State Supreme Court in Manhattan that despite the Ithaca Medical Center's "loose, careless, improper" management, the methadone clinic was a necessity and must stay open. Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz had sued to have the center, a methadone clinic at 177 East 84th Street, closed as a public nuisance.
With $40,000 in prize money on the line, it was inevitable that Rod Jenkins would put in a first-time appearance at the Lake Placid horse show.
The Labor Department announced today that $239-million in nationwide Neighborhood Youth Corps funds had been released to the states to provide summer jobs for poor youths.

Charles W. Colson, former special counsel to President Nixon, has refused to give the Senate Watergate committee staff any further interviews before his public testimony, knowledgeable Senate sources said today.
