As a new flag of black, aquamarine and gold was raised here today, the Bahamas became an independent nation, emerging from three centuries of British colonial rule.
Mike Ford, 22-year-old member of a noted Westchester golfing family, won the Ike tournament today by two stfokes.

John W. G. Powell, a retired investment counselor and the husband of Dr. Janet Travell, who was White House physician to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, died Monday of cancer in George Washington University Hospital. He was 75 years old.

Six Roman Catholic protesters were arrested today when they knelt to pray during a tour through the White House. It was the third such incident in five days, all of them intended to protest the bombing of Cambodia.
State Senator John J. Marchi of New York, the Republican candidate for Mayor, toured northern Israel today as part of an unabashedly political pilgrimage.

The state Republican chairman, Richard M. Rosenbaum, charged yesterday that the Democratic state chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, had demanded that half of the 100 new narcotic judgeships go to Democrats in return for his party's support when the bill was before the Assembly last May.

Jon Matlack threw "a curveball down and in" to Tommy Helms leading off the sixth inning last night and the Houston Astros' second baseman lined the ball six inches inside third base for a double and the only hit off the Mets' southpaw.

The vice chancellor of the City University said yesterday that he found no fault with Dr. Kenneth B. Clark for being on the payroll of the Metropolitan Applied Research Center ?? the same time that he is receiving a salary as a full-time faculty member of the university.

A 13-year-old Bronx boy was shot to death last night while walking with a friend near his home two blocks from Bronx Park. The police were questioning members of known youth gangs in the belief that, the slaying may have been gang-related.

Two armed and masked boys burst into a detention center here today, fired one shot into a wall and escaped with a 14-year-old said to be a girlfriend of one of them. She was being held there as a runaway.

The Federal Government said today that it would produce "perhaps three dozen" microbiologists to testify as expert witnesses in its suit seeking to destroy 1.5 million cans of food products seized from Bon Vivant Soups, Inc.
The Government has ordered a recall of five more brands of aerosol cough and cold sprays that it said contained the same ingredient that forced it to act against Pertussin spray last week.

The local branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People last night defied instructions from the N.A.A.C.P. headquarters in New York and refused to back away from its endorsement of a plan that leaves a solid majority of Atlanta students in all-black schools.

The dollar continued to rally today and has now added approximately 5 per cent to its depressed value in the last two days, amid reports in Europe that a policy of official intervention in foreign-exchange markets may have already been activated.

LOS ANGELES--"As to Hemingway," F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote to a literary agent in 1929, "if any offer for moving pictures of his books for $20,000 or more came to you, don't hesitate to wire him as he's not satisfied with present picture offers . . ."

On hand at the Johnson Space Center in Houston for the first full day of planning for the United States-Russian space flight scheduled for 1975, Alexei Leonov, the Soviet cosmonaut who was the first man to walk in space, was asked if he anticipated any language problems on the joint mission.

The City Council approved nine new members for an expanded Board of Elections yesterday, but deferred approval of the 10th candidate, Vincent J. Velella, amid controversy over allegations that he is connected to the underworld.
The four slain members of the Faulk family were buried here today. The family's minister urged the public to weep for the killers, not the victims.
On the standards of the normal concert experience, Monday night's program by the Festival Symphony Orchestra in Riverside Park approached the disastrousus.

The Federal Reserve Board announced today an increase of more than 50 per cent, to about $18-billion, in its "swap" credit lines with other central banks under which it can borrow foreign currencies for use in defending the dollar's value in foreign-exchange trading.

John N. Mitchell swore to the Senate Watergate committee that he had deliberately withheld information from President Nixon about the 1972 campaign conspiracy and "White House horror stories" to prevent damage to the President's bid for re-election. He persistently denied that he had authorized the political intelligence gathering scheme that led to the Watergate break-in. [Page 1, Column 8.]

It wasn't Lindy McDaniel's fault the Yankees tumbled out of first place tonight. McDaniel, making his first start since 1967 and his first in 246 games in five years as a Yankee, allowed just three hits and struck out 11 batters, a team high this season.

Charges against a man and his wife involved in an altercation with three policemen last month in Jamaica, Queens, were reduced yesterday following a hearing in Queens Criminal Court. Charges against a second man were dismissed.

The Maryland Racing Commission refused today to change Secretariat's official time in the Preakness Stakes and thus deprived the star colt a clean sweep of speed records in his Triple Crown winning performances this spring.

Dr. Dunbar S. McLaurin, a lawyer, an economist and an organizer of the Freedom National Bank and of the Universal National Bank, blackcontrolled financial institutions in New York, died today at his home, 7 Frederick Place. He was 53 years old.

The proposal to create a pedestrian mall on Madison Avenue in midtown Manhattan comes up for vote in the Board of Estimate today. This project is frankly experimental; the proposed mall is intended to make life a little more bearable for pedestrians in one of New York's most important shopping districts by eliminating private automobile traffic, by giving human beings some breathing space and by lessening the pollution of the air they breathe.
American planes flew heavy air strikes north of Phnom Penh today against rebel troops pushing Government forces closer to the capital.

The Franklin National Bank announced yesterday that it would pay 7 per cent interest on long-term savings accounts of at least $1,000 and a minimum of four years' maturity. In addition, the bank said that it would raise the interest rates that it pays on other consumertype thrift accounts, in line with the new rate ceilings announced last Thursday by the Government, up to a maximum of 6 1/2 per cent.

Clustered in front of two television monitors in a long narrow storefront on the Lower East Side yesterday, city police officials, members of the Ninth Precinct and local residents watched an hour-long production called "No More Words."

Frederick M. Warburg, the investment banker, sportsman and philanthropist, died yesterday of heart disease at Memorial Hospital in Winchester, Va., near Snake Hill, his horse and cattle farm in Middleburg.

In a special election today, Merritt Comstock of Essex, a Republican, won a seat in Connecticut's State Senate by a majority big enough to offer a measure of comfort to Republicans in Washington and Hartford.

Two major regional banks announced sharp increases in earnings for the second quarter and the first half of 1973 yesterday. Both institutions reported higher rates of return on their shareholders' investments, but substantial increases in the cost of lendable funds narrowed their profit margins.
The Administration's top health officials announced today a new national blood policy designed to achieve an all-volunteer donor system, probably within two years.

Two friends cited by John N. Mitchell as witnesses to the last top-level talks on the Watergate bugging plan said today they were not yet prepared to resolve the dispute between Jeb Stuart Magruder's testimony that the raid was approved and Mr. Mitchell's insistence that he had vetoed it.

Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan said yesterday that' his department was preparing civil citations and proposed fines against employers in connection with the gas-tank explosion on Staten Island last Feb. 10 in which 40 construction workers were killed.
The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today the imposition of a record penalty of $101,000 against a British charter company, Laker Airways Ltd.

The Federal Reserve Board an announced today an increase of more than 50 per cent, to about $18-billion, in its "swap" credit lines with other central banks under which it can borrow foreign currencies for use in defending the dollar's value in foreign-exchange trading.

The chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, Irving R. Kaufman, told Judge Mark A. Costantino yesterday that the appellate judges "would be pleased to receive Judge Costantino's response to the newspaper accounts of his activities."

Dean Brown, a freelance photographer noted for graphic interpretations of nature and for portraitures, died Sunday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland of injuries received in a fall last Thursday near North Conway, N.H. He was 36 years old and lived at 37 Walker Street.

Australia will establish a diplomatic mission in North Vietnam later this month, the Department of Foreign Affairs announced here tonight.
The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today stringent automobile controls for the Baltimore area, including what agency officials described as "impractical" gas rationing.

The House rejected today an Administration-backed compromise designed to head off a possible veto of a four-year farm bill. The action casts doubt on the ultimate fate of the farm measure once it clears Congress and reaches the White House.

South Korea proposed today that the two Koreas exchange visits of divided families in September to pay homage at their ancestors' graves on the traditional Korean Thanksgiving Day, which falls on Sept. 11 this year.
The Newark City Counci yesterday confirmed the ap pointment of Lieut. Edward L Kerr as Police Director of this City, making him the first black to gain that post. The vote was 5 to 3.

Art, economics and women have rapidly turned SoHo, that popular loft and gallery area south of Houston Street, into a downtown frontier of boutiques and design studios.

Mrs. Gertrude Ross Davis, for many years a leading figure in the state and national social welfare fields and on problems of the aging, died today in the White Plains Hospital after a stroke. Her age was 79.

Prof. Karl Adler, the preHitler director of the Stuttgart Conservatory of Music who later headed the music department of the adult-education program at City College, died Tuesday in Albert Einstein Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 24 Linden Terrace, Leonia, N.J.

The National Cancer Institute announced today the funding of seven demonstration projects designed to make the best treatment available to more patients suffering from three types of cancer.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI)--The Senate today approved legislation--for the second time this year--allowing United States citizens to own gold. The measure would allow citizens to purchase, hold, sell or deal in gold beginning Jan. 1, 1975, or earlier if President Nixon decrees that it would not have an adverse impact on the United States international monetary position.
Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, today welcomed recent moves toward improved relations in the world and called for an end to the tension in the Middle East.

It would take a 70 per cent increase in fares to make up deficits in commuter rail operations in 1974 and 1975 if a $93-million public subsidy is not obtained, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday.
South Vietnam called on the Vitcong today to begin immediate secret talks on the country's political future patterned after earlier cease-fire negotiations.
Bond prices advanced yesterday but finished well below levels reached during a morning rally that was sparked by further strength of the dollar and prospects for the Phase 4 economic program.

The elimination round of the Maccabiah Games boxing tourney ended in a ringside uproar duc tonight with the physician to the United States team, Dr. hea Max Novich, swinging a right 197 hook at Shmuel Lalkin, secretary of the Israeli Sports Federation.

Four major banking concerns reported higher earnings yesterday for the second quarter, but mixed results for the first half of 1973. In some cases profits were down; in others, they were up.

Greg Luzinski is called Bull by his Philadelphia teammates because of his physical proportions. Luzinski, 22 years old, stands 6 feet 1 inch and weighs 220 pounds, all solid muscle.

The South Korean Government announced today a series of economic measures, including a ban on construction of "nonessential" buildings and rationing of steel billets, to cope with the effects of United States export controls on scrap iron and farm products.

Congress sent to President Nixon today legislation authorizing up to $3,064,500,000 for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

A Brazilian jetliner crashed in flames just short of Orly Airport here today, killing 122 of the 134 persons aboard. The plane, a Boeing 707 of Varig Airlines on its way from Rio de Janeiro, belly-landed in an onion patch, narrowly missing the village of Saulx-les-Chartreux.

The Fire Department's proposed "concurrent" platoon system creating a third tour of duty between 3 P.M. and midnight violates the Administrative Code, Justice Nathaniel T. Helman ruled in State Supreme Court yesterday.

Dr. J. Erik Jorpes, the Swedish biochemist who identified the structure of heparin almost 40 years ago and helped make the potent blood thinner a standard therapy for many common disorders, died here yesterday. He was 78 years old.

Stereotypers Union No. 1 yesterday announced that it had broken off negotiations with the Publishers Association of New York on a new contract to replace the one that expired last March 30.

Early-morning activity at horse racing tracks is traditional with trainers, clockers, owners and exercise boys or girls testing thoroughbreds. On Tuesday and Thursdays, while the sun is inching its way into a new day, Monmouth Park has an added hum to the thundering hoofbeats.

For its second week of the summer season, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here is presenting the Hartford Ballet Company with Lisa Bradley and Michael Uthoff, who is also the troupe's artistic director.

The Board of Estimate killed the proposed Madison Avenue Mall yesterday and dealt a damaging blow to the prestige of Mayor Lindsay, who had made the project a top priority of his last six months in office.

What Brilliance scored with expected refulgence in the $27,500 Astoria Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The crowd of 19,619 made Joseph Lacroix's filly the odds-on choice in the 67th running of the famous stakes, and she scored by a length at a return of $3.40 for $2.
The State Education Department has estimated that $54.7-million would be paid to the state's private colleges and universities during the 1973-74 academic year under the so-colled Bundy aid program.
John M. Haydon, Governor of American Samoa, has been charged with violating the Hatch Act.
More than 10 million people in six droughtstricken African countries face starvation by October unless aid is forthcoming, newsmen at the United Nations were told last night.

In an attempt to "overcome objections" to its original legislation to solve the Northeast rail crisis, the Nixon Administration today sent a series of modifications of its proposal to Congress that would provide more Federal funds.

The General Signal Corporation reported yesterday that it had received three contracts $11-25-million for production of with a combined value of automatic controls, hydropneumatic braking systems and 31 other components for use in three major transit projects.
Cesare Cardinal Zerba, a scholarly prelate who served for 40 years in the Roman Catholic Church's central administration, died at his home here today of diabetes. He was 81 years old.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk, head of the Peking-based Cambodian government in exile, warned here last night that President Nixon had only one "tiny door" through which to pull out of the Cambodia situation-direct negotiation with the Khmer Rouge, or Cambodian Communists, if the Communists agreed to it.
York Kildea who retired early this year as a regional vice president of the Chemical Bank because of illness, died yesterday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 63 years old.

A Government witness testified today that he had witnessed cooking "discrepancies" in the processing of canned goods by Bon Vivant Soups, Inc., and other sanitary hazards in the company's Food preparation areas.

In a late charge long after the leaders had been in and a fierce wind had moderated Tom Weiskopf welded a 33, 35-68 to snatch a stroke lead over Jack Nicklaus and Bert Yancey in the opening round of the 102d British Open golf championship today.

An appeal from Dacca to the Soviet Union to divert some of the wheat it is buying from the United States to help avert a severe food shortage in Bangladesh suggests a fruitful new area for constructive Soviet-American cooperation. Bengall sources say they have pledged to reimburse the Soviets next year with "surplus" wheat they expect to get from the United States under the Food for Peace program.

Mrs. John N. Mitchell, saying that she was phoning from Washington, "where I'm staying with my husband," told United Press International early today that the former Attorney General was being completely honest with Senate Watergate investigators.

The City Planning Commission Chairman, John E. Zuccotti, announced yesterday that, to expedite the construction of a 2,000-room hotel in the Times Square area, he has scheduled an Aug. 1, public hearing on applications for special permits.
The retiring Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. John Ryan, is taking an around-the-world tour with his wife that could cost the Government $100,000, a member of Congress charged today.

Rebel army soldiers who took part in an abortive insurrection late last month originally had planned to kidnap President Salvador Allende Gossens to spark a coup, an official report by the Chilean Army said today.

Despite advances in tranquilizing drugs and the growth of community health facilities, 28 per cent of the patients discharged from state mental institutions in recent years have been readmitted within six months of their release, according to State Department of Mental Hygiene statistics.

WASHINGTON--Various experts recently proposed assorted remedies for the oil-auto energy crisis. Dr. Arthur Burns of the Federal Reserve has suggested a horsepower tax; Secretary Morton has urged the states to lower their speed limits, and Secretary Shultz has proposed voluntary car pools.
Northern Ireland's new Assembly will meet for the first time on July 31.
The State Power Authority last night announced a new contract, subject to Governor Rockefeller's approval, to sell electricity to the Aluminum Company of America at Massena.

The Newark City Council yesterday confirmed the appointment of Lieut. Edward L. Kerr as Police Director of this city, making him the first black to gain that post. The vote was 5 to 0, with three abstentions.
The State Insurance Department's requirement that insurance companies include their corporate investment profits in their rate-making formulas was upheld today by the State Supreme Court.

The Rev. Jesse Jackson, whose Operation PUSH came calling on Avon Products, Inc., last spring, presided at a news conference here yesterday at which a "covenant," valued at an estimated $59-million, was signed with the giant cosmetics company.
The Soviet Union launched today a communications satellite that might be part of plans to renew the manned space program soon.

Maj. Gen. Winant Sidle, Army chief of information, was named today to become the first commander of the newly created Seventh Reserve Readiness Region and deputy commander of the Fifth Army, based at Fort Sam Houston, Tex.

State Supreme Court Justice Nathaniel T. Helman yesterday temporarily barred the enforcement of a five-day old city law meant to prevent utility companies from digging up streets in the business district during the daytime.

Mrs. Florence Haeussler Goodfellow, wife of Col. M. Preston Goodfellow, retired, who was deputy director of the Office of Strategic Services during World War II, died of a stroke here yesterday at Doctors Hospital.

Wilson C. Van Duzer, New York Republican Assemblyman from 1943 to 1964, died, apparently of a heart ailment, Monday evening. He was 79 years old and had lived for many years in Middletown, N. Y. He leaves his widow, Gladys, a son and two daughters.

Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today "there is absolutely no prospect whatever of impeachment" of President Nixon. Mr. Proxmire said on the C.B.S. program "Capitol Cloakroom," "There is no question about it; I think the President will survive."

Ten conservative Republican Senators called on President Nixon at the White House tonight to tell him that they were not deserting him because of the Watergate scandals.
Seven young Palestinian guerrillas, accused of armed raids against Israeli targets in Nicosia on April 9, pleaded innocent today at the opening of their trial.

It would take a 70 per cent increase in fares to make up C deficits in commuter rail operations in 1974 and 1975 if a $93-million public subsidy is not obtained, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday.

The stock market's summer rally gathered momentum in brisk trading yesterday as confidence grew that another international monetary crisis would be averted and that the Nixon Administration was moving closer to Phase 4 of its economic program.

Pickets chanted "We will not move" in front of District 1 Community School Board offices on the Lower East Side yesterday, protesting a move voted by six new members of the nine-member board.
The City Health Department yesterday cited 17 more food establishments for having failed to correct health code violations.

The Northern Illinois Gas Company's offering of a million shares of common stock was won by underwriters headed by Blyth Eastman Dillon Co. The group bid $24.773 a share and will reoffer them to the public at $25.50 a share. Northern Illinois Gas closed at 25 1/2, up 1/4, on the New York Stock Exchange.

George Cavich, a 41-year-old bachelor, was sitting up in bed today within 12 hours after surgeons at the Medical College of Virginia gave him a new heart. Mr. Cavich, a bank executive who lives in the Virginia Eastern Shore community of Melfa, was described as being "in fine spirits" by hospital officials.

Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, today assailed as "a renewal of the cold war" the moves on Capitol Hill to block trade concessions to the Soviet Union until Jews and others are allowed to emigrate freely.

Mitchell before the Senate Watergate committee provides a dismal picture of ethical standards and human relationships in the upper levels of the Nixon Administration. Robert Ryan, the versatile and durable film and stage actor, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 63 years old and had lived at 135 Central Park West since the death of his wife last year. Previously, he had a home in the Dakota, at 1 West 72d Street.

The City Planning Commission heard a rehash of last-ditch arguments for and against the $200-million convention hall on the West Side yesterday at a hearing to allocate $50-million from the current capital budget for site acquisition and initial construction.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation, which is continuing to expand its consumer non-food operations, announced yesterday an agreement in principle to acquire the Knickerbocker Toy Company, Inc., for stock valued at about $25-million.

The Board of Estimate killed the proposed Madison Avenue Mall yesterday and dealt a damaging blow to the prestige of Mayor Lindsay, who had made the project a top priority of his last six months in office.

A state appeals court ruled today that the Mount laurel Municipal Utilities Authority could not revise the fees it charged a housing developer because the fees had been set by contracts with private companies that were taken over by the authority.

The commander of American Army troops in the Pacific met today with President Nguyen Van Thieu and Premier Tran Thien Khiem in talks that presumably included the forthcoming halt in Anerican bombing of Cambodia.

Lieut. Col. Edison w. Miller, a former prisoner of war who faces misconduct charges, was declared medically unfit for duty because of the injuries and the illness he suffered in confinement in a North Vietnamese prison, a Marine Corps spokesman said..

Local moviegoers will have an opportunity to view six new Japanese feature films from Aug. 17 through Sept. 13 at the Elgin Theater, Eighth Avenue and 19th Street. According to a spokesman for the theater, all of the films were made within the last two years.

A temporary restraining order was obtained against the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union in Federal Court here yesterday on charges that the union, with the acquiescence of employers, discriminates against job applicants because of their race.

Witnesses before a Congressional committee charged today that the Government was doing a poor job of enforcing laws that forbid discrimination against women and even failed to live up to some of these laws itself.
The Mets helped make it as painless as possible for their followers at Shea Stadium yesterday by taking only 1 hour 59 minutes to lose to the Houston Astros, 7-1.

A proposal to make it harder to put House members on record when they vote on amendments was put aside today for a week by the House Rules Committee. The effort to reduce the number of votes is based on a belief there has been an increase in frivolous, unnecessary votes because of the new House electronic voting system.

New Hampshire has been declared a Federal disaster area because of recent floods, Representative James C. Cleveland said today. The declaration by President Nixon qualifies the state for immediate Federal aid for clearance of debris, highway repairs and homeowner loans at 5 per cent interest.

The trial of Ted Patrick, who has specialized in helping parents "rescue" young people from various religious groups, was put off yesterday until July 20 in Manhattan Criminal Court, because of a congested court calendar. Through his attorney, Patrick M. Wall, he pleaded not guilty to misdemeanor charges of unlawful imprisonment and assault in the third degree brought by 21-year-old Daniel Voll, a member of the New Testament Missionary Fellowship.

At least two persons were killed when fire swept through a department store here tonight. The police said two bodies were discovered on the fifth floor of the Galeries Barbes, which specializes in furniture and is situated behind the tourist area of Montmartre in Northern Paris.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose sharply yesterday in stepped-up trading. The Amex index increased 0.22 to 22.58 in the sharpest gain since Jan. 27, 1972, when it rose 0.27. Volume rose to 2,729,000 shares compared with 2,225,000 day the day before.

Thurman Munson had absolutely no success batting against Steve Stone, his former college batterymate, for the first time today. But the catcher's timely throw in the ninth inning helped secure a 2-1 victory for the Yankees over Stone and the Chicago White Sox.

President Nixon today signed a bill deferring this year's referendum for national wheat quotas. The new law defers the referendum, normally scheduled before Aug. 1, until Oct. 15 or until adjournment of the first session of the 93d Congress, whichever is earlier.

Two hearing aid manufacturers and distributors have reached agreement with the Federal Trade Commission, but three others have denied complaints that the companies limit competition through restrictions on dealers, the commission announced today.

President Rafael Caldera of Venezuela will meet with Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba in Havana in the last half of September, Government sources said here today. President Caldera will stop over in the Cuban capital while flying from Caracas to the United Nations in New York.
Voters in the Connetquol school district in Suffolk County yesterday defeated a budget of more than $18-million in one of the school elections on Long Island.

Three vacationing New Yorkers including a police detective assigned to the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, were among five presumed victims in the crash of a private plane near here, the Santa Barbara County sheriff's office said today.

A second Siamese twin girl, who underwent emergency surgery July 7 to save her life, died yesterday at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. The twin girls were born April 5 at St. John's Hospital in Brooklyn.

France's warning to world shipping and aircraft to stay away from her nuclear test zone in the South Pacific came into force today as New Zealand's protest frigate, the Otago, entered the banned area.

The Ford Motor Company and Colgate Palmolive announced larger dividends for their shareholders today. Ford's shareholders will receive an extra dividend of 20 cents in September as well as a quarterly payment increased to 80 cents. Ford had been paying a dividend of 70 cents each quarter. Ford shareholders on July 30 will receive the payments on each share they hold.

ULAN BATOR, MongoliaUnlike their Chinese neighbors, the Mongolians do not go in for stage-managed tours. Whereas a foreigner traveling in China is likely to be conducted from one carefully chosen institution to another, meeting people who have been painstakingly schooled for the purpose, a visitor to Mongolia is left largely to his own devices, with visits to anything but the obvious tourist spots arranged reluctantly, and only after considerable badgering.

The Air Force got into a quarrel today with Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin on the question of whether Gen. John D. Ryan was taking a Government-paid junket with his wife before retiring as Chief of Staff of the Air Force.

The builders of a 24-story apartment house that collapsed near here March 2, killing 14 workmen, 'were fined $300 yesterday for using inadequate supports beneath . the newly poured concrete floors. In addition to the 14 deaths, 34 men were injured when the Skyline Plaza North Building at Bailey's Crossroads in Virginia collapsed and buried the workers.

High Argentine Government and military officials reported tonight that President Hector J. Campora would imminently announce his intention to resign, paving the way for a take-over of the Presidency by Juan D. Peron, the nation's former dictator.

A confrontation between France and the United States was avoided at the last minute to pave the way for last weekend's agreement designed to end the latest monetary crisis.
Ocean County Judge Robert H. Doherty Jr. reserved decision today on two remaining counts of a state suit against the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.
President Nguyen Van Thieu announced a Cabinet shuffle today that puts control over the Government even more firmly in his own hands.

An attorney for four of the original defendants in the Watergate bugging case has told Federal prosecutors that his clients accepted offers of money and executive clemency in return for their guilty pleas at the Watergate trial last January, well-informed sources said today.
Thomas J. Meskill's campaign in 1970 received money from a dummy fund in Washington, according to state officials. The contribution was never reported.
Interest rates on home mortgages rose "modestly and irregularly" in June, the Federal Home Loan Board said yesterday.
On a television interview with Mike Wallace this evening, Norman Mailer discusses his new biography of Marilyn Monroe and says that "I could not ignore the possibility of a murder."

Ellen Green, who, in her dress and demeanor, looks like a Gibson Girl gone delightfully wrong, is having fun with period songs this week at Reno Sweeney, 126 West 13th Street, but without resorting to sheer camp.

In line with the Metropolitan Museum's policy of greater public disclosure, the announcement of its acquisition of 25 Chinese paintings was accompanied by a 30page appendix verifying the legality of their provenance and giving the opinions of authorities outside the museum on their authenticity, quality and desirability as additions to the Metropolitan's collections.

The incoming president of the, American Bar Association pledged yesterday a "major thrust" in the coming year toward improving the way in which the nation's lawyers are regulated and disciplined.

The Board of Estimate's rejection of Mayor Lindsay's proposed test of the Madison Avenue Mall is a setback to the idea of progressive city planning for the longrange public good. The Lindsay administration has brought many innovative advances in zoning, preservation and urban design to New York City in recent years.

The 8:20 A.M. out of Old Greenwich had just cleared Rye station and was picking up speed when the brakes grabbed on with a jolt that snapped our heads. Below us sparks flew from the iron wheels. In four car lengths we were at a full stop.

President Nixon, still suffering chest pains as a result of viral pneumonia, will be able to carry no more than a quarter of his normal work load for the next few days, doctors attending him reported today.

Two tugs are assisting a luxury liner that has run aground on a sandbar off the Caribbean Island of Grenada. A company spokesman said that the weather was good in the area and there was no danger to the 43,975-ton Canberra, flagship of the P O Lines Ltd.
President Nixon was deeply troubled last May that he did not recognize the Watergate cover-up earlier, according to a White House official who saw him often throughout the spring.

Amid conflicting reports on persistence of clashes between the Hutu majority and Tutsi minority of Burundi, it is apparent that militant Hutu refugees are continuing attempts to organize and encourage raids into Burundi with the aim of overthrowing the predominantly Tutsi Government.

The Vietcong today canceled the scheduled release of two Canadian officers they have been holding over two weeks after announcing yesterday that the two men could be picked up this morning by an international recovery team.

The number of homicides in the city in the first half of 1973 increased by 81, or 10 per cent, over the same months last year, to a new high, according to statistics released by Dr. Milton Helpern, the Chief Medical Examiner.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian head of state, said today that he would leave next week for a threeweek visit to North Korea, and would not meet Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, when he comes to Peking.
Anita Zarnowiecki of Sweden achieved her sixth gold medal in six events today as she and a twin brother, Bernt, dominated swimming competition at the ninth Maccabiah Games.
Total business inventories rose by nearly $2-billion in May, the second largest monthly increase during the current expansion of the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

The beach at Sandy Hook State Park reopened for bathers yesterday. The State Environmental Protection Department said the "red tide"-an infestation of marine microorganisms that irritate the eyes and noses of bathers-had dispersed as a result of cooler weather.

The dollar rallied earlier this week, spurred by reports that the central bank governors, meeting in Basel, had agreed to come to its defense. The United States let it be known that it had increased its arrangements to "swap" dollars for foreign currencies from $12 billion to $18 billion, but refused to say whether or not the Federal Reserve Bank of New York would or would not actually intervene in markets to support the dollar.
H. Harold Gumm, a lawyer who had many musical and theatrical clients in New York, died today at his home, 48 GooseneckPoint Road. He was 92 years old.

California tomato growers have resorted to what one broker described today as "a kind of legal black-market device" to sell the bumper summer crop in Eastern markets despite the Government's 60-day price freeze.

The director of the Selective Service System, Byron V. Pepitone, issued a warning today that failure of 18year-olds to register for the draft was a law violation that could result in their prosecution.

Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of Manhattan, called today for an investigation of the Food and Drug Administration's one-year extension given to X-ray equipment manufacturers to meet Federal performance standards.

Thousands of panic-stricken Burundi farmers are fleeing with their families and herds away from the border with Tanzania after yesterday's attack by the Tanzanian Army on a military post in which 10 Burundi soldiers were killed and four wounded.

Scientists at Princeton University have announced what appears to be a significant advance toward obtaining useful energy from the thermonuclear, or fusion, reaction that is the basis of the hydrogen bomb. This latest step, which involves using beams of the form of heavy hydrogen known as deuterium, has enabled experimenters to come closer to attaining the high pressures and temperatures required.

The unraveling thus far of the complex and fascinating story of the quilting phenomenon in this country over the last century will not fully prepare viewers for the exhibition of Amish patchworks that opened here this week.

Shearson, Hammill Co. disclosed yesterday that it was laying off 100 more employes as part of a cost-reduction program at the large brokerage firm, bringing to 300 the number of employes released since March 31.

The world's largest container crane-179 feet high, 90 feet wide and capable of lifting 70 tons on the end of a 100-foot boom-was dedicated in Brooklyn by Mayor Lundsay yesterday.

The Israeli Government moved today to dissociate itself from film production of "Jesus Christ Superstar," the rock opera that has been denounced as anti-Semitic by major Jewish organizations in the United States.

Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, called John W. Dean 3d "this little rat" yesterday and said that Mr. Dean, former counsel to the President, was only trying to save himself by his Watergate testimony.

President Nixon and Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. are planning to use each other's past statements as legal weapons at their forthcoming confrontation over the issue of the President's cooperation with the Watergate inquiry.
For several months, the Human Resources Administration has been shaking itself free of the tangled lines of authority and responsibility that have been crippling its effectiveness.
Mrs. Helen Edwards Fosburgh and Hugh Whitney Fosburgh have announced that their daughter, Miss Lacey Fosburgh, will be married here on Aug. 10 to Marc Libarle, a recent law graduate.

Stop the Music showed his expected competency in the $84,375 Dwyer Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The Greentree Stable star was backed into odds-on favoritism by the crowd of 31,966 in the 11/4-mile event for 3-year-olds, and he won with little effort.
YAPHANK, L. I. - Mrs. Roger Moreland has the pioneer spirit and her 1862 farmhouse surrounded by fields in the middle of Suffolk county offers the appropriate setting.

BABYLON, L.I. - For 10 months, a contractor - sponxored "ethics committee" has been available to resolve the complaints of homeowners in Queens and on Long Island, and although the committee has not been flooded with business, it is reporting "100 per cent success" with the cases It has handled so far.
Senator Mike Mansfield, calling William P. Rogers "the best Secretary of State in my 36 years here," said today he hoped it was not true that Henry A. Kissinger would soon replace Mr. Rogers.

Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week got off to one of the finest starts in its 75-year history today. The wind, a solid 10-15 knots from the westsouthwest, enabled Donald B. King, the regatta chairman, to set substantial courses on Long Island Sound for the fleet of 252.

HEWITT--A rugged, backto-nature program at the Wildcat Mountain Wilderness Center near here, a project described by its sponsors as one inspiring both initiative and self-confidence, is now more than half way through its first year.

The Sunday Observer is reporting in tomorrow's editions that Portuguese soldiers wiped out a village in the East African territory of Mozambique on the same day last December as another massacre was said to have taken place in a nearby village.

Yes, the Soviet Union and China will be taking more American grain and soybeans; some 10.5 million metric tons, according to the export orders filed thus far with the Department of Agriculture's Export Marketing Service.

West Germany, the Olympic gold medal winner, and Britain, which finished fourth in the 1972 games in Munich, will compete in the National Horse Show this year.

The Senate investigation into the Watergate scandals, and particularly into the degree of participation of President Nixon and his senior aides, is moving nearer to the decisive stage. President Nixon's attack of viral pneumonia may retard the evolution of events slightly, but his illness has fortunately responded to treatment and rest for which the nation is grateful. Political friends and foes alike will wish him a speedy recovery.

WASHINGTON--Having flexed its muscles in extracting a compromise from President Nixon to halt the bombing in Cambodia by Aug. 15, Congress does not seem about to back away from new confrontations with the White House.

Edward M. Kennedy is a front runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976, a Gallup Poll reported yesterday. The Massachusetts Senator is the first choice of 40 per cent of those polled. George C. Wallace of Alahama is second with 16 per cent.

Darrell Evans moved back into a tie for the major league home-run lead tonight by belting his 26th homer, highlighting a four-run rally that gave the Atlanta Braves a 4-1 victory over the Montreal Expos.

Movie-making is at a record level here, according to Christine Conrad, Mayor Lindsay's executive coordinator for film production. American and foreign producers "have shot 35 features here, wholly or in part, during the six months ended June 30, which tops the previous high of 27 filmed during the first six months of last year," Miss Conrad stated.

New York City's Legal Aid Society lawyers have ended their unique strike and gone back to work, pending completion of a detailed new contract. The net result is that needy people ought to get somewhat better legal services, which both sides in the strike conceded that they needed.

RAMAH, N.M.-This community of 1,200 Navajos, many of them semiliterate weavers and sheep herders, is educating its children in ways that suggest a possible turnabout in national Indian educational policy. Unlike nearly all other Indians in America, the people of Ramah manage and control their own high school, through a seven-person, all-Navajo school board and a staff three-fourths of whom are Navajos.

Land reform in the Philippines has made steady, if unspectacular headway since it was decreed by President Ferdinand E. Marcos last October, but its progress is now facing a major roadblock.

Miss Barbara Newmyer, a former press representative for the Columbia Broadcasting System here, and Mark W. Johnson, a senior lawyer in the Washington office of C.B.S., were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Newmyer Jr. Rabbi E. William Seaman performed the ceremony.
President Nixon's doctors reported today that he was making "good progress" in recovering from a siege of viral pneumonia. They said he was on an "improving trend."
Squatters on Government land along the Delaware River have won a measure of recognition from a Fcderal agency.

Miss Dorothy Meredith Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Warner, was married here at noon to Andrew Curtis Greene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Greene. Both families are of Short Hills. Rabbi Barry Greene performed the ceremony at the Chanticler.

PARIS, July 15--The Belgian international airline Sabena has just ordered 10 American airplanes instead of 10 French ones in a dramatic illustration of the way the devaluation of the dollar is beginning to help American sales overseas.

Community-mindedness has not always been the foremost concern of Channel 3, a television station here whose call letters are WLBT. For years, the station seemed mindful only of the 60 per cent of this Deep South community that is white, once going so far as to flash "sorry, cable trouble" during a network interview with a black leader.
Work is expected to begin shortly on a hospitality center for out-of-town buyers in the Garment District, a project financed jointly by the city and a group of leaders in the apparel industry.

WASHINGTON - A vicious attack by a 33-year-old Democratic lawyer, bedazzled by his moment in the limelight, upon the only witness to come before the Watergate committee with clean hands - an upright, respected, gentle human being of 59 named Richard Moore - is proof that the purpose of the Ervin committee is not to bring out the truth but to bring down the President.
A reversal of the 3-2 majority on the City Council here could result from an investigation of the May 8 election by the office of Attorney General George F. Kugler.

A former prisoner of war said today that eight American P.O.W.'s whose charges of collaboration with the enemy were dropped by the Pentagon caused the beatings of several of their fellow prisoners by the North Vietnamese.

Under the guise of solving the energy crisis, oil and regional interests are threatening to undermine the National Environmental Protection Act. A key test will take place tomorrow when the Senate votes on an amendment to a bill by Senator Jackson of Washington to ease the way for building a pipeline to carry oil from Alaska's North Slope to West Coast ports.

International Two Canadian officers of the International Commission of Control and Supervision in South Vietnam who had been held captive by the Vietcong for 17 days were freed and returned to Saigon by helicopter. The two men stated that they had been constantly interrogated, taken on forced marches and beaten while in detention. [Page 1, Cols. 1-2.]

Penthouse magazine, which features nudity, announced yesterday that it would defend venders of the periodical who might be accused of selling pornographic material under the recent United States Supreme Court ruling permitting local communities to set obscenity standards.

Work on drafting a new charter for the national Democratic party will begin next weekend, when 100 Democratic leaders from across the country meet here. Attending the meeting will be members of a charter commission created last year by the Democratic National Convention in Miani Beach. The pro-

Because of an accident involving the portable concert shell that moves from borough to borough for the New York Philharmonic's summertime concerts in the city's parks, two programs in Central Park and one in Staten Island have been added to the schedule.
Dr. Walter J. Fischel, professor emeritus of Semitic languages and literature at the University of California, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.
The Larchmont Yacht Club's 75th Race Week got good wind today for the second day on Long Island Sound as a fleet of 191 boats sailed.

The New York Attorney General's office reports that it obtained $238,551 in restitution to homeowners and apartment tenants in the first six months of this year. Nearly half of the total-$115,083-was in deposits returned to buyers of one- and two-family homes by builders who failed to accomplish construction that had been agreed upon. " Torture during interrogation, or as a disciplinary measure within prisons, is no longer even motivated by a desire to gather 'intelligence' . . . torture is widely used not only as an instrument of intimidation but as an end in itself ... in many instances torture has become no more or less than a matter of habit."

A special legislative committee will recommend today reductions in pension benefits for new public employes and an end to the grouping of city sanitationmen and transit workers with policemen and firemen for pension purposes.

Olga Korbut, the Soviet Union's triple Olympic gold medalist, is free to continue her tricky gymnastic performances, at least until November, Arthur Gander, president of the International Gymnastics Federation, said today.
Donald C. Alexander, the new Commissioner of Internal Revenue, believes that one of his most important tasks will be "maintaining public confidence in this agency."

Ragtime, a 62-foot sloop from Long Beach, Calif., won the 27th trans-Pacific yacht race early today, beating the defending champion, Windward Passage, in the closest race in the history of the 2,225-mile event.
Representative Ella T. Grasso, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that she would cosponsor legislation to create a bipartisan Federal elections commission to "keep elections clean."
Roger McCluskey and A. J. Foyt, two venerable and versatile pros, won twin 200-mile races today before a crowd of 43,700 at Michigan International Speedway.

Nolan Ryan of the California Angels pitched his second no-hitter of the season yesterday when the former New York Mets' right-hander defeated the Tigers, 6-0, at Detroit. Ryan threw his first no-hitter on May 15 against the Kansas City Royals.

They have been doing what most first-time visitors to New York do--taking the cruise around Manhattan Island, going to Radio City Music Hall, visiting the Bronx Zoo, getting a glimpse of the inside of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

At the Helsinki conference of European foreign ministers, Western spokesmen properly put much emphasis on the importance of free communications across the boundaries of the world's ideological blocs. The Museum of the City of New York, at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, marks its 50th birthday tomorrow, and has begun a series of golden anniversary shows to continue through Labor Day.
President Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr of Iraq has appointed Mohammed Said el-Rifai as acting Minister of Defense, the Middle East News Agency said today in a dispatch from Baghdad.

A $161-million-a-year rate increase for Consolidated Edison electric customers has been proposed by a state Public Service Commission examiner, with opponents contending that a new concept included in the proposal would anticipate -and thereby accelerate -- continued inflation.

Since its beginnings more than a hundred years ago with a Chinese grocery on Race Street, Philadelphia's tiny Chinatown, as close-knit as a shred of silk, has survived its early days of opium dens and bloody Tong wars, and continuing years of racial isolation and growing urban decay.

Anita Zarnowiecki, Sweden's swimming star, raced today to her seventh gold medal at the ninth Maccabiah Games. But 15 minutes after winning the 200-meter individual medley, Miss Zarnowiecki finished second, eight seconds behind Wendy Weinberg of Baltimore in the 800-meter freestyle event.
" Macbeth" is perhaps the most startling of Shakespeare's tragedies. Images of blood, death and violence are everywhere, sleep is murdered and a particular madness, corrupted by remorse, reigns.

A recently completed report by staff members of the National Institutes of Health recommends prohibiting any experiments that would prolong the life of an aborted fetus once its ultimate survival was judged to be impossible.

The American Stock Exchange favors prompt disclosure of all securities trades on a consolidated ticker, but firmly opposes the bid by the Securities and Exchange Commission to directly control the ticker tape's operation, according to a statement by Paul Kolton, Amex chairman, issued over the weekend.
Philip Grill, a partner in Armando's restaurant, which was on East 61st Street and earlier on East 55th Street, died Thursday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 70 years old.

The Administration is inching forward in its perception of the energy crisis facing this country; at least it is falling no further behind the rapidly evolving public awareness. President Nixon's most recent energy message fills in some of the more glaring blanks in his earlier anticlimactic statement.
The Financial Accountants Standards Board yesterday called on financial executives, analysts, accountants and other interested parties to offer critiques of pronouncements of its predecessors,

More than 1,500 stock-car-racing fans huddled this afternoon in the drafty grandstand of Trenton Speedway daring to hope against the obvious, but it was a lost cause.

The New Mexico Supreme Court has ruled that the state cannot impose a tax on the reservation income of Indians who live on a reservation. The court, in handing down its opinion Friday, also said that the 4 per cent state gross receipts tax could not be, assessed against reservation businesses that are owned by reservation Indians.
Two Canadian officers of the International Commission of Control and Supervision, who had been held captive by the Vietcong for 17 days, were freed yesterday and returned to Saigon by helicopter.

Six young experts from the metropolitan area gained an early lead in the final of the Fun City regional knockout bridge championship yesterday afternoon at the New York Hilton. Jay Mechutan, Mike Engel, August Boehm, George Tornay, Marcel Friedmann, all of New York, and Bob Ryder of Caldwell, N.J., led by 25 international match points after 32 deals of a scheduled 64.

DISNEYLAND It's not ough that they are showing the great Walt Disney movies over at Lincoln Center's Tully Hall; now there's a new spate of Disney creations being showcased at the Lincoln Center Library just across the way at 64th Street, at the Amsterdam Avenue end of the center.
Fire officials said today the vault-like construction of the giant United States Military Records Center, designed for security, was the major reason the building burned out of control for two days.

Two separate traffic accidents claimed four lives and injured 20 persons yesterday in the metropolitan area. A man, a woman and a child were killed on Interstate 95 at Englewood, N.J. According to the state police, their car was backing up on the busy route when it was struck by a second car.

Miss Toby Ruth Goldstein and Todd Niles York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd N. York of East Hills, were married this afternoon at the Roslyn Country Club. StateSupreme Court Justice Steven B. Derounian performed the ceremony.

The public is scheduled to have its first opportunity this week to see and hear the man who has been the most mysterious figure among the strangely assorted cast of characters in the Watergate affair.

Politicians predicted privately yesterday that some sort of transportation bond issue would emerge from the special state legislative session that starts a week from today. Publicly, they called on Governor Rockefeller to disclose precisely what he had in mind.
King Hussein of Jordan and his Premier, Zaid al Rifai, returned home today after a five-day visit to London and talks with Prime Minister Heath. An official statement

The Delaware River Basin Commission charged today that 50 municipalities and private companies in three states had failed to develop adequate facilities for treatment of wastes Jumped into the Delaware River.

Mrs. Carole Jo Skala, a 35year-old mother of three from Shingle Springs, Calif., shot a three-under-par 70 today to win the $30,000 George Washington golf tournament by one stroke with a 54-hole total of 214.

For the residents of the Morrisania section of the Bronx, Claremont Park is a vital urban oasis. During the day, the leafy green triangle, with its swimming pool, ballfields and playgrounds, belongs to the children.

Some tax lawyers point out that businessmen and women could profit by rethinking their estate plans these inflationary days-taking into account the liquidity needed to pay Federal estate taxes and state inheritance or estate taxes.
Israel will shorten the three-year period of compulsory military service for men by three months, the Government announced today after a Cabinet meeting in Jerusalem.
City Controller Abraham D. Beame will start "shoring up the left" this week with a series of endorsements by liberal Democratic officeholders who had opposed him in the Democratic mayoral primary.

Squatters on Government land along the Delaware River have won a measure of recognition from a Federal agency. The squatters, who are facing a new eviction threat, feel that the recognition by the agency, the National Park Service, lends some moral support to their claim to use the land.

Citing the recent rise in health violations reported at city restaurants, the Health Services Administration announced yesterday that it would require restaurants to send food-handling establishments to send representative to a special course in environmental sanitation the agency was starting today.

The Lakeland terrier, though a very old breed in England, didn't gain recognition in the United States until 1934. Today, at the Twin Brooks Kennel Club show on The Mall, it gained further recognition when Ch. Tarnbreck Cassius, owned by the Countess Ersilia LeNy of Milford, N. J., was named best in a field of 1,227 dogs.
Deane Beman shot a 67 today for a 13-under-par total of 271 and won the $125,000 ShrineRobinson open by a stroke over Bob Dickson and Bunky Henry, who closed with 66's.
The dollar's value has sunk too far and the United States Government should act to bolster it, the the French Finance Minister, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, said today.
This rural town in Sussex County has become the focal point in a tug of war between New Jersey supermarkets and the United Farm Workers over grapes and iceberg lettuce.
Pope Paul VI, in an apparent reference to reports of massacres in Mozambique, today denounced "the atrocious attacks perpetrated by inhuman and organized delinquency."

Joe Namath reported to the Jets training camp at Hofstra University today for his physical examination and received permission to leave the preseason training camp to fulfill some television commitmenis.

Fighting between Cambodian Government forces and Communist-led insurgents entered the fourth week today near Kompong Tuol, 10 miles south of the capital, as the insurgents attacked scattered Government outposts.

Richard Schaub, New Jersey Banking Commissioner, is expected to announce today that the ceiling on savings bank mortgage rates will be raised to 8 per cent to free mortgage money that has been virtually unavailable to home buyers for 10 days.

Willie McCovey, a big man with a history of doing things in a big way for the San Francisco Giants, clouted his 400th and 401st major-league home runs yesterday to become the 15th player to reach that total. Willie Mays and Mel Ott were the only Giant players to hit more homers.

Gary Koch, four holes down with 11 to play, rallied to tie the match, then sank a 16-foot eagle putt on the 35th hole today to score a 1-up victory over Guy Cullins of Denton, Tex., to win the 70th annual TransMississippi amateur golf tournament. -

Miss Barbara Louise Bluestone, a professional weaver with a studio in Copenhagen, Denmark, was married here today to Jorgen Jensen, an archeologist and curator of the bronze-age department at the Danish National Museum there.

Fred 0. Meyer, the owner of Oregon's largest retail concern, has ordered a line of "Watergate T-shirts" removed from his company's sales floors. A spokesman for the Fred Meyer Shopping Center said yesterday that it was Mr. Meyer's "personal decision and reflected his feelings about the shirts."

Like the escalator on which he sprained his ankle 10 days ago, Sam McDowell had his ups and downs yesterday. But the ups-outs when he needed them-overcame the downsseven walks-and the Yankees defeated the Kansas City Royals, 2-0.

Mrs. Carole Jo Skala, a 35year-old mother of three from Shingle Springs, Calif., shot a three-under-par 70 today to win the $30,000 George Washington golf tournament by one stroke with a 54-hole total of 214.
There was a faint scent of" compromise in the air last week between the Nixon Administration and Congress over a possible solution of the Northeast a rail crisis.
How many other communities across the country may, like Duluth, Minn., have possibly hazardous quantities of asbestos in their drinking water?
Henry A. Whalen, who organized the United Veterans of the Bronx Memorial Day parades on the Grand Concourse for 20 years, died Friday in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx.

Ernesto Marcel of Panama retained his World Boxing Association featherweight crown last night with a 12th-round technical knockout of Antonio Gomez of Venezuela. Gomez didn't answer the bell for the 12th round, having taken too much punishment from the champion to continue.
A lot of the California money that used to go into the stock market is now being invested in silver coins and is supporting a new, rapidly growing industry.

A Bronx firehouse was stoned late Saturday night and early yesterday morning after a dispute between a fireman and neighborhood youths who he said were sitting on his parked car.
Bindu Khare, a 32-year-old mother of three children, has a rather precarious job.

The collapse of the dollar is threatening to force a stoppage of the world economy. Overnight, America's failure to hold the line for the dollar has spread a sense of alarm that world prosperity is about to follow the plunging dollar and the plummeting New York stock market into paralysis.

Serious crimes reported in the city's low-income public housing projects declined by 29 per cent last year, compared with a drop of 18 per cent in such reports in the city as a whole, the Housing Authority said yesterday.

The city has been winning 43 per cent of its claims to halt or reduce grants to welfare clients in controversial "fair hearings," which recipients can demand before any changes can be made in their status.

Miss Jean Marie Uhlich, daughter of Mrs. George W. Eckert of Elmont, L.I., and the late Frederick Uhlich, was married here today to William R. Heidtman, Sheriff of Palm Beach County.

A lengthy eighth inning in which the California Angels scored five runs may have cost Nolan Ryan an American League strike-out record today but the stiffness the fireballing right-hander developed during the wait wasn't enough to prevent his second no-hitter of the season.

Usually, the only football players who can see their mistakes on instant replay are professionals. But at Seton Hall's evening football clinic tomorrow through Friday, young players from grade school through senior year of high school will have a chance to watch their techniques minutes after a completed play.

Helen Hayes has donated more than $13,000 towards the restoration of a dilapidated, 140-year-old church in Cold Spring, N. Y., it was announced today. The church, Chapel of Our Lady, has been abandoned since 1906.
Luigi Moretti, who designed the Watergate complex in Washington, died Saturday on a yachting cruise in the Tyrrhenian Sea. He was 66 years old.

Yields on United States Treasury bills were mixed in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities. The average rate for threemonth bills in this week's sale is 7.967 per cent,

In yesterday's column, certain questions and answers were posed about Norman Mailer's "Marilyn: A Biography" (Grosset Dunlap, $19.95). It was suggested that the book was not written to generate money and publicity for the author, as some observers have suggested, but rather as a logical outgrowth of certain themes that have been preoccupying Mr. Mailer in recent years-chief among them women, sex and cinema.
LoVoca Gathering Company, a subsidiary of Coastal States Gas Producing Company, was taken to court today by Attorney General John L. Hill, who asked for an operating receivership.
A convicted bond swindler has told a Senate committee of two examples of case-fixing in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office during the tenure of Aaron E. Koota, now a State Supreme Court justice.
An 80-year-old man and his son, 55, were robbed of $11,000 last. evening in Forest Hills, Queens, as they were about to make a night deposit at a bank on Queens Boulevard, the police reported.
Dr. Brewster Huntington Gere, former head of the mathematics department at Hamilton College, died yesterday of a pulmonary edema in McLean, Va. He was 62 years old and formerly lived in Clinton, N.Y.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I . Blandine Bedel was surprised that the tallest building she saw was only two stories high. Mrs. William Jones was disappointed because nobody ate the baked beans she had cooked "from scratch."

Short-term interest rates continued to press higher yesterday, with banks paying nearly 9 1/2 per cent to attract large deposits for three months and between 10 1/2 and 11 3/4 for another source of money, Federal funds.

Bernhard Knollenberg, historian and former library director of Yale Univesity, died here July 6. He was 80 years old and lived at Parker's Point. Mr. Knollenberg, who was library director at Yale from 1938 to 1943, wrote several books about the American Revolution.

Hugh C. Laughlin, retired executive vice president and director of Owens-Illinois, Inc., died here yesterday at the age of 69. Mr. Laughlin retired in 1969 after 17 years as an officer of the glass company.

Florida marine patrolmen, whose day-to-day job includes keeping peace between spiny lobster and stone crab fishermen in the Florida Keys, now are being forced to keep an eye out for treasure poachers.

State engineers charged yesterday that Orange and Rockland Utilities had tried to justify a gas rate increase by moving its thermometer from the side of its heated headquarters building to the top of a 100-foot radio tower to prove that 1972 was the coldest in 36 years.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday it had received an order for six 1.1-million-kilowatt nuclear steam supply systems and fuel from five utilities in four states. Based on total generating capacity, this would be the largest single nuclear order placed.

It didn't surprise his mother that Alexander Porter Butterfield gave Watergate investigators the unvarnished facts-including the information that disputed conversations between President Nixon and his aides are all on tape somewhere in the White House vaults.

Three thieves stole some $30,000 in women's undergarments from the warehouse of the Lovable Company in Queens last night after abducting the concern's foreman at gunpoint in front of his home and forcing him to admit them to the warehouse, the police reported.

Herbert W. Kalmbach, a personal attorney and key political fund-raiser for President Nixon, described to the Senate Watergate committee today, how, during a series of secret meetings and clandestine calls from telephone booths, he raised $220,000 for the seven Watergate defendants.

Ned Manuel of the Riverside (Conn.) Yacht Club and Peggy Lambert of the Belle Haven Club, Greenwich, Conn., won the Fireball Class races on Long Island Sound today in the first of three junior regattas of the Larchmont Yacht Club's 75th Race Week.

Peter Fishbach of Mill Neck, seeded fifth, defeated Jim Webber of Old Westbury, 6-1, 6-2, in the first round of the Nassau invitation tennis tournament at the Shore Tennis Club today.

The First National Bank of Chicago, one of the nation's 10 largest banks with well over $13-billion in assets, raised its prime lending rate to 81/2 per cent yesterday. The new level equals the record high for this key minimum rate on large business loans posted during the 1969-1970 credit "crunch."
The Baltimore Colts traded Bubba Smith. the huge defensive end, to the Oakland Raiders today for Raymond Chester star tight end.

Scheinman today to impanel a special county grand jury to investigate "all phases of design, construction and operation" of the Sullivan County International Airport.
Mrs. Joan Baim Simon, wife of Neil Simon, the playwright, died Wednesday of cancer at the age of 41. Mrs. Simon had danced professionally with the Martha Graham Company and other troupes.
A 92-year-old woman who had been confined to a wheel chair since she broke her hip several weeks ago was beaten yesterday by a man who stole 62 cents, the police said. The victim.

An alliance of environmental and transit-rider groups announced the filing of a suit yesterday seeking to compel the state to stabilize transit and commuter fares to meet national "clean air" standards.
General Motors said today it had begun notifying the owners of 3,100 intermediate-size cars and 5,800 medium-duty trucks of possible brake problems on their vehicles. All are 1973 models.

Joseph and Ida Dash have had to change some of their routines since their son has become the star of a daytime television series. Their son, Samuel, a Philadelphia lawyer, is chief counsel to the Senate committee investigating the Watergate scandal.

The American Foreign Service Association, which represents all State Department employes, took a middle position today between the Nixon Administration and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee over the rejection of President Nixon's nominee for Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs.

Policemen and troops seized almost a ton of arms, ammunition and explosives on a British ship that arrived here from Montreal today.

A Nassau County State Supreme Court justice ordered today that the 20-year-old natural mother of a 16-month-old girl should have custody of the baby even though the girl and her adoptive parents had fled the state.

Mrs. Doris J. Bachman filed a second suit yesterday against the Columbia Broadcasting System, its board of directors, Michael Burke and a syndicate he formed to buy the New York Yankees for $10-million earlier this year.

The Soviet Union announced today that its atomic breeder reactor, the world's first power source of its type, had gone intmcommercial production. It had been undergoing tests since its startup last December.

The official records are obscure on the point, but from at least 1827 one or another branch of the United States Congress has relied upon small boys, or pages, to carry messages of state. A Select Committee report of 1841 explained: "Members frequently take interest in a promising boy, or have their sympathies awakened by his orphan or destitute situation, and press the officer of the House to engage him in this service."

The five top-ranking officers of Weis Securities, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange firm now in liquidation, were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy and securities fraud.

President Nixon, described today as "progressing satisfactorily" in his fight against viral pneumonia, was reported almost set to make final decisions on a Phase 4 economic program.

Both he and the Congressional Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation are now conducting separate investigations to determine whether partisan political influence was exerted on the choice of certain tax returns for exhaustive audits, as a means of embarrassing selected "enemies" of the Administration.
The Federal Open Market Committee called for moderate growth in the monetary aggregates over the months ahead at its meeting April 17, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

American, British Dutch and Canadian oil interests won rights today to drill for oil off the coast of South Vietnam.
Federal Judge Mark A. Costantino meted out 15-year prison terms yesterday to three men convicted of the armed robbery of a Queens bank nearly three years ago.
