A high-level North Vietnamese delegation has concluded an eight-day visit to the Soviet Union with announcement of broad new Soviet economic aid for North Vietnam's postwar reconstruction.

Democrats in Congress disclosed today details of a proposed law to regulate the enormous growth of strip mining, particularly for coal, and the measure seemed likely to stir one of the major legislative battles of the year.

Two men, described by their victim, a monsignor as "suave, well-spoken robbers," entered a church rectory on the East Side yesterday morning, bound and gagged the priest, and fled with the $800 Sunday collection.
The White House confirmed today that nearly all of President Nixon's official meetings and telephone conversations had been secretly recorded since 1971.

The five top-ranking officers of Weis Securities, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange firm now in liquidation, were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy and securities fraud.

What do you do if you're the Bolshoi Ballet company, nearing the end of a onemonth tour here, and two American dance companies send out invitations for separate receptions at the same time on the same day?

The Military Personnel Record Center, scene of a two-day fire last week, had been scheduled to receive a fire prevention award today from the public buildings service of the General Services Administration.
Following are excerpts from the transcript of testimony today on the 20th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:
Nine yachts had crossed the finish line with two more expected late tonight in the trans-Pacific yacht race from San Pedro, Calif., that started July 4.
China has purchased 440,000 pounds of tobacco from the United States worth an estimated $500,000, according to the Agriculture Department.
The House voted today to require the President to permit increases in food prices whenever necessary to avoid shortages of supplies.

State engineers charged yesterday that Orange and Rockland Utilities had tried to justify a gas rate increase by moving its thermometer from the side of its heated headquarters building to the top of a 100-foot radio tower to prove that 1972 was the coldest in 36 years.
Earnings at Pfizer, Inc., a diversified ethical drug producer that derives about half its sales from abroad, rose 18 per cent in the second quarter on a sales gain of 17 per cent.

Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the United States Ambassador to India, has been instructed to turn over a complex of American aid buildings to the Indian Government and to start negotiations on a compromise settleturn over a complex of American-owned rupees with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

Herbert W. Kalmbach, a personal attorney and key political fund-raiser for President Nixon, described to the Senate Watergate committee today how, during a series of secret meetings and clandestine calls from telephone booths, he raised $220,000 for the seven Watergate defendants.

The Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, called on President Nixon today to submit voluntarily to Senate investigators any White House papers that might indicate that a crime had been committed.
State Banking Commissioner Richard F. Schaub today raised the interest rate lenders may charge on mortgages to 8 per cent from 7 1/2 per cent in a move designed to attract more money to the market.

Defense motions contended yesterday that massive publicity made it impossible for former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans to receive a fair trial on charges involving a $200,000 cash contribution to President Nixon's 1972 election campaign.

Dr. Karl Loewenstein, emeritus professor of jurisprudence and political science at Amherst College, died last Tuesday in Heidelberg, Germany, while traveling in Europe. He was 82 years old and had made his home here since joining the faculty in 1936.
Dick Allen, the Chicago White Sox' injured first baseman, was the leading vote-getter for the American League starting team in the All-Star game, according to yesterday's final returns.

Two of the nation's largest banking concerns - the San Francisco-based BankAmerica Corporation, parent company of the largest privately owned bank in the world, and the Charter New York Corporation--reported yesterday sharp increases in profits for the second quarter and first half of 1973.

Mention the Hennessy Grand Prix to somebody not familiar with ocean powerboat ?? and he may think both driver and boat run on Cognac. Oddly, there have been enough zany occurrences in the annual world-championship race to warrant such a notion.

The postponement of President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's scheduled visit to Washington this week because of President Nixon's illness is probably a good thing for both Pakistan and the United States. Mr. Bhutto's representatives here have made clear that a prime purpose of his trip was to try to persuade Washington to resume its old role as Pakistan's major military supplier.
The second largest party in India, Jan Sangh, today demanded a parliamentary election and said Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had "completely lost grip" on the nation.

The Environmental protection Agency, which four months ago granted a one-year suspension of 1975 air pollution standards to five American auto manufacturers, extended the suspension today to cover 27 other car makers.
American planes struck within seven miles of Phnom Penh today in an efforts to repel what official sources described as a growing threat to the capital.

William Sheptinsky, a middle-aged restaurant owner from Brooklyn, went back to school yesterday, to learn how to keep rats away from his kitchen, how to store food at the right temperature and how to survive the scrutiny of Health Department inspectors.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. yesterday reported record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first six months of this year. It also announced major management appointments.

Watching a dancer profoundly alter a movement style is like hearing a singer change the register of the voice. It is a mild shock but fascinating to observe. Currently, John Prinz is half-way between his former lyrical style and a new dramatic presentation, which he employed Sunday evening at State Theater as American Ballet Theater presented Rudi van Dantzig's "Monument for a Dead Boy."

In sworn testimony that was immediately and strenuously challenged, a Government witness stated today that Bon Vivant Soups, Inc., had "falsified" about 20 records of its canning operations that were turned over to the Federal Food and Drug Administration.
WASHINGTON, July 16--the Bureau of the Census offered statistical evidence today that American Indians are the poorest minority in the country.

President Nixon had listening devices in the White House that would have automatically tape-recorded his conversations with John W. Dean 3d and other key figures in the Watergate case, a former White House aide disclosed today.

Negotiators from the United Automobile Workers and the auto industry settled themselves into the plush, air-conditioned offices of the General Motors Corporation here today to listen to the often frustrated, discordant voices of the 725,000 workers who man the assembly lines.
A sudden wave of buying in both blue-chip and glamour issues enabled the stock market to score a strong gain yesterday in light trading.
Reactions ranging from shock to "So what?" greeted the disclosure today that conversations with President Nixon had been hugged as a matter of White House routine.

AUSTIN, Tex.--Three weeks of moving about Europe left these impressions: The miracle of economic and social development in southern Europe (from Lisbon to Ankara) may turn out to be even more impressive in the long run than postwar revival and growth in Western Europe. In part,
Industrial production rose only three-tenths of 1 per cent in June, the smallest increase in a year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today on the basis of preliminary figures.

During the four-day uprising at the Attica Correctional Facility In September, 1971, a total of 43 persons were killed-one correction officer who was assaulted by Inmates during the first minutes of the revolt, three inmates apparently murdered by other inmates during the time they held prison yard D, and 39 inmates and hostages killed by gunfire when D yard was recaptured.

President Nixon had listening devices in the White House that would have automatically tape-recorded his conversations with John W. Dean 3d and other key figures in the Watergate case, a former White House aide disclosed today.

Transport of New Jersey, the state's largest bus company, has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve rate increases on almost half of its major routes operating into New York City and Philadelphia.

" There can be no doubt that this trip has been a tremendous success," said Senator Warren G. Magnuson of Washington as he and seven other Congressmen ended a two-week tour of China. "You will see that it will bear fruit in the not too distant future.

An Illinois official said yesterday that policyholders of the Equity Funding Life Insurance Company, which is enmeshed in a huge fraud involving the creation of fake insurance policies, appeared to be unusually loyal.

There is a malady peculiar to the advertising business that can have costly repercussions-it's called client fatigue. It causes advertisers to call for a change of campaign before the one that is running has an opportunity to work.
After 31 games in 27 consecutive days, the Yankees rested yesterday while their three nearest rivals continued to chase them in the American League's East.
Four of the five defendants in the Fountain Valley murder trial fought with United States marshals today before being subdued.

With one eye on the weather over the Great Plains and the other on the insatiable export demand, grain and soybean traders bid up most futures contracts to limit highs yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

E-Systems, Inc. said yesterday its directors had approved a tender offer to purchase 400,000 of its outstanding common shares at $12.50 per share. The offer will be made by an employee stock ownership trust. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, closed at 11 3/4, up 1 3/4.
The value of the dollar skidded downward again in slow trading in Europe, where dealers still awaited some sign that individual Governments might, intervene to support it.
Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Inc., one of the nation's leading Wall Street brokerage houses, yesterday reported a net loss of $1.25-million for the third fiscal quarter ended June 30.

The Ehyl Corporation ?? Richmond, Va,, annournced yesterday an agreement ?? build a $4.4-million alkyl aluminum manufacturing facility in Boussens, France, subject to approval by the French Govern ment of an offer by Ethyl to acquire a major interest in Produits Chimiques d'Sidobre Sinnova, S. A. of Neuilly France, upon whose property the plant will be built.
Undaunted by weakness of the dollar abroad and by rising interest rates at home, bargainhunting stock buyers pushed prices up yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

The principal of Ball High School here said today that he received a warning in July 1972, from Coach Joe Woolley that his house might be burned down if he didn't go along with altering the transcript of Kerry Jackson, a University of Oklahoma quarterback.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger acknowledged today that Air Force B-52 bombers were secretly attacking Cambodia in 1969 and 1970 while the United States was publicly professing its respect for that nation's neutrality in the Vietnam war.

Ned Manuel of the Riverside (Conn.) Yacht Club and Peggy Lambert of the Belle Haven Club, Greenwich, Conn., won the Fireball Class races on Long Island Sound today in the first of three junior regattas of the Larchmont Yacht Club's 75th Race Week.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y. - I think it occurred when Senator Gurney turned to Senator Ervin and accused him of harassing the witness, not questioning him, that I sensed my strong personal affection for Senator Sam, affection beyond respect, affection approaching family feeling.

Five years ago and more, Pal Benko dominated the Swiss-system tournament circuit in the United States. Plane ticket in hand, pocket chess set in breast pocket, Benko was everywhere-and won everywhere.

" Someone made a killing" in the United States grain sale to the Soviet Union, Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today. Mr. Jackson said he believed some persons, possibly in the Department of Agriculture, profited from the grain sales.
After almost. 18 months of Inactivity because of a broken hand, Oscar Bonavena will return to Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night to oppose Jerry Quarry.
The fingerprinting of 50 to 60 eighthgrade Newark boys in a murder investigation was delayed today, giving lawyers representing the youths time to oppose the order.
The East Germans, under pressure from the West, today called off a ban they had intended to impose to keep West Berliners nut of East Germany during a Communist festival in East Berlin.

Paul Miller is afraid he may become an endangered species. Mr. Miller, a 24-year-old motorcycle mechanic from Pennsauken, voiced his fears Monday at a public hearing on the proposed Federal curbs on auto pollution in New Jersey.
A delegation of 18 Chinese led by Han Shu, acting head of the Washington mission of the People's Republic of China visited colonial Williamsburg unannounced

Twelve more food-handling establishments were cited by the city yesterday as Health Code violators after they failed two inspections and because their owners had not provided "valid reasons" for not meeting the standards.
A MANY YEARS AGO The styles of the nineteentwenties and nineteen-thirties are hanging on the walls of the exhibition room of the Society of Illustrators, 128 East 63d Street (TE 8-2560).

Victor S. Axelroad, a lawyer and adjunct lecturer in the speech department of the Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University since 1957, died Friday on a vacation in Edinburgh, Scotland. He was 58 years old and lived at 77 Seventh Avenue.

John V. Tunney, the Democratic Senator from California, yesterday answered the critics of the omnibus sports bill, the Amateur Athletic Act of 1973 that he co-sponsored, and the 38-year-old son of the onetime heavyweight champion in effect put on boxing gloves.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)--The House Ways and Means Committee turned down today an effort to write a major import-limitation provision into President Nixon's trade legislation. The 16-to-6 vote rejected an amendment offered by Representative James A. Burke, Democrat of Massachusetts, co-author of the Burke-Hartke Bill around which many protectionist organizations and important segments of organized labor have rallied.
Homeowners are asked by the National Wildlife Federation to think of their backyards as potential wildlife refuges.
The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., said yesterday it had sent to member firms for comment a proposal that would revise the listing criteria for NASDAQ stocks.

Contributions totaling $206,312 were made by donors to the successful runoff primary campaign of Controller Abraham D. Beame for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, according to political committee statements on file yesterday at the Board of Elections.
State Banking Commissioner Richard F. Schaub today raised the interest rate lenders may charge on mortgages to 8 per cent from 7 1/2 per cent in a move designed to attract more money to the market.

Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the Jewish Defense League, said today that he had proposed to American associated that they blow up the now-empty Iraqi Embassy in Washington to draw attention to the plight of the 400 Jews he said were still in Iraq.
left-wing Peronists are concerned that Hector J. Campora's resignation from the presidency Friday is developing into a triumph for conservative political forces in Argentina.

The only question of substance before the recent convention of the National Education Association in Portland, Ore., was how to merge with the American Federation of Teachers without being swallowed up by its parent union, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Suspensions, sudden retirements, holdouts and demands to be traded highlighted the pro football scene yesterday as coaches counted their seasoned players due in training camp.

Scott Meredith, Inc., agents for Norman Mailer, issued a statement yesterday declaring that "no dispute exists between Fred Lawrence Guiles, author of 'Norma Jean,' and Norman Mailer, author of 'Marilyn.'"
Alfred T. Cox, who retired in 1971 as a Department of Defense specialist on Far Eastern matters, died today at his home in Arlington Towers Apartments in Arlington, Va. He was 57 years old.

A plane in the Powder Puff Derby, a transcontinental air race for women, was forced down in Iowa by a loss of power, but the pilots won a farmer's thanks for landing in his cornfield instead of his soybeans.

President Nixon had listening devices in the White House that would have automatically tape-recorded his conversations with John W. Dean 3d and other key Watergate case figures, Alexander P. Butterfield, a former White House aide, testified at the Senate Watergate hearing. Mr. Butterfield, head of the Federal Aviation Administration, was a surprise witness.
The fingerprinting of 50 to 60 eighthgrade Newark boys in a murder investigation was delayed today, giving lawyers representing the youths time to oppose the order.

From 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. each day, Ruth. Prawer Jhabvala sits in her study and writes of India. She writes with cool, fragile precision of middleclass New Delhi, of vain Cabinet ministers, searching American women, sad businessmen, foolish British visitors, arrogant Indian youths and tragicomic lovers.
James F. Murray, director of group sales for the New York Mets since 1962, died Sunday of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 87-39 Marengo Street, Jamaica, Queens.

Robert C. (Sonny) Carson, a black activist, and seven other men were indicted yesterday on charges of killing one man and kidnapping another in retaliation for their purported robberies of a black-owned hotel in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
Jorge Velasquez, among the leading riders on the New York circuit, rarely offers an objection against a rival jockey, but he felt himself forced to do so at Aqueduct yesterday.
The newest Governmenlt-sponsored financial agency began operations today with the announcement of the offering of $105-million worth of stock by the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae.
The Emerson Electric Company of St. Louis, Mo., has been awarded a $17.9-million contract by the Corps of Engineers acting for the United States Postal Service.

The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 NEPA-is perhaps the most important single piece of modem environmental law now on the statute books. That law is under attack in the Senate today in the form of a proposal by Senator Gravel of Alaska. It is imperative that the law not be breached or undermined, and that the Gravel amendment be defeated.
Many investors who check the averages periodically complain that their stocks are lower than the so-called indicators would imply.

The special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox. today rejected a contention by a convicted Watergate conspirator, James W. McCord Jr., that the prosecution of his case had been so "fraudulent" that he should be granted a new trial.

Authoritative sources here report that President Nixon sent President Lon Nol of Cambodia a letter early this month inviting him to come to the United States for medical treatment related to his stroke in 1971, but that the invitation was declined, reportedly in the belief that it was a move to case him out of power.

C. Jackson Grayson, dean of the School of Business Administration of Southern Methodist University and former chairman of the United States Price Commission, has been elected to the board of the University Computing Company of Dallas, Texas.
The chairman of the Select Committee on Pensions said today that he was optimistic that the Legislature would approve the committee's recommendations.

President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt accused the United States today of trying to bring about a postponement of a discussion on the Middle East by the United Nations Security Council in favor of its proposal for negotiations between Egypt and Israel on the reopening of the Suez Canal.

The leaders of both houses of the State Legislature said today they would appeal the State Supreme Court decision that declared unconstitutional the present system of financing public education largely through local property taxes.
Some of the Jets' rookies stood around today with their arms folded, overlooked in the shuffle marking Piclure Day, one of the major routines of a pro football training camp.

Israel Friend, a 70-year-old lawyer who led a drive for rent control in Clifton, was named Mayor of the Passaic County municipality last night by the City Council. Mr. Friend will fill the seat of former Mayor Anna Latteri, who died of cancer July 8 after serving three-and-a-halfyears in the position. Mr. Friend followed Mrs. Latteri by 64 votes in the nonpartisan 1970 elections.

Alexander's, Inc., one of New York's largest retail chains, said "We know of no reason for the sudden increase in price of our stock" following a sizable trading in its stock yesterday on the New York Stock Exchangc.

Ida Bailey Allen, author of more than 50 cookbooks and other books, sales of which were estimated at 20 million copies, died yesterday in the Notre Dame Convalescent home in Norwalk, Conn. She was 88 years old and formerly lived here.
The White House confirmed today that nearly all of President Nixon's official meetings and telephone conversations had been secretly recorded since 1971.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit refused today to disqualify United States District Court Judge Robert Varner of Montgomery from hearing a $5-million damage suit growing out of the sterilization of two teenaged Montgomery black girls.

Grambling College will play Morgan State in the annual Whitney M. Young Jr. memorial football game at Yankee Stadium on Sept. 22. The game, played for the benefit of the New York Urban Lcaguc's educational programs,

ABEND-Paul Jr. of 304 West 34 St. Loving brother of Bertha Ryan. Reposing at the Universal Chapels at 52nd St. and Lexington Ave. Tuesday I P.M. Services Wednesday I P.M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. ADLER-Michael J. Beloved husband of Mimi, devoted father of Debra, Lisa Sheldon., cherished grandfather of Mark Todd. Loving brother of Leo, David, Raye Sophie. Funeral services will be held at the Boulevard, Coney Island Ave., Bklyn, July 17th.
Bob Gibson and Joe Torre put their talents together last night in Busch Stadium and the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the San Francisco Giants, 3-2.

In a game sprinkled with body-jarring incidents that caused one imaginative fan in the crowd of 7,688 to label it the second battle of Atlanta, the Braves defeated the New York Mets, 8-6, tonight in the opener of a thre-game series.
Premier Kirti Nidhi Bista resigned today, and King Birenda Bir Bikram Shah Deva tried to appease the Premier's critics in the National Assembly by asking its chairman to form a new government.
Launching officials today carefully tested the communications system aboard the command module that will carry three more astronauts to Skylab July 28 for an eightweek space research mission.

Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira today admonished Secretary of State William P. Rogers and other high-level American officials on flaws in the management of the American economy as seen by the Japanese.

Barry Gray, the WMCA radio late-night talk-show host, has notified the station's management that he is quitting at the end of the year unless the outlet drops its nighttime broadcasts of New York Yankees baseball games.

The Drug Enforcement Administration issued today a new set of guidelines for Federal narcotics agents with the aim of preventing future abuses such as mistaken raids on the homes of innocent families.

Relman Morin, an Associated Press reporter who retired last year after a distinguished career during which he won two Pulitzer Prizes, was found dead yesterday in his apartment, 161 East 66th Street. He was 65 years old.
A B-52 pilot charged with disobeying an order to fly a mission over Cambodia has been sent to his home base in the United States, Air Force sources said today.

The New York Stock Exchange appeal for a $300-million increase in fixed commission rates of member firms opened before the Securities and Exchange Commission today with an estimate by James J. Needham, chairman of the exchange, that members' losses in the first half of 1973 would total $1 92-million.
Homeowners are asked by the National Wildlife Federation to think of their backyards as potential wildlife refuges.

Mrs. Robert Young of Aspetuck Valley, Mrs. J. Howard Rambin Jr. of Woodway and Mrs. Thomas Israel of the Century Country Club scored 80's today on the West Course at the Winged Foot Golf Club to lead the way through the qualifying round of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association'sQ 34th annual championship.

Donald Danforth Sr., retired chairman of the board of the Ralston Purina Company died Saturday in Barnes Hospital. Mr. Danforth, son of the late William H. Danforth, who founded the company in 1894, retired from active management in 1963 but remained a director.

A committee on international terrorism opened a four-week meeting here today with but scant hope among the 35 member nations participating that it would be able to agree upon a formula for concrete actions.
Premier Marcello Caetano of Portugal flew in for an official visit today heavily guarded against anti-Portueese demonstrators.

In sworn testimony that was immediately and strenuously challenged, a Government witness stated today that Bon Vivant Soups, Inc., had "falsified" about 20 records of its canning operations that were turned over to the Federal Food and Drug Administration.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that Congress "should and must have a reply from President Nixon to all the charges that have been made" regarding the Watergate scandal. Speaking at the 12th annual conference of the New York State Broadcasters Association.
The islands of Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard appeared to be sharply divided today on proposed Federal legislation to limit their development in hopes of protecting their beauty.
The United States Court of Appeals upheld today the conviction of W. A. Boyle, former United Mine Workers president, on charges of illegally contributing union funds to political campaigns.
Calling the Nixon Administration's latest clean-air proposals lawless, the Sierra Club said today that it would return to court seeking to nullify them.
About 100 prisoners holding out in two dormitories at the Virginia Prison Farm abandoned their rebellion today after state troopers and guards retook three cellblocks held by other inmates.
The police said today they had arrested a 19-year-old suspect in the fatal mugging last November of a Westport psychiatrist in the Father Panik Village housing project here.
Federal District Judge Alfonso J. Zirpoli today approved a $22.5-million settlement in an antitrust case involving four large manufacturers of gypsum wallboard.
The wolf and kangaroo have been added to the State Department of Agriculture and Market's list of endangered species, it was announced today.

In charge over the last eight rounds, Danny McAloon of the Bronx scored a unanimous decision over Irish Pat Murphy of West New York, N.J., last night in a 10-round junior middleweight fight at the Felt Forum.

The two Canadian officers of the International Commission of Control and Supervision, freed by the Vietcong yesterday after 17 days' detention, have told their superiors in Saigon that they have "no doubt" that the Communists had orders to arrest and mistreat them as a way of harassing the Canadian delegation to the commission.

A rise in meat and fish prices reported in the Consumer Affairs Department's market basket for the week of July 5 to 11 helped send the cost of feeding a family of four up by 0.3 per cent compared with the previous week.

To the Editor: As the mother of a young newspaper editor and a member of the minority who were not a part of the "patriotic reaction of the American voters" in November, I find Ambassador Rankin's arguments concerning a free press and the public's right to know [letter July 9] a bit difficult to follow.

A 28-year-old taxicab driver was fatally shot yesterday afternoon when he was apparently held up two miles from Kennedy International Airport in the Springfield Gardens section of Queens. He was the first driver of a medallion cab to be slain since last November.

A 70-year-old Bronx woman called away from the telephone to answer her doorbell was beaten to death in a robbery attempt yesterday while her sister-in-law waited on the open phone line, the police reported.

Mayor Lindsay's office said yesterday that it would be "pointless" for the city to contribute to a state-local transit subsidy plan, as Governor Rockefeller has proposed, unless it provided a long-range solution to stabilizing the subway fare.

The National News Council, a foundation-financed organization set up to monitor national media performance and freedom of press issues, yesterday named William B. Arthur, former editor of Look magazine, as its executive director.
A protest by a United States coach and other coaches forced two Norwegian guest competitors to quit the ninth Maccabiah Games today. The American coach, Roy Chernock, who led the protest,

The General Accounting Office informed Congress today that the Navy had underestimated the cost of establishing a home port for a carrier task force in Greece, partly because it had failed to ask the Greek Government whether a port near Athens would be available.

Secretary of Defense James R. in a Schlesinger acknowledged today that Air Force B-52 bombers were secretly attacking Cambodia in 1969 and 1970 while the United States was publicly professing its respect for that nation's neutrality in the Vietnam war.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing of the New York Stock Exchange's application for a $300-million increase in the fixed brokerage commission rate was all but bogged down today in a discussion of telephone rates and the method of determining the impact of inflation.
Governor Rockefeller disclosed yesterday the appointment of Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the yachtsman and Republican fund-raiser, as chairman of the newly created State Racing and Wagering Board.

In the Watergate catastrophe that has engulfed him, Mr. Nixon is fighting desperately against two separate but interrelated dangers. As an individual, he has to defend himself against highly detailed charges that he is guilty of obstructing justice and of other crimes.

Mayor Julius Wilensky of Stamford, Conn., announced that the city would no longer enforce a welfare residency ordinance that was described by a Federal court as an attempt "to wall welfare residents out." Last Thursday Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall rejected without comment the city's final appeal. His ruling upheld the findings of two lower Federal courts.

Trading in the stock of Alexander's, Inc., one of New York's largest retailers, was suspended yesterday pending a news announcement that reportedly will involve an offer to purchase control of Alexander's.
Hugh Mulligan, reputedly a major bookmaker and briber of police officials, died on Sunday in Queens General Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 90-09 220th Street, Queens Village.
To the Editor: Professor Ebel's June 17 letter, headed "To Regain a Sense of Moral Purpose," seems to miss the point of the failure of our schools and colleges to achieve moral education.

Daniel P. Moynihan, the United States Ambassador to India, met with the Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in New Delhi today to begin discussions on how to dispose of $840-million in rupees owned by the United States.
G. H. Walker Co., Inc., announced plans yesterday to acI quire the securities brokerage business of Laird, Inc. Both are medium-sized firms of the New York Stock Exchange.
The Federal Trade Commission accused the nation's eight largest oil companies today of conspiring, over a period of at least 23 years, to monopolize the refining of petroleum products.
The Senate rejected today a Republican effort to scale down a proposed new minimum wage for nearly 47 million workers from $2.20 an hour to $2.05 an hour.

At least five radio stations in the New York area have been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury in Newark that is investigating allegations of payola, drug use and organized-crime involvement in the record industry.
Another rally in the stock market abruptly ran out of gas late yesterday, and the market closed only moderate ly higher after posting strong gains early in the session.

The Federal Communications Commission asked the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to investigate the reported violation of company tariffs by the White House in connection with recording devices placed on telephones used by President Nixon.

Governor Rockefeller said today there was a "very good possibility" that the state would acquire upstate railroad trackage under his new transit bond plan and contract with railroad companies to maintain services for small communities that had no air service.
President Kennedy made tape recordings of "highly sensitive" telephone conversations and staff meetings in the White House, the director of the Kennedy Library said tonight.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed new fraud charges today against C. Arnholt Smith, a San Diego millionaire and former head of the WestgateCalifornia Corporation, as well as of the United States National Bank of San Diego.

Thefts from pleasure boats moored at marinas in the metropolitan area are stirring increasing concern because, while boats are becoming more elaborate and expensive, the police are being diverted from marine patrols to what officials consider more pressing street duty.

Joan Hemingway, a granddaughter of Ernest Hemingway, is tracking his literary footsteps. The 23-year-old daughter of Jack Hemingway, the son of the late novelist and his first wife, has collaborated with Paul Bonnecarrere, a French newsman, on her first novel, "Rosebud."

Mrs. Grace Cochran of Bedford Village, N. Y., testified in Federal District Court here today that there was nothing abnormal in the appearance of the container or the contents of a can of Bon Vivant vichyssoise that killed her husband two years ago and left her paralyzed for months.
Major banking concerns in New York, Chicago and in the West reported substantially higher earnings yesterday for the second quarter and the first half of 1973.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts will be the main speaker at the Democratic fund-raising gala Sept. 6 at the National Guard encampment in Sea Girt, James P. Dugan, state Democratic chairman, announced today.

President Nixon received word today that he could leave the hospital Friday. On his fifth day at Bethesda Naval Medical Center, Mr. Nixon was doing so well in his recovery from viral pneumonia that his chest therapy and medication were cut down.

Herbert A. Allen, the 34-yearold investment banker, quietly moved into Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., last month and observers of the chronically ailing movie business wonder if his presence will give a revitalizing transfusion to a company that has suffered from that rundown feeling.
Seven of the 32 Model Cities programs here will be forced to close Oct. 31 because of reduced Federal financing, local officials report.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. - Uhooooooooo. It was 4:30 A.M., and the haunting wail of a conch echoed through the Sivananda Yoga Camp in the Pocono Mountains near here. Yes, Poconos, not Himalayas. It was time to get up and meditate.
The City Council delayed proposed pay raises today for Mayor Paul T. Jordan and his chief aides, and decided that if raises were granted, they would come on the installment plan.

Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, and the State Senate Crime Committee began inquiries yesterday into Federal testimony that two cases had been fixed in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office under a former prosecutor, Aaron E. Koota.

The united opposition of public employee unions to proposed changes in pension benefits for future members is apparently foundering, with police and fire units generally jubilant that they have been chosen to maintain most of their current

Henry D. Halperin, retired president of the Penn-Akron Corporation, manufacturer of brass materials in Terryville, Conn., died Monday in Doctors Hospital. He was 78 years old and had lived in Hollywood, Fla., since his retirement.

Spokesmen for the Sierra Club, the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce and the Atlantic Richfield Oil Company agreed today that one way the state could reduce its air pollution would be to improve mass transportation.
Mayor Thomas C. Rooney Jr. of Paterson, who is feuding with policemenn over a pay raise, was found not guilty today of illegal parking on a sidewalk on July 5.

In line with projections made last month before securities analysts, the Monsanto Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of the year.
