A campaign will be opened today by Citizens for Animals, 900 First Avenue, to obtain 50,000 signatures by Aug. 25 on a petition for a referendum for the city to establish a Department of Animal Affairs.
Three men were wounded this morning in a shootout in downtown Newark following an attempted robbery of a Brinks truck parked in front of the National Newark and Essex Bank on Broad Street.

One of the most pleasant and perhaps coziest off Off Broadway evenings In town s the Shade Company's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," performedd in a tiny downtown loft theater with skill, charm and bare feet. Anyone demanding splendor had better stay uptown with the Balanchine ballet.

If there is a calm at the center of the storm created by the Watergate scandal, it is the fortress-like headquarters of the Government's special prosecution force, tucked away in the ninth floor of an office building three blocks from the White House.

The special session of the Legislature due to begin next week was postponed for two days yesterday after a threehour private meeting at which Governor Rockefeller failed to win the support of legislative leaders for his plan to put a transportation-bond issue on the agenda."
The Golden Blades of the World Hockey Association took a page from out of the past yesterday and brought Harry Howell back to New York. Howell played 17
For nearly three weeks 10 young women have been hiking wearily and surviving in the Connecticut wilderness. They have experienced

The opening shot in the battle of the defense budget was fired the other day by a key Senate subcommittee which took an unequivocal stand against the Administration's grandiose program to accelerate deployment of the Trident submarine. With a long and contentious path ahead across Capitol Hill, there are promising signs that the foes of defense extravagance are picking up significant support.
Senator Sam J. Ervin's four grandchildren, in town to attend the Watergate hearings, have learned firsthand what a celebrity the Senator has become.

Although the make-up of international tournaments has nothing to do with sex, it is rare to find any of the world's leading- women players entering them. One can only guess at the reason. Is it considered undignified for the women's world champion to come out well down the list in a mixed event?

The Securities and Exchange Commission swept aside today demands of the New York Stock Exchange that it delay the start of a consolidated tape showing last-sale prices and volume in all markets until they adopt similar rules and regulations.

In what could be a case study on the making of a gubernatorial candidate, Howard J. Samuels is already waging an intensive, probably unprecedented, behind-the-scenes campaign for the Democratic nomination next year.
A Newark-based conglomerate specializing in insurance has begun construction of a 162-bed rehabilitation hospital in East Orange.

WASHINGTON-It was officially authorized by act of Congress in August of 1964. It was known then as the Vietnam war. In 1970, when our forces went into Cambodia, it became known as the Indochina war. Now, by act of Congress, it has been authorized again -albeit for only 45 days-and it is called the Cambodian war.

If the selection committee for the Pro Football Hall of Fame needed a model for setting up behavior patterns, it would have to be the Red Queen. She shocked Alice in Wonderland by screaming, "Off with her head!" The guardians of the gridiron shrine at Canton, Ohio, do an awesome job of mass decapitation every year while weighing the qualifications of those eligible for enshrinement.

Nearly 200 members of the Port Authority Police Benevolent Association voted unanimously last night to stand roll-call but not work at the tunnels, bridges and airports operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, effective at 7 A.M. today.
They brought Tony U. back today - and maybe they should make him a regular guest on the nationally televised Senate Watergate hearings.
Following is a fact sheet and calendar on Phase 4 issued by the White House:
The Florida Supreme Court upheld today a law requiring newspapers to print replies :of political candidates whom they criticize.
A domestic passenger ship carrying nearly 700 people sank early Monday in typhoon-tossed seas about 120 miles southeast of Manila, the Philippine Coast Guard said today.
Miami Beach, Fla.-Saoul Mamby, 141 pounds, New York City, outpointed Angel Robinson Garcia, 141, Miami Beach, 10 rounds; James Summerville, 232, Miami, knocked out Clyde Broun, 214, Memphis, 3.
A group of Paterson policemen starred in a film made today by, of all people, the Mayor of Paterson-and they did not appear to relish their roles.
Diamonds worth more than $100,000 bound for New York disappeared on a flight from Tel Aviv to London, police officials said today. The metal-lined boxes in
Larry Csonka, the Miami Dol phins' fullback. may miss the game against the College AllStars at Chicago July 27, Coach Don Shula reported today.
Let's see what happens if we give the President the benefit of the doubt on his decision two years ago to create The Monster With Total Recall.

The Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library, completed two years ago at a price of $18million, will undergo an 18month repair job costing $2million to $3-million, contractors bidding on the repair job have indicated.

Perry Wilson, chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, reported yesterday that net income for the first quarter climbed by 143 per cent to a record $76.9-million. or $1.27 a share, from $53.9-million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier. The 1972 figures include 3 cents a share for extraordinary items.

The president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday urged Governor Rockefeller to be guided by the evaluations of appropriate bar associations in naming 100 additional judges for narcotics cases.
Private industry took its first step yesterday to get into the business of designing and financing a space rocket, once the sole province of the Federal Government.
J. Paul Getty 3d, 16-year-old grandson of the American oil billionaire, has written an anguished letter to his mother warning that he is in danger of death at the hands of kidnappers.

James T. Halverson, director of the Federal Trade, Commission's Bureau of Competition, said today the Government might seek a significant divestiture of refinery operations to settle its antitrust complaint against the nation's eight biggest oil companies.
The disclosure of details of Phase 4 of the Nixon Administration's economic stabilization program aroused confusion and skepticism yesterday among the nation's business and labor leaders.

New Jersey National Guard troops will be spending part of their drill time over the coming year searching for sources of water pollution by collecting samples from tributaries feeding 13 major lakes and reservoirs.
A group of Paterson policemen starred in a film made yesterday by, of all people, the Mayor of Paterson-and they did not appear to relish their roles.
Norman Mailer has embarked on a legal battle with his new book about Marilyn Monroe, and to hear him and some of the other participants tell it, they will all be in court before long.

Hugh Mulligan, reputedly a major bookmaker and briber of policemen, was buried yesterday in St. Charles cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I. A funeral service, from which newsmen were barred, was held at the James Funeral Home, 200 Boundary Avenue, North Massapequa.
The Food and Drug Administration, acting on the need to keep hazardous substances out of meat and dairy food products, proposed today a strategy for determining when zero Is really zero.
A stray cat led to the discovery yesterday of a woman apparently strangled to death in her second-floor apartment at. 350 East 134th Street in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx.
President Nixon ended the freeze today on prices for health care and food, except for beef, as he outlined the fourth phase of his 23-month-old effort to combat price and wage inflation.

An underwriting group managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and Robert W. Baird Co., is offering 900,000 shares of Wisconsin Public Service Corporation common stock--par value $8 a share - at $16.75 a share. The company will use the net proceeds from the sale of the additional common stock to reduce shortterm debt incurred for construction purposes. The company's stock closed unchanged at 163/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Personal income of American consumers rose to records in June, but housing starts, another indicator of the economy's strength, fell sharply in the month.

Several high officials of the Kennedy Administration said today that they had no knowledge of the recordings of Presidential meetings or telephone calls, despite the announcement last night by the John F. Kennedy Library that it had discovered 68 Dictabelts of Presidential telephone calls and 125 magnetic tapes of Presidential meetings.
Following are some questions and answers about the new Phase 4 controls and their implications for consumers, workers and businessmen:
Walter Kennedy, who watched the National Basketball Association grow in stature during 10 years as commissioner, will retire June 1, 1975, at the end of his current five-year contract.
President Nixon's physician said today that his patient was "essentially a well man" and had recovered from the viral pneumonia that sent him to the hospital last week.
New York State has begun an investigation to determine whether major gasoline companies conspired to prevent competitive bidding on state purchase of gasoline.

Leaders of a successful fight to overturn a controversial zoning measure that had allowed apartment houses in this affluent Fairfield County town said today that they would work to establish a limited number of apartment units for the elderly.
New York State's leading expert on consumer prices for food is bitter about President Nixon's economic policies, appalled at what consumers are paying for fruit, vegetables and meat,

Interviews with food store managers and shoppers in the metropolitan area last evening indicated a fair amount of nonawareness that the freeze on food prices had been lifted, but those who did know expressed discontent and even bitterness over the prospect of big new increases in prices.
Congressional backers of a 789-mile Alaska oil pipeline Failed today in an effort to speed House action on a pipeline bill similar to one approved yesterday by the Senate.

Harry M. Appel, the man who keeps track of consumer prices in New York State, does all the food shopping for his family, consisting of himself, his wife and his son. He has been doing so ever since he moved to Albany 37 years ago.
A new after-school family living and sex education pilot program, using students and parents as "peer group leaders," will begin this fall in 15 city high schools.
Tom Seaver of the Mets and Sparky Lyle of the Yankees were the New Yorkers named yesterday to the All-Star game pitching staffs. Seaver was picked for the seventh straight time.
Arguments for and against allowing apartment dwellers to keep dogs were given during a long and at times loud hearing before the City Council's Committee on Housing yesterday.
A major revision in the rules of evidence used by state and federall courts in dealing with stock and bond thefts will be sought by leading Wall Street brokerage firms, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Chesapeake Potomac Telephone Company said today that it was insisting that the White House agree to conform to regulations regarding recording devices placed on telephones used by President Nixon.

" I remember back in the nineteen-twenties when bands like this would play on the ships and in the streets greeting incoming immigrants from Austria and Switzerland," Sue Aaron of Jamaica, Queens, said yesterday above the strains of the "Beer Barrel Polka" being played by the oom-pah-pah band in the Central Park Zoo.
Reports reached here today of executions, arrests, fighting and calls for a countercoup in Afghanistan, where the brotherin-law of King Mohammad Zahir Shah has seized power and proclaimed a republic.

Nobody was more eager to learn the facts about Phase 4 yesterday than industry executives or their bankers. David Rockefeller, Chase Manhattan Bank chairman, was scheduled to preside at a directors meeting yesterday afternoon.

At least 84 persons who worked in President Nixon's executive offices or for his reelection campaign have been given Government posts elsewhere in the Administration, 59 of them in independent regulatory agencies, a House committee reported today.
Alexander's, Inc., confirmed yesterday published reports that a British retail company may be making a tender offer to acquire control of Alexander's, a 12-store chain based in New York.
Mayor Paul T. Jordan snipped a ribbon today that symbolized the entrance of an Episcopal church foundation into the area of unsubsidized, privately operated nonprofit housing rehabilitation.
William B. Bickley, editor of The Columbia Missourian and professor of journalism at the University of Missouri, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old.
The deluge of second-quarter financial statements continued to flow yesterday from a nationwide list of companies, indicating record-breaking profits for the period on much higher sales.

The special session of the Legislature due to begin next week was postponed for two' days yesterday after a threehour private meeting at which Governor Rockefeller failed to win the support of legislative leaders for his plan to put a transportation-bond issue on the agenda.

A member of the New York Stock Exchange said today that a Big Board plan to raise $300million in revenues by increasing brokerage commission rates would only drive more small investors from the market.

Strolling along the beach in the Belle Harbor section of Queens, Mary Beame was stopped by a friend who complained mildly that they hadn't gotten together in weeks and who invited her and her husband over for Saturday nigt dessert and gin rummy.

Playing cat and mouse with the rest of the fleet, Robert (Doc) Magoon of Miami won his third Hennessy Grand Prix ocean race today by the mere margin of 3 seconds. Finishing 50 feet behind him after ISI miles was Giorgio Mondadori of Italy.
American Airlines yesterday reported earnings of $1,039,000 for the month of June, compared with $5,706,000 for June of 1972.

If the other members of the Pittsburgh Pirates would follow the example of Willie Stargell, they might shake the doldrums that have kept them in the lower regions of the National League's Eastern Division.

The Pentagon today announced the end of United States minesweeping in North Vietnamese waters. "Operation End Sweep is over and everybody is out," a Pentagon spokesman Jerry W. Friedheim, said at a briefing.

Horizon House Associates of Fort Lee obtained a temporary restraining order against the Fort Lee Rent Leveling Board. United States District Court judge Lawrence A. Whipple granted the restraining order after the apartment-house owners filed suit contesting the constitutionality of the borough's year-old rent-leveling law. The borough has been trying to cut back recently imposed rent increases. A court hearing was set for Tuesday.
Frankie Catrone is a plump, smiling, unassuming trainer who thrusts himself into the picture only when he has to, such as when he wins a Kentucky Derby, or when he has two winners out of two starts.

Melvin R. Laird, who served as Secretary of Defense when official Pentagon records were falsified to conceal the American bombing of Cambodia in 1969, criticized the falsification and said he had not known about it. Earle G. Wheeler, a retired Army general who headed the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the time, also criticized the falsification and disavowed any knowledge of the procedures. [Page 1, Column 1.]

Willie Young, the Giants' 265-pound offensive tackle, was taken to Riverview Hospital today after collapsing at the finish line of the two-mile run. He was suffering from heat exhaustion and dehydration.

Dr. Friedrich Franz Nord, professor emeritus of chemistry at Fordham University, died, apparently of a heart attack, while vacationing in Vermont last Thursday. He was 83 years old and lived at 333 Westchester Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y.

Louis J. Caldor, a New York engineer who was credited with introducing the late Grandma Moses' art to the world beyond the farmlands of her upstate home, died Tuesday at a nursing home near Clarksburg, Md. He was 73 years old.

With a long, wig-lifting horn blast, a cursing, fistshaking driver in an open car squeezed through a crowded downtown intersection yesterday, the perfect example of the raucous horn-blower that the city is out to get.

This is the moving tale of the portable music shell that will not move. The Minnie Guggenheimer Shell, which has been used to take Metropolitan Opera and New York Philharmonic concerts to parks in the five boroughs, sits today in Central Park like a beached blue whale, waiting for the city to decide what to do with it.
Striking farm workers were arrested by the hundreds here today as they angrily carried out a series of noisy and often tense demonstrations that defied court orders.

Ed Berry of Reno, Nev., finished two seconds ahead of Graham Hall of Larchmont, N. Y., today to capture the opening race of the Fireball Class national championship. The six-race sailing series is to continue through Friday.
A Federal judge ordered the Grand Rapids school system today to integrate its staff but rejected arguments that the students were segregated.
James B. McCreary, a 17year-old senior at The Hill who races out of Larchmont Y. C., was awarded the Commodore's Cup tonight at the end of the three junior days of Larchmont's 75th Race Week.

David R. Young Jr., a former White House aide, reportedly refused today to tell a House subcommittee whether his superior, John D. Ehrlichman, had approved a plan to burglarize the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

Egypt's insistence on resumption of the Middle East debate that was suspended by the Security Council last month is strangely at odds with Cairo's constructive interim suggestion that Secretary General Kurt Waldheim visit the area for talks with principals in the ArabIsraeli dispute.
Short-term interest rates ex tended their long, steep climb yesterday, reflecting the surg ing economy and efforts to con tain it by making credit ex tremely costly.
After much prodding by the United States, the South Vietnamese Government has lent 20,000 tons of valuable rice to the embattled government of Cambodia.

The president of the New York Urban Coalition urged Congress today to provide businessmen willing to expand in domestic ghetto areas the same type of "political risk" insurance United States businesses obtain for operating in developing countries.

Hairdresser name-dropping, like that of designers or restaurants, is always a favorite sport around New York. The name that bright young things have been banding about for the last couple of years is Cinandre (SeeNAHN-dreh).
The victory that has been eluding Tom Seaver for more than three weeks finally came the powerful right-hander's way tonight as the New York Mets pummeled the Atlanta Braves, 12-2.

At least eight more New York-area radio stations, including the AM and FM outlets for two of the major networks, have been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury in Newark that is investigating allegations of payola, drug use and

Without being aware of it, American consumers have been on a buying strike against the quality of their coffee for 20 years. During that time, according to people in the trade, quality declined faster than ever until, according to optimists in the trade, it hit bottom. Now there are signs, no larger than a home coffee mill, that an upturn may be developing.
OXFORD, Miss., July 18(AP)--The University of Mississippi has bought Rowan Oak, William Faulkner's home here, for $175,000 and will make it part of the new university cultural center.

While Howard Samuels is off and running for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, three potential competitors haven't even made a final decision to run yet. Still in the mulling-it-over stage are Mayor Lindsay, Representative Ogden R. Reid of Pleasantville and Representative Samuel S. Stratton of Amsterdam.

The Health Services Ad- A ministration yesterday named 15 restaurants and food stores as violators of the Health Code. The establishments failed to to correct first-inspection violations, according to Gordon Chase, the Health Services Administrator, and did not present a valid reason for such failure at hearings held by the agency. The establishments cited were the following:

Exactly one year after his last public appearance, newspapers on Taiwan broke a six-month silence on the health of 85-year-old President Chiang Kai-shek to report he is now "fully cured" of pneumonia, which he contracted last year.
Prices moved higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in moderately active trading as investors appeared to respond to a spate of strong second-quarter earnings reports.

An Administration official asserted today that the United States had decided against interfering in Cambodia's domestic political situation and was not trying to bring pressure on President Lon Nol to step down.
The breakdown of the "Minnie," the once portable concert shell, may have thrown the New York Philharmonic and the Parks Deapartment into confusion, but it seems not to have rattled the public at all.

Life in this sprawling port city has been disrupted by four days of hunger strikes and rioting by several thousand angry new immigrants from Soviet Georgia demanding better jobs and living conditions.

The Socialist Workers party filed a lawsuit in Federal court here yesterday, seeking more than $27-million in damages from President Nixon and other Government officials on charges of violating the party's constitutional rights wtih illegal activities related to the Watergate affair.
It has been estimated that more than a million people will stay at the 44 campsites within New York State's Forest Preserve in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains this season.

ADLER--Allen Richard. Of Ocean Bech, Fire Island, N. Y. Suddenly on July 17, 1973 in his 72nd Year. Husband of isbelia nee Frazer). Religious Services 7:30 P. M. Thursday July 19, 1973 at the Sullivan Funeral Home Inc., bayshore N. Y. Cremation Private.

The New York Times Company yesterday reported record revenues and earnings in the quarter and half-year ended June 30. Profit was up 105 per cent for the quarter and 86 per cent for the six months over the year-earlier periods.
Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers, said today that Government controls had forced the union to seek a reopener clause in any auto contract signed this year.

Everybody insists that the couture, or high fashion as it's called here, is suffering a protracted James Cagney sort of death scene. Like its fellow entertainments, the novel and the theater, it hasn't hit the floor yet.

In a crime closely paralleling the killing of a member of the Maryland House of Delegates last week, a 32-year-old man was shot to death early this morning and leaflets crediting a group called Black October were found near the body.
The prices of almost all commodities were bid up sharply yesterday in anticipation of the President's Phase 4 anti-inflationary efforts.

SOUTHERN COMFORT There's a new corner for South American birds and beasts in the Bronx Zoo, Fordham Road and Bronx River Parkway (WE 3-1500) and the names of the tenants seem to come right out of crossword puzzles.

Bon Vivant Soups, Inc., which is battling a Federal Governmentt suit to destroy 1.5 million cans of the company's products seized in July, 1971, was accused in Federal District Court today of mislabeling lobster bisque made prior to the condemnation order.

Despite the threat of a Presiden- co tial veto, the House of Representatives tonight passed a na measure that would limit the power of the President to commit United States armed forces to hostilities abroad without Congressional approval.
A Federal district judge asked the White House today to release a broad spectrum of private documents and transcripts of tape recordings pertaining to "activist organizations."
It is a rare event when a President of the United States concedes in a public statement that "confidence in our management of our fiscal affairs is low, at home and abroad."

Though the Cambodian insurgents continue pressing their attacks less than 10 miles from the edges of Phnom Penh despite heavy bombardment by American planes, there is no fear or panic visible in the capital's population-only discouragement and helplessness and unreality.
The disclosure of details of Phase 4 of the Nixon Administration's economic stabilizalion program aroused confusion and skepticism yesterday among the nation's business and labor leaders.
Eugene Loring's ballet, "Billy the Kid," first created for Lincoln Kirstein's Ballet Caravan in 1938, has proved marvelously durable.

Dr. Roger A. Harvey, president of the American Cancer Society in 1967-68, died of the disease Tuesday night in Colorado General Hospital in Denver. He was 63 years old and had been professor and chairman of the department of radiology at the University of Illinois College of Medicine in Chicago since 1946.

Playing cat and mouse with the rest of the fleet, Robert (Doc) Magoon of Miami won his third Hennessy Grand Prix ocean race today by the mere margin of 3 seconds. Finishing 50 feet behind him after 181 miles was Giorgio Mondadori of Italy.

The Dolly Madison Ice Company will file for bankruptcy tomorrow, it was announced here today. A spokesman for the National Diversified Industries Company, Dolly Madison's parent concern, made the disclosure after the company filed in United States District Court for a new arrangement with creditors under federal bankruptcy regulations.

The Union County Prosecutor's office was ordered today to show cause on Monday why it should not be forbidden to take the fingerprints of more than 40 Newark eighth-grade pupils in a murder investigation.
Old Forester is a 103-yearold premium bourbon brand from the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation. It is fourth in sales in its category.

Department of Correction officers looking for hacksaw blades searched the seven cell floors of the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men at 275 Atlantic Avenue. Several assistant district attorneys accompanied 120 officers in the search, but they found no blades among the 1,270 inmates.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers conferred with high South Korean officials today on a joint strategy to gain the admission of North Korea and South Korea to the United Nations as separate entities, pending the country's eventual reunification.
Rod Freeman, the tallest and least experienced player in the Giants' preseason training camp, survived his first test as a professional today: He finished the two-mile run in under 15 minutes.

Nearly 206 members of the Port Authority Police Benevolent Association voted unanimously last night to stand rollcall but not work at the tunnels, bridges and airports operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, effective at 7 A.M. today.
The Cambodian Government has begun evacuating 2,000 prisoners from a jail six and a half miles south of Phnom Penh because of fighting less than a mile away.
Two cars of a subway train became partially derailed late last night while being switched from southbound express tracks to northbound tracks at the IRT station at 86th Street and Lexington Avenue.

Despite the threat of a Presidential veto, the House of Representatives tonight passed a measure that would limit the power of the President to commit United States armed forces to hostilities abroad without Congressional approval.

The 35-foot sloop Chutzpah has won the trans-Pacific yacht race. It was her first longdistance race. Stuart Cowan, of Honolulu, owner and skipper brought his boat across the Diamond Head finish line last night. The race began in Los Angeles July 4.
The Government today renewed its charges of subversion against deposed King Constantine and ordered an inventory and valuation of the contents of the royal palaces in Athens.

Alarmed by the uncertain future facing the Government's legal Services program for the poor, national and state bar leaders met today to organize a lobbying campaign to rescue the program in the Senate.

A continued flow of good corporate earnings reports helped give American Stock Exchange prices strength yesterday. The index, which closed at 22.98, up 0.12, rose for the third trading session in a row.
Thousands of Libyans riding in cars, buses and trucks began a 1,500-mile journey eastward to Cairo today to try to force the Egyptian leadership to agree to an immediate merger of the two countries.
It has been estimated that more than a million people will stay at the 44 campsites %within New York State's Forest Preserve in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains this season.
The Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury disclosed today that intervention by the Fed eral Reserve in the foreign exchange markets to help strengthen the dollar had begun July 10.

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, a Democrat running for Mayor on the Liberal line, yesterday discounted the importance of the endorsements that Controller Abraham D. Beame has been receiving from liberal Democrats.

The Christiana Stables' Light Hearted made it four victories in an undefeated season by taking the $54,800 Hempstead Handicap, the star attraction on the Aqueduct card yesterday. Undeterred by high weight of 123 pounds, Light Hearted contributed a thrilling front-running performance to beat Inca Queen by two lengths, with Blessing Angelica next, in the 1 1/8 -mile event for older fillies and mares.
Attorneys for two young black girls who were sterlized in a federally funded clinic have asked a Federal Court to dismiss "without prejudice" a $5-million damage suit they previously filed.

The major surprise in the quarter-final stage of tile Grand Nationals, which begin the Summer National Championships here tomorrow, will not be the presence of some players new on the national scene, but the absence of the Aces.
Versatile--that's the Siberian husky. He's at home in the frozen Arctic tundra. And he's at home with Frank and Phyllis Brayton in the San Joaquin Valley where the temperature soars to 108 degrees.

Back in 1968, Robert R. Pauley left a top executive position with the American Broadcasting Company and got the idea of establishing a television news service over and above what the three commercial networks were providing.

Dr. Ira S. Witchell, an otolaryngologist who had been head of that service at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, on his way from his office in the Bronx to his home at 535 East 86th Street. He was 68 years old.

Mrs.Rebekah Lytle Van Zandt, widow of Ernest T. Van Zandt, a real estate appraiser, died yesterday in a New Rochelle nursing home. She was 87 years old and lived at 9 Brooklands Apartments on Palmer Road.

Two participants in the Watergate over-up described today, in Bizarre details, how they had funneled $450,000 of Presidential campaign money to the seven original Watergate detendants and their lawyers.
Charley Winner is virtually lost in the shadows cast by the linebackers, the Jets' unit he is coaching at training camp here.

Australia will cut all import duties by 25 per cent tomorrow in an attempt to hold down prices. Prime Minister E. Gough Whitlam announced the de cision in Canberra today, one day after the release of official statistics showing that the jump in retail prices in the June quarter of this year was the steepest for 21 years.
Greeces Orthodox Church, crippled by one of the worst crises of leadership in its 123-year history, has just been hit by charges of major financial scandals.

A police sergeant who has waged an aggressive campaign against pornography venders in midtown has been prohibited by a State Supreme Court justice from making arrests without warrants at two peep-show theaters.
The Uniroyal Tire Company has agreed to pay $80,000 to settle an alleged violation of the National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act of 1966, the Department of Transportation announced today.
Jacl Hawkins, one of the most distinctive and durable British film and stage actors, died here today in St. Stephen's Hospital. He was 62 years old.

Daniel Klepak, the Governor's newly appointed director of education-performance review, said yesterday that he would compare two city slumarea schools with widely differing reading levels to try to determine why "one works and the other doesn't."

To the Editor: The commuter must indeed be served, as your July 3 editorial "The Commuter's PATH" states. Your editorial fails to note, however, that the Port Authority does serve commuters and mass transportation.
A swarm of barge-borne cranes on the Hudson near 135th Street has been laboring for a year to create a roofed, 32-acre sewage treatment plant on a platform above the river.
Efforts to investigate allegations of payola in the record industry have run into a curious two-way traffic.

TOWSON, Mr., July 19--The new Baltimore Colts practiced in the heat today at their new training camp, Towson State College, under a new coach, Howard Schnellenberger, and the new player with high visibility was Mike Kaczmarek, who has taken Bubba Smith's place on the defensive line.

The Connecticut Civil Liberties Union warned this affluent Fairfield County town today that its plan to build electronically bugged jail cells was illegal and threatened court action if its warning was ignored.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Top executives of several grain companies are expected to tell Senate investigators tomorrow that they gave the Agriculture Department advance information on Soviet wheat deals that its officials have denied receiving.
A new reapportionment plan designed to make all City Council districts in New York "compact, convenient and contiguous," as ordered by the State Appeals Court, was introduced yesterday.

Postponement of the special session of the Legislature almost certainly portends trouble for the "historic" action that Governor Rockefeller has promised in order to head off an approaching crisis in the state's transportation system. Even before the Governor reveals his plan--supposedly by the end of this week--it is apparent that his legislative leaders are banking.

The New York Stock Exchange told a House financial panel today that a bill the panel has drafted to reform the securities industry would "dismantle" all stock exchanges and replace the auction market mechanism with a dealer system dominated by large banks and insurance companies.
The Association of American Railroads estimated today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled 15.9 billion tonmiles, 15.2 per cent above the 1972 week.

Veteran policemen who are found guilty of accepting minor gratuities will no longer automatically face dismissal and deprivation of pensions worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, under a new policy enunciated yesterday by Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley.

A class action lawsuit seeking $1-million in punitive damages from the Committee to Re-elect the President and its finance committee because of illegal use of campaign funds was filed in United States District Court here today.

Yesterday's thwarted terrorist attack on an Israeli airline office in Athens should-but probably won't-provoke some action in the dilatory Committee on Terrorism which was formally convened at the United Nations this week but shows little evidence of serious intent. An alert El Al security guard successfully barred the lone Palestinian gunman from entering the airline's Athens office.
Leading producers of copper, aluminum and other metals reported surges in sales and earnings in quarterly reports released yesterday.
One of the tragedies of the bear market is the evaporation of capital pools that have traditionally provided funds for growth of young companies.

David Hoover, the third defendant to be sentenced in a case that allegedly involved up to 18 rapes and robberies in the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years' imprisonment with a mandatory minimum sentence of eight and a third years.

Bluegrass music arrived at Philharmonic Hall in full concert for the first time Wednesday evening and was greeted by a vociferously enthusiastic audience of almost 2,000 persons who filled the hall with cheers, knowledgeable shouts of requests and an occasional rebel yell.
Major oil-burner installers said yesterday that they would no longer upgrade or install oil burners because the city antipollution criteria that went into effect July 1 were impossible to meet.
Henry A. Kissinger declared today that the White House "neither ordered nor was it aware of any falsification of records" on the secret bombing of Cambodia ordered by President Nixon in March, 1969.

John W. Dean 3d, former counsel to the President, reportedly invoked the Fifth Amendment 67 times today, refusing to confirm Watergate information he gave last month to a Senate investigating committee.
A lawyer for a theater chain argued in Federal Court today that New Jersey's obscenity law was unconstitutional even in terms of recent rulings by the United States Supreme Court.
The towaway squad under Assistant Chief Inspector William Bonacum descended on police officers' cars in the vicinity of the West 35th Street Station yesterday and hauled away eight of their vehicles.

Representative Ogden R. Reid of New York said today that unions representing employes of the Penn Central's commuter railroads had furnished him with reports of widespread i safety hazards that had re-i suited in delays, derailments, injuries and fatalities.

There was no immediate rise in retail food prices in the metropolitan area yesterday following the Government's lifting of the price freeze, but the consensus seemed to be that in about a week or even sooner there would be a number of increases.

To the Editor: The Times is most inconsistent in its editorials on the ill-conceived Madison Avenue Mall. First, on Feb. 26, you "harbored reservations about the viability of the proposed Madison Avenue experiment," you listed several flaws in the plan, you predicted that the experiment would fail and that because of its expense the mall "hardly seems entitled to top priority."

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

The police here said today that people describing themselves as the kidnappers of 16-year-old J. Paul Getty 3d had offered two days ago to send one of his fingers to his mother to prove that they were holding him.
Mrs. Virginia Mohamed Wekselblatt, who sang professionally as Virginia David, died yesterday of leukemia in Memorial Hospital. She was 47 years old and lived at 988 Sheffield Road, Teaneck, N. J.
Prices edged head - but closed below their best levels yesterday in active trading on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market.
Enforcement of Phase 4 of the Nixon Administration's economic stabilization program will rest largely with an expanded monitoring force in the Internal Revenue Service and the Cost of Living Council.
Sherman W. Dobson, 20 years old, a minister's son, was charged today with killing a Maryland state legislator under indictment on heroin conspiracy charges.

Meyer Lansky, the reputed financial adviser to the underworld, pleaded not guilty today to two counts of tax evasion. The Government said that it would use a former Mafia associate to prove that Lansky collected thousands of dollars from gambling operations that he never reported.

Angry beef processors charged today that there was no-logic in continuing ceilings on beef prices, an action they were certain would only lead to shortages in late August and even higher prices after the ceilings were lifted.

The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced today the filing of its first antidiscrimination case against a television broadcaster. The accused station is WREC-TV of Memphis, which is owned by The New York Times.
The Administration's announcement that most food prices would be allowed to rise under Phase 4 rules caused a flood of buy orders to inundate the nation's protein markets yesterday.
A roller-coaster stock market went down yesterday morning in its initial reaction to the Phase 4 economic program and then staged a brief, bizarre afternoon rally on a Watergate hearing hoax.

There was no immediate rise in retail food prices in the metropolitan area yesterday following the Government's lifting of the price freeze, but the consensus seemed to be that in about a week or even sooner there would be a numer of increases.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange as of the close of business on July 13, reflecting transactions through the trade date of July 6, increased to 20,141,505 shares from 18,701,944 shares on June 15.

Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president of the Reynolds Metals Company, told a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee yesterday that Government - backed insurance against expropriation of foreign investments "serves nations and industry well."
The Senate, amid predictions of a Presidential veto, voted today to increase the minimum wage in stages to $2.20 an hour and to extend its coverage to seven million more workers, including domestics.

The Government will be comparatively lenient in granting exceptions to Phase 4 pricing rules because they are more stringent than the old rules, John T. Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, said today.

Oversights in the design of the Skylab space vehicle, coupled with failures of the men responsible for building it to talk to one another, were blamed today for the damage shortly after launch that almost made a total loss of the whale $2.5 billion project.

LOS ANGELES - Whether or not there is any chance that Prince Norodom Sihanouk will overlook a long series of White House rebuffs and reconsider his refusal to meet Mr. Kissinger in Peking or elsewhere, the fact remains that the exiled former Cambodian Chief of State has now emerged as a major key to an Indochina settlement, and some fresh American thinking about him is in order.

About 4U persons, Incluling representatives of town and village governments, environmental groups and the Long Island Lighting Company, turned out today for a state hearing on the causes of the July 5 spill that washed oil onto beaches from Huntington Bay to Wading River.

President Nixon has decided not to give Senate investigators access to the tape recordings of his personal and telephone conversations with Watergate suspects in 1972 and 1973, a White House official said today.

The state reported that the cost of Medicaid health care benefits increased almost 20 per cent in 1972, to $249.2million. The Department of Institutions and Agencies said the increase had come about primarily because the people enrolled in the three-year-old program were using it more often.

ISLA NEGRA, Chile--My memory is not too good: so that I cannot tell the day exactly, nor month, nor year--but I believe that, no more than five years ago, something strange happened in Montevideo, Capital of Uruguay.

In an unusual appearance before a police forum today, Judge Bruce McMarion Wright of Criminal Court in Manhattan defended his policy of setting low bail for defendants that live in or have economic ties in the community in which they are arrested.

Jacob D. Muchsberg, Democratic candidate for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals, declared yesterday. that,. it elected, he would seek the ap pointment of 1,000 experienced lawyers as temporary State Supreme Court justices to up the backlog on court calendars.

Following are the texts of two announcements by Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. this afternoon-that he had been notified that tapes of President Nixon's conversations at the White House with Watergate witnesses would he made available and that tile call had been a hoax;
" There is no escape from price increases in most of the industrial products we make." "On the basis of what's known of Phase 4, we have ample justification for increasing prices."
The Nixon Administration's ruling on health care costs promises to leave the average consumer just where he was before the one-month interim freeze was announced June 13.
After a protracted, tangled debate, the Board of Estimate last night approved a housing project in Brooklyn that had been redesigned to segregate low-income families from middle-income families.

BAME--Harry A., brother of Mildred Cohen Claire Price Charles Bame. Services wil be private. BEEBER, Joseph. Suddenly in Miami. Hus band of Ann. Father of Suzanne Friedmar and Connie Colchamiro. Brother of David Albert, Mae Kalik and Ella Chodikoff Beloved grandfather. Services Parkside Forest Hills, 10 A.M. Friday, July 20.

The Labor Department announced yesterday that it had cited three employers for alleged violation of Federal jobsafety standards and proposed civil penalties totaling $27,200 in connection with the Staten Island gas tank explosion that killed 40 workmen last February.

The American Library Association has filed a petition requesting the Supreme Court to reconsider its recent pornography rulings. The action underscores the librarians' concern over the fact that the Court's majority may have been so preoccupied with the offensiveness of pornographic motion pictures and other public exploitation of lurid sex that it paid too little attention to the potential effect, of the rulings on books and libraries.

WASHINGTON, July 19--The Senate, amid predictions of a Presidential veto, voted today to increase the minimum wage in stages to $2.20 an hour and to extend its coverage to seven million more workers, including domestics.

Time Inc. will redeem all of the publicly-held debentures of Sterling Communications, Inc., for a cash outlay of $3.1-million, it was announced yesterday. Time, a majority owner of Sterling Communications, will also acquire Sterling's assets and assume its liabilities.
Leftist workers blocked traffic in the city's industrial arca today in a demonstration demanding the Government expropriate 89 factories seized by employes last month.

Europeans showed mostly positive reactions today to United States moves to fight inflation and defend the dollar. Some money managers suggested the time might be fast approaching for shifting European funds into Wall Street.
The San Diego Chargers traded Duane Thomas to the Washington Redskins tonight for two high future draft choices, ending a bizarre one-year episode in the career of the controversial running back.

The largest postal union announced today that its members had ratified a new contract with the Postal Service providing a 14 per cent rise in wages and fringe benefits over two years, plus cost of living raises.

Cynthia Hill, a 25-year-old amateur, surprised the members of the Ladies' Professional Golfers Association today and led the first round of the women's United States Open championship with a record 68.

Despite what the economists are saying Richard Tice, who runs the biggest truck farm in Bergen County, said today that he thought the retail cost of such summer steaes as peaches and corn would not be much higher, if any, than last year.

Hundreds of Port Authority policemen refused to work at the authority's bridges, tunnels and airports yesterday, and there were several traffic tie-ups, mainly at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and at Newark Airport.

When the international Olympic brass meet in Varna, Bulgaria, in the fall a new eligibility code for amateur athletes will be submitted for adoption. Under the proposed regulations practices that have not been officially approved in the past-such as an athlete's cashing in openly on his reputation-would be permitted. About the only thing forbidden in the liberalized code would be direct cash payments for competition. Without jeopardizing his amateur standing,

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, conceded with some embarrassment today that he had been the victim of a hoax after reporting minutes earlier that the White House would turn over tapes of Presidential conversations.
Dunlea (Pat) Hurley, a newspaper man and public-relations director, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Washington. He was 64 years old and lived in New Hope, Pa.
A bright-eyed, muscular man who looks and growls like George C. Scott, the actor, in "Patton," Robert Charles Mardian was one of the most aggressive conservatives in the first Nixon Administration.
Blindfolded journalists, a whole party of them, boarded a bus in Times Square this week--off for a "sensual preview," according to the publicity man in charge.

Five years after its founding, the World's Greatest Jazz Band has trimmed down from its original nine men to seven and, in the process, has loosened up and found a freshness that was not always apparent.
The European Common Market asked its nine member nations today to begin the first Continent-wide attack on pollution.

Debenham's, Ltd., the 195year old, diversified retailer in London, was identified in financial circles here yesterday as the British company that has been considering making an offer to buy control of Alexander's, Inc.

THE ADVERSARY (PRATIDWANDI), directed by Satyajit Ray; screenplay in Bengali (with English subtitles) and English by Mr. Ray, based on a story by Sunil Ganguly; directors of photography, Soumendu Ray and Purmendu Bose; editor, Dulal Dutta; music, Mr. Ray; produced by Nepal Dutte and Ahim Dutta for Priya Films; distributed by Anglo Brandon Film. Running time:
A time bomb, described by police as the work of Arab guerrillas, exploded today in Jerusalem's most popular outdoor market, injuring five persons including a young American.

Stepping in to rectify a situation that Mrs. Billie Jean King once said "stinks," Ban deodorant announced yesterday it would donate $55,000 in prize money to make the women's purse at the 1973 United States Open tennis championships equal to the man's.

The Franklin New York Corporation, the holding company for the Franklin National Bank, said yesterday that it planned an early September offering to its common stockholders of rights to subscribe for some 1,320,000 additional common shares.

A Senate subcommittee has eliminated from the Administration's proposed defense budget most of the new strategic weapons programs that the Joint Chiefs of Staff demanded last year as a condition for supporting the agreements on strategic arms control with the Soviet Union.
A Palestinian with a submachine gun seized 17 persons in a hotel lobby here today after failing in an attempt to shoot up an Israeli airline office.
When El Espanoleto won Aqueduct's third race yesterday at a first-place payoff of $27.20, the question went up among some of the students in the crowd of 19,710, "Where has Laz been hiding this one?"
Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman issued an order today designed to give 12-year-old
For the family thinking of moving from an apartment to a house, or from a small house to a larger one, these warm, sunny summer days many seem ideal for' househunting.
In some advertising quarters there is concern that the changes announced by the Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday could lead to more rule making.

Jimmy Connors upset top-seeded Stan Smith earlier this week, smashed his way to another victory today, defeating Ray Moore, of South Africa, 6-1, 2-6, 6-3, in the United States professional tennis championships.

Mrs. Rhoda Schutz Riesel, who was recently appointed an assistant state attorney general in the consumer-fraud department here, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital of an aneurysm of the aorta. She was 26 years old and lived at 308 West 77th Street.

Roy W. Tate, a former Long Island Rail Road engineer, was indicted here yesterday on a charge of criminally negligent homicide as a result of an accident near the Ronkonkoma station last March 15 in which one passenger was killed and 27 others were injured.

Some sort of a guarantee of a 35-cent fare for the city and comparable promises for suburban and upstate transit riders will be the keystone of Governor Rockefeller's transit subsidy and bond plan, Albany sources said yesterday..
Clarence E. Lewis Jr., a retired officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 62 years old.

Elsie Illingworth, a concert soprano who became an executive in the selling end of the music business, died Wednesday at the Hilaire Farm Nursing Home in Huntington, L. I. She was 87 years old and had lived until a year or so ago at 77 West 55th Street.

Officials of the General Services Administration said today that about 80 per cent of the Army and 50 per cent of the Air Force files on the sixth floor of the Military Personnel Record Center were destroyed in last week's fire.

Seventeen Irish Republican Army members, including the 24-year-old chief of the Belfast brigade, Gerry Adams, were arrested today in a big roundup by security forces in Belfast. Seven are among the organization's top men.

Hundreds of Port Authority policemen refused to work at the authority's bridges, tunnels and airports yesterday, and there were several traffic tie-ups, mainly at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and at Newark Airport.

A two-month investigation by Federal agents has failed to turn up "one iota" of evidence suggesting official impropriety in the release from prison last December of Angelo De Carlo, a leading organizedcrime figure, according to sources close to the investigation.
Interest rates spiraled to still higher levels yesterday in response to the continuing squeeze on the banking system and a lack of any surprise initiative under Phase 4 to contain inflation.

Joseph William Arcier, who until his retirement in 1966 was vice president of the Craig-Craely clothing manufacturing firm in New York, died of a heart attack today on a visit to Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 64 years old.
A reapportionment plan designed to make all City Council districts "compact, convenient and contiguous," as ordered by the State Court of Appeals, was introduced yesterday.

The Federal Government today sought to prove that Bon Vivant Soups Inc., had adulterated its products with substitute ingredients and had failed to follow its own "master formulas," or recipes, in its canning operations.
Bob Goalby and Rik Messengale matched five-under-par 65's and shared the first-round lead today in the $210,000 St. Louis Children's Hospital golf, tournament.

The General Telephone Electronics Corporation realized an increase of 12 per cent in second-quarter earnings on a revenue and sales gain of 17 per cent. For the half year, net income was up 16 per cent and sales by 15 per cent.

The overthrow of King Mohammad Zahir Shah of Afghanistan by his cousin and brother-in-law, Lieut. Gen. Mohammad Daud Khan, reflects in part the palace intrigues and tribal rivalries that might be expected in a country which, as one foreign diplomat put it, "is about to spring right into the sixteenth century."
Orangutans at the Portland, Ore., zoo are being trained to play electronic tick-tak-toe with humans who gape at them from outside their cages.
Next week's $175,000 Canadian open lost one of its chief drawing cards yesterday when Jack Nicklaus sent his regrets to tournament officials in Toronto.

From the back-yard cottage where Edwin Arlington Robinson had breakfast brought to him each morning by a patroness, to the brownstone where Theodore Dreiser slammed the front door in Sherwood Anderson's face,

About 50 years ago, while he was conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Leopold Stokowski formed a 100-member concert band called the Band of Gold, which played annual concerts at the Academy of Music. For these programs Mr. Stokowski translated a number of standard works into band language.
When El Espanoleto won Aqueduct's third race yesterday at a first-place payoff of $27.20, the question went up among some of the students in the crowd of 19,710, "Where has Laz been hiding this one?"

West Germany has stopped pressing demand to have some of its own armed forces included in the first round of troop reductions in central Europe to be negotiated by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact powers this fall in Vienna.

Every time it seems exhausted, the Watergate story develops some sensational new wrinkle that keeps the whole sordid mess alive. This week it was the disclosure that President Nixon had been recording virtually all his official conversations; so he presumably has the power to prove or disprove most charges against him.

The telephone call to Senator Ervin yesterday, purporting to convey President Nixon's willingness to turn over the secret tape recordings of his White House conversations, was a hoax; the White House says there will be no Presidential decision on the issue of the tapes until the weekend. However, we hope that the earlier false "announcement" was not really wrong but only premature.

The United States and most of the world's 23 other major developed nations are experiencing critical inflation problems for which no early solution is in sight, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

The mysterious heroin king of Southeast Asia has been reported captured in northern Thailand. The police said that Lo Hsing Han, who had been cited in several reports by United States officials as the major

The Yankees and Mets rested yesterday a half a continent apart before resuming their separate struggles-the Yankees to hold first place in the American League's East, the Mets to vacate last place in the National League's East.

Lee Davis of Birmingham, Mich., and Graham Hall of Larchmont, N.Y., continued today their two-man battle for the Fireball Class national sailing championship. Davis added a first, a third and a seconcd in that order to yesterday's fourth-place finish and took' a slight lead over Hall.

The reaction of the markets yesterday to the Administration's Phase 4 anti-inflationary price program, announced Wednesday afternoon, was as follows: Commodities: All grain, soybean and livestock prices. except cattle, rose their respective daily permissible limits. Cattle prices showed smaller gains because the ceiling on beef was kept. Live hog prices, for example, rose to a record $50.50 a hundredweight, up $5 on the day.

The first car of a 1,000-vehicle caravan carrying 30,000 Libyans on a trek to Cairo to press for a merger of the two countries reached this town 120 miles from the Libyan frontier today and continued toward the Egyptian capital.
Three teen-agers were killed and five others were injured early today when the car in which they were riding crashed against a house in suburban Henrietta.

" A few years ago two German correspondents came for a visit and said to me, 'Show me a real Tatar,'" recalled a well-educated man in a business suit. "I told them, 'I am a real Tatar,' and they looked at me incredulously."
LONG TIEN, South Vietnam, July 13--For the farmers of this village in the Mekong Delta harvesting rice is still a risky business, as it has been for years.

A close aide to Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that planning was continuing for Mr. Rogers's schedule this fall, including the trip to New York for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly in September.

Fist fights broke out last night at a community school board meeting on the Lower East Side after a board member punched the board president as the panel was moving to strip the controversial district superintendent, Luis Fuentes, of much of his power.
The Nixon Administratior, will end production controls on basic farm commodities for the first time since the Korean War as part of its Phase 4 economic plan.
Communist forces reportedly increased their pressure on Phnom Penh from the north, west and south today despite heavy air strikes by American B-52 bombers and smaller fighter-bombers.
Arthur Ashe, quick and confident, defeated Charlie Pasarell and Jimmy Connors beat Ray Moore today in secondround matches of the United States professional tennis championships at Longwood.

Joseph W. Weed, sailing the red-hulled International sloop, Mischief, and Mrs. Elaine Keehn's Class S Sloop, Red Witch, remained undefeated at the Larchmont Yacht Club's 75th Race Week today by winning for the third time when
The Rev. Eugene P. Murphy, founder of the worldwide "Sacred Heart" radio and television program, died today at the age of 81.
Offshore fishing boats from Barnegat Inlet to Block Island still continue to do well with big fellows, but inshore fishing remains generally spotty.

Some sort of a guarantee of a 35-cent fare for the city and comparable promises for suburban and upstate transit riders will be the keystone of Governor Rockefeller's transit subsidy and bond plan, Albany sources said yesterday.

Veteran policemen who are found guilty of accepting minor gratuities will no longer automatically face dismissal and deprivation of pensions wort hundreds of thousands of dollars, under a new policy enunciated yesterday by Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley.
Across the San Joaquin Valley farm workers were again arrested by the hundreds today as they continued to defy court orders in pressing their strike against grape growers.

Pieces of Night: A Novel of Chinahood, by David W. Elliott (Holt, Rinehart Winston, $6.95). Seminary Sketches, by N. G. Pomyalovsky, translated with an introduction and notes by Alfred R. Kuhn (Cornell University, $9.50). Five short stories written in 1862.
After two years of rebellion and resignation, Jim Files is relieved to be back where he feels he belongs on the New York defense--middle linebacker.

Following the death last week of an unidentified 6year-old Suffolk County boy, the Health Services Administration issued an alert yesterday against dog ticks as a source of Rocky Mounain spotted fever. The agency noted that children were more susceptible to the disease than were adults, and urged the avoidance of tick-infested areas, which are most prevalent in Suffolk and Nassau Counties where there is sand or high grass.

Judge John J. Sirica. ordered today that a second Watergate grand jury be empaneled 'at the request of the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, whose office indicated that the volume of material ready for presentation was more than the original grand jury could handle.

Despite the threat of a veto, the House passed tonight a general farm bill that included a ban on food stamps for strikers. The vote was 226 to 182. The action sends the legislation to conference with the Senate to work out differences between versions passed by both houses.

The Canadian team has withdrawn from the international squash racquets championships in South Africa next month because of South Africa's policy of racial segregation. In Montreal, the president of the Canadian Racquets Association, Smith Chapman, said the decision was made because of pressure received on the racial matter.
Senate-House conferees reported a major breakthrough today in their deadlock over whether to use money in the Highway Trust Fund for mass transit.

The ending of the price freeze has not yet brought dollar-adozen eggs in the retail food markets, but 90-cents-a-dozen eggs are already in sight, according to market reports for the State Agriculture Department.

" For a while I thought everybody was going to have to go into the black market," Sam Orisco, a fruit and vegetable buyer at the Hunts Point. Market in the Bronx, said with relief yesterday when he heard that the ceiling on food prices had been ended.
How nice to be at Jacob's Pillow now that summer's here! This remains America's most extended and most important dance festival, and under the artistic direction of its new leader, Walter Terry,

Jewish sportsmen from 27 countries danced and pranced in the oval of the Ramat Gan Stadium this evening in deliberate confusion as the Maccabiah torch was extinguished to mark the end of the ninth "Jewish Olympics."
The City Council yesterday approved unanimously a proposal to change the name of Welfare Island to Franklin D. Roosevelt Island.

Nolan Ryan, who was bypassed for the All-Star Game despite a pair of no-hifters this season, was named to the American League squad yesterday under a new ruling that added one man to each team. Willie Mays is expected to be the additional National Leaguer selected.

Joe Decker is a 26-year-old right-handed pitcher for the Minnesota Twins. He has been up and down the minor league baseball trail since 1965, the year he broke in with Pleasure Valley of the rookie Pioneer League.
A woman gave money away on Michigan Avenue yesterday. A tiny, gray-haired woman showed up close by the bridge over the Chicago River and passed out crumpled dollar bills.
